translated: Upasumbheyyā: the prefix upa- has the meaning of nearness. Sumbhanaṃ is scattering.🔽Therefore he says: “He would throw it near him.”🔽The meaning is: he would throw the bone near that dog.

original: aṭṭhikaṅkalaṃ khipeyyāti attho. Nimmaṃsattā kaṅkalanti vuccatīti iminā vigatamaṃsāya
analyzed: aṭṭhi kaṅkalam khipeyya ti atthaḥ nimmaṃsa ttā kaṅkalanti vuccati iti iminā vigata maṃsāya
translated: By “because it is called a bone without flesh” he shows that the term kaṅkala is established for a bone without flesh,

original: aṭṭhikaṅkalikāya uraṭṭhimhi vā piṭṭhikaṇṭake vā sīsaṭṭhimhi vā kaṅkala-saddo niruḷhoti
analyzed: aṭṭhikaṅkalikāya uraṭṭhimhi vā piṭṭhikaṇṭake vā sīsaṭṭhimhi vā kaṅkala saddo niruḷho ti
translated: either in the breastbone, the spine, or the skull.

original: dasseti. Sunikkantanti nillikhitaṃ katvāva nibbisesaṃ likhitaṃ.
analyzed: dasseti su nikkantam ti nillikhitam katvā ava nibbisesam likhitam
translated: Sunikkantanti: having written it down without distinction.

original: Ekattupaṭṭhānassa ajjhupekkhanavasena pavattiyā ekattā. Tenāha “catutthajhānupekkhā”ti.
analyzed: ekatta upaṭṭhānassa ajjhupekkhana vasena pavattiyā ekattā tena āha catuttha jhāna upekkhā ti
translated: Because of the singleness of the occurrence of the jhāna by way of equanimity towards the single object.

original: Yasmā panassa ārammaṇampi ekasabhāvameva, tasmā āha “sā hī”tiādi. Lokāmisasaṅkhātāti
analyzed: yasmai panassa ārammaṇam pi eka sabhāvam eva tasmai āha sā hi itiādi loka āmisa saṅkhātā ati
translated: But since its object too is of the same nature, he said, “It is indeed a single kind of object.”

original: apariññātavatthunā lokena āmasitabbato, loke vā āmisoti saṅkhaṃ gatāya vasena kāmaguṇānaṃ🔽kāmabhāvo ca āmisabhāvo ca, so eva nippariyāyato āmisanti vattabbataṃ arahati. Kāmaguṇāmisāti
analyzed: a pariññāta vatthunā lokena āmasitabbataḥ loke vā āmisaḥ ti saṅkham gatāya vasena kāma guṇānam  kāma bhāvaḥ ca āmisa bhāvaḥ ca saḥ eva nippariyāyataḥ āmisanti vattabbatam arahati kāma guṇa āmisā ti
translated: Called “worldly material things”: because they are to be handled by the world that has not fully understood the object, or because they are reckoned as “material things” in the world, the qualities of sensual desire🔽are sensual and material. And that is what they are in the ultimate sense.🔽Sensual desire for the qualities of sensual desire is sensual desire for the qualities of sensual desire.

original: kāmaguṇe chandarāgā. Gahaṇaṭṭhena bhusaṃ ādānaṭṭhena.
analyzed: kāma guṇe chanda rāgāḥ gahaṇa ṭṭhena ādāna ṭṭhena
translated: It is sensual desire in the sense of grasping and in the sense of devouring.

original: 43. Ḍayanaṃ ākāsena gamananti āha “uppatitvā gaccheyyā”ti. Gijjhādīnaṃ vāsipharasu
analyzed: ḍayanam ākāsena gamananti āha uppatitvā gaccheyya iti gijjha ādīnam
translated: Flying through the air: “flying” is going through the air.

original: na hotīti āha – “mukhatuṇḍakena ḍasantā taccheyyu”nti. Vissajjeyyunti ettha “vissajjana”nti
analyzed: na hoti iti āha mukha tuṇḍakena ettha
translated: The bird’s beak and claws do not cut and tear as a butcher’s knife and cleaver do.

original: ākaḍḍhanaṃ adhippetaṃ anekatthattā dhātūnaṃ, ākaḍḍhanañca anubandhitvā pātananti🔽āha “maṃsapesiṃ nakhehi kaḍḍhitvā pāteyyu”nti.
analyzed: ākaḍḍhanam adhippetam anekattha ttā dhātūnam ākaḍḍhanam ca anubandhitvā pātanan ti  āha maṃsa pesim nakhehi kaḍḍhitvā
translated: The bird seizes the flesh with its beak and claws and tears it off.

original: 47. Purisassa ārohanayogyaṃ poriseyyaṃ.
analyzed: purisassa ārohana yogyam poriseyyam
translated: Suitable for a man to mount: suitable for a man to ride.

original: 48. Sampannaṃ sundaraṃ phalamassāti sampannaphalaṃ. Phalūpapannanti phalehi upetanti āha “bahuphala”nti.
analyzed: sampannam sundaram phalam assa ati sampanna phalam phala upapannam ti phalehi upetanti āha bahu phalanti
translated: The fruit in it is perfect and beautiful, thus it is sampannaphala . It is endowed with fruit, thus it is bahuphala .

original: 50. Suvidūravidūreti ariyassa vinaye vohārasamucchedato suṭṭhu vidūrabhūte eva vidūre
analyzed: su vidūra vidūrā iti ariyassa vinaye vohāra samucchedato suṭṭhu vidūra bhūte eva vidūre
translated: Far away, far away: far away, far away from the destruction of speech in the Noble One’s Discipline.

original: ahaṃ ṭhito. Kassaci nāma atthassapi ajānanato na ājānantīti anājānīyāti kattusādhanamassa
analyzed: aham ṭhitaḥ kassaci nāma atthassa api a jānanataḥ na ājānanti iti an ājānīya ati kattu sādhanam assa
translated: I am standing, not knowing, not knowing any meaning, thus anājānīya .

original: dassento ajānanaketi ajānantabhojanasīsena tesaṃ dātabbapaccaye vadati. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: dassentaḥ ajānanaka iti ajānanta bhojana sīsena tesam dātabba paccaye vadati sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: Showing the instrument of that, he says “ajānanake” , referring to the requisites to be given to them by way of the food of unknowing. The rest is quite clear.

original: Potaliyasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the words of the Potaliya Sutta is ended.

original: 5. Jīvakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jīvaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Jīvaka Sutta

original: 51. Kumārena bhato posāpitoti kumārabhato, kumārabhato eva komārabhacco yathā “bhisakkameva bhesajja”nti.
analyzed: kumārena bhato posāpitaḥ iti kumāra bhato kumāra bhato eva komāra bhaccaḥ yathā bhisakkam eva bhesajjanti
translated: He is fed, nourished, by a prince, thus he is a prince’s man, a prince’s man is a komārabhacca , just as “bhisakka” is a bhesajja .

original: Ārabhantīti ettha ārabha-saddo kāmaṃ kāmāyūhanayaññuṭṭhāpanaāpattiāpajjanaviññāpanādīsupi
analyzed: ārabhanti iti ettha ārabha saddo kāmam
translated: In the word ārabhanti the word ārambha has, of course, the meanings of “accumulation of sense desires,” “setting up of a sacrifice,” “contravention of an offense,” “intimation of an offense,” and so on.

original: āgato, idha pana hiṃsane icchitabboti āha – “ārabhantīti ghātentī”ti. Uddisitvā katanti
analyzed: āgataḥ idha pana hiṃsane icchitabbo ti āha ārabhanti iti ghātenti iti uddisitvā katanti
translated: “They begin” means they kill.

original: attānaṃ uddisitvā māraṇavasena kataṃ nibbattitaṃ. Paṭiccakammanti ettha kamma-saddo
analyzed: attānam uddisitvā māraṇa vasena katam nibbattitam paṭiccakamman ti ettha kamma saddaḥ
translated: “By mentioning oneself” : it is done by mentioning oneself, by making oneself the object of the killing.🔽“By a prior act” : here the word “act” is a means of accomplishing an act. It is a past-time word.

original: kammasādhano atītakālikoti āha – “attānaṃ paṭicca kata”nti. Nimittakammassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ
analyzed: kamma sādhanaḥ atīta kālikaḥ ti āha attānam paṭicca katam ti nimitta kammassa etam adhivacanam
translated: “By a prior act” means “done by making oneself the object.” It is a designation for a prior act.🔽As in such passages as “he touches the prior act” .

original: “paṭicca kammaṃ phusatī”tiādīsu viya. Nimittakammassāti nimittabhāvena laddhabbakammassa,
analyzed: paṭicca kammam phusati iti ādīsu viya nimitta kammassa ati nimitta bhāvena laddhabba kammassa
translated: “By a prior act” means by an act that is to be obtained by way of a sign,🔽not by way of doing or causing to be done.🔽“By a prior act” is here a term for meat.

original: na karaṇakārāpanavasena. Paṭiccakammaṃ ettha atthīti maṃsaṃ paṭiccakammaṃ yathā “buddhaṃ
analyzed: na karaṇa kārāpana vasena paṭiccakammam ettha atthi iti maṃsam paṭiccakammam yathā buddham
translated: As in the case of “endowed with the Buddha” .

original: etassa atthīti buddho”ti. Tesanti nigaṇṭhānaṃ. Aññepi brāhmaṇādayo taṃladdhikā attheva.🔽Kāraṇanti ettha yutti adhippetā, sā eva ca dhammato anapetattā “dhammo”ti vuttāti
analyzed: etassa atthi iti buddho ti tesanti nigaṇṭhānam aññe pi brāhmaṇa ādayo taṃ laddhikāḥ attha eva 🔽kāraṇanti ettha yutti adhippetā sā eva ca dhammataḥ an apeta ttā dhammaḥ ti vuttā ti
translated: “Theirs” : of the Niganthas. Other Brahmins, etc., also have it, but they do not obtain it in the same way.

original: āha – “kāraṇaṃ nāma tikoṭiparisuddhamacchamaṃsaparibhogo”ti. Anukāraṇaṃ nāma mahājanassa
analyzed: āha kāraṇam nāma anukāraṇam nāma mahājanassa
translated: He said, “The reason is the eating of meat that is pure in the three respects and blameless.” The counter-reason is the declaration by the great multitude

original: tathā byākaraṇaṃ yuttiyā dhammassa anurūpabhāvato maṃsaṃ paribhuñjitabbanti anuññātaṃ
analyzed: tathā byākaraṇam yuttiyā dhammassa anurūpa bhāvataḥ maṃsam paribhuñjitabbanti anuññātam
translated: that it is proper to eat meat because it is in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: tatheva kathananti katvā. Tanti “jānaṃ uddissakataṃ maṃsaṃ paribhuñjatī”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: tathā iva kathananti katvā uddissa katam maṃsam paribhuñjati iti evam vuttam
translated: This is what is meant by “in the same way.” The eating of meat that is known to have been killed on purpose is not a reason at all,

original: paribhuñjanaṃ neva kāraṇaṃ hoti sabbena sabbaṃ abhāvato sati ca ayuttiyaṃ adhammoti🔽katvā. Tathā byākaraṇanti “jānaṃ uddissakataṃ maṃsaṃ paribhuñjatī”ti kathanaṃ yuttiyā🔽dhammassa ananurūpabhāvato na anukāraṇaṃ hoti. Parehi vuttakāraṇena sakāraṇo hutvāti
analyzed: paribhuñjanam na iva kāraṇam hoti sabbena sabbam abhāvataḥ sati ca ayuttiyam adhammaḥ ti  katvā tathā uddissakatam maṃsam paribhuñjati iti kathanam yuttiyā  dhammassa ananurūpa bhāvataḥ na anukāraṇam hoti parehi vutta kāraṇena sa kāraṇaḥ hutvā ati
translated: because it does not exist in any way. And it is not a counter-reason because it is contrary to the Dhamma.🔽The declaration that it is proper to eat meat that is known to have been killed on purpose is not a counter-reason because it is contrary to the Dhamma.🔽Having a reason because of the reason stated by others:

original: pare titthiyā ‘jāna’ntiādinā dhammaṃ kathenti vadanti, tena kāraṇabhūtena sakāraṇo
analyzed: pare titthiyāḥ jānanti ādinā dhammam kathenti vadanti tena kāraṇa bhūtena sa kāraṇaḥ
translated: the other sectarians speak thus, saying, “It is proper to eat meat that is known to have been killed on purpose.” Because of that reason,🔽having a reason, they should say, “It is proper to eat meat,”

original: hutvā. Tehi tathā vattabbo eva hutvā tumhākaṃ vādo vā anuvādo vā “maṃsaṃ paribhuñjitabba”nti
analyzed: hutvā tehi tathā vattabbaḥ eva hutvā tumhākam vādaḥ vā anuvādaḥ vā maṃsam paribhuñjitabbanti
translated: either in the same way or in a similar way.

original: pavattā tumhākaṃ kathā vā parato parehi tathā pavattitā tassā anukathā vā. Viññūhi🔽garahitabbakāraṇanti titthiyā tāva tiṭṭhantu, tato aññehi paṇḍitehi garahitabbakāraṇaṃ.🔽Koci na āgacchatīti garahitabbataṃ na āpajjatīti attho. Abhibhavitvā ācikkhantīti
analyzed: pavattā tumhākam kathā vā paratas parehi tathā pavatti tā tassāḥ anukathā vā viññūhi  garahitabba kāraṇanti titthiyāḥ tāva tiṭṭhantu tatas aññehi paṇḍitehi garahitabba kāraṇam  koci na āgacchati iti garahitabbatam na āpajjati iti atthaḥ abhibhavitvā ācikkhanti iti
translated: The reason for blame by the wise: let alone the sectarians, even by other wise men.🔽No one comes: the meaning is that he does not come to be blamed.

original: abhibhuyya madditvā kathenti, abhibhūtena akkosantīti attho.🔽52. Kāraṇehīti paribhogacittassa avisuddhatāhetūhi. Bhikkhū uddissakataṃ diṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: abhibhuyya madditvā kathenti abhibhūtena akkosanti iti attho  kāraṇehi iti paribhoga cittassa a visuddha tā hetūhi bhikkhū uddissa katam diṭṭham
translated: Having overcome: having overcome, having crushed, they speak; the meaning is that they abuse having been overcome.🔽Because of reasons: because of the reasons for the impurity of the mind, i.e., the reasons for the impurity of the mind because of the defilement of the mind.

original: Tādisamaṃsañhi paribhogānārahattā cittaavisuddhiyā kāraṇaṃ cittasaṃkilesāvahato.
analyzed: paribhoga an āraha ttā citta avisuddhiyā kāraṇam citta saṃkilesa āvahato
translated: The bhikkhus are seen to be dedicated: for such a one, the reason for the impurity of the mind is the unworthiness to consume the requisites.

original: Idāni diṭṭhasutaparisaṅkitāni sarūpato dassetuṃ “diṭṭhādīsū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: idāni diṭṭha suta parisaṅkitāni sarūpataḥ dassetum diṭṭha ādīsu utiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Now, in order to point out the seen, the heard, and the suspected in their individual characteristics, “The seen, etc.” is said. Therein,

original: tadubhayavimuttaparisaṅkitanti “diṭṭhaṃ suta”nti imaṃ ubhayaṃ anissāya – “kiṃ nu
analyzed: tad ubhaya vimutta parisaṅkitanti diṭṭham sutanti imam ubhayam a nissāya kim nu
translated: The suspected of both of those: having relied on both of these, “seen” and “heard,” “what now if … ? ”

original: kho imaṃ bhikkhuṃ uddissa vadhitvā sampādita”nti kevalameva parisaṅkitaṃ. Sabbasaṅgāhakoti
analyzed: kho imam bhikkhum uddissa vadhitvā sampāditanti kevalam eva parisaṅkitam sabba saṅgāhako ti
translated: and he is the one for whom this monk was killed and prepared.” All three of these are only suspicions. The all-inclusive:

original: sabbesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ parisaṅkitānaṃ saṅgaṇhanako.🔽Maṅgalādīnanti ādi-saddena āhunapāhunādikaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Nibbematikā hontīti sabbena🔽sabbaṃ parisaṅkitābhāvamāha. Itaresanti ajānantānaṃ vaṭṭati, jānato evettha āpatti
analyzed: sabbesam tiṇṇam parisaṅkitānam saṅgaṇhanakaḥ  maṅgala ādīnam ti ādi saddena āhuna pāhuna ādikam saṅgaṇhāti nibbematikāḥ honti iti sabbena  sabbam parisaṅkita abhāvam āha itaresanti a jānantānam vaṭṭati jānataḥ eva ittha āpatti
translated: the one who includes all three of the above suspicions.

original: hoti. Teyevāti ye uddissa kataṃ, teyeva.🔽Uddissakatamaṃsaparibhogato akappiyamaṃsaparibhogassa visesaṃ dassetuṃ “akappiyamaṃsaṃ🔽panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Purimasmiṃ sacittakā āpatti, itarasmiṃ acittakā. Tenāha – “akappiyamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: hoti te iva ati ye uddissa katam te iva  uddissa kata maṃsa paribhogataḥ akappiya maṃsa paribhogassa visesam dassetum akappiya maṃsam  pana atiādi vuttam purimasmin sa cittakā āpatti itarasmin acittakā tena āha akappiya maṃsam
translated: The auspicious, etc.: the word “etc.” includes the invited and uninvited, etc. They are free from doubt: this refers to the complete absence of all suspicion. The others: this is allowable for those who do not know, but for those who know there is an offense here. The three: the three for whom it was prepared.

original: ajānitvā bhuttassapi āpattiyevā”ti. Paribhoganti paribhuñjitabbanti vadāmīti attho.
analyzed: a jānitvā bhuttassa api āpattiyā iva ati paribhoganti paribhuñjitabbanti vadāmi iti attho
translated: In order to show the difference between the use of meat that is not allowable and the use of meat that was prepared for a specific person, the text says, “But if the meat is not allowable,” etc. In the former case, the offense is with awareness; in the latter, it is without awareness. Therefore it is said, “If one eats meat that is not allowable without knowing it, there is an offense.” Use: the meaning is, “I say it is to be used.”

original: 53. Tādisassāti tikoṭiparisuddhassa macchamaṃsassa paribhoge. Mettāvihārinopīti api-saddena
analyzed: tādisassa āti ti koṭi parisuddhassa maccha maṃsassa paribhoge mettā vihārino api iti api saddena
translated: Such as: in the use of meat and fish that is pure in the three respects. Even though he is a meditator: the word “even”

original: amettāvihārinopi. Mettāvihārino paribhoge sikhāppattā anavajjatāti dassetuṃ “idha,
analyzed: a mettā vihārinaḥ api mettā vihārinaḥ paribhoge sikhā appattāḥ anavajja tā ti dassetum idha
translated: and also those who do not dwell in loving-kindness. The passage beginning “Here, Jīvaka, a bhikkhu” is said in order to show that the use of requisites by those who dwell in loving-kindness is blameless when it has reached the culmination.

original: jīvaka, bhikkhū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aniyametvāti avisesetvā sāmaññato. Yasmā bhagavatā
analyzed: jīvaka bhikkhu iti ādi vuttam aniyametvā ti avisesetvā sāmaññataḥ yasmai bhagavatā
translated: “Without specifying” means without distinguishing, in a general way. Because the Blessed One

original: – “yato kho, vaccha, bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hotī”tiādinā mahāvacchagottasutte attā🔽aniyametvā vutto. Tathā hi vacchagotto – “tiṭṭhatu bhavaṃ gotamo, atthi pana bhoto
analyzed: yatas kho vaccha bhikkhuno taṇhā pahīnā hoti iti ādinā mahāvaccha gotta sutte attā  aniyametvā vuttaḥ tathā hi vaccha gotto tiṭṭhatu bhavam gotamaḥ atthi pana bhoto
translated: has not specified the person in the Mahāvacchagotta Sutta, which begins thus: “Vaccha, when a bhikkhu’s craving has been abandoned” .

original: gotamassa ekabhikkhupi sāvako āsavānaṃ khayā…pe… upasampajja viharatī”ti āha, “idha,
analyzed: gotamassa sāvakaḥ āsavānam khaya āpe upasampajja viharati iti āha idha
translated: For Vacchagotta said: “Let the venerable Gotama be silent. Are there any bhikkhus, disciples of the venerable Gotama, who, through the complete destruction of three fetters, are Stream-Winners, incapable of falling into states of woe, certain of Nibbāna?”

original: bhāradvāja, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharatī”tiādinā caṅkīsutte
analyzed: bhāradvāja bhikkhu aññataram gāmam vā nigamam vā upanissāya viharati itiādinā caṅkīsutte
translated: And in the Caṅkī Sutta the Blessed One has not specified the person in the passage beginning thus: “Here, Bhāradvāja, a bhikkhu dwells in some village or town” .

original: attā aniyametvā vutto. Tathā hi tattha parato – “yaṃ kho pana ayamāyasmā dhammaṃ
analyzed: attā aniyametvā vuttaḥ tathā hi tattha paratas yam kho pana ayam āyasmā dhammaṃ
translated: For there, the other party said: “But, Master Gotama, the Dhamma that Master Gotama teaches is one thing, but the way that Master Gotama’s disciples are seen practising is another” .

original: deseti, gambhīro so dhammo duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo,
analyzed: deseti gambhīraḥ saḥ dhammaḥ duddasaḥ duranubodhaḥ santaḥ paṇītaḥ a takka avacaraḥ nipuṇaḥ paṇḍita vedanīyo
translated: “The Dhamma that this venerable one teaches is profound, hard to see and hard to understand, peaceful and sublime, unattainable by mere reasoning, subtle, to be experienced by the wise.

original: na so dhammo sudesanīyo luddenā”tiādinā desanā āgatā, tasmā vuttaṃ “bhagavatā hi
analyzed: na so dhammaḥ su desanīyaḥ luddena ati ādinā desanā āgatā tasmā vuttam bhagavatā hi
translated: The teaching given in the passage beginning, “That Dhamma is not easily taught by one who is greedy” ,🔽Therefore it was said above, “For in three places the Exalted One gave this teaching referring to himself:

original: mahāvacchagottasutte, caṅkīsutte imasmiṃ sutteti tīsu ṭhānesu attānaṃyeva sandhāya🔽desanā katā”ti. Maṃsūpasecanova adhippeto macchamaṃsasahitassa āhārassa paribhogabhāvato
analyzed: mahāvacchagotta sutte caṅkīsutte imasmin sutta iti tīsu ṭhānesu sandhāya  desanā katā ati maṃsūpasecanā uva adhippetaḥ maccha maṃsa sahitassa āhārassa paribhoga bhāvato
translated: in the Mahāvacchagotta Sutta, in the Caṅkīsutta, and in this sutta.”🔽The “meat” intended is that which is “fit to be eaten,” since it is the enjoyment of food that includes the eating of fish and meat.

original: macchamaṃsassa ca idha adhippetattā.
analyzed: macchamaṃsassa ca idha adhippetattā
translated: And since fish and meat are intended here,

original: Agathito appaṭibaddho. Taṇhāmucchanāyāti taṇhāyanavasena mucchāpattiyā. Anajjhopanno
analyzed: a gathitaḥ a paṭibaddhaḥ taṇhā mucchanāya ati taṇhāyana vasena mucchā āpattiyā an ajjhopannaḥ
translated: “Unattached” means unfettered. “To the destruction of craving” means to the state of being destroyed by the destruction of craving. “Not clinging” means

original: taṇhāya abhibhavitvā na ajjhotthaṭo, gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā na saṇṭhitoti attho.
analyzed: taṇhāya abhibhavitvā na ajjhotthaṭaḥ gilitvā pariniṭṭhapetvā na saṇṭhitaḥ ti attho
translated: not clinging to the state of being overwhelmed by craving, not remaining after swallowing and digesting.

original: Tenāha – “sabbaṃ ālumpitvā”tiādi. Idha ādīnavo āhārassa paṭikūlabhāvoti āha “ekarattivāsenā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha sabbam ālumpitvā atiādi idha ādīnavaḥ āhārassa paṭikūla bhāvaḥ ti āha eka ratti vāsena atiādi
translated: Therefore it was said above, “Having swallowed everything” , etc. Here the danger is the unattractiveness of food. Therefore it was said, “By staying for one night” , etc.

original: Ayamattho āhāraparibhogoti atthasaṃyojanaparicchedikā “yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā”tiādinā
analyzed: ayam attho āhāra paribhogaḥ ti attha saṃyojana paricchedikā yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā ati ādinā
translated: This meaning is explained in the “Discourse on the Conditions for the Existence of the Aggregates” as “enjoyment of food”: “For the endurance of this body and for its welfare and comfort, and for the support of those who expect help from me” , etc.

original: pavattā āhārapaṭibaddhachandarāganissaraṇabhūtā paññā assa atthīti nissaraṇapañño.
analyzed: pavattā āhāra paṭibaddha chanda rāga nissaraṇa bhūtā paññā assa atthi iti nissaraṇa pañño
translated: He has the understanding that is the escape from the craving for nutriment that occurs bound up with desire.

original: Idamatthanti etamatthāya. Evaṃ santeti “brahmāti ca mettāvihārino samaññā”ti avatvā
analyzed: idam atthanti etam atthāya evam santā iti brahmā ati ca mettā vihārino samaññā iti avatvā
translated: “This is the meaning”: for this purpose. “If that is so”: if you speak of him thus, not saying “Brahmā is a designation for one who abides in loving-kindness,”

original: ye dhammā mettāvihārassa paṭipakkhabhūtā, tattha sāvasesaṃ pahāsi brahmā, anavasesaṃ🔽pahāsi bhagavāti sace te idaṃ sandhāya bhāsitaṃ, evaṃ sante tava idaṃ yathāvuttavacanaṃ
analyzed: ye dhammā mettāvihārassa paṭipakkha bhūtā tattha sa avasesam pahāsi brahmā anavasesam  pahāsi bhagavān ati sace te idam sandhāya bhāsitam evam sante tava idam yathāvutta vacanam
translated: but saying that he has abandoned the states that are opposed to the jhāna of loving-kindness, some abandoned with the noble paths and some abandoned by substitution of opposites,

original: anujānāmi, na mettāvihāritāsāmaññamattatoti attho.🔽55. “Pāṭiyekko anusandhī”ti vatvā visuṃ anusandhibhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “imasmiṃ hī”tiādi
analyzed: anujānāmi na attho  pāṭiyekkaḥ anusandhi iti vatvā visum anusandhi bhāvam dassetum imasmin hi itiādi
translated: then I allow this statement of yours, not because of mere similarity to one who abides in loving-kindness.🔽“A separate connection” : after saying this, he states the separate connection by saying “for in this way,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Dvāraṃ thaketīti macchamaṃsaparibhogānuññāya aññesaṃ vacanadvāraṃ pidahati,
analyzed: vuttam dvāram thaketi iti maccha maṃsa paribhogā anuññāya aññesam vacana dvāram pidahati
translated: “He blocks the door”: he closes the door against the words of others by allowing the use of fish and meat that is pure in three respects;

original: codanāpathaṃ nirundhati. Kathaṃ sattānuddayaṃ dasseti? Sattānuddayamukhena bāhirakānaṃ
analyzed: codanā patham nirundhati katham satta anuddayam dasseti satta anuddaya mukhena bāhira kānam
translated: he stops the way of accusation. How does he show the harmlessness of beings? By the harmlessness of beings he shows

original: macchamaṃsaparibhogapaṭikkhepo tayidaṃ micchā, tikoṭiparisuddhasseva macchamaṃsassa🔽paribhogo bhagavatā anuññāto. Tathā hi vuttaṃ – ‘tīhi kho ahaṃ, jīvaka, ṭhānehi maṃsaṃ🔽paribhoganti vadāmī’tiādi. Vinayepi vuttaṃ – “tikoṭiparisuddhaṃ, devadatta, macchamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: maccha maṃsa paribhoga paṭikkhepo tayidam micchā ti koṭi parisuddhassa iva maccha maṃsassa  paribhogaḥ bhagavatā anuññātaḥ tathā hi vuttam tīhi kho aham jīvaka ṭhānehi maṃsam  paribhogam ti vadāmi itiādi vinaye pi vuttam ti koṭi parisuddham devadatta maccha maṃsam
translated: The prohibition of the eating of fish and meat is wrong, because the Blessed One has permitted the eating of fish and meat that are quite pure in three respects,

original: mayā anuññāta”nti. Tikoṭiparisuddhañca bhuñjantānaṃ sattesu anuddayā niccalā. “Sattānuddayaṃ
analyzed: mayā anuññātanti ti koṭi parisuddhañca bhuñjantānam sattesu anuddayā niccalā satta anuddayam
translated: as is stated thus: “Jivaka, I say that meat may be eaten when it is pure in three respects” , etc. In the Vinaya too it is said: “Devadatta, I have permitted the eating of fish and meat that are quite pure in three respects” . And those who eat meat that is quite pure in three respects are free from cruelty towards living beings.

original: dassetī”ti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vivaranto “sace hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dasseti iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vivarantaḥ sace hi iti ādim āha
translated: In the passage “he shows his lack of cruelty towards living beings” , the meaning stated in brief is made clear by the following elaboration: “If he were to eat meat after seeking it out, etc.”

original: Paṭhamena kāraṇenāti desanāvasenapi payogavasenapi paṭhamena parūpaghātahetunā. Kaḍḍhito🔽so pāṇo. Galena pavedhentenāti yottagalena karaṇena asayhamānena. Bahupuññameva hoti
analyzed: paṭhamena kāraṇena ati desanā vasena api payoga vasena api paṭhamena parūpaghāta hetunā kaḍḍhitaḥ  saḥ pāṇaḥ galena karaṇena a sayhamānena bahu puññam eva hoti
translated: By the first reason: by the first reason, namely, the killing of living beings for the sake of one’s own consumption.🔽The living being is killed and is then bound by the neck.🔽He gains much merit because he is free from the desire to enjoy the taste, and because he is motivated by a compassionate state of mind.

original: āsādanāpekkhāya abhāvato, hitajjhāsayattā vāti adhippāyo. Esāhaṃ, bhantetiādi kasmā
analyzed: āsādana apekkhāya abhāvataḥ vāti adhippāyaḥ esā aham bhante tiādi kasmā
translated: Why does the Elder say, “I will not, venerable sir, eat meat,” etc.?

original: vuttaṃ, saraṇagamanavaseneva gahitasaraṇoti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “aya”ntiādi. Ogāhantotiādito🔽paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā suttaṃ anussaranto atthaṃ upadhārento. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: vuttam saraṇa gamana vasena iva gahita saraṇā iti codanam sandhāya āha ayantiādi ogāhantaḥ iti āditaḥ  paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā suttam anussarantaḥ attham upadhārentaḥ sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: He is called “one who has gone for refuge” because he has gone for refuge by means of the going for refuge. The rest is easily intelligible.

original: Jīvakasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: jīvaka sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “līna” in the Jīvaka Sutta is ended.

original: 6. Upālisuttavaṇṇanā🔽56. Pāvāraṃ pārupatīti pāvāriko, idaṃ tassa kulasamudāgataṃ nāmaṃ, so pana mahaddhano
analyzed: upāli sutta vaṇṇanā  pāvāram pārupati iti pāvārikaḥ idam tassa kula samudāgatam nāmam saḥ pana mahat dhanaḥ
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “līna” in the Upāli Sutta🔽is ended.🔽The word pāvāraṃ pārupati is derived from pāvārika. This is his family name. He was a very rich man, a great merchant, who held the position of a chief merchant in the city. Therefore it is said: “of the chief merchant who wore a pāvāra robe.”

original: mahābhogo nagare seṭṭhiṭṭhāne ṭhito. Tenāha “dussapāvārikaseṭṭhino”ti. Dīghattā dīghatamattā.🔽So kira pamāṇato upavacchayato diyaḍḍharatanaṃ atikkamma ṭhito. Evaṃladdhanāmoti
analyzed: mahābhogaḥ nagare seṭṭhi ṭṭhāne ṭhitaḥ tena āha dussa pāvārika seṭṭhino ti dīgha ttā dīghatama ttā  saḥ kira pamāṇataḥ upavacchayataḥ diyaḍḍha ratanam atikkamma ṭhitaḥ evaṃladdha nāmā iti
translated: It was long because of its length.🔽It is said that it was two and a half cubits long.🔽He was called “Dīghatapassī” because he had this kind of robe.

original: “dīghatapassī”ti laddhasamañño. Bāhirāyataneti titthiyasamaye piṇḍapātoti vohāro
analyzed: dīghatapassī iti laddha samaññaḥ bāhira āyatane ti titthiya samaye piṇḍapāto ti vohāro
translated: The word “external sense-base” is used in the sense of “external object.”

original: natthi, tasmā sāsanavohārena “piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto”ti vuttanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: natthi tasmā sāsana vohārena piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ ti vuttan ti adhippāyo
translated: The word “alms-food” is not used in the sense of “alms-food” in the time of the sectarians.🔽Therefore, the intention is that he is said to have “returned from his alms round” in the sense of the Dispensation.

original: Dassetīti deseti. Ṭhapetīti aññamaññasaṅkarato vavatthapeti. Kiriyāyāti karaṇena.
analyzed: dasseti iti deseti ṭhapeti iti aññam añña saṅkarataḥ vavatthapeti kiriyāya ati karaṇena
translated: “He shows” means he teaches. “He establishes” means he defines by distinguishing one from another. “By action” means by the doing.

original: Pavattiyāti pavattanena. Daṇḍāni paññapetīti ettha kasmā bhagavatā āditova tathā
analyzed: pavattiyā ti pavattanena daṇḍāni paññapeti iti ettha kasmai bhagavatā āditas va tathā
translated: “By occurrence” means by the occurrence. As to the passage beginning, “He lays down rules of conduct,” why did the Blessed One not ask him about the matter in the first place?

original: na pucchitanti? Yasmā sā tasmiṃ atthe sabhāvanirutti na hoti, sāsane loke samayantaresu🔽ca tādiso samudācāro natthi, kevalaṃ pana tasseva nigaṇṭhassāyaṃ koṭṭhālakasadiso
analyzed: na yasmā sā tasmin atthe sabhāva nirutti na hoti sāsane loke samayantaresu  ca tādisaḥ samudācāraḥ natthi kevalam pana tassa iva nigaṇṭhassa ayam koṭṭhālaka sadiso
translated: Because that is not the natural expression for that meaning, and because such a usage is not found in the Dispensation or in the world or among the other sects,

original: samudācāroti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “kammāni paññapeti” iccevāha. Acittakanti cittarahitaṃ,
analyzed: samudācāro ti imam attham dassetum kammāni paññapeti icca iva āha acittakam ti citta rahitam
translated: but it is the usage of that naked ascetic only, which is like a potsherd. In order to show this meaning, he said, “He lays down rules of conduct” as if it were the natural expression. “Without consciousness” means without consciousness,

original: cittena asamuṭṭhāpitanti attho. Kathaṃ pana tadubhayassa cittena vinā sambhavoti
analyzed: cittena asamuṭṭhāpitanti attho katham pana tad ubhayassa cittena vinā
translated: without being originated by consciousness, is the meaning. But how can both of these occur without consciousness?

original: codanaṃ sandhāya tattha nidassanamāha “yathā kirā”tiādi. Paṭivibhattānanti atthato
analyzed: codanam sandhāya tattha nidassanam āha yathā kirāti ādi atthataḥ
translated: With reference to this question, he gives the illustration beginning with the words, “It is just as though, bhikkhus.”

original: bhinnānaṃ. Paṭivisiṭṭhānanti visesanapadavasena saddatopi bhinnānaṃ. Vacanaṃ patiṭṭhapetukāmoti
analyzed: bhinnānam paṭivisiṭṭhānam ti visesana pada vasena saddataḥ pi bhinnānam vacanam patiṭṭhapetu kāmaḥ iti
translated: “Distinguishing” means distinguishing by meaning. “Distinguishing by word” means distinguishing by word as well as by the meaning of the word. “He wanted to establish his statement” means he wanted to establish his statement by the Blessed One’s approval.

original: dīghatapassino yathāvuttavacanaṃ patiṭṭhapetukāmo. Tasmiñhi patiṭṭhāpite tenappasaṅgena
analyzed: dīghatapassinaḥ yathā vutta vacanam patiṭṭhapetu kāmo tasmin hi patiṭṭhāpite tena pasaṅgena
translated: He wanted to establish the long-timer’s statement as stated. For when that is established, then without further ado

original: āgato, upāli gahapati tasmiṃ padese dhammaṃ disvā sāsane abhippasīdissati.
analyzed: āgataḥ upāli gahapati tasmin padese dhammam disvā sāsane abhippasīdissati
translated: the householder Upāli, having seen the Dhamma in that place, will be confident in the Dispensation.

original: Kathā eva upari vādāropanassa vatthubhāvato kathāvatthu. Kathāyaṃ patiṭṭhapesīti
analyzed: kathā eva upari vāda āropanassa vatthu bhāvato kathā vatthu kathāyam patiṭṭhapesi iti
translated: Discussion is a basis for a dispute because it is the source of a dispute that is superimposed on it. He established the discussion

original: kathāvatthusmiṃ, tadatthe vā patiṭṭhapesi. Yathā taṃ vādāropanabhayena na avajānāti,
analyzed: kathā vatthusmim tad atthe vā patiṭṭhapesi yathā tam vāda āropana bhayena na avajānāti
translated: in the basis for discussion, or in its meaning. Just as he did not disregard it out of fear of a dispute that is superimposed on it,

original: evaṃ tassaṃ kathāyaṃ, tasmiṃ vā atthe dīghatapassiṃ yāvatatiyaṃ vāde patiṭṭhapesi. Vādanti dosaṃ.
analyzed: evam tassam tasmin vā atthe dīghatapassim yāvatatiyam vāde patiṭṭhapesi vādanti dosam
translated: so he established the long-timer in the discussion or in its meaning up to a third time. A dispute is a fault.

original: 57. Idāni cetanāsampayuttadhammampi gahetvā kāyakammādivasena saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ🔽“apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ kāyakammaṃ nāmātiādi “kammassa
analyzed: idāni cetanā sampayutta dhammam pi gahetvā kāya kamma ādi vasena saṅgahetvā dassetuṃ  apica atiādi vuttam tattha tividham kāya duccaritam kāyakammam nāma atiādi kammassa
translated: Now, in order to show that he also included the states associated with volition and classed them as bodily action, etc.,

original: kiriyāyā”ti pāḷiyaṃ akusalakammassa adhigatattā vuttaṃ, pubbe pana aṭṭhakāmāvacarakusalacetanātiādi
analyzed: kiriyāya iti pāḷiyam akusala kammassa adhigata ttā vuttam pubbe pana aṭṭha kāmāvacara kusala cetanā tiādi
translated: he said “Moreover,” etc. Herein, the threefold bodily misconduct is called bodily action, etc. “In the performance of action” is said in the text because unwholesome action is included. But previously he said “the eight kinds of sense-sphere profitable volition,” etc.,

original: sāvajjaṃ anavajjañca sāmaññato ekajjhaṃ katvā dassitaṃ. Kasmā panettha cetanā na🔽gahitāti āha “imasmiṃ sutte kammaṃ dhura”nti. Kāyakammādibhedaṃ kammameva dhuraṃ
analyzed: sāvajjam anavajjam ca sāmaññato ekajjham katvā dassitam kasmā pana ittha cetanā na  gahitā iti āha imasmin sutte kammam dhuranti kāya kamma ādi bhedam kammam eva dhuram
translated: and the blameworthy and the blameless are shown as one in the general sense. But why is volition not included here? —🔽“In this Thread action is the burden,” he said. Action alone, classed as bodily action, etc., is the burden, the chief thing, the forerunner, not mere volition.

original: jeṭṭhakaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ, na cetanāmattameva. Evamāgatepīti kammānīti evaṃ nāmena āgatepi
analyzed: jeṭṭhakam pubbaṅgamam na cetanā mattam eva evam āgate pi iti kammāni iti evam nāmena āgate pi
translated: “In the same way in the case of the words ‘kammam anīti’ ”: in the case of the words ‘kammam anī’ which are the name for action.

original: cetanā dhuraṃ, tattha cetanaṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā vuttanti adhippāyo. Kathaṃ
analyzed: cetanā dhuram tattha cetanam jeṭṭhakam pubbaṅgamam katvā vuttanti adhippāyaḥ katham
translated: The intention is that volition is the burden, the chief thing, the forerunner, there, in the case of the words ‘kammam anī’, which are stated with volition as the chief thing.

original: pana tattha kammanti vā kammānīti vā āgate tesaṃ cetanāya dhurabhāvoti āha “yattha
analyzed: pana tattha kammanti vā kammāni iti vā āgate tesam cetanāya dhura bhāvaḥ ti āha yattha
translated: But how is it that in the case of the words ‘kammam’ and ‘kammam anī’ the burden-bearing is that of the volition? —

original: katthaci…pe… labhatī”ti. Tattha yattha katthacīti yasmiṃ kismiñci dvāre. Sā vuttāvāti🔽sā cetanā vuttāva, yā kāyasaṅkhārādipariyāyena (yassa kassaci kammassa kāyadvārādīsu
analyzed: katthacipe labhati iti tattha yattha katthaci iti yasmin kismiñci dvāre sā vuttā avāti  sā cetanā yā kāya saṅkhāra ādi pariyāyena yassa kassaci kammassa kāya dvāra ādīsu
translated: “Wherever it is stated … he finds it” he said. Herein, wherever it is stated is in any of the doors.🔽That is stated is that volition is stated.

original: pavattāpanacetanā) sampayuttadhammāpi tadaggena lokiyāpi lokuttarāpi kammameva, abhijjhādayo
analyzed: pavatta āpana cetanā sampayutta dhammā api tad aggena lokiyā api lokuttarā api kammam eva abhijjha ādayaḥ
translated: The associated states too, which are the synonyms for bodily determinations, etc., are action by the same method as the volition that occurs in the bodily door, etc., of any kind of action whatever. And the greed, etc.,

original: pana cetanāpakkhikāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Mahantanti kaṭukaphalaṃ. Na kilamati sappāṭihāriyattā paṭiññāya. Idāni tesaṃ sappāṭihāriyataṃ🔽dassetuṃ “tathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yadi akusalaṃ patvā kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ mahantanti
analyzed: pana cetanā pakkhikā ti daṭṭhabbam  kaṭuka phalam na kilamati sa pāṭihāriya ttā paṭiññāya idāni tesam sa pāṭihāriya taṃ  dassetum tathā hi itiādi vuttam yadi akusalam patvā kāya kammam vacī kammam mahantam ti
translated: but it should be regarded as belonging to the volition class.

original: vadanto na kilamati, atha kasmā bhagavā idha akusalaṃ manokammaṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ kathesīti
analyzed: vadantaḥ na kilamati atha kasmai bhagavā idha akusalam manaḥ kammam mahā sāvajjam kathesi iti
translated: “Great” means having a bitter fruit. He does not get tired because of the marvel of his vow. Now, in order to show the marvel of his vow, it is said: “Thus indeed,” etc. If, having come to unwholesome bodily action and speech action, he does not get tired, saying that they are great, then why did the Blessed One here declare unwholesome mental action to be of great danger?

original: āha “imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne”tiādi. Yāvatatiyaṃ patiṭṭhāpanamattena gatamaggaṃ paṭipajjanto.
analyzed: āha imasmim pana ṭhāne iti ādi yāvatatiyam patiṭṭhāpana mattena gata maggam paṭipajjanto
translated: Therefore it is said: “But in this place,” etc. By the mere establishment of the third time, he goes along the path that has been gone before.

original: Tenāha “kiñci atthanipphattiṃ apassantopī”ti.🔽58. Nivāsaṭṭhānabhūto bālako etissā atthīti bālakinī. Satthupaṭiññātatāya nigaṇṭhānaṃ mahāti sambhāvitattā mahānigaṇṭho.
analyzed: tena āha kiñci attha nipphattim a passantaḥ api iti  nivāsa ṭṭhāna bhūtaḥ bālakaḥ etissā atthi iti bālakinī satthu paṭiññāta tāya nigaṇṭhānam mahā ati sambhāvita ttā mahānigaṇṭhaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: “Not seeing any fulfilment of purpose,” etc.🔽It has a foolish person as its abode, thus it is a foolish woman. Because of the Blessed One’s vow, the Niganthas are greatly honoured, thus he is a great Niganthist.

original: 60. Āvaṭṭeti purimākārato nivatteti attano vase vatteti etāyāti āvaṭṭanī, māyā. Tenāha
analyzed: āvaṭṭa iti purima ākārataḥ nivatteti attanaḥ vase vatteti etāya ati āvaṭṭanī māyā tena āha
translated: It turns back, it makes one turn back from the former mode, it makes one come under its own control, thus it is a turn-back, a deception. Therefore it is said:

original: “āvaṭṭetvā gahaṇamāya”nti. Satthupaṭiññānaṃ buddhadassane cittameva na uppajjati,
analyzed: āvaṭṭetvā gahaṇam āyanti satthu paṭiññānam buddha dassane cittam eva na uppajjati
translated: “To be taken by turning round.” The thought of seeing the Buddha never arises in one who has made such a profession.

original: ayamettha dhammatā. Sace pana so taṃ paṭiññaṃ appahāya buddhānaṃ sammukhībhāvaṃ upagaccheyya,🔽sattadhā muddhā phaleyya, tasmā bhagavā “mā ayaṃ bālo vinassī”tiāditova yathā sammukhībhāvaṃ
analyzed: ayam ettha dhamma tā sace pana saḥ tam paṭiññam a pahāya buddhānam sammukhībhāvam upagaccheyya  sattadhā tasmai bhagavā mā ayam bālaḥ vinassi iti āditas uva yathā sammukhībhāvam
translated: This is the natural state of things here. But if he were to approach the presence of the Buddhas without abandoning that profession,🔽his head would split into seven pieces. Therefore the Blessed One acts in such a way that he does not get the opportunity of approaching the presence of the Buddhas, thinking: “Let not this fool be destroyed.” This matter should be illustrated by the story of the meeting with Pāṭikaputta.🔽The Blessed One said: “Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”

original: na labhati, tathā karoti. Svāyamattho pāthikaputtasamāgamena dīpetabbo. Dassanasampattiniyāmamāha
analyzed: na labhati tathā karoti su āyam atthaḥ pāthika putta samāgamena dīpetabbaḥ dassana sampatti niyāmam āha
translated: “Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”

original: “tathāgataṃ hī”tiādi. Āgamā nu kho idha tumhākaṃ santikaṃ.🔽61. Vacīsacce patiṭṭhahitvāti yathāpaṭiññātāya paṭiññāya ṭhatvā.🔽62. Sītodake amatā pāṇā pānakāle pana maranti, tepi tena sītodakaparibhogena māritā
analyzed: tathāgatam hi itiādi āgamāḥ nu kho idha tumhākam santikam  vacīsacce patiṭṭhahitvā ti yathā paṭiññātāya paṭiññāya ṭhatvā  sītā udake pāṇā pāna kāle pana maranti te api tena sītā udaka paribhogena māritā
translated: “Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”🔽“Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession of asceticism.”

original: honti, tasmā tapassinā nāma sabbena sabbaṃ sītodakaṃ na paribhuñjitabbanti tesaṃ
analyzed: honti tasmā tapassinā nāma sabbena sabbam sīta udakam na paribhuñjitabbanti tesam
translated: “Monks, I do not see even one other thing owing to the adoption of which so many people have perished as owing to the adoption of the profession

original: laddhi. Pākatikaṃ vā udakaṃ sattoti purātanānaṃ nigaṇṭhānaṃ laddhi. Tenāha “sattasaññāya🔽sītodakaṃ paṭikkhipantī”ti. Tesaṃ taṃ adhunātananigaṇṭhānaṃ vādena virujjhati. Te
analyzed: laddhi pākatikam vai udakam satto ti purātanānam nigaṇṭhānam laddhi tena āha satta saññāya  sītā udakam paṭikkhipanti iti tesam tam adhunātana nigaṇṭhānam vādena virujjhati te
translated: The ancient Niganthas held that water is a living being. Hence it is said, “They reject cold water with the perception of a living being.” This contradicts the doctrine of the present-day Niganthas,

original: hi pathavīādinavapadatthato aññameva jīvitaṃ paṭijānanti. Cittena sītodakaṃ pātukāmo
analyzed: hi pathavī ādi nava padatthato aññam eva jīvitam paṭijānanti cittena sīta udakam pātu kāmo
translated: for the latter admit a life principle that is different from the elements of earth, etc. When one wishes to drink cold water or to use it for bathing,

original: paribhuñjitukāmo hoti roge ṭhatvāpi sattānaṃ cittassa tathā na vitatatā. Tenāha –
analyzed: paribhuñjitu kāmaḥ hoti roge sattānam cittassa tathā na vitata tā tena āha
translated: one does so with a mind that is not disturbed by the thought of a living being. Even when one is sick, one’s mind is not disturbed in this way. Therefore it is said:

original: “tenassa manodaṇḍo tattheva bhijjatī”ti. Tenāti sītodakaṃ pātuṃ paribhuñjituñca icchanena.🔽Assāti yathāvuttassa nigaṇṭhassa. Tatthevāti tathācittuppādane eva. Bhijjati saṃvarassa
analyzed: tena assa manodaṇḍaḥ tattha iva bhijjati iti tena ati sītā udakam pātum paribhuñjitum ca icchanena  assa ati yathā vuttassa nigaṇṭhassa tattha iva ati tathā citta uppādane eva bhijjati saṃvarassa
translated: “The restraint of his mind breaks up right there.” The word “there” refers to the wish to drink cold water or to use it for bathing.

original: vikopitattā. Tathābhūto so nigaṇṭho sītodakaṃ ce labheyya, katipayaṃ kālaṃ jīveyya,
analyzed: vikopi tattā tathābhūtaḥ saḥ nigaṇṭhaḥ sītā udakam ce labheyya katipayam kālam jīveyya
translated: “His” refers to the Niganthas mentioned above. “Right there” means right there in the arising of such a thought. The restraint breaks up because the restraint is disturbed. If such a Niganthas were to obtain cold water, he would live for a few days,

original: alābhena pana parisussamānakaṇṭhoṭṭhatālujivhāādiko sabbaso paridāhābhibhūto mareyya.
analyzed: alābhena pana parisussamāna kaṇṭha uṭṭha tālu jivhā ādiko sabbaso paridāha abhibhūtaḥ mareyya
translated: but if he did not obtain it, he would die of thirst, his throat, palate, and tongue dried up, and so on.

original: Tenāha – “sītodakaṃ alabhamāno kālaṃ kareyyā”ti. Kasmā? Yasmā sītodakaṃ pivāya sannissitacittassa
analyzed: tena āha sītā udakam a labhamānaḥ kālam kareyya ati kasmai yasmai sītā udakam pivāya sannissita cittassa
translated: Hence he said: “If he cannot get cool water, he might die.”🔽Why? Because death comes to one whose mind is dependent on cool water.

original: maraṇaṃ hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “manodaṇḍo pana bhinnopi cutimpi ākaḍḍhatī”ti. Yasmā pana🔽tathābhūtacittassa nigaṇṭhassa manosattesu nāma devesu upapatti hotīti titthiyānaṃ
analyzed: maraṇam hoti tasmā vuttam manodaṇḍaḥ pana bhinnaḥ api cutim pi ākaḍḍhati iti yasmā pana  tathābhūta cittassa nigaṇṭhassa manosattesu nāma devesu upapatti hoti iti titthiyānam
translated: That is why it was said above: “The mind rod, though broken, drags one even to death.”🔽But because the sectarians’ doctrine is that the Nigantha’s rebirth is among the Manomayas,

original: laddhi, tasmā vuttaṃ “manodaṇḍo pana bhinnopi paṭisandhimpi ākaḍḍhatī”ti. Itīti evaṃ
analyzed: laddhi tasmā vuttam manodaṇḍaḥ pana bhinnaḥ api paṭisandhim pi ākaḍḍhati iti iti iti evam
translated: that is why it was said: “The mind rod, though broken, drags one even to rebirth.”🔽It is thus: in the way stated above with the words “Here a Nigantha … ”🔽N: to the householder Upali.

original: “idhāssa nigaṇṭho”tiādiākārena. Nanti upāliṃ gahapatiṃ. Mahantoti vadāpesi “manopaṭibaddho
analyzed: idha assa nigaṇṭhaḥ ti ādi ākārena upālim gahapatim mahantaḥ ti manaḥ upaṭibaddhaḥ
translated: Great: he made him say “great” when he said “He dies bound by mind.”

original: kālaṅkarotī”ti vadantoti adhippāyo.🔽Upāsakassāti upālissa gahapatissa. Mucchāvasenātiādinā anvayato byatirekato ca manodaṇḍassa
analyzed: kālaṅkaroti iti vadanto ti adhippāyo  upāsakassa ati upālissa gahapatissa mucchā vasena ati ādinā anvayataḥ byatirekataḥ ca manodaṇḍassa
translated: Upasaka: of Upali the householder.

original: mahantataṃ vibhāveti. Cittasantatippavattimattenevāti vinā kāyadaṇḍena vacīdaṇḍena
analyzed: mahantatam vibhāveti vinā kāya daṇḍena vacī daṇḍena
translated: By the process of elimination and by the process of addition he analyses the greatness of the mind rod with the words “By the mere occurrence of the mind’s continuity” and so on. By the mere occurrence of the mind’s continuity: without the body rod and the speech rod,

original: ca kevalaṃ cittasantatippavattimattena. Bhijjitvāpīti ettha pi-saddena abhijjitvāpi.
analyzed: ca kevalam citta santati pavattimattena bhijjitvā api iti ettha pi saddena a bhijjitvā api
translated: The word “or” in the phrase “having coveted or not having coveted” shows that it is not necessary to have coveted.🔽“Not leading to emancipation” means not leading to the destruction of the corruptions.

original: Aniyyānikāti appāṭihīrā, ayuttāti attho. Sallakkhesi upāsakoti vibhattiṃ vipariṇāmetvā
analyzed: aniyyānikā ti appāṭihīrā ayuttā ti attho sallakkhesi upāsakaḥ iti vibhattim vipariṇāmetvā
translated: The word “having considered” is a gerundive.

original: yojanā. Pañhapaṭibhānānīti ñātuṃ icchite atthe uppajjanakapaṭibhānāni.
analyzed: yojanā pañha paṭibhānāni iti ñātum icchite atthe uppajjanaka paṭibhānāni
translated: “Answers to questions” are the answers that arise to a questioner when he is desirous of knowing the meaning of a question.

original: “Manopaṭibaddho kālaṃ karotī”ti vadantena atthato manodaṇḍassa taduttarabhāvo paṭiññāto🔽hotīti āha “idāni manodaṇḍo mahantoti idaṃ vacana”nti. Tathā ceva vuttaṃ – “manodaṇḍova
analyzed: manaḥ paṭibaddhaḥ kālam karoti iti vadantena atthataḥ manodaṇḍassa tad uttara bhāvaḥ paṭiññātaḥ  hoti iti āha idāni manodaṇḍaḥ mahanto ti idam vacananti tathā ca iva vuttam
translated: By saying “he dies with his mind bound to it,” he admits that the mind-rod is the next highest after the speech-rod.🔽Therefore it is said: “This statement ‘the mind-rod is great’ ” .

original: balavā mahantoti vadāpesī”ti.🔽63. Pāṇātipātādito yamanaṃ yāmo, catubbidho yāmo catuyāmo, catuyāmasaṅkhātena saṃvarena
analyzed: balavā mahantaḥ iti  pāṇātipāta āditaḥ yamanam yāmaḥ catubbidhaḥ yāmaḥ catu yāmaḥ catu yāma saṅkhātena saṃvarena
translated: And it is said: “He made him say that the mind-rod is powerful and great” .🔽The restraint of the fourfold restraint is the fourfold restraint.🔽The one restrained by the fourfold restraint is the one restrained by the fourfold restraint.

original: saṃvuto cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana yāma-saddo koṭṭhāsapariyāyoti
analyzed: saṃvuto cātuyāma saṃvara saṃvuto aṭṭhakathāyam pana yāma saddo koṭṭhāsa pariyāyo ti
translated: But in the commentary the word yāma is a synonym for part.

original: “iminā catukoṭṭhāsenā”ti vuttaṃ. Piyajātikaṃ rūpādiārammaṇaṃ rāgavasena bālehi bhāvanīyattā
analyzed: iminā catu koṭṭhāsena ati vuttam piya jātikam rūpa ādi ārammaṇam rāga vasena bālehi bhāvanīya ttā
translated: “By this fourfold method” is said. The object of the five strands of sense pleasure, such as visible forms, is called “developed” because it is to be developed by fools through lust.

original: “bhāvita”nti vuccatīti āha “bhāvitanti pañca kāmaguṇā”ti.
analyzed: bhāvitanti vuccati iti āha bhāvitanti pañca
translated: Therefore it is said: “Developed means the five strands of sense pleasure.”

original: Yo sabbaṃ pāpaṃ āsavañca vāretīti sabbavārī, tassa navasu padatthesu sattamo padattho,🔽tena sabbavārinā pāpaṃ vāritvā ṭhitoti sabbavārivārito. Tenāha “sabbena pāpavāraṇena🔽vāritapāpo”ti. Tato eva sabbassa vāritabbassa āsavassa dhunanato sabbavāridhuto.
analyzed: yaḥ sabbam pāpam āsavañca vāreti iti sabbavārī tassa navasu padatthesu sattamaḥ padattho  tena sabba vārinā pāpam vāritvā ṭhitaḥ ti sabba vāri vāritaḥ tena āha sabbena pāpa vāraṇena  vārita pāpo ti tatas eva sabbassa vāritabbassa āsavassa dhunanataḥ sabba vāri dhutaḥ
translated: The seventh meaning among the nine meanings of the word sabba is “all-excluding,” which means “that which excludes all evil and the taints.”🔽Therefore it is said: “The all-excluding is the one who stands, having excluded evil by all-excluding.”🔽And because it washes away all the taints that should be excluded, it is the all-excluding wash.

original: Vāritabbassa nivāraṇavasena sabbavārino phuṭo phusitoti sabbavāriphuṭo. Saṅghātanti
analyzed: vāritabbassa nivāraṇa vasena sabba vārino phuṭaḥ phusito ti sabba vāri phuṭaḥ saṅghātanti
translated: The all-excluding is covered, touched, by the evil that should be excluded, therefore it is the all-excluding cover.

original: sahasā hananaṃ, asañcetanikavadhanti attho. Katarasmiṃ koṭṭhāseti tīsu daṇḍakoṭṭhāsesu katarakoṭṭhāse.
analyzed: sahasā hananam katarasmin koṭṭhāse ti tīsu daṇḍa koṭṭhāsesu katara koṭṭhāse
translated: “Killing” means killing suddenly, which means killing unintentionally. In which part? In which of the three parts of the body?

original: 64. Khaliyati samādiyatīti khalaṃ, rāsīti āha – “ekaṃ maṃsakhalanti ekaṃ maṃsarāsi”nti.
analyzed: khaliyati samādiyati iti khalam rāsi iti āha ekam maṃsakhalanti ekam
translated: “A heap” is a collection. Therefore it is said: “One meat heap means one meat collection.”

original: Vijjādharaiddhiyā iddhimā. Sā pana iddhi yasmā ānubhāvasampannasseva ijjhati, na
analyzed: vijjādhara eddhiyā sā pana iddhi yasmai na
translated: He is endowed with the psychic power of the psychic power of the possessor of supernormal power of knowledge. But that psychic power succeeds only for one who is endowed with influence,

original: yassa kassaci. Tasmā āha “ānubhāvasampanno”ti. Vijjānubhāvavaseneva ānubhāvasampanno.🔽Citte vasībhāvappatto ānubhāvāya eva vijjāya paguṇabhāvāpādanena. Etena vasībhāvaṃ
analyzed: yassa kassaci tasmai āha ānubhāva sampannaḥ ti vijjā anubhāva vasena iva ānubhāva sampannaḥ  citte vasībhāva patto ānubhāvāya eva vijjāya paguṇa bhāva āpādanena etena vasībhāvam
translated: not for anyone at all. Therefore he said “endowed with influence.” He is endowed with influence by way of the influence of knowledge.🔽By way of the influence of knowledge, he has attained mastery over his mind, by way of the influence of knowledge, by bringing about the state of being well-trained. By this he said,

original: lokiyasamaññāvasena bhagavā upāliṃ gahapatiṃ paññapetukāmo evamāha. Lokikā hi “bhāvanāmayaiddhiyā🔽iddhimā cetovasībhāvappatto parūpaghātaṃ karotī”ti maññanti. Tathā hi te isayo paresaṃ
analyzed: lokiya samaññā vasena bhagavā upālim gahapatim paññapetu kāmaḥ evam āha lokikāḥ hi  iddhimā cetaḥ vasībhāva patto para upaghātam karoti iti maññanti tathā hi te isayo paresam
translated: desiring to describe the householder Upāli by way of the mundane designation, “He who is endowed with psychic power by way of the psychic power of development,🔽who has attained mastery over his mind, harms others.” For they think thus: “The seers,

original: saṃvaṇṇenti, isīnaṃ ānubhāvaṃ kittenti. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ parato āgamissatīti.
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇenti isīnam ānubhāvam kittenti yat pana ittha vattabbam tat paratas āgamissati iti
translated: having attained mastery over their minds by way of the psychic power of development, harm others.” Thus they praise the seers, saying: “The seers have influence over the mind.” But what should be said here will come later.

original: 65. Araññameva hutvāti sabbaso araññameva hutvā. Araññabhāvena araññaṃ jātaṃ, na nāmamattena. Isīnaṃ atthāyāti isīnaṃ āsādanatthāya.
analyzed: araññam eva hutvā iti sabbaso araññam eva hutvā arañña bhāvena araññam jātam na nāma mattena isīnam atthāya ati isīnam āsādana tthāya
translated: Having become a forest only: having become a forest entirely. It has become a forest by way of the state of being a forest, not by way of the name. For the sake of the seers: for the sake of the satisfaction of the seers.

original: Godhāvarītīrato nātidūre. Usūyamānoti “na maṃ esa jano parivāretī”ti usūyaṃ karonto.
analyzed: godhāvarī tīrataḥ na atidūre na mama esa janaḥ parivāreti iti usūyam karontaḥ
translated: Not far from the bank of the Godhāvarī River. Jealous: making jealousy, thinking, “People are not surrounding me.”

original: Kiliṭṭho vatāti paṅkadantarajasiratādīhi kiliṭṭhasarīro. Anañjitamaṇḍitoti anañjitakkhiko🔽sabbena, sabbaṃ amaṇḍito ca. Tasmiṃ kāle “kālasseva akkhīnaṃ añjanaṃ maṅgala”nti
analyzed: kiliṭṭhaḥ vata iti paṅka danta raja sirata ādīhi kiliṭṭha sarīraḥ anañjita maṇḍitaḥ ti anañjita kkhiko  sabbena sabbam a maṇḍito ca tasmin kāle kālassa iva akkhīnam añjanam maṅgalanti
translated: Dirty: with a body dirty with mud, dust, hair, etc. Unanointed: not anointed with unguents.🔽Not decorated: not decorated with anything at all. At that time, it was the custom of people to think, “It is an omen if one anoints one’s eyes early in the morning,”

original: manussānaṃ laddhi, tasmā anañjanaṃ visuṃ gahitaṃ.
analyzed: manussānam laddhi tasmai anañjanam visum gahitam
translated: so not anointing was taken as a separate thing.

original: Rājā tassa vacanaṃ gahetvāti “vedesu īdisaṃ āgataṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ, bhante”ti rājā
analyzed: rājā tassa vacanam gahetvā ati vedesu īdisam āgatam bhavissati iti evam bhante iti rājā
translated: The king accepted his words: “Venerable Sir, it must have been something like this that has come to the Vedas.” The king

original: tassa purohitassa vacanaṃ gahetvā. Usumajātahadayoti uttattahadayo. Nāsikānaṃ appahonte mukhena assasanto.
analyzed: tassa purohitassa vacanam gahetvā usuma jāta hadayaḥ iti uttatta hadayaḥ nāsikānam mukhena assasantaḥ
translated: accepted the words of his chief priest. His heart was burning: his heart was hot, and his nose being unable to bear it, he was breathing through his mouth.

original: Vijitajayehi āgantvā nakkhattayuttaṃ āgamentehi nisīditabbaṭṭhānaṃ jayakhandhāvāraṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: vijita jayehi āgantvā nakkhatta yuttam āgamentehi nisīditabba ṭṭhānam jaya khandha āvāra ṭṭhānam
translated: The place where the victorious kings sat down after coming and being seated with the astrologers was the place of the victorious tent.

original: Udakavuṭṭhipātanādi tasmiṃ pāpakamme asamaṅgibhūtānampi samanuññatāya antokaraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: udaka vuṭṭhi pātana ādi tasmin pāpa kamme asamaṅgi bhūtānam pi samanuñña tāya antokaraṇa ttham
translated: The pouring down of water, etc., was for the purpose of bringing in those who were not involved in that evil deed,🔽in order to give them permission.

original: kataṃ. Katabhaṇḍavuṭṭhīti ābharaṇavassaṃ. Mahājano samanuñño jātoti yojanā. Mātuposakarāmoti
analyzed: katam kata bhaṇḍa vuṭṭhī iti ābharaṇa vassam mahājanaḥ samanuññaḥ jātaḥ iti yojanā mātuposaka rāmo ti
translated: The meaning is: the occasion of the distribution of the spoils of war. The people gave their consent in great numbers: the construction is by ellipsis. The park of the Mother’s Keeper:

original: mātari sammāpaṭipanno rāmo nāma eko puriso. Asamaṅgibhūtānanti asamanuññānaṃ.
analyzed: mātari sammāpaṭipannaḥ rāmaḥ nāma ekaḥ purisaḥ a samaṅgi bhūtānam ti a samanuññānaṃ
translated: a man named Rāma, who was a mother’s keeper, that is, who was devoted to his mother. To those who had not given their consent: to those who had not agreed.

original: Avakiriyāti asussūsataṃ paṭicca. Phuliṅgānīti aggikaṇāni. Patanti kāyeti kāye ito cito nipatanti. Ete kira nirayaṃ vivaritvā mahājanassa dassenti.
analyzed: avakiriyā ati paṭicca phuliṅgāni iti aggi kaṇāni patanti kāya iti kāye itas citas nipatanti ete kira nirayam mahājanassa dassenti
translated: Because of their refusal to listen: because of their refusal to listen to the advice. Sparks: pieces of burning charcoal. They fell on their bodies: they fell here and there on their bodies. It seems that they opened up the hell and showed it to the people.

original: Yathāphāsukaṭṭhānanti mayaṃ kañcipi desaṃ uddissa na gacchāma, yattha pana vasantassa
analyzed: yathāphāsuka ṭṭhānan ti mayam kañcipi desam uddissa na gacchāma yattha pana vasantassa
translated: A place that is convenient: the intention is this: “We do not go to any particular place, but wherever we live

original: pabbajitassa phāsu hoti, taṃ yathāphāsukaṭṭhānaṃ gacchāmāti adhippāyo. Saṅghāti saṃhatā.
analyzed: pabbajitassa phāsu hoti tam yathā phāsuka ṭṭhānam gacchāma iti adhippāyaḥ saṅghā ati saṃhatā
translated: we go to a place that is convenient for a monk.” A multitude: a collection.

original: Gaṇāti taṃtaṃseṇibhāvena gaṇitabbatāya gaṇā. Gaṇībhūtāti ekajjhāsayā hutvā rāsibhūtā.
analyzed: taṃ taṃ seṇi bhāvena gaṇitabba tāya gaṇā gaṇībhūtā ati ekajjhāsayā hutvā rāsi bhūtā
translated: A crowd: reckoned as a crowd by reason of its being a collection of troops. A multitude of crowds: a collection of crowds, that is, a collection of people who have become one in intention.

original: Adinnādānantiādīsupi niraye paccitvā manussalokaṃ āgatassa vipākāvasesenāti ānetvā yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: adinna adāna nti ādīsu pi niraye paccitvā manussa lokam āgatassa vipāka avasesena ati ānetvā yojetabbam
translated: As regards the taking of what is not given, etc., it should be construed in this way: “The remainder of the result of kamma that had to be experienced in hell after committing such-and-such an offence.”

original: Paggaṇhissāmīti sambhāvanaṃ uppādessāmi. Nesaṃ kattabbanti cintesīti yojanā. Kiṃ
analyzed: paggaṇhissāmi iti sambhāvanam uppādessāmi na īsam kattabbanti cintesi iti yojanā kim
translated: I will take up the practice of it, I will arouse respect for it. I will think of what should be done by them.🔽

original: cintesi? Āghātaṃ uppādetvā anatthakaraṇūpāyaṃ. Tenāha “so dhammakathāpariyosāne”tiādi.
analyzed: cintesi āghātam uppādetvā anattha karaṇa upāyam tena āha so dhammakathā pariyosāna itiādi
translated: I shall take it up: I shall arouse respect for it. I thought of doing this and that to them: the construction is that he thought of what he would do to them. What did he think of? He thought of arousing resentment and of a means of doing harm. Hence it is said below: “At the end of the teaching of the True Idea” , and so on.

original: Nāgabalapicchillādīnanti nāgabalasāsapaaṅkolatelakaṇikāraniyyāsādīnaṃ cikkhallānaṃ.
analyzed: nāgabala picchilla ādīnam ti nāgabala sāsapa aṅkola tela kaṇikāra niyyāsa ādīnam cikkhallānam
translated: Nāgabalapicchillādīnanti nāgabalasaṃsāpaṅkolatelakaṇikāraniyyāsādīnaṃ cikkhallānaṃ.

original: Viheṭhayiṃsu nirayādikathāhi ghaṭṭentā. Chadvārārammaṇeti cakkhādīnaṃ channaṃ dvārānaṃ
analyzed: viheṭhayiṃsu niraya ādi kathāhi cha dvāra ārammaṇā iti cakkha ādīnam channam
translated: Viheṭhayiṃsu nirayādikathāhi ghaṭṭentā. Chadvārārammaṇeti cakkhādīnaṃ channaṃ dvārānaṃ

original: ārammaṇabhūte rūpādivisaye.
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhūte rūpa ādi visaye
translated: ārammaṇabhūte rūpādivisaye.

original: Nava vuṭṭhiyoti udakavuṭṭhi sumanapupphavuṭṭhi māsakavuṭṭhi kahāpaṇavuṭṭhi ābharaṇavuṭṭhi
analyzed: nava vuṭṭhiyaḥ ti udaka vuṭṭhi sumana puppha vuṭṭhi māsaka vuṭṭhi kahāpaṇa vuṭṭhi ābharaṇa vuṭṭhi
translated: Nava vuṭṭhiyoti udakavuṭṭhi sumanapupphavuṭṭhi māsakavuṭṭhi kahāpaṇavuṭṭhi ābharaṇavuṭṭhi

original: āvudhavuṭṭhi aṅgāravuṭṭhi pāsāṇavuṭṭhi vālikāvuṭṭhīti imā nava vuṭṭhiyo. Avañcayīti
analyzed: āvudha vuṭṭhi aṅgāra vuṭṭhi pāsāṇa vuṭṭhi vālikā vuṭṭhi iti imāḥ nava vuṭṭhiyaḥ avañcayīti
translated: āvudhavuṭṭhi aṅgāravuṭṭhi pāsāṇavuṭṭhi vālikāvuṭṭhīti imā nava vuṭṭhiyo. Avañcayīti

original: sakkāraṃ karonto viya hutvā asakkāraṃ karonto anatthacaraṇena vañcayi. Adūsaketi anaparādhe.
analyzed: sakkāram karontaḥ viya hutvā asakkāram karontaḥ anattha caraṇena vañcayi adūsaka iti anaparādhe
translated: sakkāraṃ karonto viya hutvā asakkāraṃ karonto anatthacaraṇena vañcayi. Adūsaketi anaparādhe.

original: “Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā brāhmaṇakaññā”ti jātakaṭṭhakathādīsu āgataṃ, idha pana “seṭṭhidhītā”ti.
analyzed: diṭṭhamaṅgalikā brāhmaṇa kaññā ati jātaka ṭṭhakathā ādīsu āgatam idha pana seṭṭhi dhītā ati
translated: “Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā brāhmaṇakaññā” in the Jātaka Commentary, etc., but here “the merchant’s daughter.”

original: Vāreyyatthāyāti āvāhatthāya, assāti pesitapuggalassa. Tādisena nīcakulasaṃvattaniyena
analyzed: vāreyya tthāya ati āvāha tthāya assa āti pesita puggalassa tādisena nīca kula saṃvattaniyena
translated: Vāreyyatthāya = āvāhatthāya, assā = to the man sent. Tādisena = by such low-born

original: kammunā laddhokāsena caṇḍālayoniyaṃ nibbatto.
analyzed: kammunā laddha ukāsena caṇḍāla yoniyam nibbattaḥ
translated: kind of work. Laddhokāsena = having obtained a place. Caṇḍālayoniyaṃ = in the womb of a female outcaste.

original: Cammageheti cammena chādite gehe. Mātaṅgotvevassa nāmaṃ ahosi jātisamudāgataṃ. Tanti
analyzed: camma geha iti cammena chādite gehe nāmam ahosi jāti samudāgatam tanti
translated: Cammageheti = in a house covered with skin. Mātaṅgotvevassa nāmaṃ ahosi jātisamudāgataṃ. Tanti = a bell.

original: ghaṇṭaṃ. Vādento tālanena saddaṃ karonto. Mahāpathaṃ paṭipajji diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya gehadvārasamīpena.
analyzed: ghaṇṭam vādentaḥ tālanena saddam karontaḥ mahāpatham paṭipajji diṭṭhamaṅgalikāya geha dvāra samīpena
translated: Vādento = making a sound by striking it. Mahāpathaṃ paṭipajji = he went along the main road near the door of Diṭṭhamaṅgalikā’s house.

original: Tassā veyyāvaccakarā ceva upaṭṭhākamanussā paṭibaddhā ca surāsoṇḍādayo jāṇukapparādīhi sukoṭṭitaṃ koṭṭitabhāvena mucchaṃ āpannattā matoti saññāya chaḍḍesuṃ.
analyzed: tassāḥ veyyāvacca karā ca iva upaṭṭhāka manussā paṭibaddhā ca surāsoṇḍa ādayaḥ jāṇu kappara ādīhi su koṭṭitam koṭṭita bhāvena muccham āpannattā matoti saññāya chaḍḍesuṃ
translated: Her servants and attendants and her friends, the drunkards, etc., having beaten him well with their knees and elbows, etc., thought that he was dead and threw him away.

original: Atha bodhisatto āyuavasesassa atthitāya mandamande vāte vāyante cirena saññaṃ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: atha bodhisattaḥ āyu avasesassa atthitāya mandamande vāte vāyante cirena saññam paṭilabhati
translated: Then the Bodhisatta, because there was a remainder of his life, recovered consciousness after a long time when a gentle breeze was blowing.

original: Tenāha “mahāpuriso”tiādi. Gehaṅgaṇeti gehassa mahādvārato bahi vivaṭaṅgaṇe. Patitoti
analyzed: tena āha mahā purisaḥ tiādi gehaṅgaṇa iti gehassa mahā dvārataḥ bahi patito ti
translated: Hence he said “a great man” and so on. In the courtyard of the house: in the open courtyard outside the main gate of the house. He fell down:

original: pātaṃ katvā icchitatthanipphattiṃ antaraṃ katvā anuppavesena nipanno. Diṭṭhamaṅgalikāyāti
analyzed: pātam katvā icchitattha nipphattim antaram katvā an uppavesena nipannaḥ diṭṭha maṅgalikāya ati
translated: he fell down, making the fulfilment of his wish the goal, and lay down, having entered upon the attainment. Because of the auspicious sight:

original: diṭṭhamaṅgalikākāraṇena.
analyzed: diṭṭha maṅgalikā kāraṇena
translated: because of the auspicious sight.

original: Yasanti vibhavaṃ kittisaddañca. Candanti candamaṇḍalaṃ, candavimānanti attho. Ucchiṭṭhageheti parehi paribhuttagehe. Maṇḍapeti nagaramajjhe mahāmaṇḍape.
analyzed: vibhavam kittisaddam ca candanti canda maṇḍalam canda vimānanti ucchiṭṭha gehe iti parehi paribhutta gehe maṇḍape iti nagara majjhe mahā maṇḍape
translated: Wealth and fame: wealth and the sound of fame. The moon: the moon’s orb; the meaning is, the moon’s mansion. In a house that others had used: in a house used by others. He decorated: he decorated in the middle of the town in a great pavilion.

original: Khīramaṇimūlanti khīramūlaṃ, pādesu baddhamaṇimūlañca. Yāvatā vācuggatā pariyattīti
analyzed: khīra maṇi mūlanti khīra mūlam pādesu baddha maṇi mūlam ca yāvatā
translated: The price of a milk-sap tree: the price of a milk-sap tree, and the price of a gem tied to his feet. As far as speech can go:

original: yattako manussavacīdvārato uggato nikkhanto pavatto, yaṃkiñci vacīmayanti attho.
analyzed: yattakaḥ manussa vacī dvārataḥ uggataḥ nikkhantaḥ pavattaḥ yaṃ kiñci vacīmayanti attho
translated: as far as speech can go, as far as speech can reach, as far as speech can extend; the meaning is, whatever is made of speech.

original: Ākāsaṅgaṇeti vivaṭaṅgaṇe.
analyzed: ākāsaṅgaṇā iti vivaṭaṅgaṇe
translated: In the open courtyard: in the open courtyard.

original: Dummavāsīti dhūmo dhūsaro, anañjitāmaṇḍitoti adhippāyo. Otallakoti nihīnajjhāsayo,
analyzed: dumma vāsī iti dhūmaḥ dhūsaraḥ an añjita āmaṇḍitaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ otallako ti
translated: A smoky dwelling: the meaning is, adorned with smoke, with mist. A low-roofed dwelling: of low aspiration,

original: appānubhāvoti attho. Paṭimuñca kaṇṭheti yāva galavāṭakā pārupitvā. Ko re tuvanti are ko nāma tvaṃ.
analyzed: appa anubhāvaḥ ti attho paṭimuñca kaṇṭha iti yāva galavāṭakā kaḥ re tuvanti are kaḥ nāma tvam
translated: the meaning is, he has no power. ‘Take it off your neck’ means: having covered yourself down to the throat. ‘Who are you?’ means: what is your name?

original: Pakatanti paṭiyattaṃ nānappakārato abhisaṅkhataṃ. Uttiṭṭhapiṇḍanti antaragharaṃ upagamma
analyzed: pakatanti paṭiyattam nānappakārataḥ abhisaṅkhatam uttiṭṭha piṇḍanti antara gharam upagamma
translated: ‘Cooked’ means: prepared, made up in various ways. ‘The alms-food that you have stood and received’ means: having gone into the house and stood there,

original: ṭhatvā laddhabbapiṇḍaṃ, bhikkhāhāranti attho. Labhatanti lacchatu. Sapākoti mahāsatto
analyzed: ṭhatvā laddhabba piṇḍam bhikkhāhāram ti attho labhatanti lacchatu sa pākaḥ iti mahāsatto
translated: the alms-food that you have received, the meaning is, the alms-round. ‘May you get’ means: may you receive. ‘Cooked’ means: a great being

original: jātivasena yathābhūtaṃ attānaṃ āvikaroti.
analyzed: jāti vasena yathābhūtam attānam āvikaroti
translated: reveals himself as he really is by his birth.

original: Atthatthitaṃ saddahatoti samparāyikassa atthassa atthibhāvaṃ saddahantassa. Apehīti apagaccha. Ettoti imasmā ṭhānā. Jammāti lāmaka.
analyzed: attha tthitam saddahato ti samparāyikassa atthassa atthi bhāvam saddahantassa apehi iti apagaccha ettas ti imasmā ṭhānā
translated: ‘Having faith in the truth of what is true’ means: having faith in the existence of the truth for the next world. ‘Go away’ means: go from here. ‘From here’ means: from this place. ‘Young’ means: tender.

original: Anūpakhetteti ajaṅgale udakasampanne khette phalavisesaṃ paccāsīsantā. Etāya saddhāya🔽dadāhi dānanti ninnaṃ thalañca pūrento megho viya guṇavante nigguṇe ca dānaṃ dehi,
analyzed: anūpa khetta iti ajaṅgale udaka sampanne khette phala visesam etāya saddhāya  dadāhi dānanti ninnam thalam ca meghaḥ guṇavante nigguṇe ca dānam dehi
translated: ‘In a field that is not tilled’ means: in a field that is not ploughed, that is well-watered, while they are waiting for a special fruit. ‘With this faith’🔽‘give your gift’ means: just as a cloud fills up the low and the high, so you should give gifts to those who have good qualities and to those who do not.

original: evaṃ dento ca appeva ārādhaye dakkhiṇeyyeti. Dakkhiṇeyyeti sīlādiguṇasamannāgate.
analyzed: evam dento ca appa iva ārādhaye dakkhiṇeyya iti dakkhiṇeyya iti sīla ādi guṇa samannāgate
translated: ‘Giving in this way, perhaps you will succeed in pleasing those who are worthy of offerings.’ ‘Those who are worthy of offerings’ means: those who have the qualities of virtue and so on.

original: Tānīti te brāhmaṇā. Veṇupadarenāti veḷuvilīvena.
analyzed: tāni iti te brāhmaṇāḥ veṇu padarena ati veḷu vilīvena
translated: “Those” : those brahmans. “Veṇupada” : Veḷudvāre.

original: Giriṃ nakhena khaṇasīti pabbataṃ attano nakhena khaṇanto viya ahosi. Ayoti kālalohaṃ. Padahasīti abhibhavasi, attano sarīrena abhibhavanto viya ahosi.
analyzed: girim nakhena khaṇasi iti pabbatam attanaḥ nakhena khaṇantaḥ viya ahosi kālaloham padahasi iti abhibhavasi attanaḥ sarīrena abhibhavantaḥ viya ahosi
translated: “You would split a mountain with your nail” : you would split a mountain with your own nail. “A” : a iron. “You would crush” : you would crush with your own body.

original: Āvedhitanti calitaṃ viparivattetvā ṭhitaṃ. Piṭṭhitoti piṭṭhipassena. Bāhuṃ pasāreti
analyzed: āvedhitam ti calitam viparivattetvā ṭhitam piṭṭhitaḥ ti piṭṭhi passena bāhum pasāreti
translated: “Shaken” : moved, stood turning over. “Behind” : behind. “Stretches out his arms”

original: akammaneyyanti akammakkhamaṃ bāhudvayaṃ thaddhaṃ sukkhadaṇḍakaṃ viya kevalaṃ pasāreti,
analyzed: akammaneyyam ti akamma khamam bāhu dvayam thaddham sukkha daṇḍakam viya kevalam pasāreti
translated: “Not fit for work” : not fit for work, the two arms, stiff, dry as a stick, only stretches out,

original: na samiñjeti, setāni akkhīni parivattanena kaṇhamaṇḍalassa adissanato.
analyzed: na samiñjeti setāni akkhīni parivattanena kaṇha maṇḍalassa a dissanato
translated: does not bend, the white eyes, by turning, because of not seeing the black circle.

original: Jīvitanti jīvanaṃ.
analyzed: jīvitanti jīvanam
translated: “Life” : living.

original: Vehāyasanti ākāse. Pathaddhunoti pathabhūtaddhuno viya.
analyzed: ākāse pathaddhunoti viya
translated: “Through the air” : in the sky. “As if running on a path” : as if running on a path.

original: Saññampi na karotīti “ime kulappasutā”ti saññāmattampi na karoti. Dantakaṭṭhakucchiṭṭhakanti
analyzed: saññam pi na karoti iti ime kula ppasutā ati saññā mattam pi na karoti dantakaṭṭha kucchiṭṭhakam ti
translated: “Does not even think” : does not even think “These are the sons of good families.” “Tooth-stick and the remains of a meal”

original: khāditadantakaṭṭhattā vuttaṃ. Etasseva upari patissati appaduṭṭhapadosabhāvato, mahāsattassa🔽tadā ukkaṃsagatakhettabhāvato. Iddhivisayo nāma acinteyyo, tasmā kathaṃ sūriyassa
analyzed: khādita danta kaṭṭha ttā vuttam etassa iva upari patissati appaduṭṭha padosa bhāvataḥ mahāsattassa  tadā ukkaṃsa gata khetta bhāvataḥ iddhivisayaḥ nāma acinteyyaḥ tasmā katham sūriyassa
translated: because he had chewed the tooth-stick. It will fall on him, because he is not one who has done harm to others,🔽because he is a Great Being who has the appearance of one who is to be anointed on the head. The range of psychic power is inconceivable, therefore it should not be thought:

original: uggantuṃ nādāsīti na cintetabbaṃ. Aruṇuggaṃ na paññāyatīti tasmiṃ padese aruṇapabhā
analyzed: uggantum na adāsi iti na cintetabbam aruṇuggam na paññāyati iti tasmin padese aruṇa pabhā
translated: “How is it that the sun did not rise?” The dawn did not appear means that in that place the light of dawn

original: na paññāyati, andhakāro eva hoti.
analyzed: na paññāyati andhakāraḥ eva hoti
translated: did not appear, it was as if it were dark.

original: Yakkhāvaṭṭo nu kho ayaṃ kālavipariyāyo. Mahāpaññanti mahantānaṃ paññānaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: yakkhāvaṭṭaḥ nu kho ayam kāla vipariyāyaḥ mahāpaññanti mahantānam paññānam adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: Is this a demon’s trick? Is this a change in the weather? He who has great wisdom means he who is the basis for great wisdom.

original: Janapadassa mukhaṃ passathāti imassa janapadavāsino janassa upaddavena maṅkubhūtaṃ mukhaṃ passatha.🔽Etassa kathā etasseva upari patissatīti yāhi tena pāramitāparibhāvanasamiddhāhi nānāsamāpattivihāraparipūritāhi
analyzed: janapadassa mukham passatha ati imassa janapada vāsinaḥ janassa upaddavena maṅku bhūtam mukham passatha  etassa kathā etassa iva upari patissati iti yāhi tena pāramitā paribhāvana samiddhāhi nānā samāpatti vihāra paripūritāhi
translated: Do you see the face of the country? means do you see the face of this country-dweller who is overcome by misfortune.🔽This story will fall on him means that you should go to the Great Being who has the appearance of one who is to be anointed on the head, who has fulfilled the perfections, who has fulfilled the various attainments and abidings,

original: sīladiṭṭhisampadāhi susaṅkhatasantāne mahākaruṇādhivāse mahāsatte ariyūpavādakammaabhisapasaṅkhātā
analyzed: su saṅkhata santāne mahā karuṇā adhivāse mahāsatte
translated: who has a well-ordered and well-composed mind through the perfection of virtue and view, who has great compassion, and who is called “one who is spoken of as noble.”

original: pharusavācā pavattitā, sā abhisapi tassa khettavisesabhāvato tassa ca ajjhāsayapharusatāya🔽diṭṭhadhammavedaniyakammaṃ hutvā sace so mahāsattaṃ na khamāpeti, sattame divase🔽vipaccanasabhāvaṃ jātaṃ, khamāpite pana mahāsatte payogasampatti paṭibāhitattā avipākadhammataṃ
analyzed: pharusa vācā pavatti tā sā tassa khetta visesa bhāvataḥ tassa ca ajjhāsaya pharusa tāya  diṭṭhadhamma vedaniya kammam hutvā sace saḥ mahāsattam na khamāpeti sattame divase  vipaccanasa bhāvam jātam khamāpite pana mahāsatte payoga sampatti paṭibāhita ttā a vipāka dhamma tam
translated: The harsh speech was uttered, and it fell back on him, because of the excellence of the field and because of his own evil intentions.🔽It became kamma that would have to bear fruit in the very life in which it was done. If he had not forgiven the Great Being,

original: āpajjati ahosikammabhāvato. Ayañhi ariyūpavādapāpassa diṭṭhadhammavedaniyassa dhammatā,🔽tena vuttaṃ ‘etassa kathā etasseva upari patissatī’tiādi. Mahāsatto pana taṃ tassa
analyzed: āpajjati ahosi kamma bhāvataḥ ayam hi ariya upavāda pāpassa diṭṭhadhamma vedaniyassa dhamma tā  tena vuttam etassa kathā etassa iva upari patissati itiādi mahāsatto pana tam tassa
translated: it would have become kamma that would have to bear fruit in the next life. But when the Great Being forgave him, the kamma became kamma that would not have to bear fruit, because the perfection of the means had prevented it from doing so.🔽This is the nature of the evil of defaming noble ones, that it must bear fruit in the very life in which it is done.🔽Therefore it was said above, “The story will fall on his head.” The Great Being did not allow it to fall on his head; he set him free by a skillful means.

original: upari patituṃ na adāsi, upāyena mocesi. Tena vuttaṃ cariyāpiṭake –
analyzed: upari patitum na adāsi upāyena mocesi tena vuttam cariyāpiṭake
translated: Therefore it is said in the Cariyāpiṭaka:

original: “Yaṃ so tadā maṃ abhisapi, kupito duṭṭhamānaso;
analyzed: yam saḥ tadā mama kupitaḥ duṭṭha mānasaḥ
translated: “The curse he then pronounced on me, in anger and with evil intent,

original: Tasseva matthake nipati, yogena taṃ pamocayi”nti.
analyzed: tassa iva matthake yogena tam
translated: Fell back on his own head; by a skillful means I set him free.”

original: Yañhi tattha sattame divase bodhisattena sūriyuggamananivāraṇaṃ kataṃ, ayamettha
analyzed: yat hi tattha sattame divase bodhisattena sūri yuj gamana nivāraṇam katam ayam ettha
translated: Now, the prevention of the sun’s rising by the Great Being on that occasion,

original: yogoti adhippeto. Yogena hi ubbaḷhā sarājikā parisā nagaravāsino negamā ceva jānapadā
analyzed: yogaḥ iti adhippetaḥ yogena hi ubbaḷhā sa rājikā parisā nagara vāsinaḥ negamāḥ ca iva jānapadāḥ
translated: “Yoga” is intended to mean “by means of yoga.” For by means of yoga, the whole multitude of people, both town and country dwellers,🔽

original: ca bodhisattassa santikaṃ tāpasaṃ ānetvā khamāpesuṃ. So ca bodhisattassa guṇe jānitvā
analyzed: ca bodhisattassa santikam tāpasam ānetvā khamāpesuṃ saḥ ca bodhisattassa guṇe jānitvā
translated: “Yoga” is what is meant. For it was by means of yoga that the people of the city and the country, the town-dwellers and the villagers, all of them, with the king at their head, brought the ascetic to the Bodhisatta and made him ask forgiveness. And he, recognizing the Bodhisatta’s virtues,

original: tasmiṃ cittaṃ pasādesi. Yaṃ panassa matthake mattikāpiṇḍassa ṭhapanaṃ, tassa ca sattadhā🔽phālanaṃ kataṃ, taṃ manussānaṃ cittānurakkhaṇatthaṃ. Aññathā hi – “ime pabbajitā🔽samānā cittassa vase vattanti, na pana cittaṃ attano vase vattāpentī”ti mahāsattampi
analyzed: tasmin cittam pasādesi yam pana assa matthake mattikā piṇḍassa ṭhapanam tassa ca sattadhā  phālanam katam tam manussānam citta anurakkhaṇa ttham aññathā hi ime pabbajitā  samānā cittassa vase vattanti na pana cittam attanaḥ vase vattāpenti iti mahāsattam pi
translated: had faith in him. But the placing of the lump of clay on his head and the breaking of it into seven pieces

original: tena sadisaṃ katvā gaṇheyyuṃ, tadassa tesaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyāti. Tenāha “athassā”tiādi.
analyzed: tena sadisam katvā gaṇheyyum tat assa tesam dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya ti tena āha athassa atiādi
translated: was done in order to win the confidence of the people. For otherwise they would have thought: “These ascetics are not in control of their minds; they do not bring their minds under control.” And they would have taken the Great Being to be like them.
