original: Kāmāvacarā kintīti kāmāvacarā pana kusalacetanā taṃsabhāvābhāvato kinti kena pakārena
analyzed: kāmāvacarā kinti iti kāmāvacarā pana kusala cetanā kinti kena pakārena
translated: But what about the kinds of profitable volition in the sense-desire world? What is their part in the matter?

original: abyābajjhamanosaṅkhāro nāma jātoti codeti, itaro pana na sabbā kāmāvacarakusalacetanā
analyzed: abyābajjha manaḥ saṅkhāraḥ nāma jātaḥ iti codeti itaro pana na sabbā kāmāvacara kusala cetanā
translated: He asks, “What is the name of the unprofitable formation?” The other replies, “Not all kinds of profitable volition in the sense-desire world are the cause of the arising of absolute pleasure.”

original: tathā gahitā, atha kho ekaccā jhānacetanānukūlāti dassento “kasiṇasajjanakāle kasiṇāsevanakāle
analyzed: tathā gahitāḥ atha kho ekaccāḥ jhāna cetanā anukūlā ati dassento kasiṇa sajjana kāle kasiṇa āsevana kāle
translated: At the time of the preliminary work on the kasiṇa, at the time of the practice of the kasiṇa,

original: labbhantī”ti āha. Tattha kasiṇāsevanacetanā gahetabbā, sā upacārajjhānassa sādhikā.
analyzed: labbhanti iti āha tattha kasiṇa āsevana cetanā gahetabbā sā upacāra jhānassa sādhikā
translated: they are found. Herein, the thought of the practice of the kasiṇa should be taken; it is more than the thought of access jhāna.🔽So the thought of the sense sphere is in conformity with the thought of the first jhāna.

original: Tena kāmāvacaracetanā paṭhamajjhānacetanāya ghaṭitāti kasiṇasajjanacetanāpi kadāci🔽tādisā hotīti gahitā. Parikammādivasena hi pavattā bhāvanāmayā kāmāvacarakusalacetanā
analyzed: tena kāmāvacara cetanā paṭhama jhāna cetanāya ghaṭitā ati kasiṇa sat jana cetanā api kadācid  tādisā hoti iti gahitā parikamma ādi vasena hi pavattā bhāvanā mayā kāmāvacara kusala cetanā
translated: And sometimes the thought of the preliminary work on the kasiṇa is of that kind,🔽so it is taken. For the profitable thought of the sense sphere that occurs as development in the way beginning with the preliminary work on the kasiṇa is said to be near to the first jhāna because it is near to it.

original: paṭhamajjhānassa āsannatāya vuttā. Catutthajjhānacetanā tatiyajjhānacetanāya ghaṭitāti
analyzed: paṭhama jhānassa āsanna tāya vuttā catuttha jhāna cetanā tatiya jhāna cetanāya ghaṭitā ati
translated: The thought of the fourth jhāna is in conformity with the thought of the third jhāna.

original: idaṃ ekattakāyaekattasaññīsattāvāsavatāya taṃsarikkhakā upekkhāpi īdisesu ṭhānesu
analyzed: idam upekkhā api īdisesu ṭhānesu
translated: This is because the fourth jhāna is a station of beings of the kind consisting of those who have a single material body and a single perception. So equanimity of that kind is similar to that of the third jhāna in these respects.

original: sukhasarikkhatā, evaṃ santasabhāvatā ñāṇasahitatā ca. Keci pana catutthajjhānacetanānuguṇāti
analyzed: evam santa sabhāva tā ñāṇa sahita tā ca keci pana catuttha jhāna cetanā anuguṇā ati
translated: And so too the fourth jhāna’s pleasure is similar to the third jhāna’s pleasure in being peaceful, in being associated with knowledge, and in being uninterested.🔽But some say that the thought of the fourth jhāna is in conformity with the thought of the third jhāna.

original: nidassentā kasiṇasajjanakāle kasiṇajjhānakāle kasiṇāsevanakāle labbhatīti tatiyajjhānacetanāya
analyzed: nidassentā kasiṇa sajjana kāle kasiṇa jhāna kāle kasiṇa āsevana kāle labbhati iti tatiya jhāna cetanāya
translated: They are called “present” when they are present at the time of the arising of the jhāna, at the time of the development of the jhāna, at the time of the practice of the jhāna.

original: āsannaghaṭitatā vuttāti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ, vuttanayeneva tāsaṃ ghaṭitatā
analyzed: āsanna ghaṭita tā vuttā iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam vutta nayena iva tāsam ghaṭita tā
translated: They say that the nearness of the arising of the third jhāna is meant. But that is merely their opinion. The arising of these should be understood in the way already described.

original: veditabbā. Ubhayamissakavasenāti ubhayesaṃ kusalākusalasaṅkhārānaṃ sukhadukkhānañca
analyzed: veditabbā ubhaya missaka vasena ati ubhayesam kusala akusala saṅkhārānam sukha dukkhānam ca
translated: By the words “in the mixed way” is meant by the mixedness of both kinds of formations, profitable and unprofitable, and of pleasure and pain.

original: missakabhāvavasena. Vemānikapetānanti idaṃ bāhullato vuttaṃ, itaresampi vinipātikānaṃ
analyzed: missaka bhāva vasena vemānika petānam ti idam bāhullataḥ vuttam itaresam pi vinipātikānam
translated: “Petas of the Vebhāra” is said figuratively for the sake of brevity; for the rest of the ghosts too

original: kālena dukkhaṃ hotiyeva.
analyzed: kālena dukkham
translated: pain occurs by turns.

original: Tassa pahānāyāti tassa yathāvuttassa kammassa anuppattidhammatāpādanāya. Yā cetanāti🔽yā apacayagāminicetanā. Kammaṃ patvāti sukhakammanti vuccamāne maggacetanāya añño
analyzed: tassa pahānāya ati tassa yathā vuttassa kammassa anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanāya yā cetanā ati  yā apacaya gāmini cetanā kammam patvā ati sukha kammanti vuccamāne magga cetanāya aññaḥ
translated: “For the abandoning of that”: for the making of that kamma not liable to result in future existence. “That volition”:🔽that volition that leads to diminution. “Having reached the kamma”: when it is said that the kamma is pleasure, there is no other state more purified than the volition of the path, because of its extreme purity.

original: paṇḍarataro dhammo nāma natthi accantapārisuddhibhāvato. Akaṇhā asukkāti āgatāti
analyzed: paṇḍarataraḥ dhammaḥ nāma natthi accanta pārisuddhi bhāvataḥ a kaṇhā a sukkā ati āgatā ati
translated: “Neither dark nor bright” is said

original: ettha sukkabhāvapaṭikkhepakāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva. Tenāha “idaṃ pana kammacatukkaṃ patvā”tiādi.
analyzed: ettha sukka bhāva paṭikkhepa kāraṇam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva tena āha idam pana kamma catukkam patvā ātiādi
translated: The reason for the exclusion of the dry-insight worker is the same as that given above. Hence he says, “But when he has reached the fourfold kammaṭṭhāna,” etc.🔽“The faction that is not the way”: the going forth without the three robes and the dog-duty.🔽“The way of the true Dhamma”: the practice of the right way.🔽“The faction of the sectarians”: the practice of the sectarians.

original: 82. Aniyyānikapakkheti aceḷakapabbajjāya kukkuravate ca. Yogeti ñāyadhammapaṭipattiyanti🔽attho. Yonenāti yo titthiyaparivāso tena bhagavatā paññatto. Yaṃ titthiyaparivāsaṃ
analyzed: aniyyānika pakkhe iti aceḍaka pabbajjāya kukkuravate ca yoge iti ñāya dhamma paṭipattiyanti  atthaḥ yonena ati yo titthiya parivāso tena bhagavatā paññattaḥ yam titthiya parivāsam
translated: “The faction of the sectarians” is the practice of the sectarians.🔽“Having taken up”: having undertaken.🔽“Like a man who has broken a piece of gold jewelry” is like a man who has broken a golden ornament.🔽“Like a man who has broken a clay pot with his hand” is like a man who has broken a clay pot with his hand.

original: samādiyitvāti ayamettha yojanā. Ghaṃsitvā suvaṇṇaṃ viya nighaṃsoppale. Koṭṭetvā hatthena
analyzed: samādiyitvā iti ayam ettha yojanā ghaṃsitvā suvaṇṇam viya nighaṃsa uppale koṭṭetvā hatthena
translated: “Seated secluded”: secluded, alone.🔽“With his mind inclined to Nibbāna”: with his mind inclined to Nibbāna.

original: viya kulālabhājanaṃ.
analyzed: kulāla bhājanam
translated: “The supreme austerity” is the supreme state of austerity.🔽“The supreme holy life” is the supreme state of the holy life.🔽“The supreme security from bondage” is the supreme state of security from bondage.🔽“The supreme happiness” is the supreme state of happiness.🔽“The supreme attainment” is the supreme state of attainment.🔽“The supreme comfort” is the supreme state of comfort.

original: Vūpakaṭṭhoti vivitto ekībhūto. Pesitattoti nibbānaṃ pati pesitatto. Kāmaṃ tadanuttaraṃ
analyzed: vūpakaṭṭhaḥ ti vivittaḥ ekībhūto pesitatto ti nibbānam pati pesitatto kāmam tat anuttaram
translated: “The supreme purification” is the supreme state of purification.🔽“The supreme service of the Blessed One” is the supreme state of service to the Blessed One.🔽“The supreme service of the Dhamma” is the supreme state of service to the Dhamma.🔽“The supreme service of the Saṅgha” is the supreme state of service to the Saṅgha.🔽“The supreme service of the training” is the supreme state of service to the training.

original: brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ…pe… vihāsīti imināva arahattanikūṭena desanā niṭṭhāpitā hoti,
analyzed: brahmacariya pariyosānam pe vihāsi iti iminā āva arahatta nikūṭena desanā niṭṭhāpitā hoti
translated: “The supreme service of concentration” is the supreme state of service to concentration.🔽“The supreme service of wisdom” is the supreme state of service to wisdom.🔽“The supreme service of liberation” is the supreme state of service to liberation.

original: āyasmato pana seniyassa paṭipattikittanaparametaṃ ujukaṃ āpannaarahattabhāvadīpanaṃ,
analyzed: āyasmataḥ pana seniyassa paṭipatti kittana param etam ujukam āpanna arahatta bhāva dīpanam
translated: “The supreme service of the knowledge and vision of liberation” is the supreme state of service to the knowledge and vision of liberation.🔽“The supreme service of the Blessed One” is the supreme state of service to the Blessed One.🔽“The supreme service of the Dhamma” is the supreme state of service to the Dhamma.🔽“The

original: yadidaṃ “aññataro kho panā”tiādivacananti āha “arahattanikūṭenevā”ti. Arahattādhigamoyeva
analyzed: yat idam aññataraḥ kho pana iti ādi vacananti āha arahatta nikūṭena iva ati arahatta adhigamaḥ yā iva
translated: He is included among them only by the peak of arahantship.

original: tassa tesaṃ abbhantaratā. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: tassa tesam abbhantara tā sesam sabbam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The rest is all easily intelligible.

original: Kukkuravatikasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “sluggish” in the Kukkuravatika Sutta is ended.

original: 8. Abhayarājakumārasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “sluggish” in the Abhayarājakumāra Sutta🔽is ended.

original: 83. Jātiyā asamāno nihīnācariyo paradattūpajīvikāya mātuyā kucchiyaṃ jāto pādasikaputto.
analyzed: jātiyā asamānaḥ nihīna ācariyaḥ para dattu upajīvikāya mātuyā kucchiyam jātaḥ pādasika putto
translated: He was born in his mother’s womb as a son of a slave, being inferior in birth and inferior in his teacher, and he lived on what others gave him.

original: Nindāvasena vadati etenāti vādo aguṇoti āha – “vādaṃ āropehīti dosaṃ āropehī”ti.
analyzed: nindā vasena vadati etena ati vādaḥ aguṇaḥ iti āha vādam āropehi iti dosam āropehi iti
translated: He speaks of a fault by way of censure, thus “fault” is a defect. He said: “Bring a charge against him, bring a defect against him.”

original: Nibbattavasena nirayaṃ arahati, nirayasaṃvattaniyena vā kammena niraye niyutto nerayiko.
analyzed: nibbatta vasena nirayam arahati niraya saṃvattaniyena vā kammena niraye niyuttaḥ nerayiko
translated: He deserves hell because he was reborn there, or he is bound for hell because of kamma that leads to hell.

original: Āpāyikoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Avīcimhi uppajjitvā tattha āyukappasaññitaṃ antarakappaṃ
analyzed: āpāyiko ti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ avīcimhi uppajjitvā tattha āyu kappa saññitam antara kappam
translated: The same method of interpretation applies to “doomed to an unhappy destiny.” He is born in Avīci and he stays there for an eon, which is the measure of his life span.

original: tiṭṭhatīti kappaṭṭho. Nirayūpapattipariharaṇavasena tikicchituṃ sakkuṇeyyoti tekiccho,
analyzed: tiṭṭhati iti kappaṭṭhaḥ nirayu upapatti pariharaṇa vasena tikicchitum sakkuṇeyyaḥ ti tekiccho
translated: He is called “one who stays for an eon” . He is called “one who is hard to cure” because he is difficult to treat by way of avoiding rebirth in hell.

original: na tekiccho atekiccho. Dve ante mocetvāti pharusaṃ vā appiyaṃ vā kappeyyāti dve koṭṭhāse
analyzed: na tekicchaḥ a tekicchaḥ dve ante mocetvā ati pharusam vā appiyam vā kappeyya ati dve koṭṭhāse
translated: He is not one who is in need of a question, nor one who is not in need of a question. Having let go of the two extremes: having let go of the two extremes of harshness and unfriendliness.

original: muñcitvā te anāmasitvā pucchitaṃ atthaṃ tato bahi karonto uggilati nāma. Taṃ pana
analyzed: muñcitvā te an āmasitvā pucchitam attham tatas bahi karontaḥ uggilati nāma tam pana
translated: Having asked, he makes a statement outside of that, he is said to have “spat out” the question. But he is not able to do that.

original: evaṃ kātuṃ na sakkotīti āha – “uggilituṃ bahi nīharituṃ na sakkhitī”ti. Evamevāyaṃ
analyzed: evam kātum na sakkoti iti āha uggilitum bahi nīharitum na sakkhiti iti evam eva ayam
translated: Therefore it is said: “He is not able to spit out, to take out.” In the same way, this question should not be taken. This is the fault here.

original: pucchā na gahetabbā, ayamettha dosoti taṃ apucchaṃ karonto apanayanto ogilati nāma,🔽tathā pana asakkonto patiṭṭhāpento na ogilati nāma, bhagavā pana tamatthaṃ okāsampi
analyzed: pucchā na gahetabbā ayam ettha doso ti tam apuccham karontaḥ apanayantaḥ ogilati nāma  tathā pana a sakkontaḥ patiṭṭhāpento na ogilati nāma bhagavā pana tam attham okāsam pi
translated: Not asking that, he is said to have “spat out” the question by removing it.

original: akaronto ubhayathāpi asakkhīti veditabbo. Kathaṃ? Bhagavā hi “na khvettha rājakumāra
analyzed: a karontaḥ ubhayathā api asakkhi iti veditabbaḥ katham bhagavā hi na khu ettha rāja kumāra
translated: But being unable to do that, he is said not to have “spat out” the question by establishing it. But the Blessed One should be understood as being unable to do it in both ways by not making an opportunity for that matter. How?

original: ekaṃsenā”ti vadanto nigaṇṭhassa adhippāyaṃ viparivatteti, ubho ante mocetvā pañhaṃ
analyzed: ekaṃsena ati vadantaḥ nigaṇṭhassa adhippāyam viparivattā iti ubho ante mocetvā pañham
translated: For the Blessed One, saying “Here, prince, it is not by a one-sided” turns the ascetic’s intention upside down, and having let go of the two extremes, he answers the question.

original: vissajjesi, evaṃ tāva uggilituṃ asakkhi. “Na tatra rājakumāra ekaṃsenā”ti vadanto
analyzed: vissajjesi evam tāva uggilitum asakkhi na tatra rāja kumāraḥ ekaṃsena ati vadantaḥ
translated: In this way, he was not able to spit out the question. Saying “Here, prince, it is not by a one-sided”

original: eva ca “nāyaṃ pucchā evaṃ avibhāgena pucchitabbā, vibhajitvā pana pucchitabbā”ti🔽pucchāya dosaṃ dīpento taṃ hārento ogilitumpi sakkhatīti.
analyzed: eva ca na ayam pucchā evam avibhāgena pucchitabbā vibhajitvā pana pucchitabbā ati  pucchāya dosam dīpento tam hārento ogilitum pi sakkhati iti
translated: and he was able to point out the fault in the question and to refute it, even though he was unable to get up, because of the way his mind was working.

original: Uṭṭhātuṃ na sakkhissati cittassa aññathā pavattiyā. Abhayo dve magge kataparicayo🔽cheko nipuṇo vādasīlo ca hutvā vicarati. Tenāha – “so vādajjhāsayatāya tassa vacanaṃ
analyzed: uṭṭhātum na sakkhissati cittassa aññathā pavattiyā abhayaḥ dve magge kata paricayo  chekaḥ nipuṇaḥ vāda sīlaḥ ca hutvā vicarati tena āha saḥ tassa vacanam
translated: Abhaya was well acquainted with the two paths,

original: sampaṭicchanto ‘evaṃ, bhante’ti āhā”ti.
analyzed: sampaṭicchantaḥ evam bhanta iti āha ati
translated: and he was clever and skilled and had the virtue of being able to argue. Therefore it is said: “Because of his fondness for argument, he agreed with his statement, saying: ‘So it is, venerable sir.’“

original: 85. Evarūpanti yā paresaṃ appiyā amanāpā duruttavācā, evarūpā vācā, na pana pharusavācā.
analyzed: yā paresam appiyā amanāpā durutta vācā evarūpā vācā na pana pharusa vācā
translated: Such speech as is disagreeable and unpleasant to others, ill-spoken, but not necessarily harsh speech.

original: Pharusavācāya hi setughāto tathāgatānaṃ. Cetanāpharusatāya hi pharusavācā icchitā,
analyzed: pharusa vācāya hi setughātaḥ cetanā pharusa tāya hi pharusa vācā icchitā
translated: For the Buddhas are a dam against harsh speech, which is held to be the intention to be harsh,

original: na paresaṃ appiyatāmattena. Naṭṭhā nigaṇṭhā ogilikādisammatassa pañhassa ekavacanena viddhaṃsitattā.
analyzed: na paresam appiya tā mattena naṭṭhāḥ nigaṇṭhāḥ ogilikā ādi sammatassa pañhassa ekavacanena
translated: not merely the fact of being disagreeable to others. The Nigantha was destroyed because he was unable to answer the question put to him by the Elder, which was accepted by the people as a riddle.

original: 86. Dārakassa aṅke nisīdanassa kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “lesavādino”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: dārakassa aṅke nisīdanassa kāraṇam dassetum lesa vādino tiādi vuttam tattha
translated: “The slanderers” is said in order to show the reason why the boy was sitting on his lap. Herein,

original: lesavādinoti chalavādino, vādamagge vā aparipuṇṇatāya lesamatteneva vādasīlā. Osaṭasaṅgāmoti
analyzed: lesa vādinaḥ ti chala vādinaḥ vāda magge vā a paripuṇṇa tāya lesa mattena iva vāda sīlā osaṭa saṅgāmā iti
translated: ‘The liar’: the one who speaks deceitfully, or who is not fully truthful in his speech. ‘The defeated warrior’:

original: anekavāraṃ paravādamaddanavasena otiṇṇavādasaṅgāmo. Vijjhitvāti nakhena vijjhitvā.
analyzed: aneka vāram paravāda maddana vasena otiṇṇa vāda saṅgāmaḥ vijjhitvā ati nakhena vijjhitvā
translated: the one who has entered the battle of speech and has been defeated many times by his opponent. ‘Pierced’: pierced with his fingernail.

original: Imamevāti yvāyaṃ dārako attano vādabhaṅgapariharaṇatthaṃ iminā aṅke nisīdāpito, imameva
analyzed: imam eva ati yvā ayam dārakaḥ attanaḥ vāda bhaṅga pariharaṇa attham iminā aṅke imam eva
translated: ‘This very boy’: the boy who was seated on his lap in order to conceal his defeat in the debate.

original: assa dārakaṃ upamaṃ nissayaṃ katvā vādaṃ bhindissāmi. “Assa vādaṃ appaṭitatāya upamāya
analyzed: assa dārakam upamam nissayam katvā vādam bhindissāmi assa vādam appaṭita tāya upamāya
translated: ‘I will break his argument by means of a simile,

original: bhañjissāmī”ti cintetvā.
analyzed: bhañjissāmi iti cintetvā
translated: since he has not been able to refute my argument.’

original: Apaneyyaṃ assa ahanti assa dārakassa mukhato ahaṃ taṃ apaneyyaṃ. Abhūtatthova abhūtaṃ🔽uttarapadalopenāti āha “abhūtanti abhūtattha”nti. Atacchanti tasseva vevacananti
analyzed: apaneyyam assa ahanti assa dārakassa mukhataḥ aham tam apaneyyam abhūtatthā uva abhūtam  uttara pada lopena iti āha a bhūta a bhūtatthanti a tacchanti tassa iva
translated: ‘I will remove it from his mouth’: I will remove it from the mouth of the boy. ‘Non-existent’: non-existent in fact.🔽‘Non-existent’ is a synonym for ‘non-existent in fact.’🔽‘It does not exist’: it does not exist in that way.

original: āha “atacchanti na taccha”nti. Abhūtanti vā asantaṃ avijjamānaṃ. Atacchanti atathākāraṃ.
analyzed: āha a tacchanti na tacchanti vā asantam a vijjamānam a tacchanti a tathākāram
translated: ‘Non-existent’ means non-existent, non-existent in fact. ‘It does not exist’ means it does not exist in that way.

original: Anatthasaṃhitanti diṭṭhadhammikena, samparāyikena vā anatthena saṃhitaṃ, anatthe🔽vā saṃhitaṃ, na atthoti vā anattho, atthassa paṭipakkho sabhāvo, tena saṃhitanti
analyzed: anattha saṃhitanti diṭṭhadhammikena samparāyikena vā anatthena saṃhitam anatthe  vā saṃhitam na atthaḥ ti vā anatthaḥ atthassa paṭipakkhaḥ sabhāvaḥ tena saṃhitan ti
translated: Associated with what is unprofitable: associated with what is unprofitable either in the present existence or in a future existence, or associated with what is unprofitable in both. Or what is unprofitable is the opposite of what is profitable, the contrary of what is profitable, and it is associated with that.🔽

original: anatthasaṃhitaṃ, pisuṇavācaṃ samphappalāpañcāti attho. Evamettha catubbidhassapi🔽vacīduccaritassa gahitatā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: anattha saṃhitam pisuṇa vācam samphappalāpam ca ati attho evam ettha catubbidhassa api  vacī duccaritassa gahita tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: ‘Unbeneficial’: connected with what is unbeneficial either in the here-and-now or in the life to come, or connected with what is unbeneficial, or unbeneficial in the sense of being the opposite of beneficial. ‘He does not speak such talk’: he does not speak malicious speech or gossip. This is how it should be understood that all four kinds of verbal misconduct are included here.

original: Duppayuttoti duppaṭipanno. Na taṃ tathāgato bhāsati abhūtatādidosaduṭṭhattā. Tampi tathāgato na bhāsati bhūtatthepi anatthasaṃhitatādidosaduṭṭhattā.🔽Ṭhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ etissā atthīti ṭhāniyā ka-kārassa ya-kāraṃ katvā, na ṭhāniyāti aṭṭhāniyā,
analyzed: duppayuttaḥ ti duppaṭipannaḥ na tam tathāgataḥ bhāsati abhūta tā ādi dosa duṭṭha ttā tam pi tathāgataḥ na bhāsati bhūta atthe pi anattha saṃhita tā ādi dosa duṭṭha ttā  ṭhānam kāraṇam etissā atthi iti ṭhāniyā kakārassa yakāram katvā na ṭhāniyā ati a ṭhāniyā
translated: ‘Unconnected’: unpractised. ‘The Perfect One does not speak such talk’: because it is not true, and because it is wrong. ‘Nor such talk as this’: he does not speak such talk as this, even if it is true, because it is unbeneficial, and because it is wrong.

original: nikkāraṇā ayuttiyuttā, sā eva kathāti aṭṭhāniyakathā. Attapaccakkhakathaṃ kathemāti🔽attanā eva paccakkhaṃ katvā pavattiyamānaṃ chalakathaṃ kathema.
analyzed: nikkāraṇā ayutti yuttā sā eva kathā ati aṭṭhāniya kathā atta paccakkha katham kathema ati 🔽attanā eva paccakkham katvā pavattiyamānam chalakatham kathema
translated: ‘It has a basis’: it has a reason. The ‘ka’ in ‘kāraṇa’ is elided, and the ‘a’ is lengthened to make ‘ṭhāniyā’. ‘It has no basis’: it has no reason. It is unconnected, unfitting. ‘Such talk’: such talk as that. ‘He does not speak such talk’:🔽‘He does not speak such talk as this’: he does not speak such talk as this, which is talk that is a trick, that is carried on by one who makes it appear as if he were speaking of something else while really intending something else.

original: Gāmikamahallako “ime maṃ vañcetukāmā, ahameva dāni ime vañcessāmī”ti cintetvā “evaṃ bhavissatī”tiādimāha. “Na mayaṃ dāsā”tipi vattuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu pubbe tathākatikāya katattā.
analyzed: gāmika mahallakaḥ ime mam vañcetu kāmāḥ aham eva dāni ime vañcessāmi iti cintetvā evam bhavissati itiādim āha na mayam dāsa atipi vattum na asakkhiṃsu pubbe tathākatikāya kata ttā
translated: The village headman thought, “They want to cheat me. I’ll cheat them.” He said, “It will be like this,” etc. They could not say, “We are not slaves,” because they had previously agreed to be slaves.

original: Tatiyaṃ tatiyamevāti dvīsupi pakkhesu tatiyaṃ tatiyameva vācaṃ. Bhāsitabbakālaṃ anatikkamitvāti
analyzed: tatiyam tatiyam eva ati dvīsu pi pakkhesu tatiyam tatiyam eva vācam bhāsitabba kālam an atikkamitvā iti
translated: In both cases, the third statement was the third statement. He spoke without exceeding the proper time for speaking.

original: yassa yadā yathā bhāsitabbaṃ, tassa tadā tatheva ca bhāsanato bhāsitabbaṃ kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: yassa yadā yathā bhāsitabbam tassa tadā tathā iva ca bhāsanataḥ bhāsitabbam kāraṇam
translated: The reason for speaking is that one should speak when it is proper for a certain person to speak in a certain way at a certain time.

original: bhāsitabbakālañca anatikkamitvāva bhāsati.🔽87. Ṭhānuppattikañāṇenāti ṭhāne eva uppajjanakañāṇena. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāraṇe tassa
analyzed: bhāsitabba kālañca an atikkamitvā ava bhāsati  ṭhānuppattika ñāṇena ati ṭhāne eva uppajjana kañāṇena tasmim tasmim kāraṇe tassa
translated: He spoke without exceeding the proper time for speaking.🔽By knowledge of the proper occasion: by knowledge that arises only in the proper occasion. In each case,

original: taṃ taṃ avatthāya uppajjanakañāṇena, dhammānaṃ yathāsabhāvato avabujjhanasabhāvoti
analyzed: tam tam avatthāya uppajjana kañāṇena dhammānam yathā sabhāvataḥ avabujjhana sabhāvaḥ ti
translated: by knowledge that arises in that particular occasion for that particular reason, the nature of understanding the individual essences of dhammas as they really are is the essence of dhammas.

original: dhammasabhāvo. Dhamme sabhāvadhamme anavasese vā yāthāvato upadhāretīti dhammadhātu,
analyzed: dhamma sabhāvaḥ dhamme sabhāva dhamme anavasese vā yāthāvataḥ upadhāreti iti dhammadhātu
translated: The dhamma-element is the discernment of dhammas, of the individual essences of dhammas, or of the individual essences of dhammas without exception, as they really are.

original: sabbaññutā. Tenāha “sabbaññutaññāṇassetaṃ adhivacana”nti. Suppaṭividdhanti sabbaṃ
analyzed: sabbaññu tā tena āha sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa etam adhivacanan ti suppaṭividdham ti sabbam
translated: and omniscience. Hence it was said above, “This is a designation for the knowledge of omniscience.”

original: ñeyyadhammaṃ suṭṭhu paṭivijjhanavasena, suṭṭhu paṭividdhanti attho. Tenāha “hatthagataṃ🔽bhagavato”ti. Neyyapuggalavasena pariniṭṭhitāti kathāparivibhāgena ayameva desanā
analyzed: ñeyya dhammam suṭṭhu paṭivijjhana vasena suṭṭhu paṭividdhanti attho tena āha hattha gatam  bhagavato ti neyya puggala vasena pariniṭṭhitā ati kathā parivibhāgena ayam eva desanā
translated: Well penetrated: in other words, well penetrated by penetrating all knowable dhammas well. Hence it was said above, “It is as if held in the palm of the hand.”

original: cattāri ariyasaccāni dassento arahattaṃ paccakkhāsīti.
analyzed: cattāri ariya saccāni dassentaḥ arahattam paccakkhāsi iti
translated: Accomplished in the person to be trained: by the distribution of the teaching, the Exalted One demonstrated the four noble truths and realized the state of arahantship.

original: Abhayarājakumārasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: abhayarāja kumāra sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the brief exposition of the Abhaya Sutta is completed.

original: 9. Bahuvedaniyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bahu vedaniya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Bahuvedaniya Sutta

original: 88. Pañcakaṅgoti vaḍḍhakīkiccasādhane vāsiādipañcakaṃ aṅgaṃ saṃdhanaṃ etasminti pañcakaṅgo. Thambhādivatthūnaṃ thapanaṭṭhena thapati. Paṇḍitaudāyitthero, na kāḷudāyī thero.
analyzed: pañcakaṅgo ti vaḍḍhakī kicca sādhane vāsi ādi pañcakam aṅgam saṃdhanam etasmin ti pañcakaṅgo thambha ādi vatthūnam thapana ṭṭhena thapati na kāḷudāyī thero
translated: The five-limbed: the five-limbed one is the one having the five limbs, such as the axe, that are the means of accomplishing the carpenter’s work. The carpenter: the one who fixes, in the sense of fixing the timber, etc. The wise Udāyī: the elder Udāyī, not the black Udāyī.

original: 89. Pariyāyati attano phalaṃ vattetīti pariyāyo, kāraṇaṃ. Vedanāsannissito ca kāyikacetasikabhāvo
analyzed: pariyāyati attanaḥ phalam vatteti iti pariyāyaḥ kāraṇam vedanā sannissitaḥ ca kāyika cetasika bhāvo
translated: The cause: the cause is the condition, since it is distributed, i.e., it is distributed by being extended to its own fruit. The state of being physical or mental is dependent on feeling.

original: kāraṇaṃ. Tenāha – “kāyikacetasikavasena dve veditabbā”ti. Tattha pasādakāyasannissitā
analyzed: kāraṇam tena āha kāyika cetasika vasena dve veditabbā ati tattha pasāda kāya sannissitā
translated: and that is why it is said, “They should be understood as two, that is to say, as bodily and mental.” Herein, the bodily are dependent on the bodily sensitive matter,🔽the mental are dependent on the mind.

original: kāyikā, cetosannissitā cetasikā. Sukhādivasena tissoti ettha sukhanadukkhanupekkhanāni
analyzed: kāyikā cetaḥ sannissitā cetasikā sukha ādi vasena tissaḥ tissaḥ ti ettha sukhana dukkhan upekkhanāni
translated: As to the three kinds classed as pleasant feeling, etc., the cause of pleasant feeling, etc., is the three roots, greed, etc.,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of pleasant feeling, etc., and because the terms “pleasant” and so on are used according to the object.🔽As to the three kinds classed as joy, and so on, the cause of joy, and so on, is the three kinds of profitable kamma, and so on,

original: sukhādivedanāya kāraṇaṃ. Tāni hi pavattinimittāni katvā tattha sukhādisaddappavatti,🔽iminā nayena sesesupi yathārahaṃ kāraṇaṃ niddhāretvā vattabbaṃ. Upavicāravasenāti🔽ārammaṇaṃ upecca savisesapavattivasena. Yasmiñhi ārammaṇe somanassavedanā pavattati,
analyzed: sukha ādi vedanāya kāraṇam tāni hi pavatti nimittāni katvā tattha  iminā nayena sesesu pi yathāraham kāraṇam niddhāretvā vattabbam upavicāra vasena ati  ārammaṇam upecca savisesa pavatti vasena yasmin hi ārammaṇe somanassa vedanā pavattati
translated: because they are the reason for the occurrence of joy, and so on.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of existence, the cause of the three kinds of existence is the three roots, greed, and so on,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of existence.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of craving, the cause of the three kinds of craving is the three kinds of feeling,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of craving.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of contact, the cause of the three kinds of contact is the three kinds of craving,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of contact.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of craving, the cause of the three kinds of craving is the three kinds of feeling,

original: ārammaṇatāya taṃ upagantvā itaravedanāhi visiṭṭhatāya savisesaṃ tattha pavatti. Tenāha🔽“somanassaṭṭhāniyaṃ rūpaṃ upavicaratī”ti. Esa nayo sesavedanāsu gehassitānīti gehanissitāni.
analyzed: ārammaṇa tāya tam upagantvā itara vedanāhi visiṭṭha tāya sa visesam tattha pavatti tena āha  somanassa ṭṭhāniyam rūpam upavicarati iti esa nayaḥ sesa vedanāsu geha ssitāni iti geha nissitāni
translated: because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of craving.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of contact, the cause of the three kinds of contact is the three kinds of craving,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of contact.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of craving, the cause of the three kinds of craving is the three kinds of feeling,🔽because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of craving.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of contact, the cause of the three kinds of contact is the three kinds of craving,

original: 90. Pariyāyenāti “idamettha dukkhasminti vadāmī”ti vuttaṭṭhānaṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: pariyāyena ati idam ettha dukkhasmin ti vadāmi iti vutta ṭṭhānam sandhāya vadati
translated: because they are the reason for the occurrence of the three kinds of contact.🔽As to the three kinds classed as associated with the three kinds of craving, the

original: Taṃ dassentoti kāmañcettha sutte – “dvepānanda, vedanā vuttā”ti dve ādiṃ katvā vedanā🔽dassitā, ekāpi pana dassitā evāti dassento. Upatthambhetunti ekāpi vedanā vuttā mayā
analyzed: tam dassento ti kāmañca ittha sutte dvepānanda vedanā vuttā ati dve ādim katvā vedanā  dassitā ekā api pana dassitā evā ti dassentaḥ upatthambhetunti ekā api vedanā vuttā mayā
translated: “Showing that”: here in the sutta, “Two kinds of feeling, Ānanda, have been spoken of by me” , two kinds of feeling are shown beginning with the first,

original: pariyāyena, evaṃ sati dvepi vattabbāti evaṃ tassa vādaṃ upatthambhetuṃ. Kathaṃ pana🔽ekā vedanā vuttāti? Yaṃ kiñci vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā,
analyzed: pariyāyena evam sati dve api vattabbā ti evam tassa vādam upatthambhetum katham pana  ekā vedanā vuttā iti yam kiñci vedayitam sukham vā dukkham vā adukkham asukham vā
translated: but one kind is also shown. “To support”: “One kind of feeling has been spoken of by me, Ānanda, in a certain way. If that is so, two kinds should be spoken of.” In this way he supports his doctrine. But how is it that one kind of feeling is spoken of? “Whatever is felt is suffering in this world” . But what should be said here has been said in the commentary on the Itivuttaka in the way beginning:

original: idamettha dukkhasminti vadāmīti. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ itivuttakavaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽paramatthadīpaniyaṃ vuttanayena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: idam ettha dukkhasmin ti vadāmi iti yam pana ittha vattabbam tam itivuttaka vaṇṇanāyam
translated: “The Blessed One said: ‘Whatever is felt is suffering in this world’ . What is the meaning of this statement? It is this: whatever is felt is suffering in the ultimate sense, and whatever is felt is suffering in the conventional sense. What is suffering in the ultimate sense? Whatever is felt is suffering in the ultimate sense because of the suffering due to formations. What is suffering in the conventional sense? Whatever is felt is suffering in the conventional sense because of the suffering due to pain, the suffering due to change, and the suffering due to the formations in the three kinds of becoming. Thus the statement should be understood in this way.

original: Kathaṃ panettha rūpāvacaracatutthe arūpesu saññāvedayitanirodhe sukhaṃ uddhatanti
analyzed: katham pana ittha rūpāvacara catutthe arūpesu saññā vedayita nirodhe sukham
translated: “But how is pleasure stated in the fourth immaterial state and in the cessation of perception and feeling?”

original: āha “ettha cā”tiādi. Santaṭṭhenāti paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ vūpasantabhāvena. Paṇītaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: āha ettha ca atiādi santa ṭṭhena ati paṭipakkha dhammānam vūpasanta bhāvena paṇīta ṭṭhena ati
translated: “Here too,” etc. “In the sense of peace” means in the sense of the stilling of opposing states.

original: bhāvanāvisesavisiṭṭhena atappakabhāveneva seṭṭhabhāvena ca, paccayavisesena padhānabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā visesa visiṭṭhena atappaka bhāvena iva seṭṭha bhāvena ca paccaya visesena padhāna bhāvam
translated: It is also “excellent” in the sense of being brought to the fore through the special distinction of its conditions.🔽The happiness of feeling is called “happiness” in the sense of feeling.

original: nītantipi paṇītaṃ. Vedayitasukhaṃ nāma vedanābhūtaṃ sukhanti katvā. Avedayitasukhaṃ🔽nāma yāvatā niddukkhatā, tāvatā sukhanti vuccatīti.Atha vā nirodho suṭṭhu khādati
analyzed: paṇītam vedayitasukham nāma vedanā bhūtam sukhanti katvā a vedayita sukham  nāma yāvatā niddukkha tā tāvatā sukhanti vuccati iti atha vā nirodhaḥ suṭṭhu khādati
translated: The happiness of non-feeling is called “happiness” in the sense of the absence of pain.

original: khanati kāyikacetasikābādhanti vattabbataṃ arahati sattāhampi tattha dukkhassa nirujjhanato.
analyzed: khanati kāyika cetasika ābādhanti vattabba tam arahati satta aham pi tattha dukkhassa nirujjhanato
translated: Or, cessation is worthy to be called “happiness” in the sense of “it eats ,” “it chews ,” bodily and mental affliction, because for seven days there is the cessation of pain there.

original: Tenāha “niddukkhabhāvasaṅkhātena sukhaṭṭhenā”ti.
analyzed: tena āha niddukkha bhāva saṅkhātena sukhaṭṭhena ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “in the sense of the state of absence of pain.”

original: 91. Yasmiṃ yasmiṃ bhave, cittuppāde, avatthāya vā niddukkhabhāvo, dukkhassa paṭipakkhatā anupalabbhanena dukkhavivittaṃ, taṃ sukhasmiṃyeva paññapeti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: yasmin yasmin bhave cittuppāde avatthāya vā niddukkha bhāvaḥ dukkhassa paṭipakkha tā anupalabbhanena dukkha vivittam tam sukhasmiṃ yeva paññapeti sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: In whatever kind of becoming, in whatever kind of arising of consciousness, in whatever state, the absence of pain, the opposite of pain, the absence of pain through non-apprehension of pain, he declares that to be “happiness.” The rest is easy to understand.

original: Bahuvedanīyasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: bahuvedanīya sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of “languid” in the Bahuvedanīyasutta is ended.

original: 10. Apaṇṇakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: apaṇṇaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Apaṇṇakasutta

original: 93. Nānāvidhāti nānāvidhadiṭṭhikā samaṇabrāhmaṇāti pabbajjāmattena samaṇā, jātimattena🔽brāhmaṇā ca. Dassananti diṭṭhi. Gahitanti abhinivissa gahitaṃ. Iti te attano dassanaṃ🔽gahetukāmā pucchanti. Vinā dassanena loko na niyyātīti vimokkhabhāvanāya ekena dassanena
analyzed: nānāvidhā ati nānāvidha diṭṭhikā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ati pabbajjā mattena samaṇāḥ jāti mattena  brāhmaṇā ca dassananti diṭṭhi gahitanti abhinivissa gahitan iti te attanaḥ dassanaṃ  gahetu kāmā pucchanti vinā dassanena lokaḥ na niyyāti iti vimokkha bhāvanāya ekena dassanena
translated: 93. Various views: various views such as the following: ascetics and brahmins: they are ascetics in the sense of having gone into the jungle , and they are brahmins in the sense of being born into a good family . View: a view of becoming . Grasped at: grasped by misapprehending . Thus they ask the question in order to grasp their own view. The world does not escape view: by the development of the deliverance of mind that is a single view.

original: vinā loko saṃsāradukkhato na nigacchati. Ekadiṭṭhiyampi patiṭṭhātuṃ nāsakkhiṃsu saddhākārābhāvato.🔽Tathā hi te imāya desanāya saraṇesu patiṭṭhahiṃsu. Yasmā aviparīte saddheyyavatthusmiṃ
analyzed: vinā lokaḥ saṃsāra dukkhataḥ na nigacchati eka diṭṭhiyam pi patiṭṭhātum na asakkhiṃsu saddhākāra abhāvato  tathā hi te imāya desanāya saraṇesu patiṭṭhahiṃsu yasmai aviparīte saddheyya vatthusmin
translated: “Of various views” : of various kinds of views. “Ascetics and brahmans” : they are ascetics in the sense of having gone forth , and brahmans in the sense of being born in a priestly family. “Opinion” : view. “Seized” : adhered to. Thus they ask in order to seize their own opinion. “Without opinion the world does not go forth” : without one opinion, namely, the development of deliverance, the world does not go forth from the suffering of the round of rebirths. They were unable to stand upon even one view because they lacked the form of faith.🔽For it was through this teaching that they were established in the refuges. Since faith that arises in a non-erroneous object of confidence is called “having the form” ,

original: uppannasaddhā “ākāravatī”ti adhippetā, tasmā yo loke aviparītadhammadesanā, ayamevesāti
analyzed: uppanna saddhā ākāravatī iti adhippetā tasmai yaḥ loke aviparīta dhamma desanā ayam eva isā ti
translated: therefore the non-erroneous teaching of the world is just this.

original: pavattā maggasādhanagatāya saddhāya kāraṇabhāvato tannissayā saddhā, sā ākāravatīti
analyzed: pavattā magga sādhana gatāya saddhāya kāraṇa bhāvato tad nissayā saddhā sā ākāravatī iti
translated: Since it is the cause of the faith that is the means of accomplishing the path, faith is dependent on that. That faith is “having the form” .

original: vuttā. Avatthusmiñhi saddhā ayuttakāraṇatāya na ākāravatī. Ākāravatīti ettha vatī-saddo
analyzed: vuttā avatthusmin hi saddhā ayutta kāraṇatāya na ākāravatī ākāravatī iti ettha vatī saddaḥ
translated: The word “endowed” in the phrase “endowed with the mode of deportment”

original: na kevalaṃ atthitāmattadīpako, atha kho atisayatthadīpako pāsaṃsatthadīpako vā daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: na kevalam atthi tā matta dīpakaḥ atha kho ati saya ttha dīpakaḥ pāsaṃsa ttha dīpakaḥ vā daṭṭhabbo
translated: should be regarded not only as signifying mere existence but as signifying a special reason or a praiseworthy reason.

original: Tena ākāravatīti saddheyyavatthuvasena atisayakāraṇavatīti vā pāsaṃsakāraṇavatīti🔽vā ayamettha attho. Apaṇṇakoti ettha yathā kañci atthaṃ sādhetuṃ āraddhassa payogo
analyzed: tena ākāravatī iti saddheyya vatthu vasena atisaya kāraṇavatī iti vā pāsaṃsa kāraṇavatī iti  vā ayam ettha atthaḥ apaṇṇakaḥ ti ettha yathā kañci attham sādhetum āraddhassa payogaḥ
translated: So the meaning here is “endowed with a special reason” or “endowed with a praiseworthy reason” in the sense of a ground for confidence.

original: viraddho, tattha akārako viya hoti punapi ārabhitabbatāya. Aviraddho pana atthassa
analyzed: viraddhaḥ tattha a kārakaḥ viya hoti puna pi ārabhitabba tāya aviraddhaḥ pana atthassa
translated: “A sure guide”: just as a man’s effort is unsuccessful and he is as good as not having made it when he has set out to accomplish some purpose but fails to do so and has to make the effort again,

original: sādhanato apaṇṇako, evaṃ ayampi dhammo abhibhavitvā pavattanato ekaṃsato “apaṇṇako”ti
analyzed: sādhanataḥ apaṇṇakaḥ evam ayam pi dhammaḥ abhibhavitvā pavattanato ekaṃsataḥ apaṇṇakaḥ ti
translated: but when he succeeds in accomplishing it his effort is successful and is therefore a sure guide, so this Dhamma is called “a sure guide” because it leads to the goal by overcoming and is therefore a one-way path.

original: vutto. Tenāha “aviraddho advejjhagāmī ekaṃsagāhiko”ti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ tena āha aviraddhaḥ a dvejjha gāmī ekaṃsagāhikaḥ ti
translated: That is why it is said, “It is a sure guide, not a false one, a guide that leads to one’s goal and not to another’s” .

original: 94. Tabbipaccanīkabhūtāti tassā micchādiṭṭhiyā paccanīkabhūtā.
analyzed: tad vipaccanīka bhūtā ti tassāḥ micchādiṭṭhiyāḥ paccanīka bhūtā
translated: “Opposed to that wrong view”: opposed to that wrong view.

original: 95. Nesanti kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ. Akusalato nikkhantabhāveti asaṃkiliṭṭhabhāve. Ānisaṃsoti🔽suddhavipākatā. Visuddhipakkhoti visuddhibhāvo pariyodātatā. Abhūtadhammassa diṭṭhibhāvassa🔽saññāpanā ācikkhanā abhūtadhammasaññāpanā. Sāvajjesu paramavajje micchādassane paggahaṇanti🔽kuto susīlyassa paggahoti āha – “micchādassanaṃ gaṇhantasseva susīlyaṃ pahīnaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: kusalānam dhammānam akusalataḥ nikkhanta bhāve iti asaṃkiliṭṭha bhāve ānisaṃso ti  suddha vipāka tā visuddhi pakkho ti visuddhi bhāvo pariyodāta tā abhūta dhammassa diṭṭhi bhāvassa  saññāpanā ācikkhanā abhūta dhamma saññāpanā sāvajjesu paramavajje micchādassane paggahaṇanti  kutas susīlyassa paggaho ti āha micchādassanam gaṇhantassa iva susīlyam pahīnam hoti iti
translated: “They do not delight in profitable ideas” : in the sense of not delighting in the profitable, which is the opposite of delighting in the unprofitable. “Advantage” :🔽purity of outcome. “The purity side” : the state of being pure, the state of being cleansed. “Misrepresenting what is not fact” : the misrepresenting, the misdescription, of a view that is not fact.🔽“Misapprehending” : taking up, the supreme misapprehension among misapprehensions, namely, wrong view. “How can there be taking up of good behaviour” :🔽“As soon as he misapprehends, his good behaviour is abandoned” .🔽

original: Micchādiṭṭhiādayoti ettha micchāsaṅkappo paralokābhāvacintā, micchāvācā paralokābhāvavādabhūto🔽musāvādo, ariyānaṃ paccanīkatādayo. Aparāparaṃ uppajjanavasenāti punappunaṃ citte🔽uppajjanavasena. Pāpakā akusalā dhammāti paccavekkhaṇasaññāpanādikāle uppajjanakā🔽tathāpavattā akusalakhandhā.
analyzed: micchā diṭṭhi ādayo ti ettha micchā saṅkappo para loka abhāva cintā micchā vācā para loka abhāva vāda bhūto 🔽musāvādaḥ ariyānam paccanīka tā ādayaḥ apara aparam uppajjana vasena ati punappunam citte 🔽uppajjana vasena pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammā ti paccavekkhaṇa saññāpana ādi kāle uppajjanakā 🔽tathā apavattāḥ akusala khandhāḥ
translated: They are not defiled by unprofitable things. The benefit is that they are unadulterated. The purity side is the state of purity, the state of being cleansed. The misrepresentation of what is not fact is the misrepresentation and description of the view that there is no other world. original: Kaliggahoti anatthapariggaho. So pana yasmā diṭṭheva dhamme abhisamparāyañca parājayo🔽hotīti āha “parājayaggāho”ti. Dussamattoti ettha du-saddo “samādinno”ti etthāpi ānetvā
analyzed: kaliggaho ti anattha pariggaho so pana yasmai diṭṭhe iva dhamme abhisamparāyan ca parājayo  hoti iti āha parājaya gāhā hoti dussamatto ti ettha dusaddo samādinno ti ettha api ānetvā
translated: “Grasping at the wrong” is grasping at what is unprofitable. But that is defeat in this very life and in the life to come,🔽and so it is said that it is “the seizure of defeat.” As to “the bad seizure,” the prefix du- should be taken as equivalent to du- in such a word as duppariyādinna ,

original: yojetabboti āha “dupparāmaṭṭho”ti. Yathā dupparāmaṭṭho hoti, evaṃ samādinno dussamatto🔽dusamādinno vutto. Sakavādameva pharitvāti attano natthikavādameva “idameva saccaṃ
analyzed: yojetabbaḥ iti āha dupparāmaṭṭhaḥ ti yathā dupparāmaṭṭhaḥ hoti evam samādinnaḥ dussamatto  dusamādinnaḥ vuttaḥ saka vādam eva pharitvā ati attanaḥ natthika vādam eva idam eva saccam
translated: and so it is said that it is “the seizure of what is hard to seize.” It is called “the bad seizure” because it is seized in such a way that it is hard to seize. It is called “the seizure of what is hard to seize” because it is seized in such a way that it is hard to seize.

original: moghamañña”nti avadhārento aññassa okāsaadānavasena pharitvā. Tenāha “adhimuccitvā”ti.
analyzed: mogham aññanti avadhārento aññassa okāsa adāna vasena tena āha adhimuccitvā iti
translated: “Having spread out his own doctrine” : having defined his own doctrine of nothingness thus, “This alone is the truth, other than this is false,” and having spread it out by not giving an opportunity for another’s doctrine. Hence it is said, “having adhered to it” .

original: “Sambuddho”tiādi adhimuccanākāradassanaṃ. Riñcatīti viveceti apaneti. Tenāha “vajjetī”ti.
analyzed: sambuddha uti ādi adhimuccanā ākāra dassanam riñcati iti viveca iti apaneti tena āha vajjeti iti
translated: “The Enlightened One” , etc., shows the way in which he adhered to it. “He rejects” : he rejects, he removes. Hence it is said, “he disregards” .

original: 96. Kaṭaggahoti kataṃ sabbaso siddhimeva katvā gahaṇaṃ. So pana jayalābho hotīti
analyzed: katam sabbaso siddhim eva katvā gahaṇam saḥ pana jaya lābhaḥ hoti iti
translated: “The seizure of what is done” is the seizure of what is completely accomplished. But that is the seizure of victory,

original: vuttaṃ “jayaggāho”ti. Suggahitoti suṭṭhukaraṇavasena gahito. Suparāmaṭṭhoti suṭṭhu
analyzed: vuttam jaya gāho ti su gahitoti suṭṭhu karaṇa vasena gahito su parāmaṭṭhoti suṭṭhu
translated: and so it is said that it is “the seizure of victory.” “Well seized” : seized by good seizing. “Well seized upon” : well seized upon by good seizing.

original: parāparaṃ āsevanavasena āmaṭṭho. Ubhayenapi tassa kammassa katūpacitabhāvaṃ dasseti,
analyzed: para aparam āsevana vasena ubhayena api tassa kammassa kata upacita bhāvam dasseti
translated: It is “well-practised” in the sense of being practised repeatedly. Both terms show that the action has been done and stored up,

original: sotthibhāvāvahattañca saggupapattisaṃvattanato pāpasabhāvapahānato ca.
analyzed: sotthi bhāva avahat tat ca sagga upapatti saṃvattanataḥ pāpa sabhāva pahānataḥ ca
translated: and that it is of a good nature, since it leads to rebirth in the good destinations and to the abandoning of evil.

original: 97. Sahatthā karontassāti sahattheneva karontassa. Nissaggiyathāvarādayopi idha sahatthakaraṇeneva
analyzed: sahatthā karontassa ati sahatthena iva karontassa nissaggi yathāvara ādayaḥ api idha sahattha karaṇena iva
translated: “Doing with one’s own hand”: doing by oneself. Even the offences of wrong-doing and the rest are included here by the doing with one’s own hand.

original: saṅgahitā. Pacanaṃ dahanaṃ vibādhananti āha “daṇḍena pīḷentassā”ti. Sokaṃ sayaṃ karontassāti
analyzed: saṅga hitā pacanam dahanam vibādhanam iti āha daṇḍena pīḷentassa ati sokam sayam karontassa ati
translated: “Causing to cook” is cooking; “causing to burn” is burning; “causing to torment” is tormenting. Therefore it is said: “of one who torments with a stick.”🔽“Causing grief” is causing grief to another oneself, or giving rise to grief.

original: parassa sokakāraṇaṃ sayaṃ karontassa, sokaṃ vā uppādentassa. Parehi attano vacanakarehi.
analyzed: parassa soka kāraṇam sayam karontassa sokam vā uppādentassa parehi attanaḥ vacana karehi
translated: “By others who carry out one’s words” means by others who carry out one’s words.

original: Sayampi phandatoti parassa vibādhanapayogena sayampi phandato. Atipātayatoti padaṃ
analyzed: sayam pi phandato ti parassa vibādhana payogena sayam pi phandato atipātayato ti padam
translated: “One’s own shaking” means one’s own shaking by the means of causing torment to another. The word “causing to fall”

original: suddhakattuatthe hetukattuatthe ca vattatīti āha “hanantassapi hanāpentassāpī”ti.
analyzed: suddha kattu atthe hetu kattu atthe ca vattati iti āha han antassa api hanāpentassa api iti
translated: is used in the sense of the pure verb and in the sense of the causal verb. Therefore it is said: “of one who kills and of one who causes to kill.”

original: Gharassa bhitti anto bahi ca sandhitā hutvā ṭhitā gharasandhi. Kiñcipi asesetvā niravasesameva
analyzed: gharassa bhitti antar bahi ca sandhitā hutvā ṭhitā niravasesam eva
translated: “The house-joint” is the joint in a house that is fixed inside and outside. Without leaving anything, without remainder,

original: lopoti nillopo. Ekāgāre niyutto vilopo ekāgāriko. Parito sabbaso panthe hananaṃ paripantho.
analyzed: lopaḥ iti nillopaḥ ekāgāre niyuttaḥ vilopaḥ ekāgāriko paritas sabbaso panthe hananam paripantho
translated: “Lopa” is the same as “nillopa.” “Ekāgārika” is one who is confined to one house. “Paripantho” is the killing of all on the way round.

original: Pāpaṃ na karīyati pubbe asato uppādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā, tasmā natthi pāpaṃ. Yadi
analyzed: pāpam na karīyati pubbe asataḥ uppādetum a sakkuṇeyya ttā tasmā natthi pāpam yadi
translated: “Evil is not done” because it is impossible to originate what is non-existent. If

original: evaṃ kathaṃ sattā pāpaṃ paṭipajjantīti āha – “sattā pana karomāti evaṃsaññino hontī”ti.
analyzed: evam katham sattā pāpam paṭipajjanti iti āha sattā pana karoma ati evaṃsaññinaḥ honti iti
translated: that is so, how do beings commit evil? He said: “But beings think thus: ‘We do it.’ ”

original: Evaṃ kirassa hoti “imesañhi sattānaṃ hiṃsādikiriyā na attānaṃ phusati tassa niccatāya
analyzed: evam kirassa hoti imesam hi sattānam hiṃsā ādi kiriyā na attānam phusati tassa nicca tāya
translated: It seems that he thinks thus: “For these beings the doing of harm, etc., does not touch oneself because of its permanence.

original: nibbikārattā, sarīraṃ pana acetanaṃ kaṭṭhakaliṅgarūpamaṃ, tasmiṃ vikopitepi na kiñci
analyzed: sarīram pana acetanam tasmin vikopite pi na kiñci
translated: But the body is insensate, like a piece of wood or a clod of earth. So when it is injured,

original: pāpa”nti. Khuranemināti nisitakhuramayaneminā. Gaṅgāya dakkhiṇadisā appatirūpadeso,
analyzed: khura neminā ati nisita khura maya neminā gaṅgāya dakkhiṇa disā appatirūpadeso
translated: there is no evil.” “Khuranemi” is one whose sword-blade is sharp. The southern bank of the Ganges is an unsuitable region,

original: uttaradisā patirūpadesoti adhippāyena “dakkhiṇañce”tiādi vuttanti “dakkhiṇatīre manussā kakkhaḷā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: uttara disā patiḥ ūpadesaḥ ti adhippāyena dakkhiṇañca itiādi vuttanti dakkhiṇa tīre manussā kakkhaḷā ti ādim āha
translated: the northern bank a suitable region. With this intention he said “Southern” and so on. He said: “The people on the southern bank are hard” and so on.

original: Mahāyāganti mahāvijitayaññasadisaṃ mahāyāgaṃ. Sīlasaṃyamenāti kāyikavācasikasaṃvarena.
analyzed: mahā yāgam ti mahā vijita yañña sadisam mahā yāgam sīla saṃyamena ati kāyika vācasika saṃvarena
translated: “Great vehicle” : a great vehicle like the great sacrifice of King Vessavana. “By restraint in virtue” : by bodily and verbal restraint.

original: Saccavacanenāti saccavācāya. Tassa visuṃ vacanaṃ loke garutarapuññasammatabhāvato.
analyzed: saccavacanena ati saccavācāya tassa visum vacanam loke garutara puñña sammata bhāvato
translated: “By truth-speaking” : by truth-speaking. This is mentioned separately because truth-speaking is considered to be a heavier merit in the world.

original: Yathā hi pāpadhammesu musāvādo garu, evaṃ puññadhammesu saccavācā. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: yathā hi pāpa dhammesu musāvādaḥ garu evam puñña dhammesu sacca vācā tena āha bhagavā
translated: For just as lying is a heavy sin among the bad states, so truth-speaking is a heavy merit among the good states. Therefore the Exalted One said:

original: – “ekaṃ dhammamatītassā”tiādi. Vuttanayenevāti kaṇhapakkhe vuttanayena. Tattha hi🔽– “natthi pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo”ti āgataṃ, idha “atthi puññaṃ, atthi puññassa
analyzed: ekam dhammam atītassa atiādi vutta nayena iva ati kaṇha pakkhe vutta nayena tattha hi  natthi pāpam natthi pāpassa āgamaḥ ti āgatam idha atthi puññam atthi puññassa
translated: “For one who has transcended one state” , etc. “In the same way” : in the way stated in the dark side. For there it is said:

original: āgamo”ti āgataṃ, ayameva viseso. Sesaṃ vuttasadisamevāti “tesametaṃ pāṭikaṅkha”nti🔽evamādiṃ sandhāya vadati, taṃ heṭṭhā purimavārasadisaṃ.
analyzed: āgamaḥ ti āgatam ayam eva viseso sesam vutta sadisam eva ati tesam etam pāṭikaṅkhanti  evamādim sandhāya vadati tam heṭṭhā purima vāra sadisam
translated: “There is no evil, there is no approach to evil” , while here it is said: “There is merit, there is an approach to merit” . This is the only difference. The rest is similar to what was said above.

original: 100. Ubhayenāti hetupaccayapaṭisedhavacanena. Saṃkilesapaccayanti saṃsāre paribbhamanena
analyzed: ubhayena ati hetu paccaya paṭisedha vacanena saṃkilesa paccayanti saṃsāre paribbhamanena
translated: “By both” : by the denial of cause and condition. “By the condition of defilement” : by wandering in the round of rebirths.

original: kilinnassa malinabhāvassa kāraṇaṃ. Vuttavipariyāyena visuddhipaccayanti saddattho🔽veditabbo. Balantiādīsu sattānaṃ saṃkilesāvahaṃ vodānāvahañca ussāhasaṅkhātaṃ balaṃ🔽vā, sūravīrabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ vīriyaṃ vā, purisena kattabbo purisathāmo vā, so eva paraṃ
analyzed: kilinnassa malina bhāvassa kāraṇam vutta vipariyāyena visuddhi paccayanti saddattho  veditabbaḥ bala nti ādīsu sattānam saṃkilesa āvaham vodāna āvaham ca ussāha saṅkhātam balam  vā sūra vīra bhāva saṅkhātam vīriyam vā purisena kattabbo purisa thāmaḥ vā saḥ eva param
translated: and the cause of defilement is the stain. The meaning of the word should be understood as the opposite of this.🔽As to “strength” and the rest: there is no strength, no heroism, no manliness, no manly power in beings that is a cause of defilement or a cause of purification,

original: paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanappattiyā purisaparakkamo vā natthi na upalabbhati.
analyzed: param ṭhānam akkamana pattiyā purisa parakkamaḥ vā natthi na upalabbhati
translated: no strength consisting in courage, no heroism consisting in the state of a hero, no manliness consisting in the state of a man, no manly power consisting in the state of a man, that is, no ability to reach a higher and higher state, that is found.

original: Satvayogato, rūpādīsu sattavisattatāya ca sattā. Pāṇanato assāsapassāsavasena pavattiyā
analyzed: sattva yogataḥ rūpa ādīsu satta visatta tāyai ca sattā pāṇanataḥ assāsa passāsa vasena pavattiyā
translated: Beings are so called because of their being clung to and because of their being seventeenfold in the categories of visible-data eye-penetration, etc., and because of their being breathed on and because of their breathing in and breathing out by way of in-breath and out-breath.

original: pāṇā. Te pana so ekindriyādivasena vibhajitvā vadatīti āha “ekindriyo”tiādi. Aṇḍakosādīsu
analyzed: te pana saḥ ekindriya ādi vasena vibhajitvā vadati iti āha aṇḍa kosa ādīsu
translated: But he distinguishes them by way of the single faculty, etc., and so he says “single-facultied” and so on.🔽They are called “beings” because of their being born in the various kinds of generation such as the egg-born, etc., and so he says “egg-born … and so on.”

original: bhavanato bhūtāti vuccantīti āha “aṇḍakosa…pe… vadantī”ti. Jīvanato pāṇaṃ dhārento
analyzed: bhavanataḥ bhūtā ati vuccanti iti āha aṇḍa kosape vadanti iti jīvanataḥ pāṇam dhārentaḥ
translated: They are called “living beings” because of their living and because of their growing like a living being that breathes,

original: viya vaḍḍhanato jīvāti evaṃ sattapāṇabhūtajīvesu saddattho veditabbo. Natthi etesaṃ
analyzed: viya vaḍḍhanataḥ jīvā ti evam satta pāṇa bhūta jīvesu sadda atthaḥ veditabbaḥ na atthi etesam
translated: and so the meaning of the word should be understood as “living beings, beings, creatures, living creatures.”🔽There is no such thing as a self or a world or a person or a human being or a human or a man or a human soul or a human person or a human being as a human being or a human creature or a human being as a living being or a human being as a living creature or a human being as a living person or a human being as a living soul or a human being as a living self or a human being as a living world or a human being as a living person in the world or a human being as a living being in the world or a human being as a living creature in the world or a human being as a living person in the world or a human being as a living soul in the world or a human being as a living self in the world or a human being as a living world in the world or a human being as a living person in the world or a human being as a living being in the world or a human being as a living creature in the world or a human being as a living person in the world or

original: saṃkilesavisuddhīsu vasoti avasā. Natthi nesaṃ balaṃ vīriyañcāti abalā avīriyā. Niyatatāti🔽acchejjasuttāvutābhejjamaṇi viya niyatapavattanatāya gatijātibandhapajahavasena niyāmo.
analyzed: saṃkilesa visuddhīsu vaso ti a vasā natthi nesam balam vīriyam ca ati abalāḥ a vīriyāḥ  viya niyata pavatta na tāya gati jāti bandha pajaha vasena niyāmaḥ
translated: “He is called ‘one who has a fixed destiny’ because he has a fixed destiny, like the gem called ‘uncuttable’ .🔽“He is called ‘one who goes to a particular place’ because he goes to a particular place of destination among the six classes of beings by way of the abandoning of the bonds of destiny and rebirth.

original: Tattha tattha gamananti channaṃ abhijātīnaṃ tāsu tāsu gatīsu upagamanaṃ samavāyena
analyzed: tattha tattha gamananti channam abhijātīnam tāsu tāsu gatīsu upagamanam samavāyena
translated: “He is called ‘one who meets together’ because he meets together with the six classes of beings in the various destinations by way of association.

original: samāgamo. Sabhāvoyevāti yathā kaṇṭakassa tikkhatā, kabiṭṭhaphalānaṃ parimaṇḍalatā,🔽migapakkhīnaṃ vicittākāratā, evaṃ sabbassapi lokassa hetupaccayena vinā tathā tathā
analyzed: samāgamaḥ sabhāvaḥ yā iva ati yathā kaṇṭakassa tikkha tā kabiṭṭha phalānam parimaṇḍala tā  miga pakkhīnam vicitta ākāra tā evam sabbassa api lokassa hetu paccayena vinā tathā tathā
translated: “He is called ‘one who has a nature’ because he has a nature, just as the sharpness of a thorn, the roundness of a myrobalan fruit,🔽the variegated appearance of deer and birds, and so on, are the nature of those things.

original: pariṇāmo, ayaṃ sabhāvoyeva akittimoyeva. Tenāha “yena hī”tiādi.🔽Sakuṇe hanatīti sākuṇiko, tathā sūkariko. Luddoti aññopi yo koci māgaviko nesādo.
analyzed: pariṇāmaḥ ayam tena āha yena hi itiādi  sakuṇe hanati iti sākuṇikaḥ tathā sūkarikaḥ luddo ti añño pi yaḥ koci māgavikaḥ nesādaḥ
translated: And just as the world has a nature that is a transformation in such and such a way by way of cause and condition, so too this is a nature, a non-deceptive nature.🔽“He is called ‘one who kills birds’ because he kills birds, and likewise ‘one who kills pigs.’ ‘Hunter’ is a general term for any kind of hunter.

original: Pāpakammapasutatāya kaṇhābhijāti nāma. Bhikkhūti sākiyā bhikkhū, macchamaṃsakhādanato
analyzed: pāpa kamma pasuta tāya kaṇhābhijāti nāma bhikkhū iti sākiyāḥ bhikkhū maccha maṃsa khādanato
translated: “He is called ‘one of a dark clan’ because he is devoted to evil actions. ‘Monks’ here refers to the Sakyan monks, who are so called because they eat fish and meat.

original: nīlābhijātīti vadanti. Ñāyaladdhepi paccaye bhuñjamānā ājīvakasamayassa vilomagāhitāya
analyzed: nīlābhijātī iti vadanti ñāya laddhe pi paccaye bhuñjamānāḥ ājīvaka samayassa viloma gāhitāya
translated: They are called “born of the blue” .🔽They are called “eating with thorns stuck on” because they go against the Ajivika doctrine by eating when they get the requisites legitimately.

original: “paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādantī”ti vadanti. Eke pabbajitā, ye savisesaṃ attakilamathānuyogamanuyuttā.
analyzed: paccayesu kaṇṭake pakkhipitvā khādanti iti vadanti eke pabbajitāḥ ye sa visesam atta kilamatha anuyogam anuyuttā
translated: Some who have gone forth are called “thorn-doers” because they are devoted to self-mortification that is more severe .

original: Tathā hi te kaṇṭake vattentā viya hontīti kaṇṭakavuttikāti vuttā. Ṭhatvā bhuñjanadānapaṭikkhepādivatasamāyogena🔽paṇḍaratarā. Acelakasāvakāti ājīvakasāvake vadati. Te kira ājīvakaladdhiyā visuddhacittatāya
analyzed: tathā hi te kaṇṭake vattentā viya honti iti kaṇṭakavuttikā ati vuttā bhuñjana dāna paṭikkhepa ādi vata samāyogena  paṇḍaratarā acelaka sāvakā ati ājīvaka sāvake vadati te kira ājīvaka laddhiyā visuddha citta tāya
translated: For they are like those who go about with thorns stuck on them. They are called “thorn-doers” because they are like those who go about with thorns stuck on them.

original: nigaṇṭhehipi paṇḍaratarā. Nandādayo hi tathārūpāya paṭipattiyā pattabbā, tasmā nandādayo
analyzed: paṇḍaratarāḥ nanda ādayaḥ hi tathārūpāya paṭipattiyā pattabbā tasmā nanda ādayaḥ
translated: They are “whiter” than the Niganthas by reason of the combination of the following things: their giving of gifts, their receiving of requisites, their refraining from killing, etc.,🔽and their refraining from the five offences that are shared in common with the lay followers.

original: nigaṇṭhehi ājīvakasāvakehi ca paṇḍaratarāti vuttā “sukkābhijātī”ti.
analyzed: nigaṇṭhehi ājīvaka sāvakehi ca paṇḍaratarā ati vuttā sukkābhijātī iti
translated: He calls the Ajivika disciples “naked ascetics.” They are whiter than the Niganthas, it seems, because of their purity of mind due to their Ajivika belief.🔽For Nandaka and the others are to be found in such a practice, and so they are called “born of the white” .

original: Ayametesaṃ laddhīti sākuṇikādibhāvūpagamanena kaṇhābhijātiādīsu dukkhaṃ sukhañca
analyzed: ayam etesam laddhi iti sākuṇika ādi bhāva upagamanena kaṇha abhijāti ādīsu dukkham sukham ca
translated: This is their “belief.” The suffering and happiness in the “black-born” states, etc., are due to the adoption of the states of the fowler, etc.,

original: paṭisaṃvedentā anukkamena mahākappānaṃ cullāsītisahassāni khepetvā ājīvakabhāvūpagamanena
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedentāḥ anukkamena mahā kappānam culla asīti sahassāni khepetvā ājīvaka bhāva upagamanena
translated: They experience the result of that kamma in the same way as the result of the kamma of the first cycle of eighty-four thousand great eons. Then, by taking up the practice of the Ājīvakas,

original: paramasukkābhijātiyaṃ ṭhatvā saṃsārato sujjhantīti ayaṃ tesaṃ niyati ājīvakānaṃ laddhi.
analyzed: parama sukka abhijātiyam ṭhatvā saṃsārataḥ sujjhanti iti ayam tesam niyati ājīvakānam laddhi
translated: they reach the highest form of existence and are purified from the round of rebirths. This is the Ājīvakas’ doctrine of fixed destiny.

original: “Natthi dinna”nti vadanto natthiko dānassa phalaṃ paṭikkhipatīti āha – “natthikadiṭṭhi🔽vipākaṃ paṭibāhatī”ti. Tathā ceva heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇitaṃ “natthikadiṭṭhi hi natthitamāhā”ti.
analyzed: natthi dinnanti vadantaḥ natthikaḥ dānassa phalam paṭikkhipati iti āha natthika diṭṭhi  vipākam paṭibāhati iti tathā ca iva heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇitam natthika diṭṭhi hi natthitam āha ati
translated: The nihilist, who says “There is no giving,” denies the result of giving.

original: Ahetukadiṭṭhi ubhayanti kammaṃ vipākañca ubhayaṃ. So hi “ahetū apaccayā sattā saṃkilissanti
analyzed: ahetuka diṭṭhi ubhayanti kammam vipākam ca ubhayam saḥ hi ahetū apaccayā sattā saṃkilissanti
translated: The doctrine of causelessness denies both: it denies both kamma and its result. For the nihilist says, “Without cause or condition beings are defiled;🔽without cause or condition beings are purified.”

original: visujjhantī”ti vadanto kammassa viya vipākassapi saṃkilesavisuddhīnaṃ paccayattābhāvavacanato
analyzed: visujjhanti iti vadanto kammassa viya vipākassa api saṃkilesa visuddhīnam paccaya ttā abhāva vacanato
translated: By denying the existence of conditions for the defilement and purification of beings, he denies both kamma and its result.

original: tadubhayaṃ paṭibāhati nāma. Vipāko paṭibāhito hoti asati kamme vipākābhāvato. Kammaṃ
analyzed: tat ubhayam paṭibāhati nāma vipākaḥ paṭibāhitaḥ hoti asati kamme vipāka abhāvato kammam
translated: The result is denied when kamma is denied, since without kamma there is no result. Kamma is denied when the existence of kamma is denied.

original: paṭibāhitaṃ hoti asati vipāke kammassa niratthakabhāvāpattito. Atthatoti sarūpena.🔽Ubhayapaṭibāhakāti visuṃ visuṃ taṃtaṃdiṭṭhitā vuttāpi sabbe te natthikādayo natthikadiṭṭhiādivasena
analyzed: paṭibāhitam hoti asati vipāke kammassa niratthaka bhāva āpattitaḥ atthato ti sarūpena  ubhaya paṭibāhakā ti visum visum tad tad diṭṭhi tā vuttā api sabbe te natthika ādayaḥ natthika diṭṭhi ādi vasena
translated: and it is contradicted because, if there is no result, then the kamma is pointless. As to meaning: as to individual essence.🔽As to the two kinds of contradiction: though the various kinds of annihilationism are stated as to their view of annihilation, etc.,

original: paccekaṃ tividhadiṭṭhikā eva ubhayapaṭibāhakattā. “Ubhayapaṭibāhakā”ti hi hetuvacanaṃ.
analyzed: paccekam tividha diṭṭhikāḥ eva ubhaya paṭibāhaka ttā ubhaya paṭibāhakā iti hi hetu vacanam
translated: all of them are of three kinds each as to the two kinds of contradiction. For the words “as to the two kinds of contradiction” are a reason.

original: Ahetukavādā cātiādi paṭiññāvacanaṃ. Yo hi vipākapaṭibāhanena natthikadiṭṭhiko, so
analyzed: ahetuka vādā ca atiādi paṭiññā vacanam yaḥ hi vipāka paṭibāhanena natthika diṭṭhiko so
translated: The words “and the doctrines of no cause, etc.” are an assertion. For one who is an annihilationist as to the result

original: atthato kammapaṭibāhanena akiriyadiṭṭhiko, ubhayapaṭibāhanena ahetukadiṭṭhiko ca
analyzed: atthataḥ kamma paṭibāhanena akiriya diṭṭhiko ubhaya paṭibāhanena ahetuka diṭṭhiko ca
translated: is also an annihilationist as to the kamma as to meaning, and an indeterminism as to the two kinds of contradiction.

original: hoti. Sesadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ha iti sesa dvaye pi e sa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies in the case of the other two.

original: Sajjhāyantīti taṃ diṭṭhidīpakaṃ ganthaṃ uggahetvā paṭhanti. Vīmaṃsantīti tassa atthaṃ
analyzed: sajjhāyanti iti tam diṭṭhi dīpakam gantham uggahetvā paṭhanti vīmaṃsanti iti tassa attham
translated: They speculate: they learn the texts that illustrate those views and recite them. They investigate: they examine

original: vicārenti. Tesantiādi vīmaṃsanākāradassanaṃ. Tasmiṃ ārammaṇeti yathāparikappitakammaphalābhāvadīpake
analyzed: vicārenti vīmaṃsana ākāra dassanam tasmin ārammaṇe ti yathā parikappita kamma phala abhāva dīpake
translated: their meaning. They are of this kind, etc., shows the way in which they investigate. In that, as the object: in the texts that illustrate the non-existence of kamma and its result as they have been imagined.

original: “natthi dinna”ntiādinayappavattāya laddhiyā ārammaṇe. Micchāsati santiṭṭhatīti “natthi🔽dinna”ntiādivasena anussavūpaladdhe atthe tadākāraparivitakkanehi saviggahe viya🔽sarūpato cittassa paccupaṭṭhite cirakālaparicayena “evameta”nti nijjhānakkhamabhāvūpagamanena🔽nijjhānakkhantiyā tathā gahite punappunaṃ tatheva āsevantassa bahulīkarontassa micchāvitakkena
analyzed: natthi dinna nti ādi naya ppavattāya laddhiyāḥ ārammaṇe micchā satī santiṭṭhati iti natthi  dinna nti ādi vasena anussava upaladdhe atthe tad ākāra parivitakkanehi sa viggahe viya  sarūpataḥ cittassa paccupaṭṭhite cira kāla paricayena evam etat ti nijjhāna kkhama bhāva upagamanena  nijjhāna khantiyā tathā gahite punappunam tathā iva āsevantassa bahulīkarontassa micchā vitakkena
translated: Wrong mindfulness is established in the object of the view that has arisen in the form “There is no giving” and so on.🔽Wrong mindfulness is established in the object of the view that has arisen in the form “There is no giving” and so on.🔽Wrong mindfulness is established in the object of the view that has arisen in the form “There is no giving” and so on.🔽Wrong mindfulness is established in the object of the view that has arisen in the form “There is no giving” and so on.

original: samādiyamānā micchāvāyāmupatthambhitā ataṃsabhāvaṃ “taṃsabhāva”nti gaṇhantī micchāsatīti🔽laddhanāmā taṃladdhisahagatā taṇhā santiṭṭhati. Cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hotīti yathāvuttavitakkādipaccayalābhena🔽tasmiṃ ārammaṇe avaṭṭhitatāya anekaggaṃ pahāya ekaggaṃ appitaṃ viya hoti. Micchāsamādhipi
analyzed: samādiyamānā micchāvāyām upatthambhitā a taṃsa bhāvam taṃsa bhāvanti gaṇhantī micchā asatī iti 🔽laddha nāmā taṃ laddhi sahagatā taṇhā santiṭṭhati cittam ekaggam hoti iti yathā vutta vitakka ādi paccaya lābhena 🔽tasmin ārammaṇe avaṭṭhita tāya anekaggam pahāya ekaggam appitam viya hoti micchāsamādhi pi

original: hi paccayavisesehi laddhabhāvanābalehi kadāci samādhānapatirūpakiccakaro hotiyeva🔽vālavijjhanādīsu viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Javanāni javantīti anekakkhattuṃ tenākārena pubbabhāgiyesu
analyzed: hi paccaya visesehi laddha bhāvanā balehi kadāci samādhāna patirūpa kicca karaḥ  vāla vijjhana ādīsu viyā ti daṭṭhabbam javanāni javanti iti aneka kkhattum tena ākārena pubbabhāgiyesu
translated: for it is only when it has obtained the power of development through the special conditions that it sometimes acts as the proximate cause for concentration.🔽It should be regarded as like the “piercing of the gem” in the case of the “piercing of the gem and the training of the horse.”

original: javanavāresu pavattesu sabbapacchime javanavāre satta javanāni javanti. Paṭhamajavane🔽pana satekicchā honti, tathā dutiyādīsūti dhammasabhāvadassanametaṃ, na pana tasmiṃ
analyzed: javana vāresu pavattesu sabba pacchime javana vāre satta javanāni javanti paṭhama javane  pana sa tekicchāḥ honti tathā dutiya ādīsu iti dhamma sabhāva dassanam etam na pana tasmin
translated: “The impulsions impel”: in the case of the many impulsions that occur in the impulsional stage in that mode, the seven impulsions impel in the last impulsional stage.

original: khaṇe tesaṃ satekicchabhāvāpādanaṃ kenaci sakkā kātuṃ.🔽Tatthāti tesu tīsu micchādassanesu. Koci ekaṃ dassanaṃ okkamatīti yassa ekasmiṃyeva🔽abhiniveso āsevanā ca pavattā, so ekaṃyeva dassanaṃ okkamati. Yassa pana dvīsu, tīsupi
analyzed: khaṇe tesam sa tekiccha bhāva āpādanam kenacid sakkā kātum  tattha ati tesu tīsu micchādassanesu koci ekam dassanam okkamati iti yassa ekasmiṃ yeva  abhinivesaḥ āsevanā ca pavattā saḥ ekam yā iva dassanam okkamati yassa pana dvīsu tīsu pi
translated: But in the first impulsion they are only desirous of doing, and likewise in the second and the rest. This is the demonstration of the individual essences of the states. But it is not possible for anyone to make them only desirous of doing at that time.🔽“In these three wrong views”: in the case of those three wrong views. “Someone enters into one view”: he who has insistence and practice only on one enters into one view. But he who has insistence and practice on two or on all three enters into two or three.

original: vā abhinivesanā pavattā, so dve tīṇi okkamati. Etena yā pubbe ubhayapaṭibāhanatāmukhena
analyzed: vā abhinivesanā pavattā so dve tīṇi okkamati etena yā pubbe ubhaya paṭibāhana tā mukhena
translated: By this he shows that the person who has insistence and practice on two or on all three enters into two or three views by taking them as a pair or all together respectively, as the case may be.

original: vuttā atthasiddhā sabbadiṭṭhikatā, sā pubbabhāgiyā. Yā pana micchattaniyāmokkanti🔽bhūtā, sā yathāsakaṃ paccayasamudāgamasiddhito bhinnārammaṇānaṃ viya visesādhigamānaṃ🔽aññamaññaṃ ekajjhaṃ anuppattiyā asaṃkiṇṇā evāti dasseti. Ekasmiṃ okkantepītiādinā🔽tissannampi diṭṭhīnaṃ samānabalataṃ samānaphalatañca dasseti, tasmā tissopi cetā🔽ekassa uppannā aññamaññaṃ abbokiṇṇā eva, ekāya vipāke dinne itarā anubalappadāyikā🔽honti. Vaṭṭakhāṇu nāmāti idaṃ vacanaṃ neyyatthaṃ, na nītatthanti taṃ vivaritvā dassetuṃ
analyzed: vuttā attha siddhā sabba diṭṭhika tā sā pubbabhāgiyā yā pana  bhūtā sā yathāsakam paccaya samudāgama siddhitaḥ bhinna ārammaṇānam viya visesa adhigamānam  aññam aññam ekajjham anuppattiyāḥ asaṃkiṇṇāḥ eva ati dasseti ekasmin okkante pi itiādinā  tissannam pi diṭṭhīnam samāna bala tam samāna phala tam ca dasseti tasmā tissaḥ upi cetā  ekassa uppannā aññamaññam abbokiṇṇā eva ekāya vipāke dinne itarā anubala ppadāyikā  honti vaṭṭa khāṇu nāma ati idam vacanam neyyattham na nītattham ti tam vivaritvā dassetum
translated: The first is the success of the meaning of the words, and it is the common property of all views. But the second is the penetration of the right view,🔽which is the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry. The third is the penetration of the wrong view, which is the attainment of the fruit of non-return.🔽The fourth is the penetration of the view of the specific condition, which is the attainment of the fruit of arahantship. analyzed: kim pana īsā atiādi vuttam akusalam nāma etat abalam dubbalam na kusalam viya mahā balanti 🔽āha ekasmiṃ yeva atta bhāve niyataḥ ti aññathā sammatta niyāmaḥ viya micchatta niyāmaḥ api
