original: accantiko siyā. Yadi evaṃ vaṭṭakhāṇukajotanā kathanti āha “āsevanavasena panā”tiādi,
analyzed: siyā yadi evam vaṭṭa khāṇuka jotanā kathanti āha āsevana vasena pana atiādi
translated: he would be a nihilist.🔽If that is so, then the simile of the saw is contradicted.

original: tasmā yathā “sakiṃ nimuggo nimuggova hotī”ti vuttaṃ, evaṃ vaṭṭakhāṇukajotanā. Yādise
analyzed: tasmā yathā sakim nimuggaḥ nimuggaḥ iva hoti iti vuttam evam
translated: Therefore, just as it is said that “one who is submerged is submerged,” so too is the simile of the saw.

original: hi paccaye paṭicca ayaṃ taṃtaṃdassanaṃ okkanto puna kadāci tappaṭipakkhe paccaye
analyzed: hi paccaye paṭicca ayam taṃ taṃ dassanam okkantaḥ puna kadāci tad paṭipakkhe paccaye
translated: For if this view has arisen in dependence on certain conditions, it cannot be said that sometimes, in dependence on conditions opposed to those, it is thrown out.

original: paṭicca tato sīsukkhipanamassa na hotīti na vattabbaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “yebhuyyenā”ti.
analyzed: paṭicca tatas sīsu khipanam assa na hoti iti na vattabbam tena vuttam yebhuyyena ati
translated: Therefore it is said, “for the most part.”

original: Tasmāti yasmā evaṃ saṃsārakhāṇubhāvassapi paccayo akalyāṇajano, tasmā. Bhūtikāmoti
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai evam paccayaḥ akalyāṇa jano tasmai bhūti kāmo ti
translated: Because, although the conditions for the existence of the saw are present, the unwholesome person is still a condition for the saw’s movement, therefore,🔽desiring to exist,

original: diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthānaṃ vasena attano guṇehi vaḍḍhikāmo. Yaṃ panettha
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthānam vasena attanaḥ guṇehi vaḍḍhi kāmaḥ yam pana ittha
translated: desiring to increase his own qualities by means of the highest good in this life and the next.

original: keci vadanti “yathā cirakālabhāvanāya paripākūpagamaladdhabalattā upanissayakusalā
analyzed: keci vadanti yathā cira kāla bhāvanāya paripāka upagama laddha balattā upanissaya kusalā
translated: But here some say that just as wholesome roots, having become strong through the development of the wholesome for a long time,

original: akusale sabbaso samucchindanti, evaṃ akusaladhammā tatopi cirakālabhāvanāsambhavato
analyzed: akusale sabbaso samucchindanti evam akusala dhammā tatas pi cira kāla bhāvanā sambhavato
translated: completely eradicate unwholesome roots, so too unwholesome dhammas can arise through the development of the unwholesome for a long time.

original: laddhabalā hutvā kadāci kusaladhammepi samucchindanti. Evañca katvā daḷhamicchābhinivesassa
analyzed: laddha balāḥ hutvā kadāci kusala dhamme pi samucchindanti evam ca katvā daḷham icchā abhinivesassa
translated: and when they have gained strength they sometimes cut off even the profitable ideas. And in this way it is possible to show how the view of one who is strongly attached to his own view and who is bent on wrong is like a tree-stump.

original: micchādiṭṭhikassa vaṭṭakhāṇukabhāvajotanāpi samatthitā hotī”ti yathā taṃ “vassabhaññānaṃ🔽diṭṭhī”ti, taṃ na, micchattaniyatadhammānaṃ cirakālabhāvanāmattena na paṭipakkhassa🔽pajahanasamatthatā, atha kho dhammatāsiddhena paccayavisesāhitasāmatthiyena attano
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhikassa vaṭṭa khāṇuka bhāva jotanā api samatthitā hoti iti yathā tam vassabhaññānam  diṭṭhī iti tam na micchatta niyata dhammānam cira kāla bhāvanā mattena na paṭipakkhassa  pajahana samattha tā atha kho dhamma tā siddhena paccaya visesa āhita sāmatthiyena attanaḥ
translated: As it is said: “The view of the bulls of the earth” .

original: pahāyakasabhāvena pahāyakabhāvo bhāvanākusalānaṃyeva vutto, akusalānaṃyeva ca pahātabbabhāvo
analyzed: pahāyaka sabhāvena pahāyaka bhāvaḥ bhāvanā kusalānam yeva vuttaḥ akusalānam yeva ca pahātabba bhāvaḥ
translated: It is not that the abandoning of the wrong view of one whose ideas are fixed in wrongness is possible by mere long practice, but rather that the abandoning of what is to be abandoned is said by those skilled in the abandoning of it to be by the state of its own nature, which is capable of being brought about by a special condition that is established by the natural law of what is possible.

original: “dassanena pahātabbā”tiādinā nayena, akusalānaṃyeva dubbalabhāvo “abalānaṃ balīyantī”tiādinā
analyzed: dassanena pahātabbā ati ādinā nayena akusalānam yā iva dubbala bhāvaḥ abalānam balīyanti iti ādinā
translated: And the weakness of the unprofitable is said in the way beginning, “The weak are overcome by the strong” .

original: (yuttināpi nāmato vā adhigamaniyo āloko ālokabhāvato bāhirāraṇekā viya na cettha
analyzed: yuttinā api nāmataḥ vā na ca ittha
translated: And the light that is to be reached by right view is not like the light that is outside the cave, which is to be reached by the rightness of the name or by the rightness of the light.

original: paṭiññatte bhāvesatā sotuno āsaṃkitabbā visesavassa sādhetabbato sāmaññassa ca sotubhāvena
analyzed: paṭiññatte bhāvesatā sotuno āsaṃkitabbā visesavassa sādhetabbataḥ sāmaññassa ca sotu bhāvena
translated: If the opponent admits this, then the existence of the hearer must be assumed, because the distinction must be established and the hearer is the common property.

original: adhippetattā veda-saddassa lopo dīpe sabhāve sādhane yathā taṃ saddayabhāvassa nāpi🔽visuddhakaanumānādivirodhasambhāvato. Na hi sakkā antarālokassa bāhirālokassa viya
analyzed: adhippeta ttā veda saddassa lopaḥ dīpe sabhāve sādhane yathā tam saddaya bhāvassa nā api  visuddhaka anumāna ādi virodha sambhāvataḥ na hi sakkā antara ālokassa bāhira ālokassa viya
translated: The word “vedanā” is elided because it is the subject of discussion. In the world, the word “vedanā” is used in the sense of the common property, as in the expression “taṃ vedanaṃ” .🔽Nor is there any contradiction with the pure inference, etc. For it is not possible to establish the state of being visible, etc., in the material body, as in the case of the external light, by way of the internal light.🔽But is it not possible to establish the state of being visible, etc., in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body?

original: rūpakāyaṃ upādāya rūpatā cakkhuviññeyyattādike patiṭṭhāpetuṃ sakkāti vuttaṃ, nanupi
analyzed: rūpa kāyam upādāya rūpa tā cakkhu viññeyya ttā ādike patiṭṭhāpetum sakkā iti vuttam nanu pi
translated: The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.🔽The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.

original: antarāloko aviggahattā vedanā viyāti saddheva ñāṇālokassa avijjandhakārā viya vidhamaniyabhāve🔽sabbesampi kusaladhammānaṃ kenacipi akusaladhammena samucchindaniyatā siddhāva hoti).
analyzed: antara ālokaḥ aviggaha ttā vedanā viya ati saddhā iva ñāṇa ālokassa avijja andhakārā viya vidhamaniya bhāve  sabbesam pi kusala dhammānam kenacipi akusala dhammena samucchinda niyatā siddhau a hoti
translated: The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.🔽The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.

original: Vaṭṭakhāṇukacodanāya yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttamevāti tiṭṭhatesā bālajanavikatthanā.
analyzed: vaṭṭa khāṇuka codanāya yam vattabbam tam heṭṭhā vuttam eva ati tiṭṭhatā isā bāla jana vikatthanā
translated: The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.🔽The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material body.🔽The state of being visible, etc., is established in the material body by way of the internal light, because the internal light is not separate from the material body, as the external light is not separate from the external material

original: 103. Jhānacittamayāti rūpāvacarajjhānacittena nibbattā. Tathā hi tesaṃ visesena jhānamanasā
analyzed: jhāna citta mayā ati rūpāvacara jhāna cittena nibbattā tathā hi tesam visesena jhāna manasā
translated: “Born of jhāna-consciousness”: produced by jhāna-consciousness of the fine-material sphere. For they are called “mind-made” because they are produced by the jhāna consciousness of the mind, specifically,

original: nibbattattā “manomayā”ti vuttā, avisesena pana abhisaṅkhāramanasā sabbepi sattā manomayā🔽eva. Saññāmayāti etthāpi eseva nayo. Tenāha “arūpajjhānasaññāyā”ti. Ayanti rūpitābhāvapaṭipajjanakapuggalo.
analyzed: nibbatta ttā manaḥ mayā iti vuttāḥ avisesena pana abhisaṅkhāra manasā sabbe pi sattāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ  eva saññā mayā ti ettha api esa iva nayo tena āha arūpa jhāna saññāya iti ayanti rūpi tā bhāva paṭipad janaka puggalo
translated: and because they are produced by the volition of the mind, generally. All beings are mind-made in the latter sense.🔽“Born of perception”: the same method of explanation applies here. Therefore the commentator said: “by the perception of the immaterial jhānas.”🔽“One who has not attained jhāna”: one who has not reached the fine-material jhānas.🔽“One who has not attained jhāna” means one who has not reached the fine-material jhānas. “One who has not attained jhāna” means one who has not reached the fine-material jhānas.

original: Appaṭiladdhajjhānoti anadhigatarūpajjhāno. Tassapīti takkinopi. Rūpajjhāne kaṅkhā
analyzed: appaṭiladdha jhāno ti anadhigata rūpa jjhāno tassa api iti takkinaḥ api rūpa jjhāne kaṅkhā
translated: “One who has not attained jhāna” means one who has not reached the fine-material jhānas.

original: natthi anussavavasena laddhavinicchayattā.🔽104. Sārāgāyāti sarāgabhāvāya. Santiketi samīpe, na thāmagatā diṭṭhinātidūrattā sarāgā,
analyzed: na atthi anussava vasena laddha vinicchaya ttā  sa ārāgāya ati sa rāga bhāvāya santikā iti samīpe na sa rāgā

original: na sampayuttattā. Sā hi na thāmagatā vaṭṭapariyāpannesu dhammesu rajjatīti viññāyatīti🔽āha – “rāgavasena vaṭṭe rajjanassā”ti. Sabbepi saṃyojanā taṇhāvaseneva sambhavantīti
analyzed: na sampayutta ttā sā hi na thāma gatā vaṭṭa pariyāpannesu dhammesu rajjati iti viññāyati iti 🔽āha rāga vasena vaṭṭe rajjanassa ati sabbe pi saṃyojanā taṇhā vasena iva sambhavanti iti
translated: “One who has not attained jhāna” means one who has not reached the fine-material jhānas.🔽“One who has not attained jhāna

original: āha – “taṇhāvasena saṃyojanatthāyā”ti. Āruppe panassa kaṅkhā natthīti anussavavasena
analyzed: āha taṇhā vasena saṃyojana tthāya ati āruppe panassa kaṅkhā natthi iti anussava vasena
translated: He said: “For the purpose of fettering by means of craving.” But in the formless worlds he has no doubt. Therefore it is said with reference to the view that he has arrived at by hearsay.

original: laddhanicchayaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Kāmaṃ duggatidukkhānaṃ ekantasaṃvattanena natthikadiṭṭhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: laddha nicchayam sandhāya vuttam kāmam duggati dukkhānam ekanta saṃvattanena natthika diṭṭhi ādīnam
translated: Granted that the view of the non-existence of the giver, etc., is not a sure guide because it leads only to the suffering of the unhappy destinations.

original: apaṇṇakatā pākaṭā eva, nippariyāyena pana anavajjassa atthassa ekantasādhakaṃ apaṇṇakanti
analyzed: apaṇṇaka tā pākaṭā eva nippariyāyena pana anavajjassa atthassa ekanta sādhakam apaṇṇakam ti
translated: But the view that there is no such thing as what is blameless is a sure guide because it leads only to what is blameless.

original: katvā codanā, sāvajjassapi atthassa sādhane ekaṃsikabhāvaṃ gahetvā parihāro. Tenāha
analyzed: katvā codanā atthassa sādhane ekaṃsika bhāvam gahetvā parihāraḥ tena āha
translated: Therefore the objection is based on the view that it is a sure guide in the sense of leading only to what is blameless. The reply is based on the view that it is a sure guide in the sense of leading only to what is blameless.

original: “gahaṇavasenā”tiādi. Tena ruḷhīvasena “natthi dinna”ntiādīni apaṇṇakaṅgāni jātānīti dasseti.
analyzed: gahaṇa vasena atiādi tena ruḷhī vasena natthi dinna nti ādīni apaṇṇaka aṅgāni jātāni iti dasseti
translated: Therefore he said “in the sense of grasping,” etc. He shows that the four factors of the view of the non-existence of the giver, etc., arise by the method of the view of non-existence.

original: 105. Heṭṭhā tayo puggalāva hontīti attantapo parantapoti imasmiṃ catukke heṭṭhā tayo
analyzed: heṭṭhā tayo puggalā ava honti iti attantapo parantapo ti imasmin catukke heṭṭhā tayo
translated: The three types of persons are only found in the first tetrad. In the first tetrad, the three types of persons are found.

original: puggalā honti. Yathāvuttā pañcapi puggalā duppaṭipannāva, tato atthikavādādayo pañcapuggalā
analyzed: puggalāḥ honti yathā vuttā pañca api puggalāḥ duppaṭipannāḥ ava tatas atthika vāda ādayaḥ pañca puggalā
translated: The five types of persons mentioned above are only of wrong practice. The five types of persons beginning with the one who holds the view that there is a self are of wrong practice.

original: sammāpaṭipannatāya imasmiṃ catukke eko catutthapuggalova hoti. Etamatthaṃ dassetunti🔽idha heṭṭhā vuttapuggalapañcakadvayaṃ imasmiṃ catukke eva saṅgahaṃ gacchatīti vibhāgena
analyzed: sammā paṭipanna tāya imasmin catukke ekaḥ catuttha puggalaḥ uva hoti etam attham dassetun ti  idha heṭṭhā vutta puggala pañcaka dvayam imasmin catukke eva saṅgaham gacchati iti vibhāgena
translated: In the case of right practice, only the fourth type of person is found in this tetrad. The Exalted One began this teaching in order to show this meaning.🔽The two sets of five types of persons mentioned above are included in this tetrad.

original: duppaṭipattisuppaṭipattiyo dassetuṃ bhagavā imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhīti. Yaṃ panettha atthato
analyzed: duppaṭipatti su paṭipattiyaḥ dassetum bhagavā imam desanam ārabhi iti yam pana ittha atthato
translated: In order to show the difficult practice and the easy practice, the Exalted One began this teaching. But the meaning of what is not yet explained here

original: avibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyameva.🔽Apaṇṇakasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: a vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva  apaṇṇaka sutta vaṇṇanāya līna ttha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: is easy to understand.🔽The explanation of the meaning of the Sutta on the Unerring is ended.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca gahapativaggavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca gahapati vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Householder Chapter is finished.

original: 2. Bhikkhuvaggo
analyzed: bhikkhu vaggo
translated: The Chapter on the Monk

original: 1. Ambalaṭṭhikarāhulovādasuttavaṇṇanā🔽107. Ambalaṭṭhikāyanti ettha ambalaṭṭhikā vuccati sujāto taruṇambarukkho, tassa pana
analyzed: ambalaṭṭhikāyanti ettha ambalaṭṭhikā vuccati sujātaḥ taruṇambarukkho tassa pana
translated: The Advice to Rahula at Ambalaṭṭhikā

original: avidūre kato pāsādo idha “ambalaṭṭhikā”ti adhippeto. Tenāha “veḷuvanavihārassā”tiādi.
analyzed: avidūre kataḥ pāsādaḥ idha ambalaṭṭhikā ti adhippeto tena āha veḷu vana vihārassa atiādi
translated: Here, Ambalaṭṭhikā is a young mango tree. But the pavilion built not far from it is what is meant here by “Ambalaṭṭhikā.” Therefore it is said: “of the Veḷuvana Monastery.”

original: Padhānagharasaṅkhepeti bhāvanāgehappakāre yogīnaṃ geheti attho. Tikhiṇova hoti, na
analyzed: padhāna ghara saṅkhepa iti bhāvanā geha ppakāre yogīnam gehe iti attho hoti na
translated: The meditation room is a house for yogis. The meaning is: a building for meditation. He is sharp, not dull.

original: tassa tikhiṇabhāvo kenaci kātabbo sabhāvasiddhattā. Evameva attano vimuttiparipācanakammunā
analyzed: tassa tikhiṇa bhāvaḥ kenaci kātabbaḥ sabhāva siddha ttā evam eva attanaḥ vimutti paripācana kammunā
translated: and its sharpness is due to the fact that it is naturally so. So too, this venerable one, by the work of maturing his own deliverance,🔽attained the state of being sharp and clear.

original: tikkhavisadabhāvappattiyā ayampi āyasmā…pe… tattha vihāsi. Pakatipaññattamevāti pakatiyā
analyzed: tikkha visada bhāva ppattiyā ayam pi tattha vihāsi pakati paññattam eva ati pakatiyā
translated: “The rule laid down by nature”: the rule laid down by nature,

original: paññattaṃ buddhānaṃ upagamanato puretarameva cārittavasena paññattaṃ.
analyzed: paññattam buddhānam upagamanataḥ puretaram eva cāritta vasena paññattam
translated: laid down by the Buddhas as a rule of conduct before the appearance of the Buddha Vipassī.

original: 108. Udakaṃ anena dhīyati, ṭhapīyati vā etthāti udakādhānaṃ. Udakaṭṭhānanti ca khuddakabhājanaṃ.
analyzed: udakam anena dhīyati ṭhapīyati vā ettha ati udaka ādhānam udaka ṭṭhānam ti ca khuddaka bhājanam
translated: “A water-pot” is a vessel for holding water.

original: “Ovādadānatthaṃ āmantesī”ti vatvā taṃ panassa ovādadānaṃ na idheva, atha kho bahūsu
analyzed: ovāda dāna attham āmantesi iti vatvā tam panassa ovāda dānam na idha iva atha kho bahūsu
translated: “He invited him to give advice” means that the advice he gave was not only here but in many places

original: ṭhānesu bahukkhattuṃ pavattitanti tāni tāni saṅkhepato dassetvā idha saṃvaṇṇanatthaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānesu bahu khattum tāni tāni saṅkhepataḥ dassetvā idha saṃvaṇṇana attham
translated: and on many occasions. Therefore, after briefly showing those, in order to praise him here,

original: “bhagavatā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhagavatā hi itiādi vuttam
translated: “The Blessed One” and so on is said.🔽There, “not abandoned by all Buddhas” means that in the teachings of all Buddhas, the youth’s questions

original: Tattha sabbabuddhehi avijahitanti iminā sabbesaṃ buddhānaṃ sāsane kumārapañhā nāma
analyzed: tattha sabba buddhehi a vijahitanti iminā sabbesam buddhānam sāsane kumārapañhā nāma
translated: are

original: hotīti dasseti. Ekekato paṭṭhāya yāva dasakā pavattā dasa pucchā etassāti dasapucchaṃ,
analyzed: hoti iti dasseti ekekataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva dasakā pavattā dasa pucchāḥ etassa ati dasa puccham
translated: he shows that it is so. The ten questions in it are the ten questions,

original: ekekato paṭṭhāya yāva dasakā ekuttaravasena pavattaṃ vissajjanatthāya pañcapaṇṇasavissajjanaṃ🔽sāmaṇerapañhanti sambandho. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ paramatthajotikāyaṃ khuddakaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: ekekatas paṭṭhāya yāva dasakāḥ eka uttara vasena pavattam vissajjana tthāya pañca paṇṇasa vissajjanam  sāmaṇera pañhanti sambandhaḥ yat pana ittha vattabbam tat paramatthajotikāyam khuddakaṭṭhakathāyam
translated: the five-limbed answer in it is the five-limbed answer,🔽the novice’s questions, is the construction. But what should be said here has been said in the commentary on the Minor Books in the Paramattha-jotikā .

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Anādīnavadassitāya abhiṇhaṃ musā samudācaraṇato “piyamusāvādā”ti
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbam anādīnava dassitāya abhiṇham musā samudācaraṇataḥ piya musā vādā ati
translated: Because of the frequent utterance of lies through not seeing the danger in them, it is said “dear lies” .

original: vuttaṃ, udakāvasesachaḍḍanaudakādhānanikujjanaukkujjanadassanasaññitā catasso udakādhānūpamāyo
analyzed: vuttam udaka avasesa chaḍḍana audakādhāna nikujjana ukkujjana dassana saññitā catasso udakādhāna upamāyo
translated: The four similes for a water-bearing cloud are called “the pouring out of the water left over” , “the water-bearing cloud” , “the turning over” , and “the not turning over” .

original: sabbassa yuddhakammassa akaraṇakaraṇavasena dassitā dve hatthiupamāyo.
analyzed: sabbassa yuddha kammassa a karaṇa karaṇa vasena dassitāḥ dve hatthi upamāyo
translated: The two similes for an elephant are shown by the doing and not doing of the whole business of fighting.

original: Tattha rāhulasuttanti suttanipāte āgataṃ rāhulasuttaṃ. Abhiṇhovādavasena vuttanti
analyzed: tattha rāhula suttam ti sutta nipāte āgatam rāhula suttam abhiṇhovāda vasena vuttan ti
translated: Herein, the Rāhula Sutta is the Rāhula Sutta found in the Sutta Nipāta. It is said by way of frequent exhortation.

original: iminā antarantarā taṃ suttaṃ kathetvā bhagavā theraṃ ovadatīti dasseti. Idañca panāti
analyzed: iminā antarantarā tam suttam kathetvā bhagavā theram ovadati iti dasseti idam ca pana ati
translated: By this he shows that the Exalted One instructed the Elder by preaching the sutta from time to time. “And this”:

original: idaṃ yathāvuttaṃ bhagavato taṃtaṃkālānurūpaṃ attano ovādadānaṃ sandhāya. Bījanti
analyzed: idam yathāvuttam bhagavataḥ taṃ taṃ kāla anurūpam attanaḥ ovāda dānam sandhāya
translated: with reference to the Exalted One’s instruction, which is appropriate to the occasion. “Seed”:

original: aṇḍaṃ. Passasi nūti nu-saddo anujānane, nanu passasīti attho. Saccadhammaṃ laṅghitvā
analyzed: aṇḍam passasi nu ti nu saddaḥ anujānane nanu passasi iti atthaḥ sacca dhammam laṅghitvā
translated: an egg. The word “nū” is used in the sense of “indeed,” as in “Do you indeed see?”

original: ṭhitassa kiñcipi akattabbaṃ nāma pāpaṃ natthīti āha – “sampajānamusāvāde saṃvararahitassa
analyzed: ṭhitassa kiñcipi a kattabbam nāma pāpam natthi iti āha sampajāna musāvāde saṃvara rahitassa
translated: Since there is nothing that cannot be done by one who has transgressed the truth, he said: “For one who is devoid of restraint in the conscious telling of lies”

original: opammadassanatthaṃ vuttā”ti. Tathā hi –
analyzed: opamma dassana ttham vuttā ati tathā hi
translated: “is said for the purpose of showing a simile.” For thus:

original: “Ekaṃ dhammamatītassa, musāvādissa jantuno;
analyzed: ekam dhammam atītassa musāvādissa jantuno
translated: “For a person who has transgressed the one Dhamma, who is a liar,

original: Vitiṇṇaparalokassa, natthi pāpamakāriya”nti. ;🔽Uruḷhavāti uruḷho hutvā ussito. So pana damavasena abhiruyha vaḍḍhito ārohanayogyo
analyzed: vitiṇṇa para lokassa natthi pāpam akāriyanti  uruḷhavāti uruḷhaḥ hutvā ussitaḥ saḥ pana dama vasena abhiruyha vaḍḍhitaḥ ārohana yogyaḥ
translated: and who has crossed over the world to come, there is no evil that cannot be done.”🔽“Uruḷhavā” means “one who has become uruḷha , who has grown up.” But he, by means of self-control, has mounted and grown up, and is fit to mount.

original: ca hotīti āha “abhivaḍḍhito ārohasampanno”ti. Āgatāgateti attano yogyapadesaṃ āgatāgate.
analyzed: ca hoti iti āha abhivaḍḍhitaḥ āroha sampanno ti āgata āgata iti yogya padesam āgata āgate
translated: Therefore it is said: “one who has grown up, who is endowed with the ability to mount.” “Āgatāgate”: coming and going to the place that is suitable for him.

original: Paṭisenāya phalakakoṭṭhakamuṇḍapākārādayoti paṭisenāya attano ārakkhatthāya ṭhapite🔽phalakakoṭṭhake ceva uddhacchadapākārādike ca. Etaṃ padesanti etaṃ parasenāpadesaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisenāya phalaka koṭṭhaka muṇḍapa ākāra ādayaḥ ti paṭisenāya attanaḥ ārakkha atthāya ṭhapite  phalaka koṭṭhake ca iva etam etam para senā padesam
translated: The planks, the ramparts, the palisades, etc., of the enemy’s army are the planks, etc., set up by the enemy for his own protection.🔽The enemy’s army is the “there.”🔽“Just by looking” means just by looking at it.

original: Ettakenāti olokanamattena. Tassa olokanākāradassaneneva. Satampi sahassampi senānīkaṃ
analyzed: ettakena ati olokana mattena tassa olokana ākāra dassanena iva satam pi sahassam pi senānīkam
translated: Even a thousandfold army is split in two by the mere demonstration of the way of looking at it.

original: dvedhā bhijjati, tīrapātikaṃ madditaṃ hutvā padātā hutvā dvedhā hutvā palāyanti.🔽Kaṇṇehi paharitvāti pageva sarānaṃ āgamanasaddaṃ upadhāretvā yathā vego na hoti,
analyzed: dvedhā bhijjati tīrapātikam madditam hutvā padātā hutvā dvedhā hutvā palāyanti  kaṇṇehi paharitvā ati pagā iva sarānam āgamana saddam upadhāretvā yathā vegaḥ na hoti
translated: The army is routed, crushed, and split in two, and the foot soldiers flee in all directions.🔽“By striking with the ears” means by striking with the ears after first determining the sound of the approaching chariot in such a way that the momentum is not lost.

original: evaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā tehi paharitvā pātanaṃ. Paṭihatthipaṭiassātiādinā paccekaṃ pati-saddo
analyzed: evam samuṭṭhāpetvā tehi paharitvā pātanam paṭihatthi paṭiassa ati ādinā paccekam pati saddaḥ
translated: The word “struck” should be construed with each of the following terms.

original: yojetabboti. Dīghāsilaṭṭhiyāti dīghalatāya asilaṭṭhiyā.
analyzed: yojetabbo ti dīgha asi laṭṭhiyā ti dīgha latāya asi laṭṭhiyā
translated: “With the long sword-leafs” means with the long leaves of the sword-leaf plant.

original: Karaṇeti kammakaraṇe. Maññati hatthāroho. Ayamuggaranti tādise kāle gahitamuggaraṃ. Oloketvāti ñāṇacakkhunā disvā, abhiṇhaṃ sampajaññaṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti attho.🔽109. Sasakkanti passituṃ yuttaṃ katvā ussāhaṃ janetvā na karaṇīyaṃ, tādisaṃ niyamato
analyzed: karaṇa iti kamma karaṇe maññati hattha ārohaḥ ayam uggaram ti tādise kāle gahitam uggaram oloketvā iti ñāṇa cakkhunā disvā abhiṇham sampajaññam upaṭṭhapetvā ti attho  sasakkanti passitum yuttam katvā ussāham janetvā na karaṇīyam tādisam niyamataḥ
translated: ‘Instrument’: in the sense of instrumentality. ‘The elephant-driver imagines’: the elephant-driver thinks. ‘This is the time for it’: this is the time for taking up the goad. ‘Looking’: seeing with the eye of knowledge; the meaning is, giving attention again and again to clear comprehension.

original: akattabbaṃ hotīti āha “ekaṃseneva na kātabba”nti. Paṭisaṃhareyyāsīti karaṇato saṅkocaṃ🔽āpajjeyyāsi. Yathābhūto asanto nivatto akaronto nāma hotīti āha “nivatteyyāsi mā🔽kareyyāsī”ti. Anupadeyyāsīti anubalappadāyī bhaveyyāsi. Tenāha “upatthambheyyāsī”ti.
analyzed: a kattabbam hoti iti āha ekaṃsena iva na kātabbanti paṭisaṃhareyyāsi iti karaṇataḥ saṅkocam  āpajjeyyāsi yathābhūtaḥ a santaḥ nivattaḥ a karontaḥ nāma hoti iti āha nivatteyyāsi mā  kareyyāsi iti anupadeyyā asi iti anubala ppadāyī bhaveyyāsi tena āha upatthambheyyāsi iti
translated: ‘Should make an effort’: should generate eagerness to see. ‘It should not be done’: such a thing is invariably not to be done.🔽‘Should turn back’: should turn away from doing it. ‘Should not do’: should not do it. ‘Should not give support’: should not give help. Hence he said ‘should not encourage’.

original: Taṃ pana anubalappadānaṃ upatthambhanaṃ punappunaṃ karaṇamevāti āha “punappunaṃ kareyyāsī”ti.
analyzed: tam pana anubala padānam upatthambhanam punappunam karaṇam eva ati āha punappunam kareyyāsi iti
translated: But that giving of help is encouragement, which is the doing again and again. Hence he said ‘should not do again and again’.

original: Sikkhamānoti taṃyeva adhisīlasikkhaṃ tannissayañca sikkhādvayaṃ sikkhanto sampādento.
analyzed: sikkhamāno ti tam yeva adhi sīla sikkham tad nissayam ca sikkhā dvayam sikkhantaḥ sampādentaḥ
translated: ‘One in training’: one who is training in that same training in the higher virtue and who is accomplishing it by means of the two trainings that have it as their basis.

original: 111. Kittake pana ṭhāneti kittake ṭhāne pavattāni. Avidūre eva pavattānīti dassento
analyzed: kittake pana ṭhāne iti kittake ṭhāne pavattāni avidūre eva pavattāni iti dassento
translated: 111. In what place: in what place they occur. Showing that they occur not far away,

original: “ekasmiṃ purebhatteyeva sodhetabbānī”ti āha. Evañhi tāni susodhitāni honti suparisuddhāni.🔽Paresaṃ appiyaṃ garuṃ gārayhaṃ, yathāvuttaṭṭhānato pana aññaṃ vā kammaṭṭhānamanasikāreneva
analyzed: ekasmin purebhatteya iva sodhetabbāni iti āha evam hi tāni su sodhitāni honti su parisuddhāni  paresam appiyam garum gārayham yathāvutta ṭṭhānataḥ pana aññam vā kammaṭṭhāna manasikārena iva
translated: he said, “They should be purified in one day, even before the morning meal.” For in this way they are well purified, well cleansed.

original: kāyakammādīni parisodhitāni hontīti na gahitaṃ. Paṭighaṃ vāti ettha vā-saddena asamapekkhaṇe
analyzed: kāya kamma ādīni parisodhitāni honti iti na gahitam paṭigham vā ati ettha vā saddena asamapekkhaṇe
translated: But the bodily action, etc., are purified by the mere attention given to the meditation subject, which is not displeasing to others, is weighty, blameless, and not of the kind already mentioned.

original: mohassa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽112. Vuttanayena kāyakammādiparisodhanaṃ nāma idheva, na ito bahiddhāti āha “buddhā…pe…
analyzed: mohassa saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo  vutta nayena kāya kamma ādi parisodhanam nāma idhā iva na itas bahiddhā iti āha buddhāpe
translated: The word “or” in the phrase “or resentment” should be understood to include delusion.🔽The purification of bodily action, etc., is done here, not outside this meditation subject, thus he said “The Buddhas … disciples” and so on. For they are ascetics and brahmans in the true sense of the words.

original: sāvakā vā”ti. Te hi atthato samaṇabrāhmaṇā vāti. Tasmāti yasmā sabbabuddhapaccekabuddhasāvakehi
analyzed: sāvakāḥ vāti te hi atthataḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ vāti tasmā ati yasmā sabba buddha paccekabuddha sāvakehi
translated: Therefore: since the path climbed by all Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples,🔽Rāhula, has been pointed out to you by me,

original: āruḷhamaggo, rāhula, mayā tuyhaṃ ācikkhito, tasmā. Tena anusikkhantena tayā evaṃ
analyzed: āruḷha maggaḥ rāhula mayā tuyham ācikkhito tasmā tena anusikkhantena tayā evam
translated: by you who are training in it.

original: sikkhitabbanti ovādaṃ adāsi. Sesaṃ vuttanayattā suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sikkhitabban ti ovādam adāsi sesam vutta naya ttā su viññeyyam eva
translated: and he gave him the advice. The rest is clear in the way already stated.

original: Ambalaṭṭhikarāhulovādasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the words of the Ambalatthika-Rāhula-Sutta is ended.

original: Samattā.
analyzed: samattā
translated: It is finished.

original: 2. Mahārāhulovādasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Rāhula Sutta

original: 113. Iriyāpathānubandhanenāti iriyāpathagamanānubandhanena, na paṭipattigamanānubandhanena.
analyzed: iriyāpatha anubandhanena ati iriyāpatha gamana anubandhanena na paṭipatti gamana anubandhanena
translated: By following the posture: by following the going of the posture, not by following the practice of the going.

original: Aññameva hi buddhānaṃ paṭipattigamanaṃ aññaṃ sāvakānaṃ. Vilāsitagamanenāti – “dūre🔽pādaṃ na uddharati, na accāsanne pādaṃ nikkhipati, nātisīghaṃ gacchati nātisaṇika”ntiādinā
analyzed: aññam eva hi buddhānam paṭipatti gamanam aññam sāvakānam vilāsita gamanena ati dūre  pādam na uddharati na acca āsanne pādam nikkhipati na ati sīgham gacchati na ati saṇikanti ādinā
translated: For the practice of the going of Buddhas is one thing, that of disciples another.

original: vuttena sabhāvasīlena buddhānaṃ cāturiyagamanena. Tadeva hi sandhāya “pade padaṃ
analyzed: vuttena sabhāva sīlena buddhānam cāturiya gamanena tat eva hi sandhāya pade padam
translated: By the going of the graceful: by the going of the Blessed One, which is endowed with the natural virtue consisting in the way already stated, namely, “He does not lift his foot too far, nor too near; he does not put it down too near, nor too far; he does not go too fast, nor too slow” .🔽For it is that very kind of going that is referred to in the passage, “Placing the foot down first with the sole and then with the whole foot” .

original: nikkhipanto”ti vuttaṃ. Padānupadikoti rāhulattherassapi lakkhaṇapāripūriyā tādisameva
analyzed: nikkhipantoti vuttam padānupadiko ti rāhula ttherassa api lakkhaṇa pāripūriyā tādisam eva
translated: By following the step: by the kind of going that was the same as that of the Elder Rāhula, who had fulfilled the characteristics of a disciple.

original: gamananti yattakaṃ padesaṃ antaraṃ adatvā bhagavato piṭṭhito gantuṃ āraddho, sabbattha
analyzed: gamanam ti yattakam padesam antaram a datvā bhagavataḥ piṭṭhitaḥ gantum āraddhaḥ sabbattha
translated: By the distance: by the distance that he had begun to go behind the Blessed One without leaving the Blessed One out of sight.

original: tameva gamanapadānupadaṃ gacchatīti padānupadiko.
analyzed: tam eva gamana pada anupadam gacchati iti padānupadikaḥ
translated: He goes following the very same steps, thus he is a “footstep-follower.”

original: Vaṇṇanābhūmi cāyaṃ tattha bhagavantaṃ therañca anekarūpāhi upamāhi vaṇṇento “tattha
analyzed: vaṇṇanā bhūmi ca ayam tattha bhagavantam theram ca aneka rūpāhi upamāhi vaṇṇentaḥ tattha
translated: This is the plane of exposition. There the Exalted One, in praising the Elder with many similes, says, “Therein,🔽the Exalted One, like a young elephant that has just come out of the forest,

original: bhagavā”tiādimāha. Nikkhantagajapotako viya virocitthāti padaṃ ānetvā yojanā. Evaṃ
analyzed: bhagavān iti ādim āha nikkhanta gaja potakaḥ viya virocittha iti padam ānetvā yojanā evam
translated: shone. ” The passage is to be brought in and applied in this way.

original: taṃ kesarasīho viyātiādīsupi ānetvā yojetabbaṃ. Tārakarājā nāma cando. Dvinnaṃ candamaṇḍalānantiādi
analyzed: tam kesarasīhaḥ ānetvā yojetabbam tārakarājā nāma candaḥ dvinnam canda maṇḍala ananti ādi
translated: So too, he is like a lion, king of beasts, etc., is to be brought in and applied in this way. The king of stars is the moon. The two moon-discs, etc.,

original: parikappavacanaṃ, buddhāveṇikasantakaṃ viya buddhānaṃ ākappasobhā ahosi, aho sirīsampattīti yojanā.
analyzed: parikappa vacanam buddha āveṇika santakam viya buddhānam ākappa sobhā ahosi aho sirī sampattī iti yojanā
translated: is a figurative expression. The beauty of the Buddhas was like the unique radiance of the Buddhas. What a splendor! What a perfection!🔽They take it up: “We will know later.” One should not expect to understand it right away.

original: Ādiyamānāti gaṇhanti. “Pacchā jānissāmā”ti na ajjupekkhitabbo. Idaṃ na kattabbanti🔽vutteti idaṃ pāṇaatipātanaṃ na kattabbanti vutte idaṃ daṇḍena vā leḍḍunā vā viheṭhanaṃ
analyzed: ādiyamānā iti gaṇhanti pacchā jānissāma ati na ajjupekkhitabbo idam na kattabbanti  vuttā iti idam pāṇa atipātanam na kattabban ti vutte idam daṇḍena vā leḍḍunā vā viheṭhanam
translated: When it is said, “This should not be done,”🔽this killing of living beings should not be done. When it is said, “This should not be done with a stick or a clod,”

original: na kattabbaṃ, idaṃ pāṇinā daṇḍakadānañca antamaso kujjhitvā olokanamattampi na kattabbamevāti
analyzed: na kattabbam idam pāṇinā daṇḍaka dānam ca antamasaḥ kujjhitvā olokana mattam pi na kattabbam eva ati
translated: this harming with a stick or a clod should not be done. When it is said, “This should not be done with a hand, or by giving a stick, or by even looking with anger,”🔽this should not be done.

original: nayasatenapi nayasahassenapi paṭivijjhati, tathā idha tāva sammajjanaṃ kattabbanti
analyzed: naya satena api naya sahassena api paṭivijjhati tathā idha tāva sammajjanam kattabbanti
translated: He penetrates it by a hundred and a thousand means. So too, when it is said here, “The sweeping should be done,”

original: vuttepi tattha paribhaṇḍakaraṇaṃ vihāraṅgaṇasammajjanaṃ kacavarachaḍḍanaṃ vālikāsamakiraṇanti
analyzed: vutte api tattha paribhaṇḍa karaṇam vihāra aṅgaṇa sammajjanam kaca vara chaḍḍanam vālikā sama kiraṇanti
translated: even though the making ready of the site, the sweeping of the courtyard of the monastery, the throwing out of the rubbish, the sprinkling of water, and the smoothing of the sand, etc.,

original: evamādinā nayasatena nayasahassena paṭivijjhati. Tenāha – “idaṃ kattabbanti vuttepi
analyzed: evamādinā naya satena naya sahassena paṭivijjhati tena āha idam kattabbam ti vutte pi
translated: are included in the sweeping, he penetrates it by a hundred and a thousand means. Therefore it is said: “When it is said, ‘This should be done,’

original: eseva nayo”ti. Paribhāsanti tajjanaṃ. Labhāmīti paccāsīsati.
analyzed: paribhāsanti tad janam labhāmi iti
translated: this is the method.” “Reproving” means reproaching. “I will get” means he desires.

original: Sabbametanti sabbaṃ etaṃ mayi labbhamānaṃ sikkhākāmataṃ. Abhiññāyāti jānitvā. Sahāyoti
analyzed: sabbam etat ti sabbam etam mayi labbhamānam sikkhā kāma tam abhiññāya ati jānitvā sahāyaḥ ti
translated: “All this” means all this that is to be got by me, the desire for training. “Having understood” means having known. “Together with”

original: raṭṭhapālattheraṃ sandhāyāha. So hi bhagavatā saddhāpabbajitabhāve etadagge ṭhapito.
analyzed: raṭṭhapāla theram sandhāya āha saḥ hi bhagavatā saddhā pabbajita bhāve etad agge ṭhapitaḥ
translated: means together with the Elder Ratthapala. For he was placed at the head by the Blessed One among those who had gone forth from the home life out of faith.

original: Dhammārakkhoti satthu saddhammaratanānupālako dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko. Pettiyoti cūḷapitā.
analyzed: dhammārakkho ti satthu saddhamma ratana anupālakaḥ dhamma bhaṇḍa āgārikaḥ pettiyaḥ ti cūḷa pitā
translated: “Guardian of the Dhamma” means the protector of the Master’s true Dhamma, the custodian of the Dhamma’s treasure. “Father” means father’s younger brother.

original: Sabbaṃ me jinasāsananti sabbampi buddhasāsanaṃ mayhameva.
analyzed: sabbam me jina sāsanam ti sabbam pi buddha sāsanam mayham eva
translated: “All the Dispensation is mine” means the entire Buddha’s Dispensation is mine.

original: Chandarāgaṃ ñatvāti chandarāgaṃ mama citte uppannaṃ ñatvā. Aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūleti vihārapariyante aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūlaṭṭhāne anucchavike.
analyzed: chanda rāgam ñatvā ati chanda rāgam mama citte uppannam ñatvā aññatarasmin rukkha mūle iti vihāra pariyante aññatarasmin rukkha mūla ṭṭhāne anucchavike
translated: Knowing that there was desire and lust in his mind: knowing that desire and lust had arisen in his mind. In a certain tree-root abode: in a certain tree-root abode that was suitable, within the monastery enclosure.

original: Tadāti aggasāvakehi pasādāpanakāle. Aññakammaṭṭhānāni caṅkamanairiyāpathepi piṭṭhipasāraṇakālepi
analyzed: tadā ti aggasāvakehi pasādāpana kāle añña kammaṭṭhānāni caṅkama nairiyāpathe pi piṭṭhi pasāraṇa kāle pi
translated: Then: at the time of arousing confidence in the chief disciples. Other meditation subjects are successful even when one is walking up and down and when one is lying down,

original: samijjhanti, na evamidanti āha – “idamassa etissā nisajjāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ anucchavika”nti.
analyzed: samijjhanti na evam idam ti āha idam assa etissā nisajjāya kammaṭṭhānam anucchavikan ti
translated: but not so this one, which is why he said: “This meditation subject is suitable to this sitting posture.”

original: Ānāpānassatinti ānāpānassatikammaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Samasīsī hotīti sace samasīsī hutvā na parinibbāyati. Paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti no ce paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti. Khippābhiññoti khippaṃ lahuṃyeva pattabbachaḷabhiñño.
analyzed: āna apāna ssatinti āna apāna ssati kammaṭṭhānam  samasīsī hoti iti sace samasīsī hutvā na parinibbāyati pacceka bodhim sacchikaroti no ce pacceka bodhim sacchikaroti khippa abhiñño ti khippam lahuṃyeva pattabba chaḷ abhiñño
translated: Mindfulness of breathing: the meditation subject of mindfulness of breathing.🔽He becomes equal in status with the Buddhas: if he does not attain Nibbāna sitting down, then he realizes the supreme perfect enlightenment. If he does not do that, then he becomes one of quick understanding.

original: Paripuṇṇāti soḷasasu ākāresu kassacipi atāpanena sabbaso puṇṇā. Subhāvitāti samathabhāvanāya
analyzed: paripuṇṇā ati soḷasasu ākāresu kassaci pi a tāpanena sabbaso puṇṇā su bhāvitā ati samatha bhāvanāya
translated: Fully developed: fully developed in the sixteen aspects, fully developed in the three sills, fully developed in the four jhānas, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications, fully developed in the fourfold and fivefold classifications,

original: vipassanābhāvanāya ca anupubbasampādanena subhāvitā. Gaṇanāvidhānānupubbiyā āsevitattā anupubbaṃ paricitā.
analyzed: vipassanā bhāvanāya ca anupubba sampādanena su bhāvitā gaṇanā vidhāna anupubbiyā āsevita ttā anupubbam paricitā
translated: and it is well developed by the successive accomplishment of insight. It is “well practiced” because it has been practiced in the order of the rules of counting.

original: Omānaṃ vāti avajānanaṃ uññātanti evaṃvidhaṃ mānaṃ vā. Atimānaṃ vāti “kiṃ imehi, mameva ānubhāvena jīvissāmī”ti evaṃ atimānaṃ vā kuto janessatīti.
analyzed: omānam vā ati avajānanam uññātanti evaṃvidham mānam vā atimānam vā ati kim imehi mama eva ānubhāvena jīvissāmi iti evam atimānam vā kutas janessati iti
translated: “Pride” is contempt, haughtiness. “Excessive pride” is thinking, “What are they to me? I will live by my own power.”

original: 114. Visaṅkharitvāti visaṃyutte katvā, yathā saṅgākārena gahaṇaṃ na gacchati, evaṃ
analyzed: visaṅkharitvā ati visaṃyutte katvā yathā saṅga ākārena gahaṇam na gacchati evam
translated: “Without mixing them up”: without mixing them up, without taking them as a unity.🔽The meaning is: “having eaten after separating them.”

original: vinibhuñjitvāti attho. Mahābhūtāni tāva vitthāretu, sammasanūpagattā, asammasanūpagaṃ
analyzed: vinibhuñjitvā ti atthaḥ mahābhūtāni tāva vitthāretu sammasanūpaga ttā a sammasanūpagam
translated: Now, as to the four great primaries: the four great primaries are extended, and the space element is not extended.

original: ākāsadhātuṃ atha kasmā vitthāresīti āha “upādārūpadassanattha”nti. Āpodhātu sukhumarūpaṃ.
analyzed: ākāsadhātum atha kasmai vitthāresi iti āha upādā rūpa dassana ttham ti āpodhātu sukhuma rūpam
translated: Why did he extend the space element? “For the purpose of showing the derived materiality.” The water element is subtle materiality.🔽In the other three, grossness and subtlety are found.

original: Itarāsu oḷārikasukhumatāpi labbhatīti āha “upādārūpadassanattha”nti. Heṭṭhā cattāri
analyzed: itarāsu oḷārika sukhuma tā api labbhati iti āha upādā rūpa dassana thanti heṭṭhā cattāri
translated: “For the purpose of showing the derived materiality” is said.🔽The four great primaries are mentioned below, but not the derived materiality.

original: mahābhūtāneva kathitāni, na upādārūpanti tassa panettha lakkhaṇahāranayena ākāsadassanena
analyzed: kathitāni na tassa pana ittha lakkhaṇa hāra nayena ākāsa dassanena
translated: But the space element is shown here by the method of defining its characteristic.

original: dassitatā veditabbā. Tenāha “iminā mukhena taṃ dassetu”nti. Na kevalaṃ upādārūpaggahaṇadassanatthameva
analyzed: dassita tā veditabbā tena āha iminā mukhena tam dassetum ti na kevalam upādā rūpa ggahaṇa dassana attham eva
translated: The space element is not extended only for the purpose of showing the apprehending of the derivative materiality.

original: ākāsadhātu vitthāritā, atha kho pariggahasukhatāyapīti dassento “apicā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ākāsadhātu vitthāritā atha kho pariggaha sukha tāya api iti dassentaḥ api ca iti ādim āha
translated: But rather for the purpose of showing the ease of apprehending it, he said: “Moreover, etc.”

original: Tattha paricchinditabbassa rūpassa niravasesapariyādānatthaṃ “ajjhattikenā”ti visesanamāha.
analyzed: tattha paricchinditabbassa rūpassa niravasesa pariyādāna attham ajjhattikena ati visesanam āha
translated: Herein, he said “internally” in order to show the purpose of the complete pervasion of the materiality that is to be discerned.

original: Ākāsenāti ākāsadhātuyā gahitāya. Paricchinnarūpanti tāya paricchinditakalāpagatampi
analyzed: ākāsena ati ākāsa dhātuyā tāya
translated: “In the space element”: when the space element is apprehended. “The materiality that is discerned”: the visible-data base, etc., that are discerned by it.

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti vibhūtaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti.
analyzed: pākaṭam hoti vibhūtam hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: It becomes evident, becomes manifest, and appears.

original: Idāni vuttamevatthaṃ sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ gāthāya dasseti. Tassāti upādāyarūpassa. Evaṃ āvibhāvatthanti evaṃ paricchinnatāya ākāsassa vasena vibhūtabhāvatthaṃ. Tanti ākāsadhātuṃ.
analyzed: idāni vutta mevattham sukha ggahaṇa attham gāthāya dasseti tassa ati upādāya rūpassa evam āvi bhāva attham ti evam paricchinna tāya ākāsassa vasena vibhūta bhāva attham tanti ākāsa dhātum
translated: Now, in order to show by a stanza the meaning just stated for the sake of easy memorizing, he said: “That” refers to the derivative materiality. “In this way” refers to the meaning of the manifestation by means of the space that is discerned. “That” refers to the space element.

original: 118. Ākāsabhāvaṃ gatanti catūhi mahābhūtehi asamphuṭṭhānaṃ tesaṃ paricchedakabhāvena
analyzed: ākāsa bhāvam catūhi mahābhūtehi tesam paricchedaka bhāvena
translated: “Has become the space element”: the uncombined state of the four great primaries, which is their delimitation.

original: ākāsanti gahetabbataṃ gataṃ, ākāsameva vā ākāsagataṃ yathā “diṭṭhigataṃ, atthaṅgata”nti
analyzed: ākāsanti gahetabbatam gatam ākāsam eva vā ākāsa gatam yathā diṭṭhi gatam atthaṅgatanti
translated: Space is what has become the object of grasping or it is space itself as “gone to space,” as in the case of “gone to a view” and “gone to perversion” .

original: ca. Ādinnanti imanti taṇhādiṭṭhīhi ādinnaṃ. Tenāha “gahitaṃ parāmaṭṭha”nti. Aññattha
analyzed: ca ādinnam ti imanti taṇhā diṭṭhīhi ādinnam tena āha gahitam parāmaṭṭhanti aññattha
translated: Seized is what is seized by craving and views. Hence he said “grasped at and misapprehended” .

original: kammajaṃ “upādinna”nti vuccati, na tathā idhāti āha “sarīraṭṭhakanti attho”ti. Pathavīdhātuādīsu
analyzed: kamma jam upādinnanti vuccati na tathā idha ati āha sarīraṭṭhakam ti attho ti pathavī dhātu ādīsu
translated: What is born of kamma is called “seized” in the sense of being taken as an object of clinging, but not so here. Hence he said: “The meaning is: present in the body” .

original: vuttanayenevāti mahāhatthipadopame vuttanayadassanaṃ sandhāya vadati.🔽119. Tādibhāvo nāma niṭṭhitakiccassa hoti, ayañca vipassanaṃ anuyuñjati, atha kimatthaṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena iva iti mahā hatthi pada upame vutta naya dassanam sandhāya vadati  ta ādi bhāvaḥ nāma niṭṭhita kiccassa hoti ayaṃ ca vipassanam anuyuñjati atha kimattham
translated: As in the case of the earth element, etc. : he says this referring to the seeing of the method in the Great Forty-Four Discourse .🔽The state of being that is said to be the state of one whose task is done is that of one who is engaged in insight. But what is the purpose of stating the state of being that is the state of one whose task is done?

original: tādibhāvatā vuttāti? Pathavīsamatādilakkhaṇācikkhaṇāhi vipassanāya sukhappavattiatthaṃ.
analyzed: tad ādi bhāva tā vuttā ati pathavī sama tā ādi lakkhaṇa ācikkhaṇāhi vipassanāya sukha ppavatti attham
translated: It is for the purpose of showing that insight is easily accomplished by one who has the characteristics of the state of one whose task is done.🔽Hence he said: “With regard to the desirable and the undesirable, etc.” .

original: Tenāha “iṭṭhāniṭṭhesū”tiādi. Gahetvāti kusalappavattiyā okāsadānavasena pariggahetvā.
analyzed: tena āha iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu itiādi gahetvā iti kusala ppavattiyā okāsa dāna vasena pariggahetvā
translated: Having seized: having taken possession of by giving opportunity for the occurrence of profitable ideas.

original: Na patiṭṭhitoti na nissito na laggo.
analyzed: na patiṭṭhitaḥ ti na nissitaḥ na laggaḥ
translated: Not settled down: not clinging, not adhering.

original: 120. Brahmavihārabhāvanā asubhabhāvanā ānāpānassatibhāvanā ca upacāraṃ vā appanaṃ🔽vā pāpento vipassanāya pādakabhāvāya aniccādisaññāya vipassanābhāvena ussakkitvā
analyzed: brahmavihāra bhāvanā asubha bhāvanā āna apāna sati bhāvanā ca upacāram vā  vā pāpentaḥ vipassanāya pādaka bhāvāya anicca ādi saññāya vipassanā bhāvena ussakkitvā
translated: The development of the divine abidings, foulness, and mindfulness of breathing, whether it reaches access or absorption,🔽is a condition for the arising of insight by being a proximate cause for it, and it is a condition for the attainment of the supramundane states by being a proximate cause for the path.

original: maggapaṭipāṭiyā arahattādhigamāya hotīti “mettādibhāvanāya pana hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Yattha🔽katthaci sattesu saṅkhāresu ca paṭihaññanakilesoti āghātabhāvameva vadati ñāyabhāvato
analyzed: magga paṭipāṭiyā arahatta adhigamāya hoti iti mettā ādi bhāvanāya pana hoti iti vuttam yattha  katthaci sattesu saṅkhāresu ca āghāta bhāvam eva vadati ñāya bhāvataḥ
translated: But the condition for the arising of insight is the perception of impermanence, etc., which is the footing for insight.🔽The “perversion of perception” is the perversion of perception of permanence, etc., in the form of the perception of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of view” is the perversion of view of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: aññesampi. Asmimānoti rūpādike paccekaṃ ekajjhaṃ gahetvā “ayamahamasmī”ti evaṃ pavattamāno.🔽121. Idaṃ kammaṭṭhānanti ettha gaṇanādivasena āseviyamānā assāsapassāsā yogakammassa
analyzed: aññesam pi asmimānaḥ ti rūpa ādike paccekam ekajjham gahetvā ayam aham asmi iti evam pavattamānaḥ  idam kammaṭṭhānam ti ettha gaṇanā ādi vasena āseviyamānāḥ assāsa passāsāḥ yoga kammassa
translated: The “perversion of the mind” is the perversion of the mind of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of lust” is the perversion of lust of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of conceit” is the perversion of conceit of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of views” is the perversion of views of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of approval” is the perversion of approval of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of inattention” is the perversion of inattention to impermanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of negligence” is the perversion of negligence in regard to impermanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of the defilements” is the perversion of the defilements of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of the fetters” is the perversion of the fetters of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.🔽The “perversion of the taints” is the perversion of the taints of permanence, etc., in the case of the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: patiṭṭhānatāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ. Tattha pana tathāpavatto manasikāro bhāvanā. Ettha ca🔽tasseva therassa bhagavatā bahūnaṃ kammaṭṭhānānaṃ desitattā caritaṃ anādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānāni
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna tāya kammaṭṭhānam tattha pana tathā pavattaḥ manasikāraḥ bhāvanā ettha ca 🔽tassa iva therassa bhagavatā bahūnam kammaṭṭhānānam desita ttā caritam an ādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānāni
translated: The “perversion of perception” is the perversion of perception of permanence,

original: sabbesaṃ puggalānaṃ sappāyānīti ayamattho siddho, atisappāyavasena pana kammaṭṭhānesu
analyzed: sabbesam puggalānam sappāyāni iti ayam attho siddhaḥ ati sappāya vasena pana kammaṭṭhānesu
translated: The meaning of “suitable for all” is established, but as to the extreme suitability of the meditation subjects,🔽

original: vibhāgakathā kathitāti veditabbā.🔽Mahārāhulovādasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: vibhāga kathā kathitā iti veditabbā
translated: The meaning of “suitable for all” is established, but the exposition of the meditation subjects should be understood as given in the Commentaries according to what is suitable for each person.🔽The explanation of the meaning of “the brief exhortation to Rāhula” is ended.

original: 3. Cūḷamālukyasuttavaṇṇanā🔽122. Evaṃ ṭhapitānīti “sassato loko”tiādinayappavattāni diṭṭhigatāni aniyyānikatāya🔽na byākātabbāni na kathetabbāni, evaṃ ṭhapanīyapakkhe ṭhapitāni ceva niyyānikasāsane
analyzed: cūḷamālukya sutta vaṇṇanā  evam ṭhapitāni iti sassataḥ loko ti ādi naya ppavattāni diṭṭhi gatāni aniyyānika tāya  na byākātabbāni na kathetabbāni evam ṭhapanīya pakkhe ṭhapitāni ca iva niyyānika sāsane
translated: The exposition of the shorter discourse on the Māluṅkyas

original: chaḍḍanīyatāya paṭikkhittāni ca, apicettha atthato paṭikkhepo eva byākātabbato. Yathā🔽eko kammakilesavasena itthattaṃ āgato, tathā aparopi aparopīti satto tathāgato vuccatīti
analyzed: chaḍḍanīya tāya paṭikkhittāni ca api ca ittha atthataḥ paṭikkhepaḥ eva byākātabbataḥ yathā  ekaḥ kamma kilesa vasena itthattam āgato tathā aparaḥ api aparaḥ api iti satto tathāgataḥ vuccati iti
translated: “Thus set forth”: the views that occur in the form “The world is eternal” are not to be expounded because they are not conducive to the goal of going forth from the world. They are not to be expounded, not to be talked about. They are set forth in the category of things to be set forth, and they are rejected in the true Dhamma, which is conducive to the goal, because they are to be abandoned. And here the rejection is in the sense of the refusal to expound.🔽“The world is eternal”: just as one person has come to this state of existence because of his kamma and defilements, so too another person and another. Thus the world is called “eternal” .

original: āha – “tathāgatoti satto”ti. Taṃ abyākaraṇaṃ mayhaṃ na ruccatīti yadi sassato loko,
analyzed: āha tathāgato ti satto ti tam a byākaraṇam mayham na ruccati iti yadi sassataḥ loko
translated: “The world is not eternal”: the world is not eternal in the sense of being permanent.

original: sassato lokoti, asassato loko, asassato lokoti jānāmāti byākātabbameva, yaṃ pana
analyzed: sassataḥ loko ti a sassataḥ loko a sassataḥ loko ti jānāma ati byākātabbam eva yam pana
translated: “The world is eternal” or “The world is not eternal,” or “The world is finite” or “The world is infinite,” or “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul is one thing and the body another,” or “After death a Tathāgata exists” or “After death a Tathāgata does not exist” or “After death a Tathāgata both exists and does not exist” or “After death a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist” should be acknowledged as a matter that is not to be expounded.

original: ubhayathā abyākaraṇaṃ, taṃ me cittaṃ na ārādheti ajānanahetukattā abyākaraṇassa.
analyzed: ubhayathā a byākaraṇam tam me cittam na ārādha iti a jānana hetuka tā a byākaraṇassa
translated: “The world is eternal” and “The world is not eternal” are to be answered thus: “The world is not eternal.” But the non-answering in both cases is not acceptable to me, because the reason for non-answering is ignorance.

original: Tenāha – “ajānato kho pana apassato etadeva ujukaṃ, yadidaṃ na jānāmi na passāmī”ti.🔽Sassatotiādīsu sassatoti sabbakāliko, nicco dhuvo avipariṇāmadhammoti attho. So hi🔽diṭṭhigatikehi lokīyanti ettha puññapāpatabbipākā, sayaṃ vā tabbipākākarādibhāvena
analyzed: tena āha a jānataḥ kho pana a passataḥ etat eva ujukam yat idam na jānāmi na passāmi iti  sassatā tiādīsu sassatā ti sabbakālikaḥ niccaḥ dhuvaḥ a vipariṇāma dhammaḥ ti attho saḥ hi  diṭṭhigatikehi ettha puñña pāpa tabbipākā sayam vā tad bipāka ākara ādi bhāvena
translated: Therefore it is said: “For one who does not know and does not see, it is proper to say: ‘I do not know, I do not see.’“🔽In the case of “eternal” and so on, “eternal” means existing in all three periods of time. The meaning is: “permanent, stable, not subject to change.” For the world is called “loka” in the sense that it is “wandered through” by beings who are themselves wandering, or in the sense that it is “wandered through” by the results of merit and demerit, or in the sense that it is “wandered through” by the results of kamma that are not separated from the doer.

original: aviyuttehi lokīyatīti lokoti adhippeto. Etena cattāropi sassatavādā dassitā honti.
analyzed: a viyuttehi lokīyati iti etena cattāro api sassata vādāḥ dassitāḥ honti
translated: By this, the four eternalist doctrines are shown.

original: Asassatoti na sassato, anicco addhuvo bhedanadhammoti attho, asassatoti ca sassatabhāvapaṭikkhepena
analyzed: a sassatoti na sassataḥ aniccaḥ addhuvaḥ bhedana dhammo ti attho a sassataḥ ti ca sassata bhāva paṭikkhepena
translated: “Not eternal” means not eternal, impermanent, unstable, subject to destruction. The meaning is: “not eternal.” And by the negation of the state of being eternal,

original: ucchedo dīpitoti sattapi ucchedavādā dassitā honti. Antavāti parivaṭumo paricchinnaparimāṇo,
analyzed: ucchedaḥ dīpito ti satta pi uccheda vādāḥ dassitāḥ honti
translated: annihilation is shown. Thus the seven annihilationist doctrines are shown. “Finite” means limited, circumscribed, having boundaries.

original: asabbagatoti attho. Tena “sarīraparimāṇo, aṅguṭṭhaparimāṇo, yavaparimāṇo paramāṇuparimāṇo
analyzed: a sabba gataḥ ti attho tena sarīra parimāṇaḥ aṅguṭṭha parimāṇaḥ yava parimāṇaḥ paramāṇu parimāṇaḥ
translated: the meaning is, not all-pervading. Thus the theories that the self is the size of the body, the size of a thumb, the size of a grain of rice, the size of an atom,

original: attā”ti evamādivādā dassitā honti.
analyzed: attā ati evamādi vādāḥ dassitāḥ honti
translated: are shown.

original: Tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti tathāgato jīvo attā maraṇato imassa kāyassa bhedato paraṃ
analyzed: tathāgataḥ param tathāgataḥ jīvaḥ attā maraṇataḥ imassa kāyassa bhedataḥ param
translated: The Tathāgata exists after death: the Tathāgata, after death, exists, is, is found, after the breakup and dissolution of this body.

original: uddhaṃ hoti atthi saṃvijjatīti attho. Etena sassatabhāvamukhena soḷasa saññīvādā,
analyzed: uddham hoti atthi saṃvijjati iti etena sassata bhāva mukhena soḷasa saññīvādā
translated: The meaning is that he exists. Thus the sixteen views of the eternalist type,

original: aṭṭha asaññīvādā, aṭṭha ca nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā dassitā honti. Na hotīti natthi na🔽upalabbhati. Etena ucchedavādo dassito hoti. Apica hoti ca na ca hotīti atthi natthi
analyzed: aṭṭha asaññī vādāḥ aṭṭha ca nevasaññīnāsaññīvādāḥ dassitāḥ honti na hoti iti natthi na  upalabbhati etena uccheda vādaḥ dassitaḥ hoti apica hoti ca na ca hoti iti atthi natthi
translated: the eight views of the annihilationist type, and the eight views of the neither-existence-nor-non-existence type are shown.🔽Does not exist: is not, is not found. Thus the annihilationist view is shown.🔽Moreover, both exists and does not exist: is and is not. Thus the view of partial-eternalism is shown.

original: cāti. Etena ekaccasassatavādo dassito. Neva hoti na na hotīti pana iminā amarāvikkhepavādo
analyzed: ca ati etena ekacca sassata vādaḥ dassitaḥ na iva hoti na na hoti iti pana iminā amarā vikkhepa vādo
translated: Neither exists nor does not exist: is neither and is not. Thus the escapist view is shown.

original: dassitoti veditabbaṃ. Bhagavatā pana aniyyānikattā anatthasaṃhitāni imāni dassanānīti
analyzed: dassitaḥ ti veditabbam bhagavatā pana aniyyānika ttā anattha saṃhitāni imāni dassanāni iti
translated: But the Exalted One has shown these views as not leading to emancipation and as unprofitable.

original: tāni na byākatāni, taṃ abyākaraṇaṃ sandhāyāha ayaṃ thero “taṃ me na ruccatī”ti. Sikkhaṃ
analyzed: tāni na byākatāni tam a byākaraṇam sandhāya āha ayam thero tam me na ruccati iti sikkham
translated: He did not comment on them. Referring to that non-commenting, the elder said, “That does not appeal to me.”

original: paṭikkhipitvā yathāsamādinnasikkhaṃ pahāya.
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā yathā samādinna sikkham pahāya
translated: Having renounced the training, having given up the training he had undertaken.

original: 125. Tvaṃ neva yācakoti ahaṃ bhante bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ carissāmītiādinā. Na yācitakoti tvaṃ mālukyaputta mayi brahmacariyaṃ carātiādinā.🔽126. Parasenāya ṭhitena purisena. Bahalalepanenāti bahalavilepanena. Mahāsupiyādi
analyzed: tvam na iva aham bhante bhagavati brahmacariyam carissāmi itiādinā na tvam mālukyaputta mayi brahmacariyam cara atiādinā  para senāya ṭhitena purisena bahala lepanena ati bahala vilepanena mahā supiya ādi
translated: “You are not a supplicant” means “Venerable sir, I will lead the holy life under the Blessed One.” “You are not one who has asked” means “I will lead the holy life under you, Malunkyaputta.”

original: sabbo muduhidako veṇuviseso saṇho. Maruvāti makaci. Khīrapaṇṇinoti khīrapaṇṇiyā,🔽yassā chindanamatte paṇṇe khīraṃ paggharati. Gacchanti gacchato jātaṃ sayaṃjātagumbato
analyzed: sabbaḥ muduhidakaḥ veṇu visesaḥ saṇhaḥ maruvā ti khīrapaṇṇinā iti khīrapaṇṇiyā  chindana matte paṇṇe khīram paggharati gacchanti gacchataḥ jātam sayaṃjāta gumbataḥ
translated: By a man standing in the enemy’s army. With a thick ointment means with a thick unguent. The whole of the soft bamboo, beginning with the great bamboo, is soft. The maruvaka is the makaci. The milk-leaf tree is the milk-leaf plant,

original: gahitanti adhippāyo. Sithilahanu nāma dattā kaṇṇo pataṅgo. Etāya diṭṭhiyā sati na
analyzed: gahitam ti adhippāyo sithilahanu nāma dattā kaṇṇaḥ pataṅgo etāya diṭṭhiyā sati na
translated: the leaf of which exudes milk when cut. The self-originated creeper is the creeper that grows by itself. The meaning is that it is taken from that. The loose-jawed is the datta-kaṇṇo pataṅgo . When this view exists, he is not a true bhikkhu.

original: hotīti “sassato loko”ti etāya diṭṭhiyā sati maggabrahmacariyavāso na hoti, taṃ pahāya eva pattabbato.
analyzed: hoti iti sassataḥ loko ti etāya diṭṭhiyā sati magga brahmacariya vāsaḥ na hoti tam pahāya eva pattabbato
translated: “There is no” : with the view “The world is eternal” there is no abiding in the life of purity consisting in the path, because it is to be attained only by abandoning that view.

original: 127. Attheva jātītiādinā etā diṭṭhiyo paccekampi saṃsāraparibrūhanā kaṭasivaḍḍhanā nibbānavibandhanāti dasseti.🔽128. Tasmātihāti idaṃ aṭṭhāne uddhaṭaṃ, ṭhāneyeva pana “vuttapaṭipakkhanayena veditabba”nti🔽imassa parato katvā saṃvaṇṇetabbaṃ. Attano phalena araṇīyato anugantabbato kāraṇampi
analyzed: attha iva jātī iti ādinā etāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ paccekam pi saṃsāra paribrūhanā kaṭasivaḍḍhanā nibbāna vibandhanā ti dasseti  tasmā atihā ti idam aṭṭhāne uddhaṭam ṭhāne iya iva pana vutta paṭipakkha nayena veditabbanti  imassa paratas katvā saṃvaṇṇetabbam attanaḥ phalena araṇīyataḥ anugantabbataḥ kāraṇam pi
translated: . “There is self” , etc., show that these views, even individually, extend the round of rebirths, increase the cemetery, and obstruct the attainment of Nibbāna.🔽. “Therefore” : this is the explanation of the word “therefore” in the text, which is given in the wrong place. It should be given after “should be understood in the opposite sense to that” .

original: “attho”ti vuccatīti āha “kāraṇanissita”nti. Tenāha “brahmacariyassa ādimattampī”ti.🔽Pubbapadaṭṭhānanti paṭhamārambho. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.🔽Cūḷamālukyasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.🔽4. Mahāmālukyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: atthaḥ iti vuccati iti āha kāraṇa nissitanti tena āha brahmacariyassa ādimattam pi iti  pubba padaṭṭhānam ti paṭhama ārambhaḥ sesam su viññeyyam eva  cūḷamālukya sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The reason is called “meaning” because it is to be sought and followed for the sake of its fruit.

original: 129. Oraṃ vuccati kāmadhātu, tattha pavattiyā saṃvattanato oraṃ bhajantīti orambhāgiyāni,
analyzed: oram vuccati kāmadhātu tattha pavattiyā saṃvattanataḥ oram bhajanti iti orambhāgiyāni
translated: Therefore it is said to be “dependent on the reason.” Hence it is said: “the mere beginning of the life of purity” .🔽“The basis of the first term” is the first beginning.

original: heṭṭhimamaggavajjhatāya orambhāge heṭṭhākoṭṭhāse bhajantīti orambhāgiyāni ka-kārassa🔽ya-kāraṃ katvā. Tenāha “heṭṭhākoṭṭhāsikānī”tiādi. Kammunā hi vaṭṭena ca dukkhaṃ saṃyojentīti
analyzed: heṭṭhima magga vajjhatāya orambhāge heṭṭhā koṭṭhāse bhajanti iti orambhāgiyāni kakārassa  yakāram katvā tena āha heṭṭhā koṭṭhāsikāni itiādi kammunā hi vaṭṭena ca dukkham saṃyojenti iti
translated: They are called lower fetters because they are to be abandoned by the lower path. They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.🔽They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.🔽They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.

original: saṃyojanāni, orambhāgiyasaññitāni saṃyojanāni yassa appahīnāni, tasseva vaṭṭadukkhaṃ.
analyzed: saṃyojanāni orambhāgiya saññitāni saṃyojanāni yassa appahīnāni tassa iva vaṭṭa dukkham
translated: The round of kamma and the round of results are suffering. They fetter to that, thus they are fetters.

original: Yassa pana tāni pahīnāni, tassa taṃ natthīti. Appahīnatāya anusetīti ariyamaggena
analyzed: yassa pana tāni pahīnāni tassa tam natthi iti appahīna tāya anuseti iti ariya maggena
translated: They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.

original: asamucchinnatāya kāraṇalābhe sati uppajjati, appahīnabhāvena anuseti. Anusayamāno
analyzed: asamucchinnatāya kāraṇa lābhe sati uppajjati appahīna bhāvena anuseti anusayamānaḥ
translated: They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.🔽The round of kamma and the round of results are suffering. They fetter to that, thus they are fetters.🔽They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.🔽They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.

original: saṃyojanaṃ nāma hotīti anusayattaṃ pharitvā pavattamāno pāpadhammo yathāvuttenatthena
analyzed: saṃyojanam nāma hoti iti pharitvā pavattamānaḥ pāpa dhammaḥ yathāvuttena atthena
translated: The round of kamma and the round of results are suffering. They fetter to that, thus they are fetters.

original: saṃyojanaṃ nāma hoti. Etena yadi pana anusayato saṃyojanaṃ pavattaṃ, tathāpi ye te
analyzed: saṃyojanam nāma hoti etena yadi pana anusayato saṃyojanam pavattam tathā api ye te
translated: They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.

original: kāmarāgādayo “anusayā”ti vuccanti, teyeva bandhanaṭṭhena saṃyojanānīti dasseti.
analyzed: kāma rāga ādayaḥ anusayā ti vuccanti teyeva bandhana ṭṭhena saṃyojanāni iti dasseti
translated: They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.🔽The round of kamma and the round of results are suffering. They fetter to that, thus they are fetters.🔽They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.🔽They are called lower because they are at the lower end of the three rounds of existence. They are called fetters because they fetter to suffering by means of the round of kamma and the round of results.🔽The round of kamma and the round of results are suffering. They fetter to that, thus they are fetters.🔽They are called lower fetters because they are fetters and they are lower.

original: Evaṃ santepīti yadeva orambhāgiyasaṃyojanaṃ bhagavatā pucchitaṃ, tadeva therenapi
analyzed: evam santaḥ ipi iti yat eva orambhāgiya saṃyojanam bhagavatā pucchitam tat eva therena api
translated: Still, although the Elder answered the question asked by the Blessed One, namely, “What is the fetter here? ”

original: vissajjitaṃ, tathāpi ayaṃ laddhi sannissayā. Tattha dosāropanāti dassetuṃ “tassa
analyzed: vissajjitam tathā api ayam laddhi sannissayā tattha dosa āropanā ti dassetum tassa
translated: by the same word “fetter,” nevertheless the opinion is that the Blessed One’s intention was based on the underlying tendency. Herein, the word “assigning” in the words “assigning the fault to his doctrine” is a term for teaching.

original: vāde”tiādi vuttaṃ. Samudācārakkhaṇeyevāti pavattikkhaṇe eva. Na hi sabbe vattamānā🔽kilesā saṃyojanatthaṃ pharantīti adhippāyo. Tenāti tena kāraṇena, tathāladdhikattāti
analyzed: vāda itiādi vuttam samudācāra kkhaṇe yeva āti pavatti kkhaṇe eva na hi sabbe vattamānā  kilesā saṃyojana attham pharanti iti adhippāyaḥ tena ati tena kāraṇena tathā laddhika ttā ati
translated: The meaning is: at the moment of manifestation. For the intention is that not all defilements that are present can be said to fetter by the meaning of the word “fetter.”🔽For that reason, for that cause, is what is meant. The construction is: he thought “I shall teach the Dhamma.”

original: attho. Cintesi “dhammaṃ desessāmī”ti yojanā. Attano dhammatāyevāti ajjhattāsayeneva.
analyzed: attho cintesi dhammam desessāmi iti yojanā attanaḥ dhamma tāya iva ati ajjhatta āsayena iva
translated: By his own nature: by his own inner disposition.

original: Visaṃvāditāti satthu cittassa anārādhanena vivecitā. Evamakāsi evaṃ dhammaṃ desāpesi.🔽130. Sakkāyadiṭṭhipariyuṭṭhitenāti pariyuṭṭhānasamatthasakkāyadiṭṭhikena. Tathābhūtañca
analyzed: visaṃvāditā ati satthu cittassa anārādhanena vivecitā evam akāsi evam dhammam desāpesi  sakkāya diṭṭhi pariyuṭṭhitena ati pariyuṭṭhāna samattha sakkāya diṭṭhikena tathābhūtam ca
translated: He deceived: he deceived by not pleasing the Teacher’s mind. He did so: he taught the Dhamma in this way.🔽By the perversions of perception and so on: by the perversions of perception, etc., that are the perversions of perception, etc., and by the perversions of perception, etc., that are the causes of the perversions of perception, etc.

original: cittaṃ tāya diṭṭhiyā vigayhitaṃ ajjhotthaṭañca nāma hotīti āha “gahitena abhibhūtenā”ti.
analyzed: cittam tāya diṭṭhiyā vigayhitam ajjhotthaṭam ca nāma hoti iti āha gahitena abhibhūtena ati
translated: By the perversions of perception, etc., that are the perversions of perception, etc., is what is meant.🔽By the perversions of perception, etc., that are the causes of the perversions of perception, etc., is what is meant.

original: Diṭṭhinissaraṇaṃ nāma dassanamaggo tena samucchinditabbato, so pana nibbānaṃ āgamma
analyzed: diṭṭhi nissaraṇam nāma dassana maggo tena samucchinditabbataḥ saḥ pana nibbānam āgamma
translated: “Escape from views” is the path of seeing, since it is by that that they are to be cut off. But that cuts them off by means of Nibbāna.

original: taṃ samucchindati, tasmā vuttaṃ “diṭṭhinissaraṇaṃ nibbāna”nti. Avinoditā anīhaṭāti
analyzed: tam samucchindati tasmai vuttam diṭṭhi nissaraṇam nibbānanti a vinoditā anīhaṭā ati
translated: That is why it is said, “Escape from views is Nibbāna.”🔽By the two phrases “not yet abandoned” and “not yet given up” he says that they have not yet been abandoned by cutting them off.

original: padadvayenapi samucchedavasena appahīnattaṃyeva vadati. Aññaṃ saṃyojanaṃ añño anusayoti🔽vadanti, sahabhāvo nāma aññena hoti. Na hi tadeva tena sahāti vuccatīti tesaṃ adhippāyo.
analyzed: pada dvayena api samuccheda vasena vadati aññam saṃyojanam aññaḥ anusayaḥ ti  vadanti sahabhāvaḥ nāma aññena hoti na hi tat eva tena saha ati vuccati iti tesam adhippāyaḥ
translated: They say that the fetter is one thing and the underlying tendency another.🔽The meaning of “co-existent” is that it is with another. For it is not said that it is itself with itself. This is their intention.

original: Aññenāti atthato aññena. Avatthāmattato yadipi avayavavinimutto samudāyo natthi,🔽avayavo pana samudāyo na hotīti so samudāyato añño evāti sakkā vattunti yathāvuttassa
analyzed: aññena ati atthataḥ aññena avatthā mattataḥ yadi pi avayava vinimuttaḥ samudāyaḥ natthi  avayavaḥ pana samudāyaḥ na hoti iti so samudāyataḥ aññaḥ eva ati sakkā vattunti yathā vuttassa
translated: “With another” : in the sense of different in meaning. Although there is no collection apart from the parts,🔽nevertheless the part is not the collection. So it can be said that it is different from the collection.🔽Suspecting that the answer given above is not conclusive, he raises another alternative, “But it might be said” , etc.,

original: parihārassa appāṭihīrakataṃ āsaṅkitvā pakkhantaraṃ āsallitaṃ “athāpi siyā”tiādinā.
analyzed: parihārassa appāṭihīrakatam āsaṅkitvā pakkhantaram āsallitam atha api siyā tiādinā
translated: because there are answers to the alternatives.

original: Pakkhantarehi parihārā hontīti yathāvuttañāyenapi añño puriso athāpi siyā, ayaṃ panettha
analyzed: pakkha antarehi parihārāḥ honti iti yathāvutta ñāyena api aññaḥ puriso atha api siyā ayam pana ittha
translated: “It might be said” , etc., is said in the following way: “Although it is so, still it might be said that the man is different.

original: añño dosoti āha “yadi tadevā”tiādi. Athāpi siyā tuyhaṃ yadi parivitakko īdiso yadi🔽tadeva saṃyojanantiādi. Imamatthaṃ sandhāyāti paramatthato so eva kileso saṃyojanamanusayo
analyzed: aññaḥ doso ti āha yadi tat eva atiādi atha api siyā tuyham yadi parivitakkaḥ īdisaḥ yadi  tat eva saṃyojana nti ādi imam attham sandhāya ati paramatthato saḥ eva kileso saṃyojanam anusayo
translated: “Another fetter” is said. If you think thus, “If that is so, then the fetter is the same as the underlying tendency,” then the meaning intended is this: in the ultimate sense the defilement itself is the fetter, the underlying tendency, and the shackle; but in the conventional sense there is a distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned.”🔽The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.🔽The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.🔽The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.

original: ca, bandhanatthaappahīnatthānaṃ pana attheva bhedoti imamatthaṃ sandhāya.🔽132. Tacacchedo viya samāpatti kilesānaṃ samāpattivikkhambhanassa sāracchedassa anusayassa🔽dūrabhāvato. Pheggucchedo viya vipassanā tassa āsannabhāvato. Evarūpā puggalāti abhāvitasaddhādibalatāya
analyzed: ca bandhana ttha appahīna tthānam pana atthā iva bhedaḥ ti imam attham sandhāya  taca chedaḥ viya samāpatti kilesānam samāpatti vikkhambhanassa sāra chedassa anusayassa  dūra bhāvataḥ pheggu chedaḥ viya vipassanā tassa āsanna bhāvataḥ evarūpā abhāvita saddhā ādi bala tāya
translated: The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.🔽The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.🔽The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.

original: dubbalanāmakāyā puggalā, yesaṃ sakkāyanirodhāya…pe… nādhimuccati. Evaṃ daṭṭhabbāti🔽yathā so dubbalako puriso, evaṃ daṭṭhabbo so puriso gaṅgāpāraṃ viya sakkāyapāraṃ
analyzed: dubbala nāmakāyā puggalāḥ yesam na adhimuccati evam daṭṭhabbā ati  yathā saḥ dubbalakaḥ purisaḥ evam daṭṭhabbaḥ saḥ purisaḥ gaṅgā pāram viya sakkāya pāram
translated: The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path, while the underlying tendency is abandoned by the mundane and supramundane paths.

original: gantuṃ asamatthattā. Vuttavipariyāyena sukkapakkhassa attho veditabbo.
analyzed: gantum asamattha ttā vutta vipariyāyena sukka pakkhassa atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning intended is this: the distinction in the meaning of “abandoned” and “not abandoned” is due to the fact that the fetter is abandoned by the supramundane path

original: 133. Upadhivivekenāti iminā upadhivivekāti karaṇe nissakkananti dasseti, upadhivivekāti
analyzed: upadhi vivekena ati iminā upadhi vivekā ati karaṇe nissakkana nti dasseti upadhi vivekā ati
