translated: Either going forth on the day of attaining arahatship or parinibbāna — this method is not common to all.

original: āha “bhūmadevatā pana tiṭṭhantī”ti. Tattha kāraṇavacanaṃ “nilīyanokāsassa atthitāyā”ti.
analyzed: āha bhūmadevatā pana tiṭṭhanti iti tattha kāraṇa vacanam nilīyana ukāsassa atthi tāya ati
translated: “But the earth-deities stand by,” he said. Herein, the reason is stated thus: “because there is a place for them to lie down in.”

original: Araññapabbatādipavivekaṭṭhānaṃ nilīyanokāso. Sesakāmabhaveti kāmaloke. Laḷitajanassāti
analyzed: arañña pabbata ādi paviveka ṭṭhānam nilīyana ukāso sesa kāma bhave iti kāma loke laḷita janassa ati
translated: A place of seclusion such as a forest, a mountain, etc., is a place for them to lie down in. In the rest of the sense-desire realm: in the sense-desire world. Of those who delight in pleasure:

original: ābharaṇālaṅkāranaccagītādivasena vilāsayuttajanassa.
analyzed: ābharaṇa alaṅkāra nacca gīta ādi vasena vilāsa yutta janassa
translated: of those who delight in pleasure by way of ornaments, adornments, dancing, singing, etc.

original: Sopīti “so aññatra ekenā”ti vutto sopi. Karato na karīyati pāpanti evaṃ na kiriyaṃ
analyzed: so api iti saḥ aññatra ekena ati vuttaḥ saḥ api karataḥ na pāpam ti evam na kiriyam
translated: That one too: that one too who is referred to thus: “except for one.” He does not prevent the doing of evil: he does not prevent the doing of evil in this way:

original: paṭibāhati. Yadi attānaṃyeva gahetvā katheti, atha kasmā mahāsatto tadā ājīvakapabbajjaṃ
analyzed: paṭibāhati yadi gahetvā katheti atha kasmai mahāsatto tadā ājīvakapabbajjam
translated: “Do not do it.” If he spoke thus, taking himself as an example, then why did the Great Being

original: upagacchīti āha “tadā kirā”tiādi. Tassapīti na kevalaṃ aññesaṃ eva pāsaṇḍānaṃ, tassapi.
analyzed: upagacchi iti āha tadā kirāti ādi tassa api iti na kevalam aññesam eva pāsaṇḍānam tassa api
translated: go forth as an Ājīvaka ascetic at that time? He said: “At that time, it is said,” etc. That one too: not only of other sectarians, but also of that one.

original: Vīriyaṃ na hāpesīti tapojigucchavādaṃ samādiyitvā ṭhito virāgatthāya taṃ samādiṇṇavattaṃ
analyzed: vīriyam na ha apesi iti tapaḥ jiguccha vādam samādiyitvā ṭhitaḥ virāga tthāya tam samādiṇṇa vattam
translated: He did not slacken his energy: standing firm after taking up the doctrine of austerity and self-mortification, he did not abandon that conduct which he had undertaken for the purpose of becoming dispassionate;

original: na pariccaji, satthusāsanaṃ na chaḍḍesi. Tenāha – “kiriyavādī hutvā sagge nibbattatī”ti.
analyzed: na pariccaji satthu sāsanam na chaḍḍesi tena āha kiriya vādī hutvā sagge nibbattati iti
translated: he did not cast off the Teacher’s instruction. Therefore it is said: “One who holds the doctrine of kamma is reborn in heaven.”

original: Tevijjavacchasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.🔽2. Aggivacchasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tevijjavaccha sutta vaṇṇanāya līna ttha ppakāsanā samattā  aggivaccha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “subtle” is ended.🔽The discussion of the world’s finitude and infinitude

original: 187. Lokassa sassatatāpavattipaṭikkhepavasena pavatto vādo ucchedavādo eva hotīti🔽sassataggāhābhāve ucchedaggāhabhāvato puna paribbājakena “asassato loko”ti vadantena
analyzed: lokassa sassata tā pavatti paṭikkhepa vasena pavattaḥ vādaḥ uccheda vādaḥ eva hoti iti  sassata ggāha abhāve uccheda ggāha bhāvataḥ puna paribbājakena a sassataḥ lokaḥ iti vadantena
translated: is a doctrine of annihilationism.

original: ucchedaggāho pucchito, bhagavatāpi so eva paṭikkhittoti āha “dutiye nāhaṃ ucchedadiṭṭhiko”ti.🔽Antānantikādivasenāti ettha antānantikaggahaṇena antavā loko anantavā lokoti imaṃ
analyzed: uccheda ggāhaḥ pucchitaḥ bhagavatā api saḥ eva paṭikkhittaḥ ti āha dutiye na aham uccheda diṭṭhiko ti  anta ānantika ādi vasena āti ettha anta anantika ggahaṇena antavā lokaḥ anantavā loko ti imaṃ
translated: Since the doctrine of annihilationism is implied by the absence of the doctrine of eternalism, the wanderer again asked the Exalted One whether he held the doctrine of annihilationism, saying, “Is the world finite?” The Exalted One replied, “I do not hold the doctrine of annihilationism in the second case either.”🔽The doctrine of finitude and infinitude, etc.

original: vādadvayamāha. Ādi-saddena “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra”ntiādivādacatukkaṃ saṅgaṇhāti, itaraṃ🔽pana dvayaṃ sarūpeneva gahitanti. Paṭikkhepo veditabboti “tatiye nāhaṃ antavādiṭṭhiko,
analyzed: vāda dvayam āha ādi saddena tam jīvam tam sarīra iti ādi vāda catukkam saṅgaṇhāti itaram  pana dvayam sarūpena iva gahitanti paṭikkhepaḥ veditabbaḥ ti tatiye na aham antavādiṭṭhiko
translated: The doctrine of finitude and infinitude is included in the first two cases. The doctrine of finitude is the view that the world is finite, and the doctrine of infinitude is the view that the world is infinite. The word “etc.” includes the fourfold doctrine of identity, etc. The other two doctrines are included in the first two cases.🔽The rejection of the doctrines of finitude and infinitude, etc.

original: catutthe nāhaṃ anantavādiṭṭhiko”ti evamādinā paṭikkhepo veditabbo. “Hoti tathāgato
analyzed: catutthe na aham ananta vādiṭṭhikaḥ ti evamādinā paṭikkhepaḥ veditabbaḥ hoti tathāgato
translated: The rejection of the doctrines of finitude and infinitude, etc., should be understood as follows: “I do not hold the doctrine of finitude in the third case either, nor the doctrine of infinitude in the fourth case either.”

original: paraṃ maraṇā”ti ayampi sassatavādo, so ca kho aparantakappikavasena, “sassato loko”ti
analyzed: param ayam pi sassata vādo so ca kho aparantakappika vasena sassataḥ
translated: “The world is infinite” is also eternalism, but it is so in the sense of the past, while the other is so in the sense of the future.🔽“The soul and the body are the same” is eternalism, but it is so in the sense of the future, while the other is so in the sense of the past.🔽“The soul is one thing and the body another” is also eternalism, but it is so in the sense of the past, while the other is so in the sense of the future.🔽“The Tathagata exists after death” is eternalism, but it is so in the sense of the future, while the other is so in the sense of the past.

original: pana pubbantakappikavasenāti ayametesaṃ viseso. “Na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā”ti
analyzed: pana pubbanta kappika vasena ati ayam etesam viseso na hoti tathāgataḥ param maraṇā ti
translated: “The Tathagata does not exist after death” is annihilationism, but it is so in the sense of the living being, while the other is so in the sense of formations.🔽“The Tathagata both exists and does not exist after death” is eternalism and annihilationism, but it is so in the sense of the future and the past respectively.🔽“The Tathagata neither exists nor does not exist after death” is eternalism and annihilationism, but it is so in the sense of the past and the future respectively.🔽“The world is not eternal” is annihilationism, but it is so in the sense of the living being, while the other is so in the sense of formations.

original: ayampi ucchedavādo, so ca kho sattavasena, “asassato loko”ti pana sattasaṅkhāravasenāti vadanti.🔽189. Sappatibhayaṃ uppajjanato saha dukkhenāti sadukkhaṃ. Tenāha “kilesadukkhenā”tiādi.🔽Tesaṃyevāti kilesadukkhavipākadukkhānaṃyeva. Saupaghātakanti sabādhaṃ. Saupāyāsanti🔽saparissamaṃ saupatāpaṃ sapīḷaṃ. Sapariḷāhanti sadarathaṃ.🔽Kiñci diṭṭhigatanti imā tāva aṭṭha diṭṭhiyo mā hontu, atthi pana, bho gotama, yaṃ
analyzed: ayam pi uccheda vādo saḥ ca kho satta vasena a sassataḥ loko ti pana satta saṅkhāra vasena ati vadanti  sa patibhayam uppajjanataḥ saha dukkhena ati sa dukkham tena āha kilesa dukkhena atiādi  tesam yeva ati kilesa dukkha vipāka dukkhānam yeva sa aupaghātakam ti sa bādham sa upāyāsanti  sa parissamam sa aupatāpam sa pīḍam sa pariḍā hanti  kiñci diṭṭhi gatanti imāḥ tāva aṭṭha diṭṭhiyaḥ mā hontu atthi pana bho gotama yaṃ
translated: “The world is not not-eternal” is also annihilationism, but it is so in the sense of formations, while the other is so in the sense of the living being.

original: kiñci diṭṭhigataṃ gahitaṃ. Na hi tāya diṭṭhiyā vinā kañci samayaṃ pavattetuṃ yujjatīti
analyzed: kiñci diṭṭhi gatam gahitam na hi tāya diṭṭhiyā vinā kañci samayam pavattetum yujjati iti
translated: “The world is finite” is eternalism, but it is so in the sense of the future, while the other is so in the sense of the past.🔽“The world is infinite”

original: adhippāyena pucchati. Apaviddhanti samucchedappahānavasena chaḍḍitaṃ. Paññāya diṭṭhanti
analyzed: adhippāyena pucchati apaviddhanti samuccheda ppahāna vasena chaḍḍitam paññāya diṭṭhanti
translated: He asks with a purpose. “Cast off”: abandoned by way of cutting off and giving up. “Seen with wisdom”:

original: vipassanāpaññāsahitāya maggapaññāya bhagavatā paṭividdhaṃ. Yattha uppajjanti, taṃ
analyzed: vipassanā paññā sahitāya magga paññāya bhagavatā paṭividdham yattha uppajjanti tam
translated: seen by the Blessed One with the wisdom of the path accompanied by insight wisdom. “Where they arise”:

original: sattaṃ mathenti sammaddantīti mathitāti āha “mathitānanti tesaṃyeva vevacana”nti.
analyzed: sattam mathenti sammaddanti iti mathitā ati āha tesam yā iva
translated: “They burn” : they burn the being. “They are burned”: they are a synonym for those .

original: Kañci dhammanti rūpadhammaṃ arūpadhammaṃ vā. Anupādiyitvāti aggahetvā.
analyzed: kañci dhammanti rūpa dhammam arūpa dhammam vā an upādiyitvā ati aggahetvā
translated: “Any idea”: a form idea or a formless idea. “Without clinging to”: without grasping.🔽“Does not come to be reckoned as”: does not come to be reckoned as this or that. “It is not proper” :

original: 190. Na upetīti saṅkhaṃ na gacchatīti atthoti āha “na yujjatī”ti. Anujānitabbaṃ siyā
analyzed: na upeti iti saṅkham na gacchati iti atthaḥ iti āha na yujjati iti anujānitabbam siyā
translated: it is not proper that it should be reckoned as this or that. “Should be allowed” :

original: anupādāvimuttassa kañcipi uppattiyā abhāvato. “Evaṃ vimuttacitto na upapajjatī”ti
analyzed: anupādāvimuttassa kañcipi uppattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ evam vimutta cittaḥ na upapajjati iti
translated: because there is no arising of anything for one liberated by non-clinging. “With mind liberated thus, he does not come to be reckoned” :

original: kāmañcetaṃ sabhāvapavedanaṃ parinibbānaṃ, eke pana ucchedavādino “mayampi ‘satto
analyzed: kāmam ca itam sabhāva pavedanam parinibbānam eke pana uccheda vādinaḥ mayam pi satto
translated: although this is the natural parinibbāna, still some annihilationists say, “We too say that a being does not come to be reckoned in the future,

original: āyatiṃ na upapajjatī’ti vadāma, samaṇo gotamopi tathā vadatī”ti ucchedabhāveyeva
analyzed: āyatim naḥ upapajjati iti vadāma samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ api tathā vadati iti
translated: and the recluse Gotama too says thus,” and they misrepresent the annihilationists’ doctrine as the doctrine of the Blessed One.

original: patiṭṭhahissanti, tasmā bhagavā “na upapajjatīti kho vaccha na upetī”ti āha. “Upapajjatī”ti
analyzed: patiṭṭhahissanti tasmai bhagavā na upapajjati iti kho vaccha na upeti iti āha upapajjati iti
translated: “They will not be established,” so the Blessed One said, “Vaccha, he does not come to be reborn.”

original: pana vutte sassatameva gaṇheyyāti yojanā. Sesadvayepi eseva nayo. Appatiṭṭhoti ucchedavādādivasena
analyzed: pana vutte sassatam eva gaṇheyya ati yojanā sesa dvaye pi esā iva nayaḥ appatiṭṭhaḥ ti uccheda vāda ādi vasena
translated: But if he were to say, “He comes to be reborn,” they would take it to mean eternalism. The same method applies to the other two cases.🔽“Not established” : devoid of establishment by way of annihilationism, etc.

original: patiṭṭhārahito. Anālamboti tesaṃyeva vādānaṃ olambārammaṇassa abhāvena anālambo.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā rahitaḥ anālambo ti tesam yeva vādānam olamba ārammaṇassa abhāvena anālambo
translated: “Without support” : without a support for leaning, since there is no object for leaning on those views.

original: Sukhapavesanaṭṭhānanti tesaññeva vādānaṃ sukhapavesanokāsaṃ mā labhatūti. Ananuññāya
analyzed: sukha pavesana ṭṭhānanti tesaṃ eva vādānam sukha pavesana ukāsam mā labhatu iti an anuññāya
translated: “No foothold” : let them not get a foothold for the easy entry into those views.

original: ṭhatvāti “na upapajjatī”tiādinā anujānitabbāya paṭiññāya ṭhānahetu. Anuññampīti anujānitabbampi
analyzed: ṭhatvā iti na upapajjati iti ādinā anujānitabbāya paṭiññāya ṭhāna hetu anuññam pi iti anujānitabbam pi
translated: “Without acquiescence” : without a reason for standing by the admission that should be acquiesced in, namely, “He does not come to be reborn,” etc.🔽“Even if acquiesced in” : even if it should be acquiesced in.🔽He rejects the second question. But the Dhamma is the principle of conditionality in meaning.

original: dutiyapañhaṃ paṭikkhipi. Pariyatto pana dhammo atthato paccayākāro evāti āha “dhammoti
analyzed: dutiya pañham paṭikkhipi pariyattaḥ pana dhammo atthataḥ paccaya ākāraḥ eva ati āha dhammo ti
translated: “The Dhamma” : the principle of conditionality.

original: paccayākāradhammo”ti. Aññattha payogenāti imamhā niyyānikasāsanā aññasmiṃ micchāsamaye
analyzed: paccaya ākāra dhammo ti aññattha payogena ati imamhā niyyānika sāsanā aññasmin micchā samaye
translated: “In another context” : in another wrong context outside this Dispensation, which leads out .

original: pavattappayogena, aniyyānikaṃ vividhaṃ micchāpaṭipattiṃ paṭipajjantenāti attho. “Aññavādiyakenā”tipi
analyzed: pavatta ppayogena aniyyānikam vividham micchā paṭipattim paṭipajjantena ati atthaḥ aññavādiyakena atipi
translated: By the occurrence of the application of the word “only” the meaning is: “while practicing the various kinds of wrong practice that do not lead to the goal.”

original: pāṭho, paccayākārato aññākāradīpakaācariyavādaṃ paggayha tiṭṭhantenāti attho.
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ paccaya ākārataḥ añña ākāra dīpaka ācariya vādam paggayha tiṭṭhantena ati atthaḥ
translated: The reading “aññavādiyakenā” is also found, which means: “while standing in opposition to the teachers’ doctrine, which reveals the mode of the conditions in a mode other than that.”

original: 191. Appaccayoti anupādāno, nirindhanoti attho.🔽192. Yena rūpenāti yena bhūtupādādibhedena rūpadhammena. Taṃ rūpaṃ tappaṭibaddhasaṃyojanappahānena
analyzed: appaccayaḥ ti anupādānaḥ nirindhanaḥ ti attho  yena rūpena ati yena bhūtu pāda ādi bhedena rūpa dhammena tam rūpam tad paṭibaddha saṃyojana ppahānena
translated: “Without remainder” means without clinging, without fuel.🔽“By which form”: by which form-thing classed as the four primary elements, etc. That form has been abandoned by the Tathāgata whose cankers are destroyed by the abandoning of the fetters bound up with that form, and has become incapable of arising.

original: khīṇāsava-tathāgatassa pahīnaṃ anuppattidhammataṃ āpannaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ pāḷiyaṃ “anuppādadhamma”ntiādi.🔽Aññesaṃ jānanāya abhāvaguṇatāya guṇagambhīro. “Ettakā guṇā”ti pamāṇaṃ gaṇhituṃ na
analyzed: khīṇāsava tathāgatassa pahīnam an uppatti dhamma tam āpannam tena vuttam pāḷiyam an uppāda dhamma nti ādi  aññesam jānanāya abhāva guṇa tāya guṇa gambhīraḥ ettakā guṇāti pamāṇam gaṇhitum na
translated: Therefore it is said in the text: “It has become incapable of arising.”

original: sakkuṇeyyo. “Īdisā etassa guṇā”ti pariyogāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya duppariyogāḷhoti.
analyzed: sakkuṇeyyaḥ īdisā etassa guṇāti pariyogāhitum a sakkuṇeyya tāya duppariyogāḷhaḥ ti
translated: It is profound in virtue of the quality of being beyond the scope of others’ knowledge. It is immeasurable, for it cannot be measured by thinking: “There are so many virtues.” It is hard to fathom, for it cannot be fathomed by thinking: “His virtues are like this.”

original: Dujjānoti agādhatāya gambhīro “ettakāni udakaḷhakasatānī”tiādinā pametuṃ na sakkāti
analyzed: agādha tāya ettakāni uda kaḷhaka satāni iti ādinā pametum na sakkā ati
translated: It is hard to penetrate, for it is profound in the sense of being unfathomable. It cannot be measured by thinking: “There are so many hundred thousand gallons of water.”

original: appameyyo, tato eva dujjāno. Evamevānti yathā mahāsamuddo gambhīro appameyyo dujjāno,
analyzed: appameyyaḥ tatas eva dujjānaḥ evam eva anti yathā mahā samuddaḥ gambhīraḥ appameyyaḥ dujjānaḥ
translated: So too, the one who is free from cankers is like the great ocean in that he is deep, immeasurable, and difficult to fathom in terms of his special qualities.

original: evameva khīṇāsavopi guṇavasena, tasmā ayaṃ rūpādiṃ gahetvā rūpītiādivohāro bhaveyya,🔽parinibbutassa pana tadabhāvā tathā paññāpetuṃ na sakkā, tato taṃ ārabbha upapajjatītiādi
analyzed: evam eva khīṇa āsavaḥ api guṇa vasena tasmai ayam rūpa ādim gahetvā rūpī iti ādi vohāraḥ  parinibbutassa pana tad abhāvā tathā paññāpetum na sakkā tatas tam ārabbha upapajjati itiādi
translated: Therefore, the expression “he is possessed of form” and so on would be applicable to him if he were to apprehend form, etc.🔽But because he is not so, he cannot be described in this way. Therefore, it would not be proper to say that he is reborn in dependence on that.

original: na yujjeyya. Yathā pana vijjamāno eva jātavedo byattena purisena nīyamāno puratthimādidisaṃ🔽gatoti vucceyya, na nibbuto, evaṃ khīṇāsavopīti dassento “evamevā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: na yujjeyya yathā pana vijjamānaḥ eva jātavedaḥ byattena purisena nīyamānaḥ puratthima ādidisam  gataḥ iti vucceyya na nibbutaḥ evam khīṇāsavaḥ api iti dassentaḥ evam eva iti ādim āha
translated: Just as the fire that exists is said to have gone to the east, etc., when it is carried there by a strong man, and is not said to have been extinguished,🔽so too is the one who is free from cankers.🔽As regards the word “impermanence,” the apprehension of impermanence indicates the absence of essence.

original: Aniccatāti ettha aniccatāgahaṇaṃ asāranidassanaṃ. Tena yathā so sālarukkho sākhāpalāsādiasārāpagamena🔽suddho sāre patiṭṭhito, evamayaṃ dhammavinayo sāsavasaṅkhātaasāravigamena lokuttaradhammasāre
analyzed: anicca tā ti ettha anicca tā gahaṇam asāra nidassanam tena yathā saḥ sāla rukkhaḥ sākhā palāsa ādi asāra apagamena  suddhaḥ sāre patiṭṭhitaḥ evam ayam dhamma vinayaḥ sa āsava saṅkhāta asāra vigamena lokuttara dhamma sāre
translated: By this he shows that just as that sāla tree, by the disappearance of its branches, leaves, etc.,

original: patiṭṭhitoti dasseti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: patiṭṭhitaḥ ti dasseti sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: is established in its essence, so too is this Dhamma and Discipline established in the supramundane essence of the Dhamma by the disappearance of the essence of the world known as the taints. The rest is easily intelligible.

original: Aggivacchasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: aggivaccha sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “vaccha” in the Aggivacchagotta Sutta is finished.

original: 3. Mahāvacchasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Discourse on Vaccha

original: 193. Saha kathā etassa atthīti sahakathī, “mayaṃ pucchāvasena tumhe vissajjanavasenā”ti🔽evaṃ sahapavattakathoti attho. Etasseva kathitāni, tattha paṭhame vijjāttayaṃ desitaṃ,
analyzed: saha kathā etassa atthi iti sahakathī mayam pucchā vasena tumhe vissajjana vasena ati  evam saha pavatta kathā uti attho etassa iva kathitāni tattha paṭhame vijjā ttayam desitam
translated: “One who has a discussion” is a discussant; the meaning is, one who has a discussion going on together, as in the words, “We ask, you answer.”🔽The three knowledges are taught in the first sutta,

original: dutiye agginā dassitanti tevijjavacchasuttaṃ aggivacchasuttanti nāmaṃ visesetvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dutiye agginā dassitan ti tevijja vaccha suttam aggi vaccha suttam ti nāmam visesetvā vuttam
translated: and fire in the second. Thus the sutta on the three knowledges is distinguished by the name “Aggivacchagotta Sutta.”

original: Sīghaṃ laddhiṃ na vissajjenti, yasmā saṅkhārānaṃ niyatoyaṃ vināso anaññasamuppādo,
analyzed: sīgham laddhim na vissajjenti yasmā saṅkhārānam niyataḥ ayam vināsaḥ anañña samuppādo
translated: They do not let go of their gain quickly, because this destruction of formations is certain, not subject to another origination.

original: hetusamuppannāpi na cirena nijjhānaṃ khamanti, na lahuṃ. Tenāha “vasātela …pe… sujjhantī”ti.
analyzed: hetu samuppannā api na cirena nijjhānam khamanti na lahum tena āha sujjhanti iti
translated: Though they originate from a cause, they do not last long, they do not last even a little while. Therefore it is said: “The waters in the channels … are purified.”

original: Pacchimagamanaṃ ñāṇassa paripākaṃ gatattā. Yaṭṭhiṃ ālambitvā udakaṃ tarituṃ otaranto
analyzed: pacchima gamanam ñāṇassa paripākam gata ttā yaṭṭhim ālambitvā udakam taritum otaranto
translated: The going to the west is the culmination of knowledge. A man who enters the water to cross it by holding on to a stick

original: puriso “yaṭṭhiṃ otaritvā udake patamāno”ti vutto. Kammapathavasena vitthāradesananti
analyzed: purisaḥ yaṭṭhim otaritvā udake patamāno ti vuttaḥ kammapatha vasena vitthāra desanam ti
translated: is said to “enter the water holding on to a stick.” The detailed teaching by way of the courses of kamma

original: saṃkhittadesanaṃ upādāya vuttaṃ. Tenāha “mūlavasena cetthā”tiādi. Vitthārasadisāti
analyzed: upādāya vuttam tena āha mūla vasena ca itthā atiādi vitthāra sadisā iti
translated: and this is said with reference to the teaching in brief. Hence he said: “Herein, the teaching in brief is the root” . “Like the detailed teaching” :

original: kammapathavasena idha desitadesanāva mūlavasena desitadesanaṃ upādāya vitthārasadisā.
analyzed: kamma patha vasena mūla vasena desita desanam upādāya vitthāra sadisā
translated: the teaching here in terms of the courses of kamma is like the detailed teaching with reference to the root.

original: Vitthāradesanā nāma natthīti na kevalaṃ ayameva, atha kho sabbāpi buddhānaṃ nippariyāyena🔽ujukena niravasesato vitthāradesanā nāma natthi desanāñāṇassa mahāvisayatāya karaṇasampattiyā
analyzed: vitthāra desanā nāma natthi iti na kevalam ayam eva atha kho sabbā api buddhānam nippariyāyena  ujukena niravasesataḥ vitthāra desanā nāma natthi desanā ñāṇassa mahā visaya tāya karaṇa sampattiyā
translated: There is no detailed teaching: not only this, but there is no detailed teaching in the sense of a complete, unreserved, and unrestricted teaching by the Buddhas.🔽For the knowledge of teaching has a vast domain, and the knowledge of omniscience is of great potency because of the perfection of its cause.

original: ca tajjāya mahānubhāvattā sabbaññutaññāṇassa. Sabbaññutaññāṇasamaṅgitāya hi avasesapaṭisambhidānubhāvitāya
analyzed: ca tajjāya mahā anubhāva ttā sabbaññu taññāṇassa sabbaññu taññāṇa samaṅgi tāya hi avasesa paṭisambhidā anubhāvitāya
translated: For it is by the possession of the knowledge of omniscience, by the influence of the other analytical knowledges,

original: aparimitakālasambhatañāṇasambhārasamudāgatāya kadācipi parikkhayānarahāya anaññasādhāraṇāya
analyzed: aparimita kāla sambhata ñāṇa sambhāra samudāgatāya kadācipi parikkhaya ana rahāya anañña sādhāraṇāya
translated: and by the attainment of the requisites of knowledge accumulated over an immeasurable period of time that the Buddhas, who are endowed with the analytical knowledge of ready speech, which is never exhausted, which is not shared by others,

original: paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāya pahūtajivhāditadanurūparūpakāyasampattisampadāya vitthāriyamānā
analyzed: paṭibhāna paṭisambhidāya pahūta jivhā ādi tad anurūpa rūpa kāya sampatti sampadāya vitthāriyamānā
translated: and which is accompanied by the perfection of the physical body with its preeminent tongue, etc.,

original: bhagavato desanā kathaṃ parimitā paricchinnā bhaveyya, mahākāruṇikatāya pana bhagavā🔽veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ tattha tattha parimitaṃ paricchinnaṃ katvā niṭṭhapeti. Ayañca
analyzed: bhagavataḥ desanā katham parimitā paricchinnā bhaveyya mahā kāruṇika tāya pana bhagavā  veneyya ajjhāsayā anurūpam tattha tattha parimitam paricchinnam katvā niṭṭhapeti ayaṃ ca
translated: How could the Blessed One’s teaching be limited and defined? But because of his great compassion,🔽the Blessed One defines it in this way and that in accordance with the dispositions of those who need training. And this

original: attho mahāsīhanādasuttena dīpetabbo. Sabbaṃ saṃkhittameva attajjhāsayavasena akathetvā
analyzed: atthaḥ mahāsīhanāda suttena dīpetabbo sabbam saṃkhittam eva a kathetvā
translated: meaning should be illustrated by the Mahāsīhanāda Sutta . For the whole of that sutta is given without any omission in order to show the dispositions of those who need training,

original: bodhaneyyapuggalajjhāsayavasena desanāya niṭṭhāpitattā. Na cettha dhammasāsanavirodho
analyzed: bodhaneyya puggala jjhāsaya vasena desanāya niṭṭhāpita ttā na ca ittha dhamma sāsana virodho
translated: and it is concluded by the teaching in order to show the True Idea. And there is no contradiction here with the True Idea and Discipline,

original: pariyāyaṃ anissāya yathādhammaṃ dhammānaṃ bodhitattā sabbalahuttā cāti.
analyzed: pariyāyam a nissāya yathādhammam dhammānam bodhita ttā sabbala huttā ca ati
translated: for the True Idea is shown in accordance with the True Idea by means of the method of interpretation. And it is the most important.

original: 194. Satta dhammā kāmāvacarā sampattasamādānaviratīnaṃ idhādhippetattā.
analyzed: satta dhammā kāmāvacarā sampatta samādāna viratīnam idha adhippeta ttā
translated: Seven ideas are of the sense sphere because the kinds of success and undertaking and abstention intended here are of the sense sphere.

original: Aniyametvāti “sammāsambuddho, sāvako”ti vā niyamaṃ visesena akatvā. Attānameva…pe… veditabbaṃ, tathā hi paribbājako “tiṭṭhatu bhavaṃ gotamo”ti āha.
analyzed: aniyametvā ti sammāsambuddhaḥ sāvakaḥ iti vā niyamam visesena a katvā veditabbam tathā hi paribbājakaḥ tiṭṭhatu bhavam gotamaḥ iti āha
translated: Without defining: without making a distinction by saying ‘ Fully Enlightened One ’ or ‘ disciple ’. He should understand it by himself … for the wanderer said ‘ Let the Reverend Gotama remain seated ’.

original: 195. Satthāva arahā hoti paṭipattiyā pāripūribhāvato. Tasmiṃ byākateti tasmiṃ “ekabhikkhupi sāvako”tiādinā suṭṭhu pañhe kathite.
analyzed: arahā hoti paṭipattiyā pāripūri bhāvato tasmin byākatā iti tasmin suṭṭhu pañhe kathite
translated: When that was spoken: when that question was well asked thus, “Even one bhikkhu disciple of mine … “

original: 196. Sampādakoti paṭipattisampādako.
analyzed: sampādakaḥ ti paṭipatti sampādakaḥ
translated: The one who perfects: the one who perfects the practice.

original: 197. Sekhāya vijjāyāti sekhalakkhaṇappattāya maggapaññāya sātisayaṃ katvā karaṇavasena
analyzed: sekhāya vijjāya ati sekha lakkhaṇa ppattāya magga paññāya sa atisayam katvā karaṇa vasena
translated: The knowledge of the learner: the knowledge of the path, which has reached the characteristic of being a learner, is so described because it is done with excess.

original: vuttā, phalapaññā pana tāya pattabbattā kammabhāvena vuttā. Tenāha “heṭṭhimaphalattayaṃ
analyzed: vuttā phala paññā pana tāya pattabba ttā kamma bhāvena vuttā tena āha heṭṭhima phala ttayam
translated: But the knowledge of fruition is described as the function because it is to be reached by that . That is why it is said, “The three lower fruitions are to be reached by that” .

original: pattabba”nti. Imaṃ panettha aviparītamatthaṃ pāḷito eva viññāyamānaṃ appaṭivijjhanato
analyzed: pattabbanti imam pana ittha aviparītam attham pāḷitaḥ eva viññāyamānam a paṭivijjhanato
translated: But because he does not understand that the correct meaning here is to be discerned from the text itself,

original: vitaṇḍavādī “yāvatakaṃ sekhena pattabbaṃ, anuppattaṃ taṃ mayā”ti vacanalesaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: vitaṇḍa vādī yāvatakam sekhena pattabbam an uppattam tam mayā ati vacana lesam gahetvā
translated: the one who argues takes the wording “What is to be reached by the learner, that has been reached by me”🔽and says, “The path of arahatship has been reached by him too.”

original: “arahattamaggopi anena pattoyevā”ti vadati. Evanti idāni vuccamānāya gāthāya.
analyzed: arahatta maggaḥ upi anena pattaḥ yā iva iti vadati evam ti idāni vuccamānāya gāthāya
translated: Thus: in the verse now to be spoken.

original: Kilesāni pahāya pañcāti pañcorambhāgiyasaṃyojanasaṅkhāte saṃkilese pahāya pajahitvā,
analyzed: kilesāni pahāya pañca ati pañca urambhāgiya saṃyojana saṅkhāte saṃkilese pahāya pajahitvā
translated: Having abandoned the five defilements: having abandoned, having got rid of, the defilements called the five lower fetters,

original: pahānahetu vā. Paripuṇṇasekhoti sabbaso vaḍḍhitasekhadhammo. Aparihānadhammoti aparihānasabhāvo.
analyzed: pahāna hetu vā paripuṇṇa sekhaḥ ti sabbasas vaḍḍhita sekha dhammo a parihāna dhammo ti a parihāna sabhāvaḥ
translated: The “non-regressing type” is one who has the nature of not regressing.🔽For one who has no regression in virtue, etc., which are the factors of the path,

original: Na hi yassa phātigatehi sīlādidhammehi parihāni atthi, samādhimhi paripūrakāritāya
analyzed: na hi yassa atthi samādhimhi paripūra kāri tāya
translated: has attained mastery over the mind through the fulfilment of concentration.

original: cetovasippatto. Tenāha “samāhitindriyo”ti. Aparihānadhammattāva ṭhitatto.
analyzed: tena āha samāhiti indriya uti
translated: Therefore it is said, “his faculties are concentrated.” And because he is of the non-regressing type, he is “composed.”

original: Anāgāminā hi asekhabhāvāvahā dhammā paripūretabbā, na sekhabhāvāvahāti so ekantaparipuṇṇe
analyzed: anāgāminā hi asekha bhāva āvahā dhammā paripūretabbā na sekha bhāva āvahā ati so ekanta paripuṇṇe
translated: For the non-returner, the factors that lead to the state of the non-trainer must be fulfilled, but not the factors that lead to the state of the trainer. Therefore he is called a “fully developed trainer”

original: sekho vutto. Etaṃ na buddhavacananti “maggo bahucittakkhaṇiko”ti etaṃ vacanaṃ na
analyzed: sekhaḥ vuttaḥ etam na buddha vacanan ti maggaḥ bahu citta kkhaṇikaḥ ti etam vacanam na
translated: This is not the word of the Buddha. The statement “The path is of many moments” is not

original: buddhavacanaṃ anantarekantavipākadānato, bahukkhattuṃ pavattane payojanābhāvato ca
analyzed: buddha vacanam anantara ekanta vipāka dānataḥ bahu kkhattum pavattane payojana abhāvato ca
translated: the word of the Buddha, because it does not give immediate results and because there is no purpose in its occurrence many times.

original: lokuttarakusalassa, “samādhimānantarikaññamāhu, na pāraṃ diguṇaṃ yantī”ti evamādīni
analyzed: lokuttara kusalassa samādhim ānantarikaññam āhu na pāram diguṇam yanti iti evamādīni
translated: The sutta passages such as “The path is immediate, they say, not twice-born, not going beyond”

original: suttapadāni etassatthasādhakāni. Orambhāgiyasaṃyojanappahānena sekkhadhammaparipūribhāvassa
analyzed: sutta padāni orambhāgiya saṃyojana ppahānena sekkha dhamma paripūri bhāvassa
translated: prove the meaning of this. The fact that the fulfilment of the training factors is due to the abandoning of the fetters pertaining to the lower realms

original: vuttatāya attho tava vacanena virujjhatīti. Assa āyasmato vacchassa.🔽198. Abhiññā vā kāraṇanti yañhi taṃ tatra tatra sakkhibhabbatāsaṅkhātaṃ iddhividhapaccanubhavanādi,
analyzed: vutta tāya atthaḥ tava vacanena virujjhati iti assa āyasmataḥ vacchassa  abhiññā vā kāraṇam ti yat hi tam tatra tatra sakkhibhabba tā saṅkhātam iddhividha paccanubhavana ādi
translated: The meaning of what you have said is contradicted by what has been said.🔽The reason is higher knowledge: for the reason for the direct-experience of the various kinds of supernormal power, etc., is higher knowledge,

original: tassa abhiññā kāraṇaṃ. Atha iddhividhapaccanubhavanādi abhiññā, evaṃ sati abhiññāpādakajjhānaṃ
analyzed: tassa abhiññā kāraṇam atha iddhividha paccanubhavana ādi abhiññā evam sati abhiññā pādaka jhānam
translated: which is called “the state of being able to do” here and there. But if the direct-experience of the various kinds of supernormal power, etc., is higher knowledge, then the jhāna that is the basis for the higher knowledge

original: kāraṇaṃ. Avasāne chaṭṭhābhiññāya pana arahattaṃ. Ettha ca yasmā paṭhamasutte āsavakkhayo
analyzed: kāraṇam avasāne chaṭṭha abhiññāya pana arahattam ettha ca yasmā paṭhama sutte āsava kkhayo
translated: is the reason. But in the case of the sixth higher knowledge, that is, the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers, it is Arahantship that is the reason.

original: adhippeto, āsavā khīṇā eva, na puna khepetabbā, tasmā tattha “yāvadevā”ti na vuttaṃ.
analyzed: adhippetaḥ āsavā khīṇāḥ eva na puna khepetabbā tasmā tattha yāvat eva ati na vuttam
translated: And here in the first case the destruction of the cankers is intended, and since the cankers are destroyed and need not be destroyed again, “only as long as …” is not said.

original: Idha phalasamāpatti adhippetā, sā ca punappunaṃ samāpajjīyati, tasmā “yāvadevā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Tato eva hi “arahattaṃ vā kāraṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Tañhi “kudāssu nāmāhaṃ tadāyatanaṃ
analyzed: idha phala samāpatti adhippetā sā ca punappunam samāpajjīyati tasmai yāvat eva ati  vuttam tatas eva hi arahattam vā kāraṇam ti vuttam tat hi kudāssu nāma aham tad āyatanam
translated: But here the attainment of fruition is intended, and that is entered upon again and again, so “only as long as …” is said.

original: upasampajja viharissāmi, yadariyā etarahi upasampajja viharantī”ti anuttaresu vimokkhesu
analyzed: upasampajja viharissāmi yadariyāḥ etarahi upasampajja viharanti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu
translated: And that is why it is said that Arahantship is the reason. For that is said thus: “When now shall I enter upon and dwell in that attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception that noble ones of today enter upon and dwell in?” in the unsurpassed liberations

original: pihaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā abhiññā nibbattentassa kāraṇaṃ, tayidaṃ sabbasādhāraṇaṃ na hotīti
analyzed: piham upaṭṭhapetvā abhiññā nibbattentassa kāraṇam tayidam sabba sādhāraṇam na hoti iti
translated: The reason why he developed the higher knowledge after arousing longing is not common to all.

original: sādhāraṇavasena naṃ dassento “arahattassa vipassanā vā”ti āha.
analyzed: sādhāraṇa vasena nam dassentaḥ arahattassa vipassanā vā ti āha
translated: So, in order to show what is common to all, he said: “The insight of an Arahant” .

original: 200. Paricaranti nāma vippakatabrahmacariyavāsattā. Pariciṇṇo hoti sāvakena nāma🔽satthu dhamme kattabbā paricariyā sammadeva niṭṭhāpitattā. Tenāha “iti…pe… thero
analyzed: paricaranti nāma vippakata brahmacariya vāsattā pariciṇṇaḥ hoti sāvakena nāma  satthu dhamme kattabbā paricariyā sammad eva niṭṭhāpita ttā tena āha itipe thero
translated: “They ministered to him” : because they lived the life of celibacy to its conclusion. “He was ministered to by a disciple” :

original: evamāhā”ti. Tesaṃ guṇānanti tesaṃ asekkhaguṇānaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: evam āha ati tesam guṇānam ti tesam asekkha guṇānam sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: because he had completed the duties of ministering to the Teacher’s Dhamma. Therefore he said: “Thus … the Elder said” . “Their special qualities” : their qualities of those beyond training. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Mahāvacchasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
translated: The elucidation of the meaning of the brief statement in the Mahāvacchagotta Sutta is ended.

original: 4. Dīghanakhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽201. Khananaṃ khataṃ, sūkarassa khataṃ ettha atthīti sūkarakhatā, sūkarassa vā imasmiṃ
analyzed: dīghanakha sutta vaṇṇanā  khananam khatam sūkarassa khatam ettha atthi iti sūkara khatā sūkarassa vai imasmin
translated: The Long-Nails Sutta🔽“The Long-Nails’s” : the Long-Nails’s is that of a pig, or

original: buddhuppāde paṭhamaṃ khataṃ upādāya sūkarakhatā, tāya. Evaṃnāmaketi evaṃ itthiliṅgavasena
analyzed: buddhuppāde paṭhamam khatam upādāya sūkara khatā tāya evaṃnāmakā iti evam itthi liṅga vasena
translated: the Long-Nails’s is that of a pig in the sense of the first cutting of the pig in this Buddha era. By that . “By that name” : by that feminine gender

original: laddhanāmake. Paṃsudhoteti dhotapaṃsuke. Otaritvā abhiruhitabbanti pakatibhūmito
analyzed: laddha nāmake paṃsu dhotā iti dhota paṃsuke otaritvā abhiruhitabbanti pakati bhūmitaḥ
translated: ‘In the name of the cave’: in the name of the cave. ‘Having washed the dust off’: having washed the dust off. ‘Having descended and climbed up’: having descended from the natural level of the ground

original: anekehi sopānaphalakehi otaritvā puna leṇadvāraṃ katipayehi abhiruhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: anekehi sopāna phalakehi otaritvā puna leṇa dvāram katipayehi abhiruhitabbam
translated: by means of many steps and planks, he should climb up again to the cave entrance by means of several steps.

original: Ṭhitakovāti mātulassa ṭhitattā tattha sagāravasapatissavasena ṭhitakova. Kiñcāpi
analyzed: ṭhitakaḥ uvā ti mātulassa ṭhita ttā tattha kiñcā api
translated: ‘Standing’: because of his uncle’s presence, he was standing there with respect and deference. Although

original: sabba-saddo avisesato anavasesapariyādāyako, vatthuadhippāyānurodhī pana saddappayogoti
analyzed: sabba saddaḥ avisesataḥ anavasesa pariyādāyakaḥ vatthu adhippāya anurodhī pana sadda ppayogaḥ ti
translated: the word ‘all’ is all-inclusive, the use of the word is in accordance with the intended meaning.

original: tamatthaṃ sandhāya paribbājako “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti āha. Yā loke manussaupapattiyotiādikā
analyzed: tam attham sandhāya paribbājakaḥ sabbam me na khamati iti āha yā loke manussa aupapattiyā uti ādikā
translated: Therefore, with that meaning in mind, the wanderer said: “All is acceptable to me.” The rebirths beginning with ‘whatever rebirth there is in the world as a human being’

original: upapattiyo, tā anatthasamudāgatā tattha tattheva sattānaṃ ucchijjanato, tasmā samayavādīhi
analyzed: upapattiyaḥ tāḥ anattha samudāgatāḥ tattha tattha iva sattānam ucchijjanato tasmā samaya vādīhi
translated: are not the source of harm, because beings are destroyed right there in those places. Therefore,

original: vuccamānā sabbā āyatiṃ uppajjanaupapatti na hoti. Jalabubbuḷakā viya hi ime sattā
analyzed: vuccamānā sabbā āyatim uppajjana aupapatti na hoti jala bubbuḷakāḥ viya hi ime sattā
translated: when the doctrine of the right time is being taught, all future rebirths do not occur. For these beings, like water bubbles,

original: tattha tattha samaye uppajjitvā bhijjanti, tesaṃ tattha paṭisandhi natthīti assa
analyzed: tattha tattha samaye uppajjitvā bhijjanti tesam tattha paṭisandhi natthi iti assa
translated: having arisen right there at the right time, are destroyed. They have no rebirth-linking there.

original: adhippāyo. Tenāha “paṭisandhiyo”tiādi. Assa adhippāyaṃ muñcitvāti yenādhippāyena🔽paribbājako “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti āha, taṃ tassa adhippāyaṃ jānantopi ajānanto
analyzed: tena āha paṭisandhiyā utiādi assa adhippāyam muñcitvā iti yena adhippāyena  paribbājakaḥ sabbam me na khamati iti āha tam tassa adhippāyam jānantaḥ api a jānantaḥ
translated: Intention. Hence he said “rebirths” and so on. Having released the wanderer’s intention: having understood the intention with which the wanderer said “Everything is acceptable to me,” and having released it, having understood it as it really is, he said “Everything is acceptable to me” in order to show the wanderer that he had understood his intention.

original: viya hutvā tassa akkhare tāva dosaṃ dassentoti padesasabbaṃ sandhāya tena vuttaṃ,🔽sabbasabbavisayaṃ katvā tattha dosaṃ gaṇhanto. Yathā loke kenaci “sabbaṃ vuttaṃ,🔽taṃ musā”ti vutte tassa vacanassa sabbantogadhattā musābhāvo āpajjeyya, evaṃ imassapi🔽“sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti vadato tathā pavattā diṭṭhipi nakkhamatīti atthato āpannameva
analyzed: viya hutvā tassa akkhare tāva dosam dassento ti padesa sabbam sandhāya tena vuttam  sabba sabba visayam katvā tattha dosam gaṇhantaḥ yathā loke kenaci sabbam vuttam  tam musā iti vutte tassa vacanassa musābhāvaḥ āpajjeyya evam imassa api  sabbam me nakkhamati iti vadataḥ tathā pavattā diṭṭhi pi nakkhamati iti atthataḥ āpannam eva
translated: The intention. Hence he said “in the rebirth-linking” , and so on. Having let the wanderer’s intention go by: knowing the intention with which the wanderer said “All is acceptable to me” , he pretended not to know it and showed the fault in his words first of all in the sense of partial totality. Hence it was said above “taking it as referring to partial totality” . Then he took it as referring to universal totality and showed the fault in that.🔽Just as if someone were to say “All is false,” then because of the universal application of his words, falsity would be entailed; so too, when this man said “All is acceptable to me,” then his view that occurred in that way is entailed in meaning. Hence the Blessed One said “This view of yours is also acceptable to you” .

original: hoti. Tenāha bhagavā – “esāpi te diṭṭhi nakkhamatī”ti. Yathā pana kenaci “sabbaṃ🔽vuttaṃ musā”ti vutte adhippāyānurodhinī saddappavatti, tassa vacanaṃ muñcitvā tadaññesameva
analyzed: hoti tena āha bhagavā esā api te diṭṭhi na khamati iti yathā pana kenacid sabbam 🔽vuttam musā iti vutte adhippāya anurodhinī sadda ppavatti tassa vacanam muñcitvā tat aññesam eva
translated: But just as if someone were to say “All is false,” then the occurrence of the sound is in accordance with the intention, and the words are let go by, and it is only other things that are false, so too, when the wanderer said “All is acceptable to me,” then his view that occurred in that way is let go by, and it is only other things that are acceptable to him.

original: musābhāvo ñāyāgato, evamidhāpi “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti vacanato yassā diṭṭhiyā vasena
analyzed: musābhāvaḥ ñāya āgataḥ evam idha api sabbam me na khamati iti vacanataḥ yassā diṭṭhiyāḥ vasena
translated: The meaning of the statement “All is acceptable to me” is that the view according to which the wanderer said “All is acceptable to me” is acceptable to him.

original: “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti tena vuttaṃ, taṃ diṭṭhiṃ muñcitvā tadaññameva yathādhippetaṃ🔽sabbaṃ nakkhamatīti ayamattho ñāyāgato, bhagavā pana vādīvaro sukhumāya āṇiyā thūlaṃ
analyzed: sabbam me na khamati iti tena vuttam tam diṭṭhim muñcitvā tad aññam eva yathā adhippetam  sabbam nakkhamati iti ayam atthaḥ ñāyā āgataḥ bhagavā pana vādīvaraḥ sukhumāya āṇiyā thūlam
translated: But the meaning of the statement “All is acceptable to me” is that all is acceptable to him except the view according to which he said “All is acceptable to me.”🔽The Blessed One, however, in order to remove his view by a skillful means, as if removing a coarse rope with a finer one, did not speak in accordance with the wanderer’s intention.

original: āṇiṃ nīharanto viya upāyena tassa diṭṭhigataṃ nīharituṃ tassa adhippāyena avatvā
analyzed: āṇim nīharantaḥ viya upāyena tassa diṭṭhi gatam nīharitum tassa adhippāyena avatvā
translated: But rather he pointed out the fault that was already present in the wanderer’s statement by the mere sound of it.

original: saddavasena tāva labbhamānaṃ dosaṃ dassento “yāpi kho te”tiādimāha. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: sadda vasena tāva labbhamānam dosam dassentaḥ yā api kho tā iti ādim āha tena vuttam
translated: Thus he said: “But, wanderer, what is acceptable to you?”

original: “assa adhippāyaṃ muñcitvā akkhare tāva dosaṃ dassento”ti.🔽Paribbājako pana yaṃ sandhāya “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti mayā vuttaṃ, “ayaṃ so”ti yathāvuttadosapariharaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: assa adhippāyam muñcitvā akkhare tāva dosam dassento ti  paribbājakaḥ pana yam sandhāya sabbam me na khamati iti mayā vuttam ayam saḥ ti yathāvutta dosa pariharaṇa attham
translated: Therefore it is said: “The Blessed One, having removed the wanderer’s intention, pointed out the fault in the mere sound of his statement.”🔽But the wanderer, in order to avoid the fault pointed out, said: “When I said ‘All is acceptable to me,’ this is what I meant.”

original: tasmiṃ atthe vuccamāne esa doso sabbo na hoti, evampi samaṇo gotamo mama vāde dosameva
analyzed: tasmin atthe vuccamāne esa doso sabbaḥ na hoti evam pi samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ mama vāde dosam eva
translated: “When this meaning is stated, this fault does not occur.” In this way the wanderer thought: “Even so, the recluse Gotama finds fault with my statement.

original: āropeyyāti attano ajjhāsayaṃ niguhitvā yathāvuttadosaṃ pariharitukāmo “esā me”tiādimāha.
analyzed: āropeyya iti attanaḥ ajjhāsayam niguhitvā yathāvutta dosam pariharitu kāmaḥ esā mā iti ādim āha
translated: “He would superimpose” : concealing his own view, he would say “This is mine” in order to avoid the fault stated.

original: Tattha tampassa tādisamevāti yaṃ “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti gahitaṃ vatthu, tampi tādisameva
analyzed: tattha tampassa tādisam eva ati yam sabbam me na khamati iti gahitam vatthu tampi tādisam eva
translated: “That would be just the same for him” : the matter that he has taken as “All is acceptable to me” would be just the same for him.

original: bhaveyyāti. Ayañca sabbantogadhadiṭṭhi mayhampi diṭṭhivatthu, taṃ me khameyyavāti.
analyzed: bhaveyya ati ayam ca sabba antogadha diṭṭhi mayham pi diṭṭhi vatthu tam me
translated: “That would be acceptable to me” : this view of his, “All is annihilated,” is also a view-point for me; that would be acceptable to me.

original: Yasmā pana “esāpi diṭṭhi tuyhaṃ nakkhamatī”ti yāpi diṭṭhi vuttā bhavatā gotamena,
analyzed: yasmā pana esā api diṭṭhi tuyham na khamati iti yā api diṭṭhi vuttā bhavatā gotamena
translated: “But since that view is also acceptable to you,

original: sāpi mayhaṃ nakkhamati, tasmā sabbaṃ me nakkhamatevāti paribbājakassa adhippāyo.
analyzed: sā api mayham nakkhamati tasmā sabbam me nakkhamatā iva iti paribbājakassa adhippāyaḥ
translated: then all is acceptable to me” : the wanderer’s intention is that since the view stated by the Blessed One, “That view is also acceptable to you,”🔽is also acceptable to him, then all is acceptable to him.

original: Tenāha – “taṃ pariharāmīti saññāya vadatī”ti. Tathā ca vakkhati “tasmāpi ucchedadiṭṭhi
analyzed: tena āha tam pariharāmi iti saññāya vadati iti tathā ca vakkhati tasmā api uccheda diṭṭhi
translated: Therefore the commentary says, “He speaks with the idea of avoiding that.” And he speaks thus: “Therefore annihilationism is acceptable to me.”

original: mayhaṃ nakkhamatī”ti. “Esā me diṭṭhī”ti yā ṭhitibhūtā diṭṭhi, tāya “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti
analyzed: mayham na khamati iti esā me diṭṭhī iti yā ṭhiti bhūtā diṭṭhi tāya sabbam me na khamati iti
translated: “This is my view” : the view that has become fixed. “All is acceptable to me” :

original: panettha sabbaggahaṇena gahitattā āha – “atthato panassa esā diṭṭhi na me khamatīti
analyzed: pana ittha sabba ggahaṇena gahita ttā āha atthataḥ pana assa esā diṭṭhi na me khamati iti
translated: here, by the word “all,” he has taken the view that is fixed. Therefore the commentary says, “In fact, this view is not acceptable to him.”

original: āpajjatī”ti. Ayaṃ dosoti dassento āha “yassa panā”tiādi. Esāti diṭṭhi. Rucitanti🔽diṭṭhidassanena abhinivisitvā rocetvā gahitaṃ. Tena hi diṭṭhiakkhamena arucitena
analyzed: āpajjati iti ayam doso ti dassentaḥ āha yassa pana atiādi esā ati diṭṭhi  diṭṭhi dassanena abhinivisitvā rocetvā gahitam tena hi diṭṭhi akkhamena arucitena
translated: He shows the hate thus: “But if he says …”. The view is “esā”. He likes it:🔽he takes it up by liking it after deciding on it by seeing the view. Then he should not like it:

original: bhavitabbanti sati diṭṭhiyā akkhamabhāve tato tāya gahitāya khameyya rucceyya yathā,🔽evaṃ sabbassa akkhamabhāveti aparabhāge sabbaṃ khamati ruccatīti āpajjati. Na panesa
analyzed: bhavitabbanti sati diṭṭhiyāḥ a khama bhāve tatas tāya gahitāya khameyya rucceyya yathā  evam sabbassa a khama bhāveti aparabhāge sabbam khamati ruccati iti āpajjati na pana esa
translated: if he has the view, then he should not like it, should not agree with it, as he has taken it up.

original: taṃ sampaṭicchatīti esa “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti evaṃ vadanto ucchedavādī taṃ vuttanayena
analyzed: tam sampaṭicchati iti esa sabbam me na khamati iti evam vadantaḥ uccheda vādī tam vutta nayena
translated: But he does not assent to it: this annihilationist, saying “All is not agreeable to me”,

original: sabbassa khamanaṃ ruccanaṃ na sampaṭicchati. Ñāyena vuttamatthaṃ kathaṃ na sampaṭicchatīti
analyzed: sabbassa khamanam ruccanam na sampaṭicchati ñāyena vuttam attham katham na sampaṭicchati iti
translated: does not assent to the agreement with and liking of all that is stated in the way already described. How does he not assent to the meaning stated by the right method?

original: āha “kevalaṃ tassāpi ucchedadiṭṭhiyā ucchedameva gaṇhātī”ti. Sabbesañhi dhammānaṃ
analyzed: āha kevalam tassa api uccheda diṭṭhiyāḥ ucchedam eva gaṇhāti iti sabbesam hi dhammānam
translated: He says: “He takes only the annihilation of that annihilationist view”. For all things

original: āyatiṃ uppādaṃ aruccitvā taṃ sandhāya ayaṃ “sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti vadati, ucchedadiṭṭhikesu
analyzed: āyatim uppādam a ruccitvā tam sandhāya ayam sabbam me na khamati iti vadati uccheda diṭṭhikesu
translated: he does not like the future arising of them, and with reference to them he says “All is not agreeable to me”. Among those who hold the annihilationist view,

original: ca ucchinnesu kuto ucchedadiṭṭhisabhāvoti.
analyzed: ca ucchinnesu kutas uccheda diṭṭhi sabhāvaḥ ti
translated: and when they are cut off, how can they have the nature of the annihilation view?

original: Tenāti tena kāraṇena, yasmā idhekacce sattā īdisaṃ diṭṭhiṃ paggayha tiṭṭhanti, tasmāti
analyzed: tena ati tena kāraṇena yasmai idha ekacce sattāḥ īdisam diṭṭhim paggayha tiṭṭhanti tasmā iti
translated: Tenā ti tena kāraṇena, yasmā idhekacce sattā īdisaṃ diṭṭhiṃ paggayha tiṭṭhanti, tasmāti

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Pajahanakena vā cittena ekajjhaṃ gahetvā pajahanakehi appajahanake niddhāretuṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti pajahanakena vā cittena ekajjham gahetvā pajahanakehi a pajahanake niddhāretum
translated: vuttaṃ hoti. Pajahanakena vā cittena ekajjhaṃ gahetvā pajahanakehi appajahanake niddhāretuṃ

original: bhagavā “ato…pe… bahutarā”ti avocāti āha – “pajahanakesu nissakka”nti yathā “pañcasīlehi
analyzed: bhagavā atope bahutarā ati avocāti āha pajahanakesu yathā pañcasīlehi
translated: bhagavā “ato…pe… bahutarā”ti avocāti āha – “pajahanakesu nissakka”nti yathā “pañcasīlehi

original: pabhāvanā paññavantatarā”ti. “Bahū”ti vatvā na kevalaṃ bahū, atha kho ativiya bahūti
analyzed: pabhāvanā paññavantatarā ati bahū ti vatvā na kevalam bahū atha kho ativiya bahū ti
translated: pabhāvanā paññavantatarā”ti. “Bahū”ti vatvā na kevalaṃ bahū, atha kho ativiya bahūti

original: dassento “bahutarā”ti āha. “Bahū hī”ti nayidaṃ nissakkavacanaṃ, atha kho paccattavacanaṃ.
analyzed: dassentaḥ bahutarā iti āha bahū hi iti na yidam nissakka vacanam atha kho paccatta vacanam
translated: dassento “bahutarā”ti āha. “Bahū hī”ti nayidaṃ nissakkavacanaṃ, atha kho paccattavacanaṃ.

original: Kathaṃ hi-saddoti āha “hi-kāro nipātamatta”nti. Anissakkavacanaṃ tāva tassa pajahanakānaṃ
analyzed: katham hi saddaḥ ti āha hi kāraḥ nipāta mattam ti a nissakka vacanam tāva tassa pajahana kānam
translated: Kathaṃ hi-saddoti āha “hi-kāro nipātamatta”nti. Anissakkavacanaṃ tāva tassa pajahanakānaṃ

original: bahubhāvato tepi parato “bahutarā”ti vuccīyanti. Mūladassananti ye tādisaṃ dassanaṃ
analyzed: bahu bhāvataḥ te api paratas bahutarā ti mūla dassananti ye tādisam dassanam
translated: bahubhāvato tepi parato “bahutarā”ti vuccīyanti. Mūladassananti ye tādisaṃ dassanaṃ

original: paṭhamaṃ upādiyanti, tajjātikameva pacchā gahitadassanaṃ. Vijātiyañhi paṭhamaṃ gahitadassanaṃ
analyzed: paṭhamam upādiyanti tad jātikam eva pacchā gahita dassanam vijātiyam hi paṭhamam gahita dassanam
translated: and the first is the seeing of what is of the same kind as the first,

original: appahāya vijātiyassa gahaṇaṃ na sambhavati viruddhassa abhinivesassa saha anavaṭṭhānato.
analyzed: a pahāya vijātiyassa gahaṇam na sambhavati viruddhassa abhinivesassa saha anavaṭṭhānato
translated: for it is impossible to apprehend what is of a different kind without abandoning the seeing of what is of the same kind, because of the impossibility of the simultaneous presence of mutually incompatible determinations.

original: Aviruddhaṃ pana mūladassanaṃ avissajjitvā visayādibhedabhinnaṃ aparadassanaṃ gahetuṃ
analyzed: aviruddham pana mūla dassanam a vissajjitvā visaya ādi bheda bhinnam apara dassanam gahetum
translated: But it is possible to apprehend a different seeing, distinguished by a different objective field, etc., without abandoning the uncontradicted seeing of the root.

original: labbhati. Tenāha “ettha cā”tiādi.🔽Tattha kiñcāpi ekaccasassatavādo sassatucchedābhinivesānaṃ vasena yathākkamaṃ sassatucchedaggāhanajātiko,
analyzed: labbhati tena āha ettha ca ati ādi  tattha kiñcā api ekacca sassata vādaḥ sassatu cheda abhinivesānam vasena yathākkamam sassatu cheda ggāhana jātikaḥ
translated: Hence he said, “And here too” .🔽Herein, although the doctrine of partial-eternalism is of the same kind as the apprehension of eternalism and annihilationism respectively,

original: ucchedaggāhena pana sassatābhinivesassa taṃgāhena ca asassatābhinivesassa virujjhanato
analyzed: uccheda ggāhena pana sassatā abhinivesassa taṃgāhena ca asassatā abhinivesassa virujjhanato
translated: nevertheless, since the apprehension of annihilationism contradicts the apprehension of eternalism and the apprehension of that doctrine of partial-eternalism contradicts the apprehension of non-eternalism,

original: ubhayatthapi “ekaccasassataṃ vā gahetuṃ na sakkā”ti vuttaṃ, tathā “sassataṃ vā ucchedaṃ
analyzed: ubhayattha api ekacca sassatam vā gahetum na sakkā iti vuttam tathā sassatam vā ucchedam
translated: it is said that “partial-eternalism cannot be apprehended in either way” and that “eternalism or annihilationism cannot be apprehended.”🔽For the eternalism of the root is apprehended first.

original: vā na sakkā gahetu”nti ca. Mūlasassatañhi paṭhamaṃ gahitaṃ. Āyatanesupi yojetabbanti
analyzed: vā na sakkā gahetunti ca mūla sassatam hi paṭhamam gahitam āyatanesu pi yojetabbanti
translated: The same method applies in the case of the bases.

original: paṭhamaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ sassatanti gahetvā aparabhāge na kevalaṃ cakkhāyatanameva
analyzed: paṭhamam cakkha āyatanam gahetvā apara bhāge na kevalam cakkha āyatanam eva
translated: Having first apprehended the eye-base as eternal, he later apprehends not only the eye-base but also the ear-base, etc., as eternal.

original: sassataṃ, sotāyatanampi sassataṃ, ghānāyatanādipi sassatanti gaṇhātītiādinā yojetabbaṃ.🔽Āyatanesupīti pi-saddena dhātūnaṃ indriyānampi gāho daṭṭhabbo. Idaṃ sandhāyāti “mūle
analyzed: sassatam sota āyatanam pi sassatam ghāna āyatana ādi pi sassatanti gaṇhāti iti ādinā yojetabbam  āyatanesu pi iti pi saddena dhātūnam indriyānam pi gāhaḥ daṭṭhabbo idam sandhāya ati mūle
translated: The word “also” in the phrase “in the bases” should be understood to include the elements and faculties.

original: sassata”ntiādinā vuttapaṭhamaggāhassa samānajātiyaṃ aparaggāhaṃ sandhāya.
analyzed: sassa tanti ādinā vutta paṭhama ggāhassa samāna jātiyam apara ggāham sandhāya
translated: “With reference to this” : with reference to the second apprehension of the same kind as the first apprehension stated in the phrase “at the root eternal.”

original: Dutiyavāre paṭhamavāre vuttasadisaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Tattha ādīnavaṃ disvāti🔽“yadi rūpaṃ sassataṃ siyā, nayidaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya. Yasmā ca kho idaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: dutiya vāre paṭhama vāre vutta sadisam vutta nayena iva veditabbam tattha ādīnavam disvā iti  yadi rūpam sassatam siyā na idam ābādhāya saṃvatteyya yasmai ca kho idam rūpam
translated: The second section should be understood in the same way as the first, according to the method stated.

original: asassataṃ, tasmā abhiṇhapaṭipīḷanaṭṭhena udayavayavantatāya rūpaṃ aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ
analyzed: a sassatam tasmai abhiṇha paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena udaya vayavanta tāya rūpam aniccam saṅkhatam
translated: Having seen the danger in that, he thinks: “If form were eternal, it would not be subject to affliction. But because form is not eternal, therefore, in the sense of being repeatedly afflicted, form is impermanent, conditioned,

original: paṭiccasamuppannaṃ, sassatābhiniveso micchā”tiādinā tattha sassatavāde ādīnavaṃ dosaṃ
analyzed: paṭicca samuppannam sassata abhinivesaḥ micchā ati ādinā tattha sassata vāde ādīnavam dosam
translated: dependent, and arisen from conditions. The adherence to eternalism is wrong.” Having seen the danger in the eternalist view in this way, he abandons the adherence to eternalism.

original: disvā. Oḷārikanti tasmā paṭipīḷanaṭṭhena ayāthāvaggāhatāya rūpaṃ na saṇhaṃ oḷārikameva.
analyzed: disvā oḷārikam ti tasmai paṭipīḷana ṭṭhena rūpam na saṇham oḷārikam eva
translated: and seeing that, he sees materiality as gross because of its being the opposite of subtle, in the sense of oppressing.

original: Vedanādīnampi aniccādibhāvadassanaṃ rūpavedanāādīnaṃ samānayogakkhamattā. Vissajjetīti pajahati.
analyzed: vedanā ādīnam pi anicca ādi bhāva dassanam rūpa vedanā ādīnam samāna yogakkhama ttā vissajjeti iti pajahati
translated: And the seeing of impermanence, etc., in feeling, etc., is due to the fact that the same method of contemplation applies to materiality and feeling, etc.🔽“He rejects” means he abandons.

original: Tisso laddhiyoti sassatucchedaekaccasassatadiṭṭhiyo. Yasmā sassatadiṭṭhikā vaṭṭe
analyzed: tissaḥ laddhiyaḥ ti sassatu cheda ekacca sassata diṭṭhiyaḥ yasmā sassata diṭṭhikā vaṭṭe
translated: “Three theories”: the eternalist view, the annihilationist view, and the view that holds to a middle view.🔽Because the eternalist view is near to passion,

original: rajjanassa āsannā. Tathā hi te olīyantīti vuccanti, bhavābhavadiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena imesaṃ
analyzed: rajjanassa āsannā tathā hi te olīyanti iti vuccanti bhava abhava diṭṭhīnam vasena imesam
translated: for it is said of those who hold that view that they “lean on a stick,”

original: sattānaṃ saṃsārato sīsukkhipanaṃ natthīti etāva tisso visesato gahetabbā.
analyzed: sattānam saṃsārato sīsukkhipanam natthi iti etāva tissaḥ visesataḥ gahetabbā
translated: and because there is no escape from the round of rebirths for those who hold the views of existence and non-existence, only these three should be taken as the specific views.

original: Idhalokaṃ paralokañca atthīti jānātīti ettāvatā sassatadassanassa appasāvajjatākāraṇamāha,
analyzed: idha lokam para lokam ca atthi iti jānāti iti ettāvatā sassata dassanassa appasāvajja tā kāraṇam āha
translated: “He knows that there is this world and the other world”: he shows the reason why the eternalist view is not so reprehensible,

original: vaṭṭaṃ assādeti, abhinandatīti iminā dandhavirāgatāya. Tenāha “tasmā”tiādi. Idhalokaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭam assādeti abhinandati iti iminā dandha virāga tāya tena āha tasmā atiādi idhalokam
translated: “He delights in the round of rebirths, he approves of it”: he shows the reason why the annihilationist view is not so reprehensible.

original: paralokañca atthīti jānātīti iminā tāsu tāsu gatīsu sattānaṃ saṃsaraṇaṃ paṭikkhipatīti
analyzed: para lokam ca atthi iti jānāti iti iminā tāsu tāsu gatīsu sattānam saṃsaraṇam paṭikkhipati iti
translated: “He knows that there is this world and the other world”: he shows the reason why the middle view is not so reprehensible.

original: dasseti, sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ atthīti jānātīti iminā kammaphalaṃ. Kusalaṃ🔽na karotīti iminā kammaṃ, akusalaṃ karonto na bhāyatīti iminā puññāpuññāni sabhāvato
analyzed: dasseti su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalam atthi iti jānāti iti iminā kamma phalam kusalam  na karoti iti iminā kammam akusalam karontaḥ na bhāyati iti iminā puññāpuññāni sabhāvato
translated: “He shows that there is fruit of good and bad deeds” means that he knows the fruit of kamma. “He does not do what is wholesome” means that he does kamma. “He who does what is unwholesome does not fear” means that he does evil. “He does not know the wholesome” means that he does not know the wholesome. “He does not know the unwholesome” means that he does not know the unwholesome. “He does not know what is blameworthy” means that he does not know what is blameworthy. “He does not know what is blameless” means that he does not know what is blameless. “He does not know what is to be cultivated” means that he does not know what is to be cultivated. “He does not know what is not to be cultivated” means that he does not know what is not to be cultivated. “He does not know what is base” means that he does not know what is base. “He does not know what is noble” means that he does not know what is noble. “He does not know the Dhamma” means that he does not know the Dhamma. “He does not know the meaning” means that he does not know the meaning. “He does not know the letter” means that he does not know the letter. “He does not know the right” means that he does not know the right. “He does not know the wrong” means that he does not know the wrong. “He does not know moderation” means that he does not know moderation. “He does not know the time” means that he does not know the time. “He does not know the occasion” means that he does not know the occasion. “He does not know himself” means that he does not know himself. “He does not know others” means that he does not know others. “He does not know the higher penalty” means that he does not know the higher penalty. “He does not know the lower penalty” means that he does not know the lower penalty.

original: jāyantīti dasseti. Vaṭṭaṃ assādeti abhinandati tanninnabhāvato. Sīghaṃ laddhiṃ jahituṃ🔽na sakkoti vaṭṭupacchedassa aruccanato. Ucchedavādī hi tasmiṃ bhave ucchedaṃ maññati.🔽Tato paraṃ idhalokaṃ paralokañca atthīti jānāti sukatadukkaṭānaṃ phalaṃ atthīti jānāti🔽kammaphalavādībhāvato. Yebhuyyena hi ucchedavādī sabhāvaniyatiyadicchābhinivesesu🔽aññatrābhiniveso hoti. Sīghaṃ dassanaṃ pajahati vaṭṭābhiratiyā abhāvato. Pāramiyo
analyzed: jāyanti iti dasseti vaṭṭam assādeti abhinandati tad ninna bhāvataḥ sīgham laddhim jahitum  na sakkoti vaṭṭu upacchedassa uccheda vādī hi tasmin bhave ucchedam maññati  tatas param idha lokam para lokañca atthi iti jānāti su kata dukkaṭānam phalam atthi iti jānāti  kamma phala vādī bhāvataḥ yebhuyyena hi uccheda vādī sa bhāva niyati yad icchā abhinivesesu  aññatra abhinivesaḥ hoti sīgham dassanam pajahati vaṭṭa abhiratiyāḥ abhāvataḥ pāramiyo
translated: “He shows that there is fruit of good and bad deeds” means that he knows the fruit of kamma. “He does not do what is wholesome” means that he does kamma. “He does not fear doing what is unwholesome” means that he knows that merit and demerit arise in accordance with their true nature. “He delights in the round of rebirths” means that he is pleased with it because he is attached to it. “He is unable to abandon his views quickly” means that he is not inclined to cut off the round of rebirths. For the annihilationist imagines annihilation in that very existence.

original: pūretuṃ sakkonto paccekabuddho hutvā, lokavohāramatteneva so sammāsambuddho hutvā
analyzed: pūretum sakkontaḥ paccekabuddhaḥ hutvā loka vohāra mattena iva saḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ hutvā
translated: “After that, he knows that this world and the other world exist” means that he knows that there is fruit of good and bad deeds. “He becomes a kamma-phala-vādin” means that he is inclined to believe in the fruit of kamma. For the annihilationist is inclined to believe in the other three theories, namely, that things exist by svabhāva, by niyati, and by yadiccha. “He abandons his views quickly” means that he is not attached to the round of rebirths. “He is able to fulfil the perfections” means that he becomes a paccekabuddha. “He becomes a Sammāsambuddha” means that he becomes a Sammāsambuddha by the mere word of the world.

original: parinibbāyatīti yojanā. Asakkontoti buddho hotuṃ asakkonto. Abhinīhāraṃ katvā aggasāvakādibhāvassa
analyzed: parinibbāyati iti yojanā a sakkontaḥ ti buddhaḥ hotum a sakkontaḥ abhinīhāram katvā aggasāvaka ādi bhāvassa
translated: The construction is: “he attains Nibbāna.” “Unable”: unable to become a Buddha. “Having made his aspiration”: having fulfilled his aspiration for the state of chief disciple, etc.

original: abhinīhāraṃ sampādetvā. Sāvako hutvāti aggasāvako mahāsāvako hutvā, tatthāpi tevijjo
analyzed: abhinīhāram sampādetvā sāvakaḥ hutvā ati aggasāvakaḥ mahāsāvakaḥ hutvā tattha api tevijjaḥ
translated: “As a disciple”: as the chief disciple, the great disciple. There too, he attains Nibbāna as a disciple who is a triple-knowledge bearer,

original: chaḷabhiñño paṭisambhidāppatto vā sukkhavipassako eva vā buddhasāvako hutvā parinibbāyati.
analyzed: chaḷabhiñño paṭisambhidā appattaḥ vā sukkha vipassakaḥ eva vā buddha sāvakaḥ hutvā parinibbāyati
translated: a six-abider, one who has attained the analytical knowledges, or a dry-insight worker.

original: Sabbamidaṃ ucchedavādino kalyāṇamittanissayena sammattaniyāmokkamane khippavirāgatādassanatthaṃ
analyzed: sabbam idam uccheda vādino kalyāṇa mitta nissayena sammatta niyāma ukkamane khippa virāga tā dassana ttham
translated: All this is stated in order to show that one who has gone forth into homelessness in this Dispensation, even though he may be a nihilist, can attain Nibbāna quickly by depending on good friends and entering the right way.

original: āgataṃ. Tenāha “tasmā”tiādi.
analyzed: āgatam tena āha tasmāt iti ādi
translated: Therefore he said, “Therefore, bhikkhus, an exertion should be made to understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’“

original: 202. Kañjiyenevāti āranāḷena. Kañjiyasadisena ucchedadassanena. Pūritoti paripuṇṇajjhāsayo.🔽Soti paribbājako. Appahāyāti abhinditvā. Viggahoti kalaho idameva saccaṃ, moghamaññanti
analyzed: kañjiyena iva ati āranāḷena kañjiya sadisena uccheda dassanena pūrito ti  saḥ ti paribbājakaḥ a pahāya ati a bhinditvā viggahaḥ ti kalahaḥ idam eva saccam mogham aññanti
translated: “With just a little effort”: with just a little exertion. “With just a straw”: with a view that is like a straw. “Filled”: his heart is filled.

original: aññamaññaṃ viruddhaggāhoti katvā. Vivādanti viruddhavādaṃ. Vighātanti virodhahetukaṃ
analyzed: aññam aññam viruddhaggāho ti katvā vivādanti viruddha vādam vighātanti virodha hetukam
translated: “He”: the wanderer. “Without abandoning”: without breaking. “Quarrel”: dispute. “This alone is the truth, other ideas are silly”: this is how they grasp at opposite extremes. “Contention”: disagreement. “Bickering”: the cause of disagreement.

original: cittavighātaṃ. Vihesanti viggahavivādanimittaṃ kāyikaṃ cetasikañca kilamathaṃ. Ādīnavaṃ🔽disvāti etāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ evarūpo ādīnavo, aniyyānikabhāvatāya pana sampati āyatiñca
analyzed: citta vighātam vihesanti viggaha vivāda nimittam kāyikam cetasikam ca kilamatham ādīnavam  etāsam diṭṭhīnam evarūpaḥ ādīnavaḥ aniyyānika bhāvatāya pana sampati āyatiñca
translated: and mental anguish. They afflict with bodily and mental weariness, which is the cause for disharmony and dispute.🔽Having seen the danger: having seen the danger in these views in this way, and also the great danger in the present and future

original: mahādīnavoti evaṃ ādīnavaṃ disvā.
analyzed: evam ādīnavam disvā
translated: that comes from their being unbeneficial.

original: 205. “Esohamasmi, eso me attā”tiādinā kāyaṃ anvetīti kāyanvayo, soyeva, tassa vā samūho kāyanvayatā, kāyapaṭibaddho kileso. Tenāha “kāyaṃ…pe… attho”ti.🔽Asammissabhāvanti asaṅkarato vavatthitabhāvaṃ. Tena tāsaṃ yathāsakaṃ paccayānaṃ uppajjitvā
analyzed: esaḥ aham asmi esaḥ me attā ati ādinā kāyam anveti iti kāya anvayaḥ saḥ yā iva tassa vā samūhaḥ kāya anvaya tā kāya paṭibaddhaḥ kileso tena āha kāya pe attho ti  asammissa bhāvanti asaṅkarataḥ vavatthita bhāvam tena tāsam yathāsakam paccayānam uppajjitvā
translated: “He follows the body” means that he follows the body by thinking, “This is myself, this is my self.” The collection of that is “the bodily tie.” The defilement bound up with the body is what is meant.

original: vigamaṃ dasseti. Evañhi tāsaṃ kadācipi saṅkaro natthi. Tenāha “tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho”tiādi.
analyzed: vigamam dasseti evam hi tāsam kadāci pi saṅkaraḥ natthi tena āha tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ itiādi
translated: The state of being unmixed: the state of being defined without confusion. By this he shows the separation of these defilements after they have arisen from their respective conditions. For in this way they are never mixed up. Therefore he says, “Here is the meaning in brief.”

original: Sarūpaṃ aggahetvā “aññā vedanā”ti aniyamena vuttattā tameva vigamaṃ dassento “anuppannāva
analyzed: sarūpam aggahetvā aññā vedanā ti aniyamena vutta ttā tam eva vigamam dassento anuppannā ava
translated: Since the feeling is stated without any qualification as “another,” he shows the same separation by saying, “When the feeling has not yet arisen.”

original: honti antarahitā vā”ti āha. Sarūpato niyametvā vuccamāne kāci anuppannā vā hoti,
analyzed: honti antarahitāḥ vā iti āha sarūpataḥ niyametvā vuccamāne kāci anuppannā vā hoti
translated: and some are already past.🔽If it were stated by way of their individual characteristics, some would be unarisen,

original: kāci antarahitā vāti. Cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhāvadassanatthanti khaṇe khaṇe bhijjamānabhāvadassanatthaṃ.🔽Na kenaci saṃvadatīti kenaci puggalena saddhiṃ diṭṭhirāgavasena saṃkiliṭṭhacitto
analyzed: kāci antara hitā vāti cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa bhāva dassana ttham ti khaṇe khaṇe bhijjamāna bhāva dassana ttham  na kenacid saṃvadati iti kenaci puggalena saddhim diṭṭhi rāga vasena saṃkiliṭṭha cittaḥ
translated: and some would be already past. ‘In order to show their state of being reduced to dust’: in order to show their state of being broken up moment by moment.🔽‘He does not speak with anyone’: he does not speak with anyone with a mind defiled by lust for views.

original: na vadati. Tenāha “sassataṃ gahetvā”tiādi. Na vivadatīti viruddhabhāvo hutvā na vivadati.🔽Parivattetvāti ucchedaṃ gahetvā ekaccasassataṃ gahetvā evaṃ vuttanayena tayopi vādā
analyzed: na vadati tena āha sassatam gahetvā atiādi na vivadati iti viruddha bhāvaḥ hutvā na vivadati  parivattetvā iti ucchedam gahetvā ekacca sassatam gahetvā evam vutta nayena tayaḥ api vādāḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: ‘Having grasped at eternalism’ … ‘He does not dispute’: he does not dispute by becoming opposed .

original: parivattetvā yojetabbā. Tena voharatīti tena lokavohārena lokasamaññaṃ anatidhāvanto🔽satto puriso puggalotiādinā voharati, na pana ito bāhirakā viya abhinivisati. Tenāha🔽“aparāmasanto”ti. Kañci dhammanti rūpādīsu ekaṃ dhammampi. Parāmāsaggāhena aggaṇhantoti
analyzed: parivattetvā yojetabbā tena voharati iti tena loka vohārena loka samaññam an atidhāvanto 🔽satto puriso puggalaḥ ti ādinā voharati na pana itas bāhirakāḥ viya abhinivisati tena āha 🔽a parāmasanto ti kañci dhammanti rūpa ādīsu ekam dhammam pi parāmāsa ggāhena aggaṇhanto ti
translated: ‘Having turned around’: having grasped at annihilation, having grasped at partial eternalism, having grasped at the view of the self, having grasped at the view of the world, having grasped at the view of the world’s end, having grasped at the view of the world’s non-end, having grasped at the view of the world’s finitude, having grasped at the view of the world’s infinitude, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as finite, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as infinite, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as both finite and infinite, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as neither finite nor infinite, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having an end, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having no end, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as both having an end and having no end, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as neither having an end nor having no end, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as being created by oneself, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as created by another, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as created by oneself and another, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as created by chance, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having a cause, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having no cause, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having a cause and having no cause, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having no cause and having no non-cause, having grasped at the view of the self and the world as having a cause and having no cause and having no non-cause, having grasped at the view of the self

original: “nicca”ntiādinā, “etaṃ mamā”tiādinā ca dhammasabhāvaṃ atikkamitvā parato āmasitvā🔽gahaṇena aggaṇhanto.
analyzed: niccanti ādinā etam mama ati ādinā ca dhamma sabhāvam atikkamitvā paratas āmasitvā  gahaṇena aggaṇhanto
translated: “Permanent” and so on, and “This is mine” and so on, he does not apprehend by apprehending externally, transcending the individual essences of states.

original: Katāvīti katakicco. So vadeyyāti khīṇāsavo bhikkhu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāresu sabbaso samucchinnesupi
analyzed: katāvī iti kata kicco so vadeyya ati khīṇa āsavaḥ bhikkhu ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāresu sabbaso samucchinnesu pi
translated: “What has been done” : one who has done what had to be done. “He would say” : a bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed, even though he has completely severed the conceit “I am” and the tendency to conceive “I am,”

original: ahaṃ vadāmīti vadeyya. Tattha ahanti niyakajjhattasantāne. Mamanti tassa santakabhūte
analyzed: aham vadāmi iti vadeyya tattha aham ti niyaka jjhatta santāne tassa santaka bhūte
translated: would say “I say.” Herein, “I” is in his own internal continuity. “Mine” is in the objective field belonging to that.

original: vatthusmiṃ lokaniruḷhe. Samaññanti tattha sukusalatāya loke samaññā kusalo viditvā.🔽Vohāramattenāti kevalaṃ paccekabuddho hutvā mahābodhipāramiyo pūretuṃ asakkonto sāvako
analyzed: vatthusmim loka niruḷhe samaññanti tattha su kusala tāya loke samaññā kusalaḥ viditvā  vohāra mattena ati kevalam paccekabuddhaḥ hutvā mahā bodhipāramiyo pūretum a sakkonto sāvako
translated: “Convention” : being skilled in the world, he knows the worldly convention.🔽“Merely by conventional expression” : as if he were not one whose craving had been eliminated by the mere conventional expression “disciple” because he was unable to fulfil the perfections for great enlightenment after becoming a paccekabuddha,

original: hutvā desavohāramattena na appahīnataṇho viya andhaputhujjano abhinivesanavasena.
analyzed: hutvā desa vohāra mattena na appahīna taṇhaḥ viya andha puthujjanaḥ abhinivesana vasena
translated: but by way of adherence, like an ordinary man who has not eliminated craving.

original: 206. Sassatādīsūti sassatābhinivesādīsu. Tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānanti niddhāraṇe sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: sassata ādīsu iti sassata abhinivesa ādīsu tesam tesam dhammānam nti niddhāraṇe sāmi vacanam
translated: “The eternity view, etc.” : in the case of the eternity view, etc. “Of these and those ideas” : the genitive has the meaning of specification.

original: Sassataṃ abhiññāyāti sassatadiṭṭhiṃ samudayato atthaṅgamato assādato nissaraṇato
analyzed: sassatam abhiññāyāti sassata diṭṭhim samudayataḥ atthaṅgamataḥ assādataḥ nissaraṇataḥ
translated: Having directly known the eternalist view, he abandoned it.

original: abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya paṭivijjhitvā. Pahānanti accantappahānaṃ samucchedaṃ. Rūpassa
analyzed: abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya paṭivijjhitvā pahānanti accanta ppahānam samucchedam rūpassa
translated: Having directly known the eternalist view by penetrating it with the knowledge that distinguishes its origination, its disappearance, its satisfaction, its unsatisfactoriness, and its escape, he abandoned it by way of the complete abandonment of it, by way of its eradication.🔽Having abandoned form, he attained the destruction of the taints.

original: pahānanti rūpassa tappaṭibaddhasaññojanappahānena pahānaṃ. Anuppādanirodhena niruddhehi
analyzed: pahānam ti rūpassa tad paṭibaddha saññojana ppahānena pahānam anuppāda nirodhena niruddhehi
translated: Having abandoned form by way of the abandonment of the fetter bound up with it, he attained the destruction of the taints by not grasping the taints that had already been destroyed.🔽His mind was liberated from the taints.

original: āsavehi aggahetvāva cittaṃ vimucci. “Āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccī”ti ettha kiñcipi aggahetvā
analyzed: āsavehi aggahetvā ava cittam vimucci āsavehi cittam vimucci iti ettha kiñcipi aggahetvā
translated: “His mind was liberated from the taints” means that he liberated his mind from the taints without grasping anything, without remainder.🔽The sixteen kinds of knowledge are the sixteen kinds of knowledge beginning with the great knowledge.

original: asesetvā. Soḷasa paññāti mahāpaññādikā soḷasa paññā. Caturaṅgasamannāgatoti puṇṇauposathadivasatā,
analyzed: a sesetvā soḷasa paññā ti mahāpaññā ādikā soḷasa paññā catur aṅga samannāgataḥ ti puṇṇa auposatha divasa tā
translated: Endowed with four factors: on the day of the full moon, he had not been invited by anyone;

original: kenaci anāmantitameva anekasatānaṃyeva anekasahassānaṃ vā bhikkhūnaṃ sannipatitatā,
analyzed: kenacid an āmantitam eva aneka satānam yeva aneka sahassānam vā bhikkhūnam sannipatita tā
translated: many hundreds and thousands of bhikkhus had assembled;🔽all had been admitted to the Order by the method of the “Come, bhikkhu!” ordination; and he possessed the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: sabbesaṃ ehibhikkhubhāvena upasampannatā, chaḷabhiññatā cāti. Tenāha “tatrimāni aṅgānī”tiādi.
analyzed: sabbesam ehi bhikkhu bhāvena upasampanna tā chaḍabhiñña tā ca ati tena āha tatra imāni aṅgāni itiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “Herein, these are the factors” and so on.

original: Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: yam pana ittha atthataḥ a vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: But what has not been analyzed in terms of meaning should be understood by inference.

original: Dīghanakhasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: dīghanakha sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the word “subtle” in the Dīghanakha Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Māgaṇḍiyasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Magandiya Sutta

original: 207. Dve māgaṇḍiyāti dve māgaṇḍiyanāmakā. Devagabbhasadisanti devānaṃ vasanaovarakasadisaṃ.
analyzed: dve māgaṇḍiyā ati dve māgaṇḍiya nāmakā
translated: Two Magandiyas: two people named Magandiya. Like a god’s robe: like a robe for a god.

original: Etaṃ vuttanti “bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa agyāgāre tiṇasanthārake”ti etaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: etam vuttam ti bhāradvāja gottassa brāhmaṇassa agya āgāre tiṇa santhāraka iti etam vuttam
translated: This is what was said: “on the straw mat in the fire chamber of the brahmin of the Bharadvaja clan.”

original: Na kevalaṃ taṃ divasamevāti yaṃ divasaṃ māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako tiṇasanthārakaṃ paññattaṃ,🔽na kevalaṃ taṃ divasameva bhagavā yenaññataro vanasaṇḍo, tenupasaṅkamīti yojanā.
