analyzed: na kevalam tam divasam eva ati yam divasam māgaṇḍiyaḥ paribbājako tiṇa santhārakam paññattam  na kevalam tam divasam eva bhagavā yena aññataraḥ vana saṇḍo tena upasaṅkami iti yojanā
translated: Not only on that day: on the day when the wanderer Magandiya prepared the straw mat,🔽the Blessed One went to a certain forest grove, not only on that day.

original: Gāmūpacāreti gāmasamīpe. Saññāṇaṃ katvāti saññāṇaṃ katvā viya. Na hi bhagavato tassa🔽saññāṇakaraṇe payojanaṃ atthi.
analyzed: gāma upacāra iti gāma samīpe saññāṇam katvā ati saññāṇam katvā viya na hi bhagavataḥ tassa  saññāṇa karaṇe payojanam atthi
translated: Near a village: in the vicinity of a village. Having made a sign: as if he had made a sign. For the Blessed One had no need to make a sign.

original: Samaṇaseyyānurūpanti samaṇassa anucchavikā seyyā. Pāsaṃsattho hi ayaṃ rūpa-saddo.
analyzed: samaṇa seyyā anurūpanti samaṇassa anucchavikā seyyā pāsaṃsatthaḥ hi ayam rūpa saddo
translated: A bed suitable for an ascetic: a bed suitable for an ascetic. For the word “suitable” has the meaning of “praiseworthy.”

original: Tenāha “imaṃ tiṇasanthāraka”ntiādi. Anākiṇṇoti viluḷito aghaṭṭito. Hatthapādasīsehi
analyzed: tena āha imam tiṇa santhāraka nti ādi an ākiṇṇaḥ ti viluḷitaḥ a ghaṭṭitaḥ hattha pāda sīsehi
translated: Hence he said “the straw mat” and so on. Not crowded: not crowded out, not pressed. Not shaken: not shaken by being struck with hands, feet, and head.

original: tattha tattha pahaṭena na calito abhinno, acalitattā eva abhinnaṃ attharaṇaṃ. Paricchinditvā🔽paññatto viyāti ayaṃ chekena cittakārena cintetvā tulikāya paricchinnalekhāya paricchinditvā
analyzed: tattha tattha pahaṭena na calitaḥ abhinnaḥ eva abhinnam attharaṇam paricchinditvā  paññattaḥ viyāti ayam chekena cittakārena cintetvā tulikāya paricchinna lekhāya paricchinditvā
translated: Not broken: not broken up by being struck here and there. It is not broken up because it is not shaken. It is spread out:🔽it is spread out, as if it were a bedstead made by a carpenter and marked out with a line drawn with chalk.

original: likhitā cittakataseyyā viya. Bhūnaṃ vuccati vaḍḍhitaṃ, taṃ hantīti bhūnahuno. Tenāha
analyzed: likhitā cittakata seyyā viya bhūnam vuccati vaḍḍhitam tam hanti iti tena āha
translated: It is called “grown” because it is increased. It destroys that, thus it is a destroyer of what is grown. Hence he said “of what is increased” .

original: “hatavaḍḍhino”ti. Taṃ panāyaṃ cakkhādīsu saṃvaravidhānaṃ vaḍḍhihananaṃ maññati. Tenāha
analyzed: hata vaḍḍhino ti tam pana ayam cakkha ādīsu saṃvara vidhānam vaḍḍhi hananam maññati tena āha
translated: But he thinks that the restraint of the eye faculty, etc., is the destruction of what is grown. Hence he said “of what is bounded by a limit” .

original: “mariyādakārakassā”ti. Brūhetabbanti uḷāravisayūpahārena vaḍḍhetabbaṃ pīṇetabbaṃ.
analyzed: mariyāda kārakassa ati uḷāra visaya upahārena vaḍḍhetabbam pīṇetabbam
translated: It should be increased: it should be increased, should be nourished, by the offering of a lofty object.

original: Taṃ pana ananubhūtānubhavanena hotīti āha “adiṭṭhaṃ dakkhitabba”nti. Anubhūtaṃ pana
analyzed: tam pana ananubhūta anubhavanena hoti iti āha adiṭṭham dakkhitabbanti anubhūtam pana
translated: But that is done by experiencing what has not been experienced. Hence he said “the unseen should be seen” . But what has been experienced should be remembered. Hence he said “the heard should be heard” .

original: apaṇītaṃ hotīti vuttaṃ “diṭṭhaṃ samatikkamitabba”nti. Sesavāresupi eseva nayo. Paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānavādī
analyzed: apaṇītam hoti iti vuttam diṭṭham samatikkamitabbanti sesa vāresu pi esa eva nayaḥ parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādī
translated: “The seen should be overpassed” is said because it is not to be clung to. The same method applies to the rest of the cases.🔽The wanderer Kiṃsika was a proponent of nibbāna here and now.

original: kiresa paribbājako, tasmā evaṃ chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhiṃ paññapeti. Yasmā yaṃ channampi
analyzed: paribbājako tasmai evam chasu dvāresu vaḍḍhim paññapeti yasmai yam channam pi
translated: Therefore he thus explains the increase in the six doors.

original: cakkhādīnaṃ yathāsakaṃ visayaggahaṇaṃ paṭikkhipanto lokassa avaḍḍhitaṃ vināsameva
analyzed: cakkha ādīnam yathāsakam visaya ggahaṇam paṭikkhipanto lokassa avaḍḍhitam
translated: Since he explains the world’s non-increase as its non-decrease by denying the six faculties’ grasping of their respective objects,

original: paññapeti, tasmā so sayampi vaḍḍhihato hatavaḍḍhito.
analyzed: paññapeti tasmā so sayam pi vaḍḍhi hataḥ hata vaḍḍhitaḥ
translated: he himself is increased by the increase and decreased by the decrease.

original: Saṃkilesato ārakattā ariyo niyyānikadhammabhāvato ñāyo dhammo. Vajjalesassapi abhāvato
analyzed: saṃkilesataḥ ārakattā ariyaḥ niyyānika dhamma bhāvataḥ ñāyaḥ dhammaḥ vajja lesassa api abhāvato
translated: The noble is so called because of its distance from defilement, and the true because of its being the way to deliverance. He is skilled because he is free from the fault of confusion.

original: kusalo. Tenāha “parisuddhe kāraṇadhamme anavajje”ti. Uggatassāti uccakulīnatādinā
analyzed: tena āha parisuddhe kāraṇa dhamme anavajja iti uggatassa ati ucca kulīna tā ādinā
translated: Therefore he says, “in the pure and blameless way.”🔽The lofty is one who is lofty because of his high birth, etc.

original: uḷārassa. Mukhe ārakkhaṃ ṭhapetvāti mukhena saṃyato hutvā. Ambajambūādīni gahetvā
analyzed: uḷārassa mukhe ārakkham ṭhapetvā ati mukhena saṃyataḥ hutvā amba jambū ādīni gahetvā
translated: Having placed a guard at the door of his mouth, he is restrained by his mouth.🔽Not filling up, like picking up mango, rose-apple, etc.

original: viya apūrayamānoti ambajambūādīni aññamaññavisadisāni viya pūraṇakathānayena yaṃ
analyzed: viya a pūrayamānaḥ iti amba jambu ādīni añña mañña visadisāni pūraṇa kathā nayena yam
translated: Not filling up is the method of teaching by way of filling up with mango, rose-apple, etc., which are mutually different.

original: kiñci akathetvā. Tenāha “mayā kathitaniyāmenā”ti.
analyzed: kiñci a kathetvā tena āha mayā kathita niyāmena ati
translated: without saying anything. Hence he said: ‘in the way I have told you.’

original: 208. Phalasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhitoti divāvihārato vuṭṭhitoti attho. Divāvihāropi hi “paṭisallāna”nti
analyzed: phala samāpattiyā vuṭṭhitaḥ ti divāvihārataḥ vuṭṭhitaḥ ti atthaḥ divāvihāraḥ api hi paṭisallānam ti
translated: ‘Arisen from his fruition attainment’: the meaning is: arisen from his day-meditation. For day-meditation is called ‘seclusion’

original: vuccati “rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādī”tiādīsu. Bhagavā
analyzed: vuccati rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evam cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi iti ādīsu bhagavā
translated: in such passages as ‘When he had gone into seclusion and was meditating’ .

original: hi phalasamāpattito vuṭṭhānuttarakālaṃ tesaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ sutvā divāvihārato vuṭṭhāya🔽tattha gato. Saṃvego nāma sahottappañāṇaṃ, taṃ nibbindanavasenapi hoti, saṃveganissitaṃ
analyzed: hi phala samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāna uttara kālam tesam kathā sallāpam sutvā divāvihārataḥ vuṭṭhāya  tattha gataḥ saṃvegaḥ nāma saha uttappa ñāṇam tam nibbindana vasena api hoti saṃvega nissitam
translated: The Blessed One, having heard their conversation after he had arisen from his fruition attainment, went there after arising from his day-meditation.

original: sandhāyāha “pītisaṃvegena saṃviggo”ti. So pana yasmā purimāvatthāya calanaṃ hoti
analyzed: sandhāya āha pīti saṃvegena saṃviggo ti saḥ pana yasmai purima avatthāya calanam hoti
translated: ‘A sense of urgency’ is knowledge accompanied by heat. It is also due to the state of dispassion. With reference to that which is based on a sense of urgency he said: ‘Urged on by the urgency of rapture.’🔽But since there is a shaking of the mind due to the previous stage,

original: cittassa, tasmā āha “calito kampito”ti. Tikhiṇasotena purisenāti bhagavantaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: cittassa tasmai āha calitaḥ kampitaḥ iti tikhiṇa sotena purisena ati bhagavantam sandhāya āha
translated: he said: ‘He shook and quivered.’ ‘A man with a sharp ear’ refers to the Blessed One.

original: 209. Dhammadesanaṃ ārabhi yathā vineyyadamanakusalo vasanaṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti idaṃ āramitabbabhāvassa
analyzed: dhamma desanam ārabhi yathā vineyya damana kusalaḥ vasana ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ati idam āramitabba bhāvassa
translated: ‘He began to teach the Dhamma in the way that one skilled in taming should do, in the way that is fitting for a place of abode’ .

original: bhāvalakkhaṇavacanaṃ. Āramati etthāti ārāmo, rūpaṃ ārāmo etassāti rūpārāmaṃ, tato🔽eva tanninnabhāvena rūpe ratanti rūparataṃ, tena sammo duppattiyā rūpena sammuditanti
analyzed: bhāva lakkhaṇa vacanam āramati ettha ati ārāmaḥ rūpam ārāmaḥ etassa ati rūpa ārāmam tatas  eva tat ninna bhāvena rūpe ratanti rūpa ratam tena sammo duppattiyā rūpena sammuditanti
translated: The words “state” and “characteristic” are said. It is a delight in that, thus it is delighting in visible forms. He who has that is a delighting-in-visible-forms person.

original: rūpasammuditaṃ, tadetaṃ tadabhihatajavanakiccaṃ tattha āropetvā vuttaṃ. Dantantiādīsupi
analyzed: rūpa sammuditam tat etam tad abhihata javana kiccam tattha āropetvā vuttam danta nti ādīsu pi
translated: Because of that he is addicted to visible forms by reason of his being addicted to them, thus he is addicted to visible forms. Because of that he is gladdened by visible forms by reason of his being gladdened by them, thus he is gladdened by visible forms. That is said of him by construing the function of the impulsion that is struck by that in that .🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of “tamed” , etc.

original: eseva nayo. Dantaṃ damitaṃ. Nibbisevananti vigatavisukāyikaṃ. Guttanti satiyā guttaṃ.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ dantam damitam nibbisevanam nibbisevanam ti vigata visu kāyikam guttam ti satiyā guttam
translated: Tamed: controlled. Not frequented: not frequented by the kinds of defilement.🔽Guarded: guarded by mindfulness.

original: Rakkhitanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Saṃvutanti apanītaṃ pavesanivāraṇena. Tenāha “pihita”nti.
analyzed: rakkhitanti tassa iva vevacanam saṃvutanti apanītam pavesa nivāraṇena tena āha pihitanti
translated: Protected: this is a synonym for the same thing. Restrained: removed by preventing its entry. Hence “closed” is said.

original: 210. Uppajjanapariḷāhanti uppajjanakilesapariḷāhaṃ. Kiṃ vacanaṃ vattabbaṃ assāti
analyzed: uppajjana pariḷāham ti uppajjana kilesa pariḷāham kim vacanam vattabbam assa ati
translated: The fever of arising: the fever of defilement that has arisen. What should be said?

original: rūpārammaṇaṃ anubhavitvā samudayādipahānaṃ pariggaṇhitvā parinibbinditvā virajjitvā
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇam anubhavitvā samudaya ādi pahānam pariggaṇhitvā parinibbinditvā virajjitvā
translated: Having experienced the object of visible form, having discerned the abandoning of origin, having been gladdened, having been dispassionate,

original: yo vimutto, tattha kiṃ vuddhihatapariyāyo avassaṃ labhati na labhatīti pucchati.
analyzed: yaḥ vimuttaḥ tattha kim vuddhi hata pariyāyaḥ avassam labhati na labhati iti pucchati
translated: he who is liberated, there what is the method of the measure of growth? Does he not get it?

original: Paribbājako tādise sārabaddhavimuttike vuddhihatoti na vadeyyāti āha “na kiñci, bho, gotamā”ti.
analyzed: paribbājako tādise sāra baddha vimuttike vuddhi hato ti na vadeyya ati āha na kiñci bho gotama ati
translated: “Nothing, Master Gotama.”

original: 211. Teti tayā, ayameva vā pāṭho. Vassaṃ vāso vassaṃ uttarapadalopena, vassituṃ arahatīti vassiko, vassakāle nivāsānucchavikoti attho.
analyzed: tā iti tayā ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ vassam vāsaḥ vassam uttara pada lopena vassitum arahati iti vassikaḥ vassa kāle attho
translated: “You”: the reading is doubtful. “Rain-resort”: the word vassaṃ is a locative of vassa, “rain,” with the final syllable elided. “Rain-resort” is a place suitable for living in during the rainy season.

original: Nātiucco hoti nātinīcoti gimhiko viya ucco, hemantiko viya nīco na hoti, atha kho
analyzed: na ati uccaḥ hoti na ati nīcaḥ iti gimhikaḥ viya uccaḥ hemantikaḥ viya nīcaḥ na hoti atha kho
translated: “Not too high”: not high like a summer house. “Not too low”: not low like a winter house.

original: tadubhayavemajjhalakkhaṇatāya nātiucco hoti nātinīco. Nātitanūnīti hemantikassa viya
analyzed: tad ubhaya vemajjha lakkhaṇa tāya na ati uccaḥ hoti na ati nīcaḥ na ati tanūni iti hemantikassa viya
translated: But it is not too high and not too low because it has the characteristic of being between the two.🔽“Not too small”: not small like a winter house.

original: na khuddakāni. Nātibahūnīti gimhikassa viya na atibahūni. Missakānevāti hemantikagimhikesu🔽vuttalakkhaṇavomissakāni. Uṇhapavesanatthāyāti niyūhesu purebhattaṃ pacchābhattañca
analyzed: na khuddakāni na atibahūni iti gimhikassa viya na atibahūni missakān eva ati hemantika gimhikesu  vutta lakkhaṇa vomissakāni uṇha pavesana atthāya ati niyūhesu purebhattam pacchābhattam ca
translated: “Not too large”: not large like a summer house.🔽“Mixed”: having the characteristics stated in the case of the winter house and the summer house.🔽“For the purpose of warding off heat”: in order to ward off heat that has entered in, as the sun’s rays fall in the forenoon and afternoon.

original: patitasūriyobhāsavasena uṇhassa abbhantarapavesanatthāya. Bhittiniyūhāni nīharīyantīti
analyzed: patita sūriya ubhāsa vasena uṇhassa abbhantara pavesana tthāya bhitti niyūhāni nīharīyanti iti
translated: “The wall-niches are removed”:

original: dakkhiṇapasse bhittīsu niyūhāni nīharitvā karīyanti. Vipulajālānīti puthulachiddāni.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa passe bhittīsu niyūhāni nīharitvā karīyanti vipula jālāni iti puthula chiddāni
translated: and they are made by taking out the rubbish into the walls on the right. With wide nets means with wide openings.

original: Udakayantānīti udakavāhakayantāni.
analyzed: udaka yantāni iti udaka vāhaka yantāni
translated: With water-carrying pipes means with pipes for carrying water.

original: Nīluppalagacchake katvāti vikasitehi nīluppalehi gacchake naḷinike katvā. Gandhakalalanti
analyzed: nīluppala gacchake katvā ati vikasitehi nīluppalehi gacchake naḷinike katvā gandha kalalanti
translated: Made like a bed of blue lotuses means made like a bed of fully-blossomed blue lotuses. With fragrant mud means with mud mixed with perfume.

original: gandhamissakakaddamaṃ. Yamakabhittīti yugaḷabhitti, tassā antare nāḷi, yato udakaṃ🔽abhiruhati. Lohanāḷinti lohamayayantanāḷiṃ. Jālanti tambalohamayaṃ jālaṃ. Heṭṭhā
analyzed: gandha missaka kaddamam yamaka bhitti iti yugaḷa bhitti tassāḥ antare yatas udakam  abhiruhati loha nāḷim iti tamba loha mayam jālam heṭṭhā
translated: With double walls means with double walls; inside it there is a pipe through which the water🔽rises. With a copper pipe means with a copper water-carrying pipe. With a copper net means with a copper net.

original: yantaṃ parivattentīti heṭṭhābhāge udakayantaṃ gamenti. Udakaphusite temente vivaṇṇatā
analyzed: yantam parivattenti iti heṭṭhābhāge udaka yantam gamenti udaka phusite temente vivaṇṇa tā
translated: Turning the water-carrying pipe below means going to the water-carrying pipe below. When the water is heated by the sun’s heat and is steaming and discolored,

original: māhosīti nīlapaṭaṃ nivāseti. Divākāleti divasavelāya. Ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto viharāmīti
analyzed: nīla paṭam nivāsa iti divākāla iti divasa velāya ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ viharāmi iti
translated: I put on a blue robe, thinking: ‘Let there be no trouble.’ At the time of day means at the time of day. I dwell with a mind inwardly peaceful means

original: etena attano phalasamāpattivihāro bhagavatā dassitoti āha – “tāya ratiyā ramamānoti
analyzed: etena attano phala samāpatti vihāraḥ bhagavatā dassito ti āha tāya ratiyā ramamāno ti
translated: by this the Blessed One shows his own dwelling in the attainment of fruition. He said: “I delight in that delight”

original: idaṃ catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpattiratiṃ sandhāya vutta”nti.
analyzed: idam catuttha jhānika phala samāpatti ratim sandhāya vuttam ti
translated: this was said with reference to the delight in the attainment of fruition in the fourth jhāna.

original: 212. Mahā ca nesaṃ papañcoti nesaṃ rājūnaṃ mahāpapañco rājiddhivasena sabbadā sampattivisayo
analyzed: ca nesam papañco ti nesam rājūnam mahā papañcaḥ rājiddhi vasena sabbadā sampatti visayo
translated: 212.Their great proliferation: their great proliferation is the great proliferation of the kings’ prosperity, which is the object of their success,

original: ca, anubhavituṃ na labhantīti adhippāyo. Mante gavesantā vicaranti, na bhogasukhaṃ.
analyzed: ca anubhavitum na labhanti iti adhippāyaḥ mante gavesantāḥ vicaranti na bhoga sukham
translated: and the meaning is that they do not get to experience it. They wander about seeking for the thought, not for the pleasure of enjoyment.

original: Gaṇanā nāma acchinnagaṇanā, na vigaṇagaṇanā na paṇagaṇanā. Āvaṭṭoti yathādhigate
analyzed: gaṇanā nāma acchinna gaṇanā na vigaṇa gaṇanā na paṇa gaṇanā yathā adhigate
translated: Counting is unbroken counting, not interrupted counting, not counted in groups.🔽Turning away: he would turn away, turn back, turn round, from the heavenly sensual desires, the cause for which is sensual desire.

original: dibbe kāme pahāya kāmahetu āvaṭṭo nivatto parivattito bhaveyya. Evaṃ mānusakā kāmāti
analyzed: dibbe kāme pahāya kāma hetu āvaṭṭaḥ nivatto parivattitaḥ bhaveyya evam mānusakā kāmā ti
translated: So too, in the case of human sensual desires:

original: yathā koci kusaggena udakaṃ gahetvā mahāsamudde udakaṃ mineyya. Tattha mahāsamudde
analyzed: yathā koci kusaggena udakam gahetvā mahā samudde udakam mineyya tattha mahā samudde
translated: just as one might take water in a blade of grass and say “I have taken water from the great ocean,”🔽in the great ocean the water is indeed great, vast, and excellent,

original: udakameva mahantaṃ vipulaṃ paṇītañca, evaṃ dibbānaṃ kāmānaṃ samīpe upanidhāya mānusakā
analyzed: udakam eva mahantam vipulam paṇītam ca evam dibbānam kāmānam samīpe upanidhāya mānusakā
translated: so too, in the case of human sensual desires, which are placed in proximity to the heavenly sensual desires,

original: kāmā appamattakā oramattakā nihīnā, dibbāva kāmā mahantā vipulā uḷārā paṇītā. Samadhigayhāti
analyzed: kāmāḥ appamattakāḥ oramattakāḥ nihīnāḥ dibbāḥ ava kāmāḥ mahantā vipulāḥ uḷārā paṇītā samadhigayhāti
translated: the human sensual desires are trifling, contemptible, inferior, while the heavenly sensual desires are great, vast, abundant, and excellent.

original: sammā adhigamanavasena niggayha dibbampi sukhaṃ hīnaṃ katvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sammā adhigamana vasena niggayha dibbam pi sukham hīnam katvā tiṭṭhati
translated: Having attained: having attained them by right attainment, he stands having made even the heavenly pleasure inferior.

original: 213. Ārogyahetukaṃ sukhaṃ assa atthīti sukhī, taṃ panassa rogavigamatovāti āha “paṭhamaṃ🔽dukkhito pacchā sukhito”ti. Serī nāma attādhīnavuttīti āha “serī ekako bhaveyyā”ti.
analyzed: ārogya hetukam sukham assa atthi iti sukhī tam panassa roga vigamataḥ vā ati āha paṭhamam  dukkhito pacchā sukhito ti serī nāma atta adhīna vuttī iti āha serī ekakaḥ bhaveyya iti
translated: He is happy because he has the kind of happiness that has a cause in health. But that is due to his being free from sickness. That is why he said: “First sick, then happy” . The solitary man is one who lives independently. That is why he said: “The solitary man should live alone” .

original: Attano vaso sayaṃvaso, so etassa atthīti sayaṃvasī. Aṅgārakapallaṃ viya kāmavatthupariḷāhahetuto.🔽Tacchetvāti ghaṭṭetvā, kaṇḍūyitvāti attho.
analyzed: attanaḥ vaso sayaṃvaso saḥ etassa atthi iti sayaṃvasī aṅgāraka pallam viya kāma vatthu pariḷāha hetutaḥ  tat śetvā iti ghaṭṭetvā kaṇḍūyitvā iti
translated: He was happy because he had the kind of happiness that has a cause, namely, health. But he was happy only after he had got rid of his illness. That is why he said: “First sick, later well” . A “serene man” is one who acts independently. That is why he said: “A serene man, alone” . “Self-master” : he has self-control. The object of his sensual desire is like a burning coal.🔽“To scratch” : to rub.🔽It is said that leprosy destroys the skin and the flesh, leaving the blood and sinews.

original: 214. Yena kāyo madhurakajāto hoti, taṃ kira kuṭṭhaṃ chaviṃ vināseti, cammaṃ chiddajātaṃ
analyzed: yena kāyaḥ madhuraka jātaḥ hoti tam kira kuṭṭham chavim vināseti cammam chidda jātam
translated: That is why he said: “With his skin and flesh destroyed” .🔽He “regained” them because he was overcome by ignorance.

original: viya hoti. Tenevāha “upahatakāyappasādo”ti. Paccalatthāti paṭilabhi. Avijjābhibhūtatāya🔽virodhipaccayasamāyogena paññindriyassa upahatattā. Āyatiṃ dukkhaphalatāya etarahi
analyzed: viya hoti tena iva āha upahata kāya ppasādaḥ ti paccalatthā ati avijjā abhibhūta tāya  virodhi paccaya samāyogena paññindriyassa upahata ttā āyatim dukkha phala tāya etarahi
translated: The faculty of wisdom was destroyed by the concurrence of opposing conditions.

original: ca kilesadukkhabahulatāya kāmānaṃ dukkhasamphassatā, tadubhayasaṃyuttesu tesu ca
analyzed: ca kilesa dukkha bahula tāya kāmānam dukkha samphassa tā tad ubhaya saṃyuttesu tesu ca
translated: Sensual desires have painful impact because they bear painful results in the future and because they are accompanied by a multitude of defilement-born pains in the present.

original: taṃ asallakkhitvā ekantasukhābhiniveso viparītasaññāya, na kevalāya sukhavedanāya
analyzed: tam a sat lakkhitvā ekanta sukha abhinivesaḥ viparīta saññāya na kevalāya sukha vedanāya
translated: Without discerning this, he is devoted to the idea of complete happiness, and his perception is distorted by the pleasant feeling.

original: sukhāti pavattasaññī.
analyzed: sukhā ati pavatta saññī
translated: Without discerning that, he is obsessed with the idea of complete happiness. He is obsessed with the idea of happiness because of the perception that is contrary to the fact and because of the pleasant feeling.

original: 215. Tānīti kuṭṭhasarīre vaṇamukhāni. Asucīnīti asubhāni. Duggandhānīti vissagandhāni.🔽Pūtīnīti kuṇapabhūtāni. Idānīti etarahi. Nakhehi vippatacchanaaggiparitāpanehi atinippīḷanakāle
analyzed: tāni iti kuṭṭha sarīre vaṇa mukhāni asucīni iti asubhāni duggandhāni iti vissa gandhāni  pūtīni iti kuṇapa bhūtāni idāni iti etarahi nakhehi ati nippīḍana kāle
translated: “Those” are the openings of the sores in the leper’s body. “Filth” is the impurity. “Stench” is the smell of pus.🔽“Rotten” is the state of being a corpse. “Now” is at the present time. “When the fire of the sun is burning” is when there is great torment from the sun’s heat.

original: pāṇakā…pe… paggharanti, tena vedanā tanukā hoti. Evanti vuttanayena vedanāya tanukabhāvato.
analyzed: pāṇa kāpe paggharanti tena vedanā tanukā hoti evanti vutta nayena vedanāya tanuka bhāvato
translated: The worms…etc… ooze out. Because of the slightness of the feeling in the way described,

original: Ārogyabhāve dhanalābhādilābhuppattito, asati ca ārogye lābhassa niratthakabhāvato,🔽diṭṭhadhammikādisabbasampattīnaṃ lābhassa nimittabhāvato ca ārogyaparamā lābhā. Nibbāne
analyzed: ārogya bhāve dhana lābha ādi lābha uppattitaḥ asati ca ārogye lābhassa niratthaka bhāvato  diṭṭhadhammika ādi sabba sampattīnam lābhassa nimitta bhāvataḥ ca ārogya paramāḥ lābhāḥ nibbāne
translated: health is the highest gain because of the occurrence of the gain of wealth, etc., when there is health, and because of the uselessness of gain when there is no health,🔽and because of the state of being the cause for the gain of all the accomplishments of the present life, etc. Health is the highest gain because of the occurrence of happiness in Nibbāna,

original: sukhuppattito, asati ca nibbānādhigame tādisassa sukhassa anupalabbhanato, sabbasaṅkhatavivittattā
analyzed: sukha uppattitaḥ asati ca nibbāna adhigame tādisassa sukhassa anupalabbhanato sabba saṅkhata vivitta ttā
translated: and because of the non-occurrence of such happiness when there is no attainment of Nibbāna, and because of the state of being free from all formations.

original: ca sabbaso ca saṃsāradukkhābhāvato, adhigate ca tasmiṃ sakalavaṭṭadukkhābhāvato ca
analyzed: ca sabbaso ca saṃsāra dukkha abhāvato adhigate ca tasmin sakala vaṭṭa dukkha abhāvato ca
translated: and because of the complete absence of suffering in the round of rebirths, and because of the absence of all suffering in the round in what is attained,

original: nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukhaṃ. Pubbabhāgamaggānanti kāyānupassanādibhedabhinnānaṃ ariyamaggassa
analyzed: nibbānam paramam sukham pubbabhāga maggānam ti kāya anupassanā ādi bheda bhinnānam ariya maggassa
translated: Nibbana is the supreme bliss. The paths that lead to the deathless: the paths that are the forerunners of the noble paths classed as mindfulness of the body, etc.,

original: pubbabhāgiyānaṃ maggānaṃ. Tesañca amatagāmitā nāma tanninnatāvaseneva sacchikiriyāvasenāti
analyzed: pubbabhāgiyānam maggānam tesam ca amata gāmi tā nāma tad ninna tā vasena iva sacchikiriyā vasena ati
translated: and the realization of their being “the path to the deathless” is only by way of their inclination to the deathless and by way of their being the means to its realization.

original: āha “pubbabhāgagamaneneva amatagāmina”nti. Aṭṭhaṅgiko ariyamaggo khemo sabbaparissayasamugghātanena
analyzed: āha pubba bhāga gamanena iva amata gāminan ti aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ariya maggaḥ khemaḥ sabba parissaya samugghātanena
translated: Hence it is said, “They lead to the deathless by leading to the forerunner of the deathless.” The noble eightfold path is safe because it is free from all danger by the complete eradication of all the hindrances,

original: anupaddutattā, taṃsamaṅgīnaṃ sabbaso anupaddutattā taṃsamaṅgīnaṃ sabbaso anupaddavahetuto🔽ca. Laddhivasena gahitāti sassatavādādīhi kevalaṃ tesaṃ laddhivasena tathā gahitā.
analyzed: an upadduta ttā taṃ samaṅgīnam sabbasas an upadduta ttā taṃ samaṅgīnam sabbasas an upaddava hetutaḥ  ca laddhi vasena gahitā ati sassata vāda ādīhi kevalam tesam laddhi vasena tathā gahitā
translated: and because it is the cause of the complete freedom from danger for those who possess it.🔽They are held to be safe and leading to the deathless by mere assertion: they are held to be so by eternalists, etc., only by mere assertion.

original: Khemaamatagāminanti iminā hi “khemaṃamatagāmina”nti vibhattialopena niddeso, attho
analyzed: khema amata gāminaṃ ti iminā hi vibhatti a lopena niddesaḥ attho
translated: Safe and leading to the deathless: the demonstrative pronoun “that” is omitted in “safe and leading to the deathless.”

original: pana vibhattilopena daṭṭhabboti dasseti.
analyzed: pana vibhatti lopena daṭṭhabbaḥ iti dasseti
translated: But the meaning should be understood by supplying the omitted demonstrative pronoun.

original: 216. Anomajjatīti anu anu omajjati. Aparāparaṃ hatthaṃ heṭṭhā otārento majjati.🔽217. Chekanti ghanabhāvena vītaṃ. Ghanamaṭṭhabhāvena sundaraṃ hotīti āha “sampanna”nti. Sādhūhi paramappicchasantuṭṭhehi lāto gahitoti sāhuḷi. Saṅkāracoḷakaṃ niccakāḷakaṃ.
analyzed: anomajjati iti anu anu omajjati apara aparam hattham heṭṭhā otārentaḥ majjati  chekanti ghana bhāvena vītam ghana maṭṭha bhāvena sundaram hoti iti āha sampannanti sādhūhi parama ppiccha santuṭṭhehi lātaḥ gahitaḥ iti sāhuḷi saṅkāra coḷakam nicca kāḷakam
translated: He sinks down again and again: he sinks down by sinking down again and again, by lowering the hand below each time.

original: 218. Tattha tattha rujanaṭṭhena vibādhanaṭṭhena rogova bhūto. Vipassanāñāṇenapi sikhāppattena ārogyaṃ ekadesena passati, nibbānañca vaṭṭapaṭipakkhatoti āha “vipassanāñāṇañcevā”ti.🔽219. Antarāti paṭhamuppatti jarāmaraṇānaṃ vemajjhe. Upahatoti pittasemhādidosehi🔽dūsitabhāvena kathito. Pittādidose pana bhesajjasevanāya nivattento upahataṃ paṭipākatikaṃ🔽karonto cakkhūni uppādeti nāma. Vinaṭṭhānīti anuppattidhammataṃ āpannāni.
analyzed: tattha tattha rujana ṭhena vibādhana ṭṭhena rogaḥ uva bhūtaḥ vipassanā ñāṇena api sikhā ppattena ārogyam eka desena passati nibbānam ca vaṭṭa paṭipakkhato ti āha vipassanā ñāṇam ca eva iti 🔽antarā ti paṭhama uppatti jarā maraṇānaṃ vemajjhe pitta semha ādi dosehi 🔽dūsita bhāvena kathitaḥ pitta ādi dose pana bhesajja sevanāya nivattento upahatam paṭipākatikam 🔽karontaḥ cakkhūni uppādeti nāma vinaṭṭhāni iti an uppatti dhamma tam āpannāni
translated: A cheka: a cheka is a piece of cloth that is thick and compact. It is beautiful because of the thickness and compactness. That is why it is said, “well-made” . It is well-made because it is made by good weavers who are supremely indifferent to gain and are content. original: 220. Pubbe vutte sāhuḷiyacīre. Vaṭṭe anugatacittenāti anamatagge saṃsāravaṭṭe anādīnavadassitāya anugāmicittena.🔽221. Dhammassāti nibbānassa. Anudhammanti anurūpaṃ niyyānadhammaṃ. Tenāha “anucchavikaṃ
analyzed: pubbe vutte sāhuḷiya cīre vaṭṭe anugata cittena ati anamatagge saṃsāra vaṭṭe anādīnava dassitāya anugāmi cittena  dhammassa ati nibbānassa anudhammanti anurūpam niyyāna dhammam tena āha anucchavikam
translated: The rag-robe mentioned earlier. With a mind that has followed the round : with a mind that has followed the round of rebirths without end, because he has not seen the danger in it.

original: paṭipada”nti. Pañcakkhandheti pañcupādānakkhandhe dasseti. “Dīgharattaṃ vata, bho”tiādinā
analyzed: paṭipadanti pañca kkhandha iti pañca upādāna kkhandhe dasseti dīgharattam vata bho ti ādinā
translated: The Dhamma : Nibbāna. The way : the way that is appropriate, that leads to it. Hence he said “the practice that is in conformity with it” . The five aggregates : he shows the five aggregates as objects of clinging. “For a long time, good sirs” , etc.,

original: pāḷiyaṃ vivaṭṭaṃ dassitaṃ. Tenāha “upādānanirodhāti vivaṭṭaṃ dassento”ti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: pāḷiyam vivaṭṭam dassitam tena āha upādāna nirodhā iti vivaṭṭam dassento ti sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: is the explanation given in the text. Hence he said “showing the turning back, he said ‘with the cessation of clinging’ ” . The rest is easy to understand.

original: Māgaṇḍiyasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
translated: The exposition of the meaning of the brief statement in the Māgaṇḍiya Sutta is ended.

original: 6. Sandakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sandaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Sandaka Sutta

original: 223. Devena vassena kato sobbho devakatasobbho. Tenāha “vasso…pe… rahado”ti. Guhāti
analyzed: devena vassena kataḥ sobbhaḥ deva kata sobbhaḥ tena āha vassope guhā iti
translated: The pool made by the rain of the gods is the “divine pool.” Hence he said “the rain of the gods … the lake” . The cave

original: paṃsuguhā pāsāṇaguhā missakaguhāti tisso guhā. Tattha paṃsuguhā udakamuttaṭṭhāne
analyzed: paṃsu guhā pāsāṇa guhā missaka guhā ati tissaḥ guhā tattha paṃsu guhā udakamutta ṭṭhāne
translated: is of three kinds: the sand cave, the rock cave, and the mixed cave. Herein, the sand cave is a place where water collects.

original: ahosi ninnaṭṭhānaṃ pana udakena ajjhotthataṃ. Umaṅgaṃ katvāti heṭṭhā suduggaṃ katvā.
analyzed: ahosi ninna ṭṭhānam pana udakena ajjhotthatam umaṅgam katvā ati heṭṭhā su duggam katvā
translated: and the low-lying places were flooded with water. Having made a bridge: having made a bridge below.

original: Anamataggiyaṃ paccavekkhitvāti “na kho so sattāvāso sulabharūpo, yo iminā dīghena
analyzed: anamataggiyam paccavekkhitvā ti na kho so sattāvāsaḥ sulabha rūpaḥ yaḥ iminā dīghena
translated: Having reviewed the past: “That abode of beings is not easy to find, where I have not been born and have not gone again and again

original: addhunā anāvuṭṭhapubbo”tiādinā idañca taḷākaṃ mayā vutthapubbaṃ bhavissati, tampi
analyzed: addhunā an āvuṭṭha pubba uti ādinā idam ca taḷākam mayā vuttha pubbam bhavissati tam pi
translated: for a long time.” This tank has been lived in by me before. That place

original: ṭhānaṃ so ca attabhāvo apaññattikabhāvaṃ gatoti evaṃ anamataggiyaṃ paccavekkhitvā
analyzed: ṭhānam saḥ ca atta bhāvaḥ apaññattika bhāvam gataḥ ti evam anamataggiyam paccavekkhitvā
translated: and that person have disappeared. Having reviewed the past in this way,

original: tādisaṃ ṭhānaṃ gantuṃ vaṭṭati. Iminā nayena samuddapabbatadassanādīsupi paccavekkhaṇāvidhi veditabbo.🔽Uccaṃ nadamānāyāti uccaṃ katvā saddaṃ karontiyā kāmassādabhavassādādivatthunti “ayañca🔽ayañca kāmo iṭṭho kanto manāpo, asuko bhavo iṭṭho kanto manāpo, evamayaṃ loko piyehi
analyzed: tādisam ṭhānam gantum vaṭṭati iminā nayena samudda pabbata dassana ādīsu pi paccavekkhaṇā vidhi veditabbaḥ  uccam nadamānāya ati uccam katvā saddam karontiyā ayam ca  ayañca kāmaḥ iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ asukaḥ bhavaḥ iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ evam ayam lokaḥ piyehi
translated: it is proper to go to such a place. In this way the method of reviewing should be understood in the case of seeing the ocean, a mountain, etc.🔽While she was crying out: while she was making a loud sound. The object of sensual pleasure, of existence, etc.: “This sensual pleasure is desirable, lovely, agreeable; this existence is desirable, lovely, agreeable. Thus this world is dearer than the loved one.🔽” Thus the object called the gratification of sensual pleasure, the gratification of existence, the gratification of the world, etc.

original: piyataro”ti evaṃ kāmassādabhavassādalokassādādisaṅkhātaṃ vatthuṃ. Duggatito saṃsārato
analyzed: piyataro ti evam kāmassāda bhavassāda lokassāda ādi saṅkhātam vatthum duggatitaḥ saṃsārato
translated: From the evil states of the round of rebirths,

original: ca niyyāti etenāti niyyānaṃ, saggamaggo mokkhamaggo ca, taṃ niyyānaṃ arahati, niyyāne
analyzed: ca niyyāti etena ati niyyānam sagga maggaḥ mokkha maggo ca tam niyyānam arahati niyyāne
translated: and it goes out by this, thus it is a going-out ; it is the path to heaven and the path to deliverance. It is worthy of that, thus it is worthy of the going-out ;

original: vā niyuttāti niyyānikā, niyyānaṃ vā phalaṃ etissā atthīti niyyānikā, vacīduccaritādisaṃkilesato
analyzed: vā niyuttā ati niyyānikā niyyānam vā phalam etissā atthi iti niyyānikā vacī duccarita ādi saṃkilesato
translated: or it is occupied with the going-out, thus it is of the going-out ; or the fruit of the going-out is in it, thus it is of the going-out ; or it goes out from the defilement consisting in verbal misconduct, etc., thus it is of the going-out ;

original: niyyātīti vā niyyānīyā, ī-kārassa rassattaṃ ya-kārassa ca ka-kāraṃ katvā niyyānikā,
analyzed: niyyāti iti vā niyyānīyā īkārassa rassa ttam yakārassa ca kakāram katvā niyyānikā
translated: or it is to be gone out by, thus it is of the going-out ; the i is lengthened for the sake of the metre, and the y is made a j, thus it is of the going-out ;🔽the opposite of that is not of the going-out ;

original: cetanāya saddhiṃ samphappalāpā veramaṇi. Tappaṭipakkhato aniyyānikā, tassā bhāvo🔽aniyyānikattaṃ, tasmā aniyyānikattā. Tiracchānabhūtāti tirokaraṇabhūtā. Gehassitakathāti
analyzed: cetanāya saddhim samphappalāpā veramaṇi tad paṭipakkhato aniyyānikā tassāḥ bhāvo  a niyyānikattam tasmai a niyyānikattā tiracchāna bhūtā ati tirokaraṇa bhūtā geha sita kathā ati
translated: the state of that is🔽not of the going-out ;

original: kāmapaṭisaṃyuttakathā. Kammaṭṭhānabhāveti aniccatāpaṭisaṃyuttacatusaccakammaṭṭhānabhāve.
analyzed: kāma paṭisaṃyutta kathā kammaṭṭhāna bhāve iti anicca tā paṭisaṃyutta catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna bhāve
translated: because of that, ‘because of not being of the going-out’ . ‘Become beasts’ : become concealed. ‘House talk’ : talk connected with sense desires. ‘The state of the meditation subject’ : the state of the meditation subject consisting of the four noble truths connected with impermanence.

original: Saha atthenāti sātthakaṃ, hitapaṭisaṃyuttanti attho. Visikhāti gharasanniveso, visikhāgahaṇena
analyzed: saha atthena ati sa atthakam hita paṭisaṃyuttanti atthaḥ visikhā ati ghara sannivesaḥ visikhā gahaṇena
translated: ‘With meaning’ : profitable ; the meaning is ‘connected with welfare.’ ‘House’ : a house-site. By the word ‘house’

original: ca tannivāsino gahitā “gāmo āgato”tiādīsu viya. Tenevāha “sūrā samatthā”ti “saddhā
analyzed: ca tad nivāsinaḥ gahitāḥ gāmaḥ āgataḥ iti ādīsu tena iva āha sūrā samatthā ati saddhā
translated: and the inhabitants of that place are included, as in the expressions “the village has come” and “the town has come.” That is why he says “the faithful and the confident” and “the slaves and slave-women.” The slave-women are mentioned by the expression “the place for the pots,” thus he says “or the story of the slave-women.”

original: pasannā”ti ca. Kumbhaṭṭhānappadesena kumbhadāsiyo vuttāti āha “kumbhadāsikathā vā”ti.🔽228. Vohāro viya tesaṃ tathā vohāramattaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ “brahmacariyavāse”ti. Akatāti🔽samena, visamena vā kenaci hetunā na katā na vihitā. Katavidho karaṇavidhi natthi
analyzed: pasannā iti ca kumbha ṭṭhāna ppadesena kumbhadāsiyaḥ vuttā iti āha kumbhadāsi kathā vā ti  vohāraḥ viya tesam tathā vohāra mattam gahetvā vuttam brahmacariya vāsā iti akatā ati  samena visamena vā kenacid hetunā na katā na vihitā katavidhaḥ karaṇa vidhi natthi
translated: As in ordinary usage, so in the Dispensation, it is said “in the life of purity” by taking it as mere usage. Unmade means not made, not created, by any means, whether fair or foul. There is no rule of creation in them.

original: etesanti akaṭavidhā. Padadvayenapi loke kenaci hetupaccayena nesaṃ anibbattataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: etesan ti akaṭavidhā pada dvayena api loke kenaci hetu paccayena na esam anibbatta tam dasseti
translated: By the two expressions he shows that they are not born in the world for any reason or cause.

original: Iddhiyāpi na nimmitāti kassaci iddhimato cetovasippattassa devassa, issarādino vā🔽iddhiyāpi na nimmitā. Animmātāti kassaci animmāpitā. Rūpādijanakabhāvanti rūpasaddādīnaṃ🔽paccayabhāvaṃ, rūpādayopi pathaviyādīhi appaṭibaddhavuttikāti tassa adhippāyo. Yathā
analyzed: iddhiyā api na kassaci iddhimataḥ cetaḥ vasi pattassa devassa issara ādinaḥ vā 🔽iddhiyā api na nimmitā a nimmātā ati kassaci a nimmāpitā rūpa ādi janaka bhāvanti rūpa sadda ādīnam 🔽paccaya bhāvam rūpa ādayaḥ api pathaviya ādīhi appaṭibaddha vuttikā ti tassa adhippāyaḥ yathā
translated: Not created by magic power means not created by the magic power of anyone who has attained mental mastery, such as a deity of magic power or a world ruler. original: pabbatakūṭaṃ kenaci anibbattitaṃ kassaci ca anibbattanakaṃ, evametepīti āha “pabbatakūṭā🔽viya ṭhitāti kūṭaṭṭhā”ti. Yamidaṃ bījato aṅkurādi jāyatīti vuccati, taṃ vijjamānameva
analyzed: pabbata kūṭam kenaci a nibbattitam kassaci ca a nibbattanakam evam ete api iti āha pabbata kūṭāḥ  viya ṭhitā ati yam idam bījataḥ aṅkura ādi jāyati iti vuccati tam vijjamānam eva
translated: Just as a mountain peak is not made by anyone and does not make anyone, so too these states are not made by anyone and do not make anyone. This is the meaning.

original: tato nikkhamati nāvijjamānaṃ, aññathā aññatopi aññassa upaladdhi siyāti adhippāyo.🔽Evaṃ ṭhitāti evaṃ nibbikārā ṭhitā. Ubhayenapīti atthadvayenapīti vadanti. “Kūṭaṭṭhā
analyzed: tatas nikkhamati na avijjamānam aññathā aññatas pi aññassa upaladdhi siyā ti adhippāyaḥ  evam ṭhitā ati evam nibbikārā ṭhitā ubhayena api iti attha dvayena api iti vadanti kūṭaṭṭhā
translated: The intention is this: what is called “arisen from a seed” is only what exists that comes out of it, not what does not exist. Otherwise, anything could come from anything.🔽“Thus established”: thus established without making anything. They say that it is by both meanings, by the two terms “established like a mountain peak” and “established like a pillar.”

original: esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā”ti padadvayenapi. Tesaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ. Ṭhitattāti nibbikārābhāvena
analyzed: esika ṭṭhāyi ṭṭhitā ti pada dvayena api tesam sattannam kāyānam ṭhita ttā ati nibbikāra abhāvena
translated: Of those seven bodies. “Established”: because of being established without making anything.

original: ṭhitattā. Na calantīti vikāraṃ nāpajjanti. Vikārābhāvato hi tesaṃ sattannaṃ kāyānaṃ🔽esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitatā. Aniñjanañca atthato pakatiyā avaṭṭhānamevāti dassetuṃ “na vipariṇāmentī”ti
analyzed: ṭhita ttāḥ na calanti iti vikāram na āpajjanti vikāra abhāvataḥ hi tesam sattannam kāyānam  esika ṭṭhāyi ṭṭhita tā aniñjanam ca atthataḥ pakatiyā avaṭṭhānam eva ati dassetum na vipariṇāmenti iti
translated: “Do not move”: they do not undergo alteration. For it is because of their non-alteration that those seven bodies are established like a pillar.

original: vuttaṃ. Tathā avipariṇāmadhammattā eva te aññamaññaṃ na byābādhenti. Sati hi vikāraṃ
analyzed: vuttam tathā a vipariṇāma dhamma ttā eva te aññam aññam na byābādhenti sati hi vikāram
translated: And because of their non-alteration they do not mutually oppress one another. For if they were to alter, they would mutually oppress one another.

original: āpādetabbatāya byābādhakatāpi siyā, tathā anuggahetabbatāya anuggāhakatāti tadabhāvaṃ
analyzed: āpādetabba tāya byābādhaka tā api siyā tathā anuggahetabba tāya anuggāhaka tā ati tad abhāvam
translated: And since it is to be looked after, it is also a burden. And since it is to be supported, it is a support.

original: dassetuṃ pāḷiyaṃ “nāla”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum pāḷiyam nāla nti ādi vuttaṃ
translated: In order to show the absence of these things, the text says, “It is not to be killed” and so on.

original: Pathavī eva kāyekadesattā pathavīkāyo. Hantuṃ vā ghātetuṃ vā samattho nāma natthi
analyzed: pathavī eva kāya ika desattā pathavī kāyaḥ hantum vā ghātetum vā samatthaḥ nāma natthi
translated: The earth body is a part of the earth body. There is no one who can kill or slay the bodies of living beings,

original: jīvasattamānaṃ kāyānaṃ niccatāya nibbikārabhāvato, eteneva nesamahantabbatā aghātetabbatā
analyzed: jīva sattamānam kāyānam nicca tāya nibbikāra bhāvataḥ etena iva nesama hantabba tā a ghātetabba tā
translated: because they are permanent and because they are inactive. By this very fact, the impossibility of their being killed or slain

original: atthato vuttāyevāti daṭṭhabbā. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “sattannaṃtveva kāyāna”ntiādi. Sotuṃ
analyzed: atthataḥ vuttāya iva ati daṭṭhabbā tathā hi vuttam sattannam tu eva kāyānam ti ādi sotum
translated: is stated in the text. For this is said: “For the seven bodies only” and so on. There is no one who can hear or make heard,

original: vā sāvetuṃ vā samattho nāma natthīti paccekaṃ nesaṃ savanesu asamatthattā tadekadesādīsupi
analyzed: vā sāvetum vā samatthaḥ nāma natthi iti paccekam savanesu a samattha ttā tad eka desa ādīsu pi
translated: because each of them is incapable of hearing. This shows that they are incapable of being heard by a part of them or by a collection of them.

original: asamatthataṃ dīpeti. Yadi koci hantā natthi, kathaṃ satthappahāroti āha “yathā muggarāsiādīsū”tiādi.
analyzed: dīpeti yadi koci hantā natthi katham sattha ppahāraḥ iti āha yathā muggara asi ādīsu itiādi
translated: If there is no one who can kill, how can there be the abandoning of the body? He says, “As in the case of a bundle of sticks” and so on.

original: Kevalaṃ saññāmattameva hoti, hananaghātanādi pana paramatthato nattheva kāyānaṃ avikopanīyabhāvatoti
analyzed: kevalam saññā mattam eva hoti hanana ghātana ādi pana paramatthataḥ nattha iva kāyānam a vikopanīya bhāvato ti
translated: There is only mere perception. But killing, slaying, and so on are not really so, because the bodies cannot be disturbed.

original: adhippāyo. Kevalaṃ takkamattena niratthakaṃ diṭṭhiṃ dīpetīti etena yasmā takkikā
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ kevalam takka mattena niratthakam diṭṭhim dīpeti iti etena yasmā takkikā
translated: The intention. By this he shows that the view is useless, being based on mere conjecture.

original: niraṅkusatāya parikappanassa yaṃ kiñci attanā parikappitaṃ sārato maññamānā tatheva
analyzed: niraṅkusa tāya parikappanassa yam kiñci attanā parikappitam sārataḥ maññamānā tathā iva
translated: The intention is this: by this he shows that since the theorists are unrestrained in their speculation, they hold the view of the theorists, clinging to whatever they themselves have speculated about as being true.

original: abhinivissa takkadiṭṭhiggāhaṃ gaṇhanti, tasmā na tesaṃ diṭṭhivatthusmiṃ viññūhi vicāraṇā
analyzed: abhinivissa takka diṭṭhi ggāham gaṇhanti tasmā na tesam diṭṭhi vatthusmim viññūhi vicāraṇā
translated: Therefore the wise should not investigate the basis of their views.

original: kattabbāti dasseti. Kecīti sārasamāsācariyā. Pañcindriyavasenāti pañcarūpindriyavasena.
analyzed: kattabbā ati dasseti keci iti sārasa māsa ācariyā pañca indriya vasena ati pañca rūpa indriya vasena
translated: “Some” are the teachers of the Sārasamāsa. “By the five faculties” is by the five material faculties.

original: Kammanti laddhi kammabhāvena supākaṭattā. Avaṅkakathātāraṇādikā dvāsaṭṭhi paṭipadā.
analyzed: kamma bhāvena paṭipadā
translated: “Action” is the sixty-two ways of speaking, such as the avoidance of crooked speech.

original: Ekasmiṃ kappeti ekasmiṃ mahākappe.🔽Purisabhūmiyoti padhānapuggalena niddeso, itthīnampetā bhūmiyo icchanteva. Bhikkhu
analyzed: ekasmin kappe iti ekasmin mahākappe  purisa bhūmiyaḥ ti padhāna puggalena niddesaḥ itthī nampetāḥ bhūmiyaḥ icchantā iva bhikkhu
translated: “In one” is in one great aeon.🔽“The plane of men” is a designation for the principal human beings; women also desire this plane.

original: ca pannakotiādi tesaṃ pāḷiyeva. Tattha pannakoti bhikkhāya vicaraṇakoti vadanti,
analyzed: ca pannaka uti ādi tesam tattha pannakaḥ ti bhikkhāya vicaraṇako ti vadanti
translated: “The monk and the tortoise,” etc., are in their texts. Herein, they say that “the tortoise” is one who wanders for alms.

original: tesaṃ vā paṭipattiṃ paṭipannako. Jinoti jiṇṇo, jarāvasena nihīnadhātukoti vadanti,🔽attano vā paṭipattiyā paṭipakkhaṃ jinitvā ṭhito. So kira tathābhūto kassacipi dhammaṃ
analyzed: tesam vā paṭipattim paṭipannakaḥ jinoti jiṇṇaḥ jarā vasena nihīna dhātukaḥ iti vadanti  attanaḥ vā paṭipattiyā paṭipakkham jinitvā ṭhitaḥ so kira tathābhūtaḥ kassaci pi dhammaṃ
translated: or one who has undertaken the practice of those who are so. “Victor” : they say that he is “victorious” because he is “aged” , that is, because his elements have declined owing to old age.

original: na katheti, tenāha “na kiñci āhā”ti. Alābhinti “so na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhatī”tiādinā
analyzed: na kathā iti tena āha na kiñci so na paṭiggaṇhati iti ādinā
translated: Or he is “victorious” because he has stood victorious over the opposition to his own practice. It seems that he does not teach the Dhamma to anyone in that state. Therefore it is said, “He does not say anything.” “Not receiving” : he does not receive from the mouth of a pot, etc.

original: nayena vuttaalābhahetusamāyogena alābhiṃ. Tato eva jighacchādubbalaparetatāya sayanaparāyaṇaṃ
analyzed: nayena vutta alābha hetu samāyogena alābhim tatas eva jighacchā dubbala pareta tāya sayana parāyaṇam
translated: He is “not receiving” because of the non-occurrence of the conditions for receiving. Therefore, because of the weakness and exhaustion caused by hunger,

original: samaṇaṃ pannabhūmīti vadati.
analyzed: samaṇam panna bhūmī iti vadati
translated: he is “lying down, the ascetic, on the bare ground.”

original: Ājīvavuttisatānīti sattānaṃ ājīvabhūtāni jīvikāvuttisatāni. Pasuggahaṇena eḷakajāti🔽gahitā, migaggahaṇena rurugavayādisabbamigajāti. Bahū devāti cātumahārājikādibrahmakāyikādivasena
analyzed: ājīva vutti satāni iti sattānam ājīva bhūtāni jīvikā vutti satāni pasu ggahaṇena eḷaka jāti  gahitāḥ miga ggahaṇena ruru gavaya ādi sabba miga jāti bahū cātumahārājika ādi brahmakāyika ādi vasena
translated: “The hundred occupations of living”: the hundred occupations of living beings for the sake of livelihood. By the mention of “cattle” the species of goats is included,🔽and by the mention of “deer” all the species of deer such as the ruru and the gayal are included. “Many gods”: because of the internal divisions of these, there are many gods, such as the gods of the realm of the Four Great Kings, the gods of the Brahma-world, and so forth.

original: nesaṃ antarabhedavasena bahū devā. Tattha cātumahārājikānaṃ ekacco antarabhedo “mahāsamayasuttena”
analyzed: antara bheda vasena bahū devā tattha cātumahārājikānam ekaccaḥ antara bhedaḥ mahā samaya suttena
translated: Herein, one internal division of the gods of the realm of the Four Great Kings is mentioned in the Mahāsamaya Sutta:

original: dīpetabbo. Mānusāpi anantāti dīpadesakulavaṃsājīvādivibhāgavasena mānusāpi anantabhedā.
analyzed: dīpetabbaḥ mānusā api anantā ati dīpa desa kula vaṃsa ājīva ādi vibhāga vasena mānusā api ananta bhedā
translated: and should be illustrated. “Humans are infinite” : humans too are of infinite variety, according to the divisions of continent, country, family, race, livelihood, etc.

original: Pisācā eva pesācā, te aparapetādayo mahantā veditabbā.
analyzed: pisācā eva pesācā te aparapeta ādayaḥ mahantā veditabbā
translated: “Ghosts” are the same as “spirits” . They should be understood as greater than the others.🔽The Chaddanta Lake and the Mandakini River are called the Kuṇḍikā River and the Mucalinda River. “Knots” are the knots in bamboo.

original: Chaddantadahamandākiniyo kuḷīramucalindanāmena vadati. Gaṇṭhikāti pabbagaṇṭhikā. Paṇḍitopi…pe… uddhaṃ na gacchati, kasmā? Sattānaṃ saṃsaraṇakālassa niyatabhāvato.
analyzed: kuḷīra mucalinda nāmena vadati gaṇṭhikā ati pabbagaṇṭhikā uddham na gacchati kasmā sattānam saṃsaraṇa kālassa niyata bhāvato
translated: The wise man … does not go up. Why? Because the time for beings’ wandering on is fixed.

original: Aparipakkaṃ saṃsaraṇanimittaṃ sīlādinā paripāceti nāma sīghaṃyeva visuddhippattiyā.
analyzed: a paripakkam saṃsaraṇa nimittam sīla ādinā paripāca iti nāma sīgham yā iva visuddhi ppattiyā
translated: When the cause for wandering on is unripened, he ripens it by means of virtue, etc., and is quickly reborn in the Pure Abodes.

original: Paripakkaṃ phussa phussa patvā patvā paripakkabhāvāpādanena byantiṃ karoti nāma.
analyzed: paripakkam phussa phussa patvā patvā paripakka bhāva āpādanena byantim karoti nāma
translated: When it is ripened, he makes it subside by attaining the fruition again and again and bringing it to maturity.

original: Suttaguḷeti suttavaṭṭiyaṃ. Nibbeṭhiyamānameva paletīti upamāya sattānaṃ saṃsāro anukkamena
analyzed: sutta guḷā iti sutta vaṭṭiyam nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti iti upamāya sattānam saṃsāraḥ anukkamena
translated: “A ball of thread” is a ball of yarn. “It unwinds as it is being taken out” illustrates the fact that beings’ wandering on is gradual.

original: khīyateva, na tassa vaddhīti dasseti paricchinnarūpattā.
analyzed: khīyatā iva na tassa vaddhi iti dassā iti paricchinna rūpa ttā
translated: He shows that it is diminished, not increased, because it has a limited form.

original: 229. Niyativāde pakkhipantoti sabbaññutaṃ paṭijānitvāpi padesaññutāya asampāyamāno tattha attano aññāṇakiriyaṃ pariharituṃ asakkonto ca “evamesā niyatī”ti niyativāde pakkhipanto.🔽230. Dhammakathāya apassayabhūto anussavo etassa atthīti anussavī, tenevassa apassayavādaṃ
analyzed: niyati vāde pakkhipanto ti sabbaññu tam paṭijānitvā api padesaññu tāya a sampāyamāno tattha attanaḥ aññāṇa kiriyam pariharitum a sakkonto ca evam esā niyatī iti niyati vāde pakkhipanto  dhamma kathāya apassaya bhūtaḥ anussavaḥ etassa atthi iti anussavī tena iva assa apassaya vādam
translated: “He who includes it in the doctrine of fate” is one who, though claiming omniscience, is unable to be all-knowing in every respect. Unable to avoid the charge of ignorance, he includes it in the doctrine of fate, saying: “This is the way fate is.”

original: dassetuṃ “anussavanissito”ti āha. Savanaṃ saccatoti yaṃ kiñci anussavaṃ, taṃ savanaṃ🔽saccanti gahetvā ṭhito. Piṭakasampadāyāti ganthasampādanena, tādisaṃ ganthaṃ paguṇaṃ
analyzed: dassetum anussava nissitaḥ ti āha savanam saccatas ti yam kiñci anussavam tam savanam  gahetvā ṭhitaḥ piṭaka sampadā āyāti gantha sampādanena tādisam gantham paguṇam
translated: He has a tradition that is not based on what is heard. He is a traditionalist. In order to show that his doctrine is not based on what is heard, the commentary says: “It is based on tradition.” He is one who holds that any tradition is true because it is heard.

original: vācuggataṃ katvā taṃ nissāya dhammaṃ katheti. Tenāha “vaggapaṇṇāsakāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: vācuggatam katvā tam nissāya dhammam katheti tena āha vagga paṇṇāsakāya atiādi
translated: He is one who has mastered the texts. He is one who has mastered the texts by memorizing them and making them familiar by recitation. He teaches the Dhamma based on that. Therefore the commentary says: “He is one who has mastered the five or ten-thousandfold collections of the scriptures.”

original: 232. Mandapaññoti parittapañño. Momūhoti sammuyhako. “Evantipi me no”tiādinā vividho
analyzed: manda pañño ti paritta paññaḥ momūho ti sammuyhako me no ti ādinā vividhaḥ
translated: He is one of little wisdom, of limited wisdom. He is confused, bewildered. “I do not say ‘thus’ ”—this is a diversity, a variety of doubt.

original: nānappakāro khepo vācāya paravādānaṃ khīpanaṃ vācāvikkhepo, taṃ vācāvikkhepaṃ, na
analyzed: nānappakāraḥ khepaḥ vācāya paravādānam khīpanam vācā vikkhepaḥ tam vācā vikkhepam na
translated: The scattering of words, the scattering of speech, is the scattering of words against the doctrines of others. He is one who has the scattering of words.

original: marati na pacchijjati yathāvutto vādavikkhepo etāyāti amarā, tattha pavattā diṭṭhi
analyzed: marati na pacchijjati yathā vuttaḥ vāda vikkhepaḥ etāya āti amarā tattha pavattā diṭṭhi
translated: Or else, the view that occurs in the way described is “without death” because it does not die, i.e. it is not destroyed, by the shaking of the doctrine.

original: amarāvikkhepo, taṃ amarāvikkhepaṃ. Apariyantavikkhepanti “evampi me no”tiādinā pucchitassa
analyzed: amarā vikkhepaḥ tam amarā vikkhepam apariyanta vikkhepanti evam pi me no ti ādinā pucchitassa
translated: The shaking without death is the shaking without death. The shaking without limit is the shaking by way of not coming to an end of the question “Is it so?” etc.

original: apariyosāpanavasena vikkhepaṃ. Ito cito ca sandhāvati ekasmiṃ sabhāve anavaṭṭhānato.🔽Gāhaṃ na upagacchatīti micchāgāhatāya uttaravidhānāya purimapakkhaṃ ṭhapetvā gāhaṃ
analyzed: a pariyosāpana vasena vikkhepam itas citas ca sandhāvati ekasmin sabhāve anavaṭṭhānato  gāham naḥ upagacchati iti micchā gāhatāya uttara vidhānāya purima pakkham ṭhapetvā gāham
translated: It shakes back and forth, running here and there, because it does not stand on any single nature.🔽It does not take up a position means that it does not take up a position by way of a wrong position, by way of a reply to a previous position.

original: na upagacchati. Amarāsadisāya amarāya vikkhepoti amarāvikkhepo.
analyzed: na upagacchati amara asadisāya amarāya vikkhepo ti amara a vikkhepo
translated: The shaking without death is the shaking without death, which is like death.

original: Idaṃ kusalanti ettha iti-saddo pakārattho, iminā pakārenāti attho. Amarāvikkhepiko🔽yathā kusale, evaṃ aññasmiṃ yaṃ kiñci kenaci pucchitaṃ atthaṃ attano aruccanatāya
analyzed: idam kusalam ti ettha iti saddo pakāra attho iminā pakārena ati atthaḥ amarāvikkhepikaḥ  yathā kusale evam aññasmin yam kiñci kenacid pucchitam attham attanaḥ a ruccana tāya
translated: In the phrase “this is wholesome,” the word iti has the meaning of a particle, i.e. it means “in this way.” The one who shakes without death🔽just as in the case of the wholesome, so in the case of any other matter that is asked about by someone, he falls into shaking here and there by way of “Is it so? I do not say so,” etc. because of his own lack of approval.

original: “evantipi me no”tiādinā tattha tattha vikkhepaññeva āpajjati, tasmā “evantipi me
analyzed: evam tipi me no ti ādinā tattha tattha āpajjati tasmai evam tipi me
translated: Therefore, “Is it so? I do not say so.

original: no”tiādi tattha tattha pucchitākārapaṭisedhanavasena vikkhipanākāradassanaṃ. Nanu
analyzed: no tiādi tattha tattha pucchita ākāra paṭisedhana vasena vikkhipana ākāra dassanam nanu
translated: “No” is the expression of the mode of evasion by way of the denial of the question asked here and there.

original: cettha vikkhepavādino vikkhepapakkhassa ananujānanaṃ vikkhepapakkhe avaṭṭhānaṃ yuttanti?
analyzed: ca ittha vikkhepa vādinaḥ vikkhepa pakkhassa ananujānanam vikkhepa pakkhe avaṭṭhānam yuttam ti
translated: Now, is it not proper that the evaders should not admit the side of evasion and should not stand on the side of evasion?

original: Na, tatthāpi tassa sammūḷhassa paṭikkhepavaseneva vikkhepavādassa pavattanato. Tena
analyzed: na tattha api tassa sammūḷhassa paṭikkhepa vasena iva vikkhepa vādassa pavattanato tena
translated: No, because the evaders proceed by way of the denial of the confused one even there. Therefore,

original: vuttaṃ “no”ti. Tathā hi sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto raññā ajātasattunā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ
analyzed: vuttam no ti tathā hi sañcayaḥ belaṭṭha putto raññā ajātasattunā sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam
translated: it is said “No.” Thus, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhaputta, when asked by King Ajātasattu about the fruit of reclensions visible here and now,

original: puṭṭho paralokattikādīnaṃ paṭisedhanamukhena vikkhepaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: puṭṭhaḥ para loka ttika ādīnam paṭisedhana mukhena vikkhepam
translated: evaded by way of the denial of the other world, etc.

original: Etthāha – “nanu cāyaṃ sabbopi amarāvikkhepiko kusalādayo dhamme paralokattikādīni🔽ca yathābhūtaṃ anavabujjhamāno tattha tattha pañhaṃ puṭṭho samāno pucchāya vikkhepamattaṃ
analyzed: ettha āha nanu ca ayam sabbaḥ api amara avikkhepikaḥ kusala ādayaḥ dhamme  ca yathābhūtam an avabujjhamāno tattha tattha pañham puṭṭho samāno pucchāya vikkhepa mattam
translated: Here it may be said: “But does not this entire evader of the immortals, not understanding as they really are the things such as the wholesome, etc., and the other world, etc.,

original: āpajjati, tassa kathaṃ diṭṭhigatabhāvo. Na hi avattukāmassa viya pucchitamatthaṃ
analyzed: āpajjati tassa katham diṭṭhigata bhāvaḥ na hi a vattu kāmassa viya pucchitam attham
translated: when asked here and there about a question, fall into mere evasion of the question? How is he a one gone astray in views? For, like one who does not want to speak, he does not speak the meaning of the question.

original: ajānantassa vikkhepakaraṇamattena tassa diṭṭhigatikatā yuttā”ti? Vuccate – na heva
analyzed: a jānantassa vikkhepa karaṇa mattena tassa diṭṭhigatika tā yuttā iti vuccate na hā iva
translated: and it is proper that he should be one who has fallen into views by merely evasive answers because he does not know?”

original: kho pucchāya vikkhepakaraṇamattena tassa diṭṭhigatikatā, atha kho micchābhinivesavasena.
analyzed: kho pucchāya vikkhepa karaṇa mattena tassa diṭṭhi gatika tā atha kho micchā abhinivesa vasena
translated: It may be replied as follows: It is not only by merely evasive answers to a question that he has fallen into views, but rather by wrong adherence.

original: Sassatābhinivesena micchābhiniviṭṭhoyeva hi puggalo mandabuddhitāya kusalādidhamme
analyzed: sassata abhinivesena micchā abhiniviṭṭhaḥ yeva hi puggalaḥ manda buddhi tāya kusala ādi dhamme
translated: For it is only a person who has fallen into wrong adherence through adherence to the doctrine of eternalism who, because of his dullness,

original: paralokattikādīni ca yāthāvato appaṭipajjamāno attanā aviññātassa atthassa paraṃ🔽viññāpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya musāvādabhayena ca vikkhepaṃ āpajjatīti. Atha vā puññapāpānaṃ🔽tabbipākānañca anavabodhena asaddahanena ca tabbisayāya pucchāya vikkhepakaraṇaṃyeva🔽sundaranti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā visuṃyeva sā ekā diṭṭhi
analyzed: para loka ttika ādīni ca yāthāvataḥ a paṭipajjamānaḥ attanā a viññātassa atthassa param  viññāpetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya musāvāda bhayena ca vikkhepam āpajjati iti atha vā puñña pāpānam  tad vipākānam ca anavabodhena asat dahanena ca tad visayāya pucchāya vikkhepa karaṇam yeva  khantim rucim uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā sā ekā diṭṭhi
translated: not understanding the profitable, etc., and not rightly practising the way to the world beyond, etc., is unable to make others understand

original: sattabhaṅgadiṭṭhi viyāti daṭṭhabbā, indriyabaddhato ca tatiyaṭṭhānabhāve dassito.
analyzed: satta bhaṅga diṭṭhi viyā ti daṭṭhabbā indriya baddhato ca tatiya ṭṭhāna bhāve dassito
translated: a matter that he himself does not understand, and who, because of fear of lying, resorts to evasion. Or alternatively, it may be taken that he has no understanding and no faith in merit and demerit and their ripening, and so he regards evasion of the question as a good thing and he adheres to it by arousing liking and approval for it. Then that view that has arisen in him is to be regarded as a separate view, like the view of the annihilation of the individual, and it is shown as the third place of his adherence because of the presence of the faculties.

original: 234. Sannidhikārakaṃ kāmeti ettha anindriyabaddhāni adhippetānīti tilataṇḍulādiggahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: sannidhi kārakam kāma iti ettha anindriya baddhāni adhippetāni iti tila taṇḍula ādi gahaṇam
translated: “He stores up” : here the meaning is that he stores up what is not bound up with the faculties. The words “sesame seeds, grain, etc.” are mentioned

original: tassa lokassa appasādaparihāratthaṃ kadāci taṇḍulanāḷiādisaṅgahaṇakaraṇaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: tassa lokassa appasāda parihāra attham kadāci taṇḍula nāḷi ādi saṅgahaṇa karaṇam sandhāya
translated: in order to show that he stores up such things as grain, rice, etc., in order to avoid the lack of confidence of the world.

original: vuttaṃ “tilataṇḍulādayo paññāyantī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam tila taṇḍula ādayaḥ paññāyanti iti
translated: “Sesame seeds, grain, etc., are found with him” is said with reference to his storing up.

original: 236. Ājīvakā matā nāmāti ime ājīvakā sabbaso sammāpaṭipattirahitā micchā eva ca paṭipajjamānā
analyzed: ājīvakāḥ matāḥ nāma ati ime ājīvakā sabbaso sammā paṭipatti rahitā micchā eva ca paṭipajjamānā
translated: “The Ājīvakas are dead” : these Ājīvakas are completely devoid of right practice and are practicing wrongly.

original: adhisīlasaṅkhātassa sīlajīvitassa abhāvena matā nāma. Puttamatāti mataputtā. Samaṇe
analyzed: adhi sīla saṅkhātassa sīla jīvitassa abhāvena matā nāma putta matā ati mata puttā samaṇe
translated: Because of the absence of the life of virtue called “adhisīla,” they are dead. “Their children” : their dead children.

original: gotame brahmacariyavāso atthīti samaṇaṃ eva gotamaṃ parisuddho suparipuṇṇo takkarassa
analyzed: gotame brahmacariya vāsaḥ atthi iti samaṇam eva gotamam parisuddhaḥ su paripuṇṇo takkarassa
translated: “There is the life of celibacy in the recluse Gotama” : in the recluse Gotama alone is there the life of celibacy, complete and pure, which is the bearer of true knowledge,

original: sammā dukkhakkhayāvaho brahmacariyavāso atthi. Etenettha dhammasudhammatādidīpanena
analyzed: sammā dukkha kkhaya āvahaḥ brahmacariya vāsaḥ atthi etena ittha dhamma su dhamma tā ādi dīpanena
translated: which is the bearer of true suffering’s destruction. By showing here the true nature of the Dhamma, etc.,

original: buddhasubuddhatañca dīpeti, aññattha natthīti iminā bāhirakesu tassa abhāvaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: dīpeti aññattha natthi iti iminā bāhirakesu tassa abhāvam sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: he shows the Buddha’s perfect enlightenment. By saying that it is not found elsewhere, he shows that it is not found among the sectarians. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Sandakasuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: sandaka sutta vaṇṇanāya līnattha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the words of the Sandaka Sutta is ended.

original: 7. Mahāsakuludāyisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: THE GREAT DISCOURSE WITH SAKULUDAYIN

original: 237. Abhiññātāti ediso ediso cāti abhilakkhaṇavasena ñātā. Appasaddassa vinīto, appasaddatāya🔽mandabhāṇitāya vinītoti ca appasaddavinītoti vuccamāne aññena vinītabhāvo dīpito
analyzed: abhiññātā ati edisaḥ edisaḥ ca ati abhilakkhaṇa vasena ñātā appasaddassa vinītaḥ appasadda tāya  manda bhāṇitāya vinītaḥ iti ca appasadda vinītaḥ ti vuccamāne aññena vinīta bhāvaḥ dīpito
translated: “Well known”: known by the description of his characteristics as “such and such.”

original: hoti, bhagavā pana sayambhuñāṇena sayameva vinīto. Tasmā pāḷiyaṃ “appasaddavinīto”ti
analyzed: hoti bhagavā pana sayambhu ñāṇena sayam eva vinīto tasmā pāḷiyam appasadda vinīto ti
translated: “Well trained in the quiet state”: “well trained” means “trained by another.” But the Blessed One is self-trained by his own knowledge. Therefore in the text he is not called “well trained by another.”

original: na vuttaṃ. Tenāha “na hi bhagavā aññena vinīto”ti.
analyzed: na vuttam tena āha na hi bhagavā aññena vinītaḥ ti
translated: “The Blessed One is not trained by another” is said.

original: 238. Hiyyodivasaṃ upādāya tato āsannāni katipayāni divasāni purimāni nāma honti,🔽purimānīti ca pubbakāni, atītānīti attho. Tato paranti yathā vuttaatītadivasato anantaraṃ
analyzed: hiyyodivasam upādāya tatas āsannāni katipayāni divasāni purimāni nāma honti  purimāni iti ca pubbakāni atītāni iti atthaḥ tatas param ti yathā vutta atīta divasataḥ anantaram
translated: “The previous days”: the days that are near to yesterday and the day before are called “previous.”🔽“Previous” means “former,” “past.”🔽“The following days”: the days after the past day mentioned are “following.”

original: paraṃ purimataraṃ atisayena purimattā. Iti imesu dvīsu pavattito yathākkamaṃ purimapurimatarabhāvo,
analyzed: param purimataram atisayena purimattā iti imesu dvīsu pavattitaḥ yathākkamam purima purimatara bhāvaḥ
translated: “The following days” are more “following” than the previous days. Thus the previous and the following days are respectively called “previous” and “following.”

original: evaṃ santepi yadettha “purimatara”nti vuttaṃ, tato pabhuti yaṃ yaṃ oraṃ, taṃ taṃ
analyzed: evam sante pi yat ettha purimataram ti vuttam tatas pabhuti yaṃ yaṃ oraṃ taṃ taṃ
translated: Still, in the case of the words “earlier than” , what is earlier than that is “later than” , and what is later than that is “earlier than” .

original: paraṃ, yaṃ yaṃ paraṃ, taṃ taṃ “purimatara”nti vuttaṃ hoti. Kutūhalayuttā sālā kutūhalasālā
analyzed: param yam yam param tam tam purimataran ti vuttam hoti kutūhala yuttā sālā kutūhala sālā
translated: A hall of curiosity is a hall of curiosity .🔽Like “a chariot of knowledge” .

original: yathā “ājaññaratho”ti. Ime dassanādayo.
analyzed: yathā ājaññaratho ti ime dassana ādayo
translated: These are seeing, etc.

original: Ayathābhūtaguṇehīti ayathābhūtaṃ micchādīpitaatthamatteneva ugghositaguṇehi samuggato
analyzed: ayathābhūta guṇehi iti ayathābhūtam micchā dīpita attha mattena iva ugghosita guṇehi samuggataḥ
translated: Not having qualities as they are : not having qualities that are proclaimed by the mere meaning that is wrongly proclaimed.🔽Proclaimed : proclaimed by being raised up.

original: ghosito. Taranti atikkamanti etenāti titthaṃ, aggamaggo. Diṭṭhigatikamaggo pana ayathābhūtopi
analyzed: ghositaḥ taranti atikkamanti etena ati tittham aggamaggaḥ diṭṭhigatika maggaḥ pana ayathābhūtaḥ api
translated: A ford is a path by which one crosses over . The supreme path is a ford. But even though the path of the view of individuality, etc., is not as it is,🔽it is called a ford because of the way in which it is spread out for them. Those who make it are founders of sects .

original: tesaṃ tathā vitaraṇaṃ upādāya titthanti voharīyatīti taṃ karontā titthakarā. Osaratīti pavisati.
analyzed: tesam tathā vitaraṇam upādāya titthanti voharīyati iti tam karontā titthakarāḥ osarati iti pavisati
translated: It flows in : it enters.🔽Consistent : not contradictory in the beginning and at the end.

original: 239. Sahitanti pubbāparāviruddhaṃ. Na kiñci jātanti paṭiññādosahetudosaudāharaṇadosaduṭṭhadosatāya
analyzed: sahitanti pubba apara aviruddham na kiñci jātanti paṭiññā dosa hetu dosa udāharaṇa dosa duṭṭha dosa tāya
translated: Nothing has happened : no fault of assertion, no fault of reason, no fault of example, no fault of corruption has happened.🔽Therefore he said: “Your proposition is overthrown.”

original: na kiñci jātaṃ. Tenāha “āropito te vādo”ti. Vadanti tena paribhāsantīti vādo doso.
analyzed: na kiñci jātam tena āha āropito te vādaḥ iti vadanti tena paribhāsanti iti vādaḥ doso
translated: They assert by means of it, they revile by means of it: that is a fault.

original: Sabhāvakkosenāti sabhāvato pavattakoṭṭhāsena.
analyzed: sabhā vakkosena ati sabhāvataḥ pavatta koṭṭhāsena
translated: By the measure of the bowl’s capacity: by the measure of the bowl’s contents.

original: 240. Pīḷeyyāti madhubhaṇḍena saha bhājane pīḷetvā dadeyya. Sabrahmacārīhi sampayojetvāti sahadhammikehi viheṭhanapayogaṃ katvā, tenāha “vivādaṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: pīḍeyya iti madhu bhaṇḍena saha bhājane pīḍetvā dadeyya sabrahmacārīhi sampayojetvā ati sahadhammikehi viheṭhana payogam katvā tena āha vivādam katvā iti
translated: He should give it to him after pressing it down with a vessel together with the honey-mixture. He should make him share it with his companions in the life of purity: he should make him share it with his co-religionists after making him do the act of molesting. Hence it is said: “after making him have a dispute.”

original: 241. Itarītarenāti paṇītato itarena. Tenāha “lāmakalāmakenā”ti.
analyzed: itarītareṇa ati itarena tena āha lāmaka lāmakena ati
translated: With the other: with the inferior one. Hence it is said: “with the thin and watery.”

original: 242. Bhattakosakenāti kosakabhattena, khuddakasarāvabhattakenāti attho. Beluvamattabhattāhārāti🔽billapamāṇabhattabhojanā. Oṭṭhavaṭṭiyāti mukhavaṭṭiyā. Sabbākārenevāti sabbappakāreneva.🔽Anappāhāroti na vattabbo kadāci appāhāroti katvā. Tattha ativiya aññehi avisayhaṃ🔽appāhārataṃ bhagavato dassetuṃ “padhānabhūmiya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Mayāti nissakkavacanaṃ.🔽Visesatarāti tena dhammena visesavantatarā.
analyzed: bhattakosakena ati kosaka bhattena khuddaka sarāva bhattakena ati attho beluva matta bhatta āhārā ti 🔽billa pamāṇa bhatta bhojanā oṭṭha vaṭṭiyā ati mukha vaṭṭiyā sabba ākārena iva ati sabba ppakārena iva 🔽anappāhāro ti na vattabbo kadāci appāhāro ti katvā tattha ativiya aññehi avisayham 🔽appāhāra tam bhagavataḥ dassetum padhāna bhūmiyan tiādi vuttam mayā iti nissakka vacanam 🔽visesatarā ti tena dhammena visesavantatarā
translated: By the measure of the bowl’s contents: by the measure of the bowl’s food. The meaning is: by the measure of the small amount of food. He should eat a meal the measure of a young palm-leaf:🔽he should eat a meal the measure of a leaf of a young palm. He should eat a meal the measure of a bel fruit: he should eat a meal the measure of a bel fruit. He should eat a meal the measure of a myrobalan fruit: he should eat a meal the measure of a myrobalan fruit. He should eat a meal the measure of half a myrobalan fruit: he should eat a meal the measure of half a myrobalan fruit. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of sesamum: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of sesamum. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of rice: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of rice. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of barley: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of barley. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of dust: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of dust. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of flour: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of flour. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of bean: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of bean. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of kidney-bean: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of kidney-bean. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of cow-dung: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of cow-dung. He should eat a meal the measure of a grain of dust: he should eat a meal the measure of a grain of dust. He should eat a meal the

original: Vatasamādānavaseneva paṃsukūlaṃ dhārentīti paṃsukūlikāti āha – “samādinnapaṃsukūlikaṅgā”ti,
analyzed: vata samādāna vasena iva paṃsu kūlam dhārenti iti paṃsukūlikā iti āha samādinna paṃsukūlikaṅgā iti
translated: She wore the rag-robe by undertaking the practice of wearing rag-robes.

original: saddattho pana “visuddhimagge” vuttanayena veditabbo. Piṇḍapātikā sapadānacārinotiādīsupi
analyzed: sadda atthaḥ pana visuddhi magge vutta nayena veditabbaḥ piṇḍapātikā sa padāna cārinaḥ ti ādīsu pi
translated: The meaning of the word saddhā is given in the Visuddhimagga.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the rest of the headings.

original: eseva nayo. Tattha tattha satthena chinditattā satthalūkhāni. Yaṃ yaṃ sappāyaṃ, tasseva
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tattha tattha satthena sattha lūkhāni yam yam sappāyam tassa iva
translated: The word satthalūkha means “rough with a knife.”

original: gahaṇaṃ uccinanti āha “uccinitvā…pe… thiraṭṭhānameva gahetvā”ti. Alābulomasānīti🔽alābulomāni viya sukhumatarāni cīvarasuttaṃsūni etesaṃ santīti alābulomasāni. Pātitasāṇapaṃsukūlanti
analyzed: gahaṇam uccinanti āha uccinitvā ape thira ṭṭhānam eva gahetvā ati alābu lomasāni iti  alābu lomāni viya sukhumatarāni cīvara sutta aṃsūni etesam santi iti alābu lomasāni
translated: The word uccinitvā means “having picked up.”🔽The word alābulomasāni means “having finer threads than flax.”

original: kaḷevarena saddhiṃ chaḍḍitasāṇamayaṃ paṃsukūlaṃ, yaṃ tumbamatte puḷave odhunitvā satthā gaṇhi.
analyzed: kaḷevarena saddhim chaḍḍita sāṇa mayam paṃsukūlam yam tumba matte puḷave odhunitvā satthā gaṇhi
translated: The word pātitasāṇapaṃsukūla means “a rag-robe made of jute that has been thrown away.”

original: “Yathāpi bhamaro puppha”ntiādinā vuttaṃ madhukarabhikkhācāravataṃ “piṇḍiyālopabhojanaṃ
analyzed: yathā api bhamaro pupphanti ādinā vuttam madhukara bhikkhā cāravatam piṇḍiyāla upabhojanam
translated: The word piṇḍiyālopabhojana means “eating alms-food.”

original: nissāya pabbajjā”ti vacanato bhikkhūnaṃ pakatibhūtaṃ vatanti vuttaṃ “uñchāsake vate🔽ratā”ti. Vata-saddo cettha pakativatasaṅkhātaṃ sakavataṃ vadati. Tenāha “uñchācariyasaṅkhāte
analyzed: nissāya pabbajjā ti vacanataḥ bhikkhūnam pakati bhūtam vatam ti vuttam uñchāsake vate  vata saddo ca ittha pakativata saṅkhātam saka vatam vadati tena āha uñchā cariya saṅkhāte
translated: “The going forth is dependent on the alms” , the natural state of the bhikkhus is called “the alms-going” .🔽The word vata here signifies one’s own natural state called “the alms-going” . Therefore it is said: “the natural state of the bhikkhus called the alms-going” .

original: bhikkhūnaṃ pakativate”ti. Uccanīcagharadvāraṭṭhāyinoti mahantakhuddakagehānaṃ bahidvārakoṭṭhakaṭṭhāyino.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam pakativatā iti ucca nīca ghara dvāra ṭhāyino ti mahanta khuddaka gehānam bahi dvāra koṭṭhaka ṭṭhāyino
translated: Standing at the doors of the low and high houses means standing at the outer doors of the big and small houses.

original: Kabaramissakaṃ bhattaṃ saṃharitvāti kaṇājakamissakaṃ bhattaṃ sampiṇḍitvā. Ummārato
analyzed: kabara missakam bhattam saṃharitvā ati kaṇājaka missakam bhattam sampiṇḍitvā ummārataḥ
translated: Having collected the food mixed with the coarse and fine means having collected the food mixed with the coarse and fine grains.

original: paṭṭhāyāti gharummārato paṭṭhāya.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya ati gharummārataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: From the time of the house-threshold means from the time of the house-threshold.

original: Cīvarānuggahatthanti cīvarānurakkhaṇatthaṃ. Ettha ca yasmā buddhā nāma sadevake loke
analyzed: cīvara anuggaha tthanti cīvara anurakkhaṇa tthan ettha ca yasmai buddhāḥ nāma sa devake loke
translated: For the sake of protecting the robes means for the sake of preserving the robes. And here, since the Buddhas are the unsurpassed field of merit in the world with its gods

original: anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ, sā cassa puññakkhettatā paramukkaṃsagatā, tasmā sattānaṃ
analyzed: anuttaram puñña kkhettam sā ca ssa puñña kkhetta tā paramukkaṃsa gatā tasmā sattānam
translated: and since their field of merit is of the highest kind, therefore, having pointed out such a service to beings

original: tādisaṃ upakāraṃ ācikkhitvā te ca anuggaṇhantā gahapaticīvaraṃ sādiyanti, catupaccayasantose
analyzed: tādisam upakāram ācikkhitvā te ca anuggaṇhantā gahapati cīvaram sādiyanti catu paccaya santose
translated: and having favoured them, they accept the lay devotee’s robe. The four requisites are the means of

original: pana ne paramukkaṃsagatā evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana ne paramukkaṃsa gatāḥ eva ti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: but they are not to be regarded as having gone beyond the stage of mere faith.

original: 244. Sappaccayanti sahetukaṃ sakāraṇaṃ hutvā dhammaṃ desetīti ayamettha attho. Codako
analyzed: sappaccayanti sa hetukam sa kāraṇam hutvā dhammam deseti iti ayam ettha atthaḥ codako
translated: With a reason: the meaning is that he teaches the Dhamma with a reason, with a cause.

original: pana adhippāyaṃ ajānanto “kiṃ panā”tiādimāha. Itaro “no na desetī”tiādinā adhippāyaṃ🔽vivarati. Nidānanti cettha ñāpakaṃ uppattikāraṇaṃ adhippetaṃ, tañca tassa tassa anuppattiyuttassa
analyzed: pana adhippāyam a jānanto kim pana atiādim āha itaraḥ no na deseti itiādinā adhippāyam  nidānam ti ca ittha ñāpakam uppatti kāraṇam adhippetam tat ca tassa tassa anuppatti yuttassa
translated: But the questioner, not understanding the intention, asks, “But does he not teach?” The other replies, “No, he does not not teach,”🔽revealing the intention.

original: atthassa paṭipakkhaharaṇato “sappāṭihāriya”nti vuccatīti āha “purimassevetaṃ vevacana”nti.
analyzed: atthassa paṭipakkha haraṇato sappāṭihāriyanti vuccati iti āha purimassa iva etam vevacanam ti
translated: As for the “source” here, what is intended is the reason for the arising of the knowledge. And that is called “with a demonstration” because it removes the opposite of the meaning that is to be understood.

original: Rāgādīnaṃ vā paṭiharaṇaṃ paṭihāriyaṃ, tadeva pāṭihāriyaṃ, saha pāṭihāriyenāti sappāṭihāriyaṃ.
analyzed: vā paṭiharaṇam paṭihāriyam tat eva pāṭihāriyam saha pāṭihāriyena ati sappāṭihāriyam
translated: Or alternatively, the removal of lust, etc., is a demonstration, and that is the demonstration. With that demonstration is “with a demonstration.”

original: Rāgādipaṭisedhavaseneva hi satthā dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: rāga ādi paṭisedha vasena iva hi satthā dhammam deseti
translated: For it is by the removal of lust, etc., that the Master teaches the Dhamma.

original: 245. Tassa tassa pañhassāti yaṃ yaṃ pañhaṃ paro abhisaṅkharitvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: tassa tassa pañhassa ati yam yam pañham paras abhisaṅkharitvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: As to “each question”: whatever question another has formed and has come to the Blessed One,

original: pucchati, tassa tassa pañhassa. Upari āgamanavādapathanti vissajjane kate tato upari
analyzed: pucchati tassa tassa pañhassa upari vissajjane kate tatas upari
translated: after the answer has been given, is the path of the argument that comes up later.

original: āgacchanakaṃ vādamaggaṃ. Visesetvā vadantoti vattati, “bho gotama, vattumarahatī”ti
