analyzed: āgacchanakam vāda maggam visesetvā vadanto ti vattati bho gotama vattum arahati iti
translated: He speaks, distinguishing, means he speaks, saying: “Sir Gotama, it is proper for you to speak.”

original: attano vādabhedanatthaṃ āhataṃ kāraṇaṃ attano māraṇatthaṃ āvudhaṃ nidassento viya
analyzed: attanaḥ vāda bhedana attham āhatam kāraṇam attanaḥ māraṇa attham nidassentaḥ viya
translated: As if showing a weapon for his own death, pointing out a reason for the breaking up of his own doctrine,

original: visesetvā vadanto pahārakena vacanena. Antarantareti mayā vuccamānakathāpabandhassa
analyzed: visesetvā vadantaḥ pahārakena vacanena antar antarā iti mayā vuccamāna kathā apabandhassa
translated: he speaks, distinguishing, with a blow, with a statement. In the middle, means in the middle of the sequence of talk that I am speaking.

original: antarantare. Dadeyya vadeyya. Evarūpesu ṭhānesūti paravādīhi saddhiṃ vādapaṭivādaṭṭhānesu.
analyzed: antar antare dadeyya vadeyya evarūpesu ṭhānesu iti paravādīhi saddhim vāda paṭivāda ṭhānesu
translated: He would give, he would say. In such cases as these, means in the cases of argument and counter-argument with opponents.

original: Te niggahetuṃ mayā desitaṃ suttapadaṃ ānetvā mamayeva anusāsaniṃ ovādaṃ paccāsīsanti.
analyzed: te niggahetum mayā desitam sutta padam ānetvā anusāsanim ovādam paccāsīsanti
translated: They will bring up a text from the scriptures taught by me in order to refute me, and they will accuse me of my own doctrine.

original: 246. Sampādemīti manorathaṃ sampādemi. Paripūremīti ajjhāsayaṃ paripūremi. Adhisīleti
analyzed: sampādemi iti manoratham sampādemi paripūremi iti ajjhāsayam paripūremi adhi sīla iti
translated: I fulfill, means I fulfill my wish. I perfect, means I perfect my intention. In the highest virtue,

original: adhike uttamasīle. Sāvakasīlato ca paccekabuddhasīlato ca buddhānaṃ sīlaṃ adhikaṃ
analyzed: adhike uttama sīle sāvaka sīlato ca paccekabuddha sīlato ca buddhānam sīlam adhikam
translated: means in the virtue that is higher, superior, than the virtue of disciples and the virtue of the Independent Buddhas. The virtue of the Buddhas is higher than that of disciples and Independent Buddhas.

original: ukkaṭṭhaṃ paramukkaṃsato anaññasādhāraṇabhāvato. Tenāha “buddhasīlaṃ nāma kathita”nti.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭham param ukkaṃsataḥ tena āha buddha sīlam nāma kathitan ti
translated: and it is the best of the best, since it is not shared by anyone else. Hence he said “called the virtue of the Enlightened One.”

original: Ṭhānuppattikapaññāti tattha tattha ṭhānaso uppannapaññā. Tenāha “tatthā”tiādi. Avasesā
analyzed: ṭhānuppattika paññā ti tattha tattha ṭhānaso uppanna paññā tena āha tattha atiādi avasesā
translated: “Wisdom arisen on occasion” is wisdom arisen on this or that occasion. Hence he said “there” and so on.

original: paññāti idha pāḷiyaṃ āgatā anāgatā ca yathāvuttañāṇadvayavinimuttā paññā.🔽247. Visesādhigamānanti satipaṭṭhānādīnaṃ adhigandhabbavisesānaṃ. Abhiññā nāma cha
analyzed: paññā ati idha pāḷiyam āgatā anāgatā ca yathāvutta ñāṇa dvaya vinimuttā paññā  visesa adhigamānam ti sati paṭṭhāna ādīnam adhigandhabba visesānam abhiññā nāma cha
translated: “Other wisdom” is wisdom not included in the two kinds of knowledge already mentioned, which is found in the texts and also outside them.🔽“Attainment of distinction” is the attainment of the distinction of the foundations of mindfulness, and so on.

original: abhiññā, tāsu ukkaṭṭhaniddesena chaḷabhiññārahatova aggamaggapaññā idha abhiññāti
analyzed: abhiññā tāsu ukkaṭṭha niddesena agga magga paññā idha abhiññā ti
translated: “Direct-knowledge” is the six kinds of direct-knowledge. The wisdom of the path of arahatship, which is the best of the six kinds of direct-knowledge, is intended here by the word “direct-knowledge.”

original: adhippetā, tassa vosānaṃ pariyosānaṃ pāramī paramukkaṃsāti avakaṃsāti ca aggaphalaṃ
analyzed: adhippetā tassa vosānam pariyosānam pāramī paramukkaṃsā ati avakaṃsā ati ca agga phalam
translated: “Its culmination” is its end, its consummation, its perfection, its excellence.

original: vuccatīti āha “abhiññā…pe… arahattaṃ pattā”ti.
analyzed: vuccati iti āha abhiññāpe arahattam pattā iti
translated: The supreme fruit is called “culmination.”🔽“The endeavour” is the effort that is the means to the attainment of the noble fruits.

original: Upāyapadhāneti ariyaphalādhigamanassa upāyabhūte padhāne. “Anuppannapāpakānuppādādiatthā”ti
analyzed: upāya padhāne iti ariya phala adhigamanassa upāya bhūte padhāne anuppanna pāpaka anuppāda ādi atthā ati
translated: “For the non-arising of unarisen evil, and so on” means for the non-arising of unarisen evil unwholesome states,

original: gahitā tatheva honti, taṃ atthaṃ sādhentiyevāti etassa atthassa dīpako sammā-saddoti
analyzed: gahitā tathā iva honti tam attham sādhentiyā iva ati etassa atthassa dīpako sammāsaddaḥ ti
translated: The word “rightly” is an illuminator of this meaning.

original: yathāadhippetatthassa anuppannapāpakānuppādādino upāyabhūte, padhānaupāyabhūteti
analyzed: yathā adhippeta tthassa anuppanna pāpaka anuppāda ādinaḥ upāya bhūte padhāna aupāya bhūtā iti
translated: The meaning is: in the means for the non-arising of arisen evil, etc., in the means for the endeavour.

original: attho. Sammā-saddassa vā yoniso atthadīpakataṃ sandhāya “yoniso padhāne”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Chandaṃ janetīti kattukamyatākusalacchandaṃ uppādeti pavatteti vā. Vāyamatīti payogaparakkamaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ sammāsaddassa vā yonisas attha dīpaka tam sandhāya yonisas padhāne iti vuttam  chandam janeti iti kattu kamya tā kusala chandam uppādeti pavatteti vā vāyamati iti payoga parakkamam
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning of “rightly” is said to be in the sense of the illuminator of the meaning of “wisely”.🔽He generates desire: he generates, he causes to arise, the desire which is the unwholesome desire to do. He makes an effort: he makes the effort of exertion.

original: karoti. Vīriyaṃ ārabhatīti kāyikacetasikavīriyaṃ karoti. Cittaṃ ukkhipatīti teneva
analyzed: karoti vīriyam ārabhati iti kāyika cetasika vīriyam karoti cittam ukkhipati iti tena eva
translated: He instigates energy: he makes bodily and mental energy. He exerts his mind: by means of that energy

original: sahajātavīriyena kosajjapakkhato cittaṃ ukkhipati. Padahatīti sammappadhānabhūtaṃ🔽vīriyaṃ pavatteti. Paṭipāṭiyā panetāni cattāri padāni āsevanābhāvanābahulīkammasātaccakiriyāhi
analyzed: sahajāta vīriyena kosajja pakkhato cittam ukkhipati padahati iti sammappadhāna bhūtam  vīriyam pavatteti paṭipāṭiyā pana itāni cattāri padāni āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkamma sā tacca kiriyāhi
translated: he co-arisen with it he exerts his mind against the side of indolence. He strives: he causes energy to arise🔽which is the striving of right endeavour. But these four terms in order should be connected with repetition, development, practice, and persistence.

original: yojetabbāni. “Padahatī”ti vā iminā āsevanādīhi saddhiṃ sikhāpattaṃ ussoḷhivīriyaṃ
analyzed: yojetabbāni padahati iti vā iminā āsevana ādīhi saddhim sikhāpattam ussoḷhi vīriyam
translated: Or alternatively, by means of this “he strives” the energy which has reached the peak and is the climax together with repetition, etc., is shown.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Vaḍḍhiyā paripūraṇatthanti yāvatā bhāvanāpāripūriyā paripūraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: yojetabbam vaḍḍhiyā paripūraṇa attham ti yāvatā bhāvanā pāripūriyā paripūraṇa attham
translated: and to be developed. “For the sake of increase and fulfilment” means for the sake of fulfilment by the fulfilment of development.

original: Yā ṭhitīti yā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ paṭipakkhavigamena avaṭṭhiti. So asammosoti so
analyzed: yā ṭhiti iti yā kusalānam dhammānam paṭipakkha vigamena avaṭṭhiti so asammoso ti so
translated: “The state of being established” is the non-disappearance of profitable ideas by the departure of their opposites. “The non-wasting” is

original: avināso. Yaṃ vepullanti yo sabbaso vipulabhāvo mahantatā. Bhāvanāpāripūrīti bhāvanāya
analyzed: avināsaḥ yam vepullanti yaḥ sabbasas vipula bhāvaḥ mahanta tā bhāvanā pāripūrī iti bhāvanāya
translated: the non-loss. “The abundance” is the all-round abundance, the greatness. “The fulfilment of development” is the fulfilment of development by

original: paripūritā. Atthotipi veditabbaṃ purimapacchimapadānaṃ samānatthabhāvato.
analyzed: paripūritāḥ veditabbam purima pacchima padānam samāna attha bhāvato
translated: the fulfilment of the path. “The meaning” should be understood as the same as the meaning of the preceding and following terms.

original: Pubbabhāgapaṭipadā kathitātaṃtaṃvisesādhigamassa paṭipadāvibhāvanāya āraddhattā.
analyzed: pubbabhāga paṭipadā kathitā ataṃtam visesa adhigamassa paṭipadā vibhāvanāya āraddha ttā
translated: The “preliminary stage of practice” has been expounded, since the exposition of the practice has been begun for the purpose of the various kinds of progress.

original: Akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppajjanena anatthāvahatā nāma natthīti vuttaṃ – “uppajjamānā”ti
analyzed: akusalānam dhammānam anuppajjanena anattha āvaha tā nāma natthi iti vuttam uppajjamānā ti
translated: Since there is no harm done by unprofitable ideas that have not arisen, it is said “when they are arising” .

original: vacanaṃ uppannānaṃ rāsantarabhāvena gahitattā. Tathā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppajjanenāti
analyzed: vacanam uppannānam rāsa antara bhāvena gahita ttā tathā kusalānam dhammānam uppajjanena ati
translated: The words “when they are arising” include those that have arisen as a mass. Likewise, since there is no benefit by profitable ideas that have not arisen,

original: vuttaṃ – anuppajjamānāti vacanaṃ uppannānaṃ rāsantarabhāvena gahitattā. Nirujjhamānāti
analyzed: vuttam anuppajjamānā iti vacanam uppannānam rāsa antara bhāvena gahita ttā nirujjhamānā iti
translated: it is said “when they are not arising” . The words “when they are not arising” include those that have arisen as a mass. “When they are ceasing”🔽and “when they have ceased” are to be understood in the same way as “when they are arising” and “when they have arisen.”

original: paṭipakkhasamāyogena vinassamānā, na khaṇanirodhavasena nirujjhamānā.
analyzed: paṭipakkha samāyogena vinassamānā na khaṇa nirodha vasena nirujjhamānā
translated: and it is not that they cease by the cessation of the moment .

original: Lobhādayo veditabbā, ye āraddhavipassakānaṃ uppajjanārahā. Sakiṃ uppajjitvāti sabhāvakathanamattametaṃ.
analyzed: lobha ādayaḥ veditabbāḥ ye āraddha vipassakānam uppajjana arahā sakim uppajjitvā iti sabhāva kathanamattam etam
translated: Greed, etc., should be understood as “arisen” in those who have begun insight. “Having arisen once”: this is merely a statement of what is generally recognized.

original: Ekavārameva hi maggo uppajjati. Nirujjhamānoti saraseneva nirujjhamāno. Na hi tassa
analyzed: eka vāram eva hi maggaḥ uppajjati nirujjhamānaḥ ti sa rasena iva nirujjhamānaḥ na hi tassa
translated: For the path arises only once. “Ceased”: ceased by itself.

original: paṭipakkhasamāyogo nāma atthi. Phalassāti anantarakāleva uppajjanakaphalassa. Paccayaṃ
analyzed: paṭipakkha samāyogaḥ nāma atthi phalassa ati anantara kāle iva uppajjanaka phalassa paccayam
translated: For it has no opposite to be associated with. “Fruit”: of the fruit that is due to arise next.

original: datvāva nirujjhatīti iminā maggo sampati āyatiñca ekanteneva atthāvahoti dasseti.🔽Purimasmimpīti “anuppannā me kusalā dhammā anuppajjamānā anatthāya saṃvatteyyu”nti
analyzed: da tvā ava nirujjhati iti iminā maggo āyatiñca ekantena iva attha āvahaḥ ti dasseti  purimasmim pi iti anuppannāḥ me kusalāḥ dhammāḥ anuppajjamānāḥ anatthāya saṃvatteyyun ti
translated: “Having given its support”: by this he shows that the path is exclusively beneficial both at the time of its presence and in the future.🔽“In the preceding case too”: in the third case, “If unarisen profitable states do not arise in me, that will lead to my harm” .

original: etasmiṃ tatiyavārepi. “Samathavipassanā gahetabbā”ti vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ, taṃ pana
analyzed: etasmin tatiya vāre pi samatha vipassanā gahetabbā ti vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam tam pana
translated: “Calm and insight should be undertaken,” it is said in the commentary.

original: maggassa anuppannatāya sabbhāvato, anuppajjamāne ca tasmiṃ vaṭṭānatthasabbhāvatoti
analyzed: maggassa anuppannatāya sabbhāvataḥ anuppajjamāne ca tasmin vaṭṭānattha sabbhāvato ti
translated: But that is in the sense of the path’s non-arising in its individual essence and in the sense of the harm to the round of rebirths if it does not arise.

original: maggassapi sādhāraṇabhāvato na yuttanti paṭikkhipati. Yadi samathavipassanānampi
analyzed: maggassa api sādhāraṇa bhāvataḥ na yuttan ti paṭikkhipati yadi samatha vipassanānam pi
translated: He rejects this by saying that it is not proper to say that the path is common to both because it is the cause of the development of serenity and insight.

original: anuppatti anatthāvahā, maggassa anuppattiyā vattabbaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: anuppatti anattha āvahā maggassa anuppattiyāḥ vattabbam natthi iti
translated: and he rejects the view that it is not proper to do so because the path is common to all. If the arising of serenity and insight is not beneficial, then there is no need to speak of the non-arising of the path.

original: Mahantaṃ, gāravaṃ hoti, tasmā “saṅghagāravena yathāruci vandituṃ na labhāmī”ti saṅghena🔽saha na nikkhami. Ettakaṃ dhātūnaṃ nidhānaṃ nāma aññatra natthi, mahādhātunidhānato
analyzed: mahantam gāravam saṅgha gāravena yathāruci vanditum na labhāmi iti saṅghena  saha na nikkhami ettakam dhātūnam nidhānam nāma aññatra natthi mahā dhātu nidhānato
translated: He has great respect for the Saṅgha, and so he does not leave with the Saṅgha, thinking: “I am not allowed to pay respect according to my wish out of respect for the Saṅgha.”

original: hi nīharitvā katipayā dhātuyo tattha tattha cetiye upanītā, idha pana rāmagāmathūpe🔽vinaṭṭhe nāgabhavanaṃ paviṭṭhā doṇamattā dhātuyo upanītā. Atimandāni noti nanu ativiya mandāni.
analyzed: hi nīharitvā katipayāḥ dhātuyaḥ tattha tattha cetiye upanītāḥ idha pana rāmagāmathūpe  vinaṭṭhe nāga bhavanam paviṭṭhāḥ doṇa mattāḥ dhātuyaḥ upanītāḥ atimandāni nanu mandāni
translated: There is no other place like the Great Relic Shrine, for relics are taken from there and enshrined in various places. Here, however, relics the size of a thumb were brought from the Rāmagāma Shrine,🔽which had been destroyed and entered by nāgas.🔽“Are they not extremely small?”

original: Saṃvijjitvāti “kathañhi nāma mādiso īdisaṃ anatthaṃ pāpuṇissatī”ti saṃvegaṃ janetvā. Īdisaṃ nāma mādisaṃ ārabbha vattabbanti kiṃ vadatīti taṃ vacanaṃ anādiyanto.
analyzed: saṃvijjitvā iti katham hi nāma mādisaḥ īdisam anattham pāpuṇissati iti saṃvegam janetvā īdisam nāma mādisam ārabbha vattabbanti kim vadati iti tam vacanam an ādiyantaḥ
translated: “Having become agitated” means: “How can someone like me suffer such misfortune?” He does not accept the statement, “Such misfortune should be spoken of in regard to someone like me,” thinking: “What is he saying?”

original: Santasamāpattito aññaṃ santhambhanakāraṇaṃ balavaṃ natthīti tato parihīno sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ
analyzed: santa samāpattitaḥ aññam santhambhana kāraṇam balavam natthi iti tatas parihīno sammāpaṭipattiyam
translated: There is no other cause of steadying the mind that is more powerful than the attainment of serenity. So how can he who has fallen away from that be established in the right way?

original: patiṭṭhā kathaṃ bhavissatīti āha “santāya…pe… na sakkotī”ti. Na hi mahārajjuyā chinnāya🔽suttatantū santhambhetuṃ sakkontīti. Samathe dassetvā tena samānagatikā imasmiṃ visaye
analyzed: patiṭṭhā katham bhavissati iti āha santāyape na sakkoti iti na hi mahā rajjuyā chinnāya  sutta tantū santhambhetum sakkonti iti samathe dassetvā tena samāna gatikāḥ imasmin visaye
translated: The thread cannot hold the cloth together when the great rope is broken.

original: vipassanāpīti iminā adhippāyenāha “evaṃ uppannā samathavipassanā…pe… saṃvattantī”ti.
analyzed: vipassanā api iti iminā adhippāyena āha evam uppannā samatha vipassanā pe saṃvattanti iti
translated: Having shown serenity, he shows insight, which is of the same course in this field, with the same intention, saying, “When serenity and insight are thus developed” and so on.

original: Kāsāvanti kāsāvavatthaṃ. Kacchaṃ pīḷetvā nivatthanti pacchimaṃ ovaṭṭikaṃ pīḷento viya daḷhaṃ katvā nivatthaṃ addasaṃsūti yojanā.
analyzed: kāsāvanti kaccham pīḷetvā nivatthanti pacchimam ovaṭṭikam pīḷentaḥ viya daḷham katvā nivattham yojanā
translated: The yellow robe: the yellow cloth. He saw the monk wearing the robe tightly, as if pressing the last fold.

original: Vuttanayenāti “kāmā nāmete aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā”tiādinā vatthukāmakilesakāmesu
analyzed: vutta nayena ati kāmāḥ nāma ete aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā ti ādinā vatthu kāma kilesa kāmesu
translated: In the way stated: in the way beginning, “These sensual desires are impermanent, suffering, and subject to change” .

original: ādīnavadassanapubbakanekkhammapaṭipattiyā chandarāgaṃ vikkhambhayato samucchindantassa
analyzed: ādīnava dassana pubbaka nekkhamma paṭipattiyā chanda rāgam vikkhambhayataḥ samucchindantassa
translated: In the case of the sensual desires as objects and the sensual desires as defilements, he should first see the danger in them and then practice the way without lust. He should suppress and uproot lust.

original: ca “anuppanno ca kāmāsavo na uppajjatī”tiādinā heṭṭhā sabbāsavasuttavaṇṇanādīsu vuttanayena.
analyzed: ca anuppannaḥ ca kāmāsavaḥ na uppajjati iti ādinā heṭṭhā sabbāsavasuttavaṇṇanā ādīsu vutta nayena
translated: and “The as-yet-unborn taint of sensual desire does not arise” and so on, in the way already stated in the description of the “Taints” chapter .

original: Ārammaṇarasaṃ anubhavitvā niruddhavipākoti tadārammaṇamāha. Anubhavitvā bhavitvā
analyzed: ārammaṇa rasam anubhavitvā tad ārammaṇam āha anubhavitvā bhavitvā
translated: The “ceased result that has had an object” is said to be “disappeared after being experienced” .🔽“Disappeared” is “bhūtavigata” . For what has been experienced and what has occurred are called “bhūta” in the sense of what is common to both.

original: ca vigataṃ bhūtavigataṃ. Anubhūtabhūtā hi bhūtatāsāmaññena bhūta-saddena vuttā. Sāmaññameva
analyzed: ca vigatam bhūta vigatam anubhūta bhūtā hi bhūta tā sāmaññena bhūta saddena vuttā sāmaññam eva
translated: For only what is common is distinguished by a prefix.

original: hi upasaggena visesīyatīti. Anubhūtasaddo ca kammavacanicchāya abhāvato anubhavakavācako
analyzed: hi upasaggena anubhūta saddo ca kamma vacanicchāya abhāvataḥ anubhavaka vācako
translated: And the word “experienced” should be regarded as a verbal noun formed by adding the -ta suffix in the sense of “experiencing” , because there is no desire to express action.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Vipāko ārammaṇe uppajjitvā niruddho bhutvāvigatoti vattabbataṃ arahati,🔽vikappagāhavasena rāgādīhi tabbipakkhehi ca akusalaṃ kusalañca kammaṃ ārammaṇarasaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ vipākaḥ ārammaṇe uppajjitvā niruddhaḥ bhutvā a vigataḥ ti vattabba tam arahati  vikappa gāha vasena rāga ādīhi tad vipakkhehi ca akusalam kusalam ca kammam ārammaṇa rasam
translated: The result is what “has occurred and disappeared” , and so it is proper to say that it “has occurred and disappeared after having had an object.”🔽But the unwholesome and wholesome kamma that has occurred and disappeared after having had an object is proper to say that it “has disappeared after having experienced the object’s taste” in the sense of grasping the result.

original: anubhavitvā vigatanti vattabbataṃ arahati. Yathāvutto pana vipāko kevalaṃ ārammaṇarasānubhavanavaseneva
analyzed: anubhavitvā vigatan ti vattabba tam arahati yathā vuttaḥ pana vipāko kevalam ārammaṇa rasa anubhavana vasena iva
translated: But the result as described above is proper to say that it “has disappeared” only in the sense of “having experienced the object’s taste.”

original: pavattatīti anubhavitvā vigatattā nippariyāyeneva vutto, tassa ca tathā vuttattā🔽kammaṃ bhavitvā vigatapariyāyena, yaṃ “uppannānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya,🔽uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā”ti ettha “uppanna”nti gahetvā taṃsadisānaṃ
analyzed: pavattati iti anubhavitvā vigata ttā nippariyāyena iva vuttaḥ tassa ca tathā vutta ttā  kammam bhavitvā vigata pariyāyena yam uppannānam akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya  uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyā ti ettha uppannam ti gahetvā tad sadisānam
translated: And because it is said in this way,🔽“kamma has occurred and has ceased” is said in the conventional sense. And the abandoning of those that are similar to the unprofitable things that have arisen and the increase of the profitable things that have arisen are said in the way beginning, “For the abandoning of unprofitable things that have arisen” .

original: pahānaṃ, vuddhi ca vuttā. Vipaccituṃ okāsakaraṇavasena uppatitaṃ atītakammañca tato🔽uppajjituṃ āraddho anāgato vipāko ca “okāsakatuppanno”ti vutto. Yaṃ uppannasaddena
analyzed: pahānam ca vuttā vipaccitum okāsa karaṇa vasena uppatitam atīta kammam ca tatas  uppajjitum āraddhaḥ anāgataḥ vipākaḥ ca okāsa kata uppannaḥ ti vuttaḥ yam uppanna saddena
translated: And kamma that has arisen and has ceased by way of making an opportunity for ripening, and also future ripening that has begun to arise are said to be “arisen by making an opportunity” .

original: vināpi viññāyamānaṃ uppannaṃ sandhāya “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sañcetanikāna”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vinā api viññāyamānam uppannam sandhāya na aham bhikkhave sañcetanikānam tiādi vuttam
translated: And that which is called “arisen” without the word “arisen” being used is referred to in such passages as “Bhikkhus, I do not say that the abandoning of the unprofitable state of mind that has arisen is effected without effort” .

original: Tesūti vipassanāya bhūmibhūtesu khandhesu. Anusayitakilesāti anusayavasena pavattā
analyzed: tesu iti vipassanāya bhūmi bhūtesu khandhesu anusayita kilesā ati anusaya vasena pavattā
translated: “Among those” means among the aggregates that are the basis for insight. “Underlying tendencies” are defilements that occur by way of underlying tendencies,🔽that have not been abandoned by the path and are to be abandoned by the path. Hence he said, “Past … not to be stated” .

original: appahīnā maggena pahātabbā kilesā adhippetā. Tenāha “atītā…pe… na vattabbā”ti. Tesañhi
analyzed: appahīnāḥ maggena pahātabbā kilesāḥ adhippetā tena āha atīta āpe na vattabbā ti tesam hi
translated: For those

original: ambarukkhopamāya vattamānāditā na vattabbā maggena pahātabbānaṃ tādisassa vibhāgassa
analyzed: amba rukkha upamāya vattamāna āditā na vattabbā maggena pahātabbānam tādisassa vibhāgassa
translated: The meaning of “inherent” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “latent” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”

original: anuppajjanato. Appahīnāva hontīti iminā appahīnaṭṭhena anusayaṭṭhoti dasseti. Idaṃ🔽bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ nāmāti idaṃ tesu khandhesu uppattirahakilesajātaṃ tāya eva uppattirahatāya
analyzed: an uppajjanataḥ appahīnāḥ ava honti iti iminā appahīna ṭṭhena anusaya ṭṭho ti dasseti idam  bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma ati idam tesu khandhesu uppatti raha kilesa jātam tāya eva uppatti rahatāya
translated: The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”

original: bhūmiladdhuppannaṃ nāma, tebhūmakabhūmiladdhā nāma hotīti attho. Tāsu tāsu bhūmīsūti
analyzed: bhūmiladdhuppannam nāma tebhūmaka bhūmiladdhā nāma hoti iti tāsu tāsu bhūmīsu iti
translated: The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”

original: manussadevādiattabhāvasaṅkhātesu upādānakkhandhesu. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ santāne anuppattianāpāditatāya
analyzed: manussa deva ādi atta bhāva saṅkhātesu upādāna kkhandhesu tasmim tasmim santāne anuppatti anāpādita tāya
translated: The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”

original: asamugghātitā. Ettha ca laddhabhūmikaṃ bhūmiladdhanti vuttaṃ aggiāhito viya.
analyzed: a samugghātitā ettha ca laddha bhūmikam bhūmi laddhanti vuttam aggi āhitaḥ viya
translated: The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”🔽The meaning of “arisen by chance” is shown by “they are not abandoned.”

original: Okāsakatuppanna-saddepi ca okāso kato etenāti okāso kato etassāti ca atthadvayepi🔽kata-saddassa paranipāto daṭṭhabbo. Āhatakhīrarukkho viya nimittaggāhavasena adhiggahitaṃ
analyzed: okāsa kata uppanna sadde pi ca okāsaḥ kataḥ etena ati okāsaḥ kataḥ etassa ati ca attha dvaye pi 🔽kata saddassa para nipātaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ āhata khīra rukkhaḥ viya nimitta ggāha vasena adhiggahitam
translated: The meaning of “

original: ārammaṇaṃ, anāhatakhīrarukkho viya avikkhambhitatāya antogadhakilesaṃ ārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇam anāhata khīra rukkhaḥ viya a vikkhambhita tāya antogadha kilesam ārammaṇam
translated: and the object is the tree with unmilked latex, since the defilements are not suppressed.

original: Nimittaggāhakāvikkhambhitakilesā vā puggalā āhatānāhatakhīrarukkhasadisā. Purimanayenevāti
analyzed: nimitta ggāhaka avikkhambhita kilesāḥ vā puggalāḥ āhata anāhata khīra rukkha sadisā purima nayena iva ati
translated: Or else the persons whose defilements are not suppressed by the apprehending of the sign are like the tree with unmilked latex.🔽“As in the case of the unsuppressed arising” should be construed as follows.

original: avikkhambhituppanne viya “imasmiṃ nāma ṭhāne nuppajjissantīti na vattabbā. Kasmā?
analyzed: a vikkhambhita uppanne viya imasmin nāma ṭhāne na uppajjissanti iti na vattabbā kasmā
translated: “Just as it is not to be said that they will not arise in such and such a place because they have not been suppressed,🔽so it is not to be said that they will not arise in such and such a person because they have not been abandoned. Why?

original: Asamugghātitattā”ti yojetvā vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: a samugghātita ttā ti yojetvā vitthāretabbam
translated: Because they have not been eradicated.”

original: Vuttaṃ paṭisambhidāmagge. Tattha ca maggena pahīnakilesānameva tidhā navattabbataṃ🔽apākaṭaṃ supākaṭaṃ kātuṃ ajātaphalarukkho upamābhāvena āgato. Atītādīnaṃ appahīnatā🔽dassanatthampi “jātaphalarukkhena dīpetabba”nti vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā acchinne rukkhe
analyzed: vuttam paṭisambhidā magge tattha ca maggena pahīna kilesānam eva tidhā  apākaṭam su pākaṭam kātum a jāta phala rukkhaḥ upamā bhāvena āgataḥ atīta ādīnam appahīna tā  dassana attham pi jāta phala rukkhena dīpetabban ti vuttam tattha yathā acchinne rukkhe
translated: This is said in the Paṭisambhidā. And there the non-assertability in three ways of defilements abandoned by the path is🔽made clear by the simile of the tree with fruit. The non-abandonment of past, etc., defilements🔽is also illustrated by the same simile. For the non-assertability of past defilements is illustrated by the fruit that has fallen from the tree,

original: nibbattārahāni phalāni chinne anuppajjamānāni na kadāci sasabhāvāni ahesuṃ honti
analyzed: nibbatta arahāni phalāni chinne anuppajjamānāni na kadāci sa sabhāvāni ahesum honti
translated: and the non-assertability of future defilements is illustrated by the fruit that has not yet appeared on the tree.

original: bhavissanti cāti tāni atītādibhāvena na vattabbāni, evaṃ maggena pahīnakilesā ca🔽daṭṭhabbā. Yathā chede asati phalāni uppajjissanti, sati ca nuppajjissantīti chedassa
analyzed: bhavissanti ca ati tāni atīta ādi bhāvena na vattabbāni evam maggena pahīna kilesā ca  daṭṭhabbā yathā chede asati phalāni uppajjissanti sati ca nu pajjissanti iti chedassa
translated: and will be’ cannot be said of them in terms of past, etc., so defilements abandoned by the path should be regarded in this way.

original: sātthakatā, evaṃ maggabhāvanāya ca sātthakatā yojetabbā.🔽Tepi pajahatiyeva kilesappahāneneva tesampi anuppattidhammatāpādanato. Abhisaṅkhāraviññāṇassāti
analyzed: sa atthaka tā evam magga bhāvanāya ca sa atthaka tā yojetabbā  te pi pajahatiyā iva kilesa ppahānena iva tesam pi anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanataḥ abhisaṅkhāra viññāṇassa ati
translated: Just as the fruit will arise if the tree is not cut down and will not arise if it is, so the path’s being a condition for the arising of defilements should be understood as having a meaning in this way.

original: paṭisandhiviññāṇassa. Upādinnaanupādinnatoti upādinnakhandhato ceva kilesato ca.🔽Upapattivasena vuṭṭhānaṃ dassetumāha – “bhavavasena panā”tiādi. Ye sotāpannassa satta
analyzed: paṭisandhi viññāṇassa upādinna anupādinna to ti upādinna khandhato ca iva kilesato ca  upapatti vasena vuṭṭhānam dassetum āha bhava vasena pana atiādi ye sotāpannassa satta
translated: He abandons them too, because their non-arising comes about through the abandoning of defilements. ‘Determinate consciousness’ is rebirth-linking consciousness. ‘Determinate and indeterminate’ is both from the aggregates that are clung to and from defilements.

original: bhavā appahīnā, tato pañca ṭhapetvā itare dve “sugatibhavekadesā”ti adhippetā. Sugatikāmabhavatoti
analyzed: bhavā appahīnā tato pañca ṭhapetvā itare dve sugati bhava eka desā ati adhippetā sugati kāma bhavato ti
translated: In order to show the emergence by way of rebirth, he said, ‘But in the case of the world of becoming’ and so on. The seven existences of the stream-enterer that are not abandoned are the five left out of the ten existences, the other two being the ‘part of the happy destiny in the world of becoming’ intended here. ‘From the happy destiny in the world of sensual desire’ means

original: sugatibhavekadesabhūtakāmabhavato. Arahattamaggo rūpārūpabhavato vuṭṭhāti uddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanasamugghātabhāvato.
analyzed: sugati bhava eka desa bhūta kāma bhavataḥ arahatta maggaḥ rūpa arūpa bhavataḥ vuṭṭhāti uddhambhāgiya saṃyojana samugghāta bhāvato
translated: The Arahant path emerges from the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming because it causes the supramundane aggregates to emerge from those kinds of becoming.

original: Yadi arahattamaggo eva ariyamaggo siyā, so eva sabbakilese pajaheyya, sabbabhavehipi🔽vuṭṭhaheyya. Yasmā pana odhisova kilesā pahīyanti, tasmā heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimamaggehi
analyzed: yadi arahatta maggo eva ariya maggo siyā saḥ eva sabba kilese pajaheyya sabba bhavehi pi  vuṭṭhaheyya yasmā pana odhisā uva kilesāḥ pahīyanti tasmā heṭṭhima heṭṭhima maggehi
translated: If the Arahant path were the only Noble Path, it would abandon all defilements and🔽it would emerge from all kinds of becoming. But since defilements are abandoned only in a specific way,🔽it abandons the defilements that remain to be abandoned by the lower paths.

original: pahīnāvasese kilese so pajahati, iti imaṃ sāmatthiyaṃ sandhāya “sabbabhavehi vuṭṭhātiyevātipi
analyzed: pahīna avasese kilese so pajahati iti imam sāmatthiyam sandhāya sabba bhavehi
translated: So it is with reference to this possibility that it is said that “it emerges from all kinds of becoming.”

original: vadantī”ti vuttaṃ. Tathā hi so eva “vajirūpamo”ti vutto.🔽Hotu tāva vuttanayena anuppannānaṃ akusalānaṃ anuppādāya, uppannānaṃ uppannasadisānaṃ🔽pahānāya anuppattidhammatāpādanāya maggabhāvanā, atha maggakkhaṇe kathaṃ anuppannānaṃ
analyzed: vadanti iti vuttam tathā hi saḥ eva vaji rūpamaḥ iti vuttaḥ  hotu tāva vutta nayena anuppannānam akusalānam an uppādāya uppannānam uppanna sadisānam  pahānāya anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanāya magga bhāvanā atha magga kkhaṇe katham anuppannānam
translated: For it is said of it: “It is like a thunderbolt” .

original: kusalānaṃ uppādāya uppannānañca ṭhitiyā bhāvanā hoti ekacittakkhaṇikattā tassāti
analyzed: kusalānam uppādāya uppannānam ca ṭhitiyā bhāvanā hoti eka citta khaṇika ttā tassa ati
translated: Now, it may be granted that the development of the path is for the non-arising of unarisen unprofitable things, for the abandoning of arisen unprofitable things, and for the attainment of their non-occurrence. But how can there be development of the path at the moment of the path, since that moment is a single conscious moment?

original: codeti, itaro “maggappavattiyāyevā”ti parihāramāha. Maggo hi kāmañcekacittakkhaṇiko,
analyzed: codeti itaraḥ magga ppavattiyāya iva ati parihāram āha maggaḥ hi kāmañca eka citta kkhaṇikaḥ
translated: For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment,

original: tathārūpo panassa pavattiviseso, yaṃ anuppannā kusalā dhammā sātisayaṃ uppajjanti,
analyzed: tathārūpaḥ panassa pavatti visesaḥ yam anuppannā kusalāḥ dhammāḥ sa atisayam uppajjanti
translated: but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly,

original: uppannā ca savisesaṃ pāripūriṃ pāpuṇanti. Tenāha “maggo hī”tiādi. Kiñcāpi ariyamaggo🔽vattamānakkhaṇe anuppanno nāma na hoti, anuppannapubbataṃ upādāya upacāravasena tathā
analyzed: uppannā ca sa visesam pāripūrim pāpuṇanti tena āha maggaḥ hi itiādi kiñca api ariya maggaḥ  vattamāna kkhaṇe anuppannaḥ nāma na hoti anuppanna pubbatam upādāya upacāra vasena tathā
translated: and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail. That is why he said, “For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment, but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly, and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail.”🔽And although the noble path is not called “unarisen” at the moment when it is occurring, still it is so called figuratively because it was previously unarisen. That is why it is said, “For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment, but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly, and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail.”

original: vuccatīti dassetuṃ “anāgatapubbaṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ayamevāti ayaṃ maggassa yathāpaccayapavatti🔽eva ṭhiti nāmāti, maggasamaṅgī puggalo maggampi bhāvento eva tassa ṭhitiyā bhāvetīti vattuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vuccati iti dassetum anāgata pubbam hi itiādi vuttam ayam eva ati ayam maggassa yathā paccaya pavatti 🔽eva ṭhiti nāma ati magga samaṅgī puggalaḥ maggam pi bhāventaḥ eva tassa ṭhitiyā bhāveti iti vattum vaṭṭati
translated: And although the noble path is not called “unarisen” at the moment when it is occurring, still it is so called figuratively because it was previously unarisen. That is why it is said, “For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment, but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly, and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail.”🔽And although the noble path is not called “unarisen” at the moment when it is occurring, still it is so called figuratively because it was previously unarisen. That is why it is said, “For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment, but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly, and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail.”🔽And although the noble path is not called “unarisen” at the moment when it is occurring, still it is so called figuratively because it was previously unarisen. That is why it is said, “For the path, it is true, may last for a single conscious moment, but the special kind of occurrence it has is such that unarisen profitable states are caused to arise abundantly, and those that have arisen reach fulfilment in detail.”🔽And although the noble path is not called “unarisen” at the moment when it is occurring,

original: Upasamamānaṃ gacchatīti vikkhambhanavasena samucchedavasena kilese upasamentaṃ vattati. Pubbabhāgindriyāni eva vā adhippetāni. Tenevāha “kilesūpasamatthaṃ vā gacchatī”ti.
analyzed: upasamamānam gacchati iti vikkhambhana vasena samuccheda vasena kilese upasamentam vattati pubba bhāga indriyāni eva vā adhippetāni tena iva āha kilesu upasamattham vā gacchati iti
translated: It goes to the stilling of defilements by way of suppression and by way of cutting off. Or the faculties of the prior stage are intended. Hence he says: “It goes to the stilling of defilements.”

original: 248. Adhimuccanaṭṭhenāti adhikaṃ savisesaṃ muccanaṭṭhena, tenāha “suṭṭhu muccanaṭṭho”ti.
analyzed: adhimuccana ṭhena ati adhikam sa visesam muccana ṭṭhena tena āha suṭṭhu muccana ṭṭhā ti
translated: By way of the meaning of well-delivering: by way of the meaning of well-delivering in excess, in a special way. Hence he says: “The meaning of well-delivering.”

original: Etena satipi sabbassapi rūpāvacarajjhānassa vikkhambhanavasena paṭipakkhato vimuttabhāve
analyzed: etena sati api sabbassa api rūpāvacara jhānassa vikkhambhana vasena paṭipakkhataḥ vimutta bhāve
translated: By this, although all the jhana of the fine-material sphere is delivered from its opposite by way of suppression,

original: yena bhāvanāvisesena taṃ jhānaṃ sātisayaṃ paṭipakkhato vimuccitvā pavattati, so bhāvanāviseso🔽dīpito. Bhavati hi samānajātiyuttopi bhāvanāvisesena pavattiākāraviseso. Yathā taṃ
analyzed: yena bhāvanā visesena tam jhānam sa atisayam paṭipakkhataḥ vimuccitvā pavattati saḥ bhāvanā visesaḥ  dīpitaḥ bhavati hi samāna jāti yuttaḥ api bhāvanā visesena pavatti ākāra visesaḥ yathā tam
translated: the special development by means of which that jhana occurs delivered from its opposite in a special way🔽is indicated. For there is a difference in the mode of occurrence by means of a special development even though there is similarity of kind,🔽as in the case of one liberated by faith and one attained to view.

original: saddhāvimuttato diṭṭhippattassa, tathā paccanīkadhammehi suṭṭhu vimuttatāya eva aniggahitabhāvena
analyzed: saddhā vimuttataḥ diṭṭhi ppattassa tathā paccanīka dhammehi suṭṭhu vimutta tāya eva a niggahita bhāvena
translated: And because of being well delivered from opposing states, it is not seized upon as a self in the way that the jhana of the prior stage is.

original: nirāsaṅkatāya abhirativasena suṭṭhu adhimuccanaṭṭhenapi vimokkho. Tenāha “ārammaṇe
analyzed: nirāsaṅka tāya abhirati vasena suṭṭhu adhimuccana ṭṭhena api tena āha ārammaṇe
translated: and it is a liberation too in the sense of a sound resolution due to the state of being resolved upon with confidence in the sense of being free from doubt. Hence it is said: “The signless has the characteristic of non-attention to the sign of formations” .🔽🔽

original: cā”tiādi. Ayaṃ panatthoti ayaṃ adhimuccanattho pacchimavimokkhe nirodhe natthi. Kevalo🔽vimuttattho eva tattha labbhati, taṃ sayameva parato vakkhati.🔽Rūpīti yenāyaṃ sasantatipariyāpannena rūpena samannāgato, taṃ yassa jhānassa hetubhāvena🔽visiṭṭhaṃ rūpaṃ hoti. Yena visiṭṭhena rūpena “rūpī”ti vucceyya rūpī-saddassa atisayatthadīpanato,
analyzed: ca atiādi ayam pana attho ti ayam adhimuccana attho pacchima vimokkhe nirodhe na atthi kevalo  vimutta tthaḥ eva tattha labbhati tam sayam eva paratas vakkhati  rūpī iti yena ayam sa santati pariyāpannena rūpena samannāgataḥ tam yassa jhānassa hetu bhāvena  visiṭṭham rūpam hoti yena visiṭṭhena rūpena rūpī iti vucceyya rūpī saddassa atisaya ttha dīpanato
translated: And it is a liberation too in the sense of a sound resolution on the object, since it is entered upon by surmounting the fear of non-existence. Hence it is said, “And in the object” , etc. But this sense of resolution is not in the last liberation, cessation, which is only a liberation in the sense of freedom from bondage. He will explain that himself later .🔽“Possessed of material form”: he is so possessed because of the materiality included in his own continuity, and that materiality is distinguished by being the cause of the jhāna. It is by the kind of materiality that is distinguished that he is called “possessed of material form,” since the word “possessed of material form” signifies excellence.

original: tadeva sasantatipariyāpannarūpanimittaṃ jhānamiva paramatthato rūpībhāvasādhakanti
analyzed: tat eva sa santati pariyāpanna rūpa nimittam jhānam iva paramatthataḥ rūpībhāva sādhakanti
translated: That same materiality included in his own continuity is the sign of the jhāna, which is what is actually possessed of material form, as it were, since it is the cause of the jhāna that is possessed of material form.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenāha “ajjhatta”ntiādi. Rūpajjhānaṃ rūpaṃ uttarapadalopena. Rūpānīti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tena āha ajjhatta ntiādi rūpa jjhānam rūpam uttara pada lopena rūpāni iti
translated: Hence it is said, “Internally” , etc. The jhāna that has materiality is “material” in the sense of omitting the prefix vi, as in the word vattama for vattha, cloth, and in the word patta for patta, leaf.

original: panettha purimapadalopo daṭṭhabbo. Tena vuttaṃ “nīlakasiṇādīni rūpānī”ti.
analyzed: pana ittha purima pada lopo daṭṭhabbo tena vuttam nīla kasiṇa ādīni rūpāni iti
translated: But in the expression “having material things” , the prefix vi is omitted, as in the words “having cloth” and “having leaves.”

original: Antoappanāyaṃ subhanti ābhogo natthīti iminā pubbābhogavasena adhimutti siyāti dasseti.🔽Evañhettha tathāvattabbatāpatticodanā anavakāsā hoti. Yasmā suvisuddhesu nīlādīsu
analyzed: antoappanā ayam subhanti ābhogo natthi iti iminā pubba ābhoga vasena adhimutti siyā ti dasseti  evam ha ittha tathāvattabba tā āpatti codanā anavakāsā hoti yasmā su visuddhesu nīla ādīsu
translated: “There is no delight in the internal as ‘beautiful’” shows that resolve is by way of the previous delight.🔽Thus the question of the possibility of the state of being as it really is here is not applicable.🔽For in the case of the colour kasiṇas such as blue, etc., which are very pure,

original: vaṇṇakasiṇesu tattha katādhikārānaṃ abhirativasena suṭṭhu adhimutti siyā, tasmā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇa kasiṇesu tattha kata adhikārānam abhirati vasena suṭṭhu adhimutti siyā tasmai aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: resolve can be very firm by reason of the predominance of the absorption already performed, and that is why

original: tathā tatiyo vimokkho saṃvaṇṇito. Yasmā pana mettādivasena pavattamānā bhāvanā satte🔽appaṭikūlato dahati, te subhato adhimuccitvāva pavattati, tasmā paṭisambhidāmagge
analyzed: tathā tatiyaḥ vimokkho saṃvaṇṇitaḥ yasmā pana mettā ādi vasena pavattamānā bhāvanā satte  a paṭikūlataḥ dahati te subhataḥ adhimuccitvā ava pavattati tasmai paṭisambhidā magge
translated: the third emancipation is commended in the commentary in this way.🔽But when development proceeds by way of loving-kindness, etc., it is only because of the non-aversion to beings that it is said that it proceeds by way of the beautiful after resolve upon the beautiful, and that is why

original: brahmavihārabhāvanā “subhavimokkho”ti vuttā, tayidaṃ ubhayampi tena tena pariyāyena
analyzed: brahmavihāra bhāvanā subha vimokkhā ti vuttā tayidam ubhayam pi tena tena pariyāyena
translated: the development of the divine abidings is called “the emancipation of the beautiful” in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: vuttattā na virujjhatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta ttā na virujjhati iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: So this should be regarded as not contradictory because it is stated in different ways.

original: Sabbasoti anavasesato. Na hi catunnaṃ arūpakkhandhānaṃ ekadesopi tattha avasiṭṭhoti.
analyzed: sabbaso ti anavasesataḥ na hi catunnam arūpa kkhandhānam eka desaḥ api tattha avasiṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: All: without exception. For not even a fraction of the four immaterial aggregates remains there.

original: Vissaṭṭhattāti yathāparicchinne kāle nirodhitattā. Uttamo vimokkho nāma ariyeheva
analyzed: vissaṭṭha ttā ati yathā paricchinne kāle nirodhi tattā uttamaḥ vimokkhaḥ nāma ariyeha iva
translated: ‘Because of its being well secluded’ means because of its being secluded for the time being delimited. ‘The supreme liberation’ is called

original: samāpajjitabbato, ariyaphalapariyosānattā diṭṭheva dhamme nibbānappattibhāvato ca.🔽249. Abhibhavatīti abhibhu parikammaṃ, ñāṇaṃ vā. Abhibhu āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ,
analyzed: samāpajjitabbataḥ ariya phala pariyosāna ttā diṭṭhe iva dhamme nibbāna ppatti bhāvataḥ ca  abhibhavati iti abhibhu parikammam ñāṇam vā abhibhu āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam
translated: because it can only be attained by noble ones, because it ends in the noble fruit, and because it brings about the attainment of Nibbāna here and now.🔽‘Overcoming’ is the preliminary work or the knowledge. ‘The base of overcoming’ is the jhāna in which that exists.🔽Or the ‘base’ is the object to be overcome, and the jhāna is that in which that exists.

original: jhānaṃ. Abhibhavitabbaṃ vā ārammaṇasaṅkhātaṃ āyatanaṃ etassāti abhibhāyatanaṃ, jhānaṃ.🔽Ārammaṇābhibhavanato abhibhu ca taṃ āyatanañca yogino sukhavisesānaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhāvato
analyzed: jhānam abhibhavitabbam vā ārammaṇa saṅkhātam āyatanam etassa ati abhibhāyatanam jhānam  ārammaṇa abhibhavanato abhibhu ca tam āyatanam ca yogino sukha visesānaṃ adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato
translated: It is the base of overcoming because it overcomes the object, and it is overcoming and the base, thus it is the base of overcoming.

original: manāyatanadhammāyatanabhāvato cātipi sasampayuttaṃ jhānaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: sa āyatana dhamma āyatana bhāvataḥ sa sampayuttam jhānam abhibha āyatanam tena āha
translated: It is the jhāna itself with its associated states that is the base of overcoming, since it is the basis for the yogi’s choice of the particular pleasure, and because it is the mind base and the mental data base. Hence it is said:

original: “abhibhavanakāraṇānī”tiādi. Tānīti abhibhāyatanasaññitāni jhānāni. Samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa
analyzed: abhibhavana kāraṇāni itiādi tāni iti abhibhāyatana saññitāni jhānāni samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa
translated: ‘The reasons for overcoming’ and so on. ‘Those’ are the jhānas called ‘bases of overcoming.’🔽When he has emerged from the attainment

original: ābhogo pubbabhāgabhāvanāvasena jhānakkhaṇe pavattaṃ abhibhavanākāraṃ gahetvā pavattoti
analyzed: ābhogaḥ pubbabhāga bhāvanā vasena jhāna kkhaṇe pavattam abhibhavana ākāram gahetvā pavattaḥ ti
translated: he directs his mind to the appearance of the object as it was in the jhāna at the moment of overcoming, which occurred in the course of the preliminary work, and he apprehends the appearance of the object as it was in the jhāna at the moment of overcoming.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Parikammavasena ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī, na appanāvasena. Na hi paṭibhāganimittārammaṇā🔽appanā ajjhattavisayā sambhavati. Taṃ pana ajjhatta parikammavasena laddhaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo parikamma vasena ajjhattam rūpa saññī na appanā vasena na hi paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇā  appanā ajjhatta visayā sambhavati tam pana ajjhatta parikamma vasena laddham kasiṇa nimittam
translated: For absorption with the counterpart sign as its object is not possible with an internal object.

original: asuvisuddhameva hoti, na bahiddhā parikammavasena laddhaṃ viya visuddhaṃ.
analyzed: a su visuddham eva hoti na bahiddhā parikamma vasena laddham viya visuddham
translated: But the kasiṇa as the sign of the water element obtained by means of the internal preliminary work is not so purified as that obtained by means of the external preliminary work.🔽“Limited” means of the size that has been made, that is, the size of a mere saucerful. Hence it is said, “not extended.”🔽“By means of the limited” means that this is called the measureless deliverance because of the limitedness of the visible object.

original: Parittānīti yathāladdhāni suppasarāvamattāni. Tenāha “avaḍḍhitānī”ti. Parittavasenevāti🔽vaṇṇavasena ābhoge vijjamānepi parittavaseneva idamabhibhāyatanaṃ vuttaṃ. Parittatā
analyzed: parittāni iti yathā laddhāni suppasara avamattāni tena āha avaḍḍhitāni iti paritta vasena iva iti  vaṇṇa vasena ābhoge vijjamāne pi paritta vasena iva idam abhibhāyatanam vuttam paritta tā
translated: For the limitedness of the object is the reason for the name “measureless deliverance.”🔽And although the measureless deliverance is so called because of the limitedness of the object, it is nevertheless called “measureless” because of the measurelessness of the jhāna factors.🔽And although the jhāna factors are measureless, still the object is called “measureless” too because it is the opposite of “limited.”

original: hettha abhibhavanassa kāraṇaṃ. Vaṇṇābhoge satipi asatipi abhibhāyatanabhāvanā nāma
analyzed: ha ittha abhibhavanassa kāraṇam vaṇṇa ābhoge sati pi a sati pi abhibhāyatanabhāvanā nāma
translated: “The person who has reached the culmination of the superior kind of knowledge” is one who has reached the culmination of the kind of knowledge that is superior because it is the cause of the measureless deliverance.

original: tikkhapaññasseva sambhavati, na itarassāti “ñāṇuttariko puggalo”ti. Abhibhavitvā
analyzed: tikkha paññassa iva sambhavati na itarassa ati ñāṇuttarikaḥ puggalaḥ ti abhibhavitvā
translated: For the development of the measureless deliverance is possible only for one whose knowledge is superior, not for another, even though the latter has mastery in the jhāna that surmounts the fine-material sphere.

original: samāpajjatīti ettha abhibhavanaṃ samāpajjanañca upacārajjhānādhigamasamanantarameva
analyzed: samāpajjati iti ettha abhibhavanam samāpajjanam ca upacāra jhāna adhigama samanantaram eva
translated: “Having surpassed any visible object” is said with reference to the preliminary-work kasiṇa. “Having surpassed any limited object” is said with reference to the absorption kasiṇa. For the absorption kasiṇa is measureless, and it is only that which is meant here by “measureless.”🔽“Having surpassed any object” is said with reference to the counterpart sign. For the counterpart sign is the opposite of any object, thus “any object” is said with reference to the preliminary-work kasiṇa, and “any limited object” with reference to the absorption kasiṇa. But the counterpart sign is the opposite of both, thus “any object” is said with reference to the preliminary-work kasiṇa and the absorption kasiṇa, and “any limited object” with reference to the absorption kasiṇa. And “any object” is said with reference to the preliminary-work kasiṇa and the absorption kasiṇa, and “any measureless object” with reference to the counterpart

original: appanājhānuppādananti āha “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetī”ti. Saha nimittuppādenāti
analyzed: appanā jhāna uppādananti āha saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam pāpeti iti saha nimitta uppādena ati
translated: He says “he brings it to absorption with the arising of the sign” because it is the sign that brings about absorption.

original: ca appanāparivāsābhāvassa lakkhaṇavacanametaṃ. Yo “khippābhiñño”ti vuccati, tatopi
analyzed: ca appanā parivāsa abhāvassa lakkhaṇa vacanam etam yaḥ khippābhiñño ti vuccati tatas pi
translated: With the arising of the sign: this is a description of the absence of a preliminary and a threshold stage.

original: ñāṇuttarasseva abhibhāyatanabhāvanā. Etthāti etasmiṃ nimitte. Appanaṃ pāpetīti bhāvanā appanaṃ neti.
analyzed: abhibhāyatana bhāvanā ettha ati etasmin nimitte appanam pāpeti iti bhāvanā appanam na iti
translated: The development of the bases of mastery is only for one who is “quick in understanding” and “has attained to view.”

original: Ettha ca keci “uppanne upacārajjhāne taṃ ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayo javanavārā
analyzed: ettha ca keci uppanne upacāra jjhāne tam ārabbha ye heṭṭhimantena dve tayaḥ javana vārā
translated: Herein, some say that when access concentration has arisen, the two or three impulsions that occur next to it are of the access state only,

original: pavattanti, te upacārajjhāna pakkhikā eva, tadanantarañca bhavaṅgaparivāsena upacārāsevanāya
analyzed: pavattanti te upacāra jhāna pakkhikāḥ eva tad anantarañca bhavaṅga parivāsena upacāra āsevanāya
translated: and that absorption comes without a preliminary and without a threshold stage, and that he brings it to absorption with the arising of the sign.

original: ca vinā appanā hoti, saha nimittuppādeneva appanaṃ pāpetī”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ.
analyzed: ca vinā appanā hoti saha nimitta uppādena iva appanam pāpeti iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam
translated: But that is merely their opinion.

original: Na hi pārivāsikaparikammena appanāvāro icchito, nāpi mahaggatappamāṇajjhānesu viya
analyzed: na hi pārivāsika parikammena appanāvāraḥ icchitaḥ na api mahaggata ppamāṇa jhānesu viya
translated: For the absorption stage is not intended here by the preliminary and threshold stages, nor is it like the jhāna of the higher paths and fruits,

original: upacārajjhāne ekantato paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā, tasmā upacārajjhānādhigamato paraṃ
analyzed: upacāra jhāne ekantataḥ paccavekkhaṇā icchitabbā tasmai upacāra jhāna adhigamataḥ param
translated: and in the access jhāna the reviewing must be done exclusively, therefore,🔽

original: katipayabhavaṅgacittāvasāne appanaṃ pāpuṇanto “saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ
analyzed: katipaya bhavaṅga citta avasāne appanam pāpuṇantaḥ saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam
translated: The reviewing should be taken as being exclusively in the access. Therefore it is said that he reaches absorption at the end of a number of life-continuum consciousnesses after the attainment of the access.🔽He reaches absorption with the arising of the sign.

original: pāpetī”ti vutto. “Saha nimittuppādenā”ti ca adhippāyikamidaṃ vacanaṃ, na nītatthaṃ,
analyzed: pāpā iti iti vuttaḥ saha nimitta uppādena ati ca adhippāyikam idam vacanam na nīta ttham
translated: This statement is intended to be understood in this way, not literally.

original: adhippāyo vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: The intention can be understood in the way already stated.

original: Na antosamāpattiyaṃ tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa asambhavato, samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa
analyzed: na antosamāpattiyam tadā tathārūpassa ābhogassa asambhavataḥ samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa
translated: Not in the attainment itself, because such an act of adverting is impossible then.

original: ābhogo pubbabhāgabhāvanāvasena jhānakkhaṇe pavattaṃ abhibhavanākāraṃ gahetvā pavattoti
analyzed: ābhogaḥ pubbabhāga bhāvanā vasena jhāna kkhaṇe pavattam abhibhavana ākāram gahetvā pavattaḥ ti
translated: The act of adverting that occurs when he has emerged from the attainment should be regarded as done by him after he has taken up the mode of adverting that occurred at the moment of the jhāna in the prior stage of development.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “iminā panassa pubbabhāgo kathito”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam abhidhamma ṭṭhakathāyam pana iminā panassa pubba bhāgaḥ kathitaḥ ti vuttam
translated: But in the Abhidhamma Commentary it is said, “This is the prior stage of his development.”

original: Antosamāpattiyaṃ tathā ābhogābhāve kasmā “jhānasaññāyapī”ti vuttanti āha “abhibhava…pe… atthī”ti.
analyzed: antosamāpattiyam tathā ābhoga abhāve kasmā jhāna saññāya api iti vuttanti āha atthi iti
translated: Why is it said, “And the perception of jhāna too” , when there is no such act of adverting in the attainment itself?

original: Vaḍḍhitappamāṇānīti vipulappamāṇānīti attho, na ekaṅguladvaṅgulādivasena vaḍḍhitappamāṇānīti tathā vaḍḍhanassevettha asambhavato. Tenāha “mahantānī”ti.🔽Rūpe saññā rūpasaññā, sā assa atthīti rūpasaññī, na rūpasaññī arūpasaññī. Saññāsīsena
analyzed: vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni iti vipula ppamāṇāni iti atthaḥ na ekaṅgula dvaṅgula ādi vasena vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni iti tathā vaḍḍhanassa iva itthā asambhavato tena āha mahantāni iti  rūpe saññā rūpa saññā sā assa atthi iti rūpa saññī na rūpa saññī a rūpa saññī saññā sīsena
translated: ‘Increased in size’: their size is increased, their magnitude is increased, is the meaning; not that they are increased in size by one or two fingerbreadths, etc., because such increase is impossible here. Hence he said ‘large’.🔽‘Perception of form’: perception of materiality. He has that, thus he is ‘percipient of form’, not percipient of form is ‘percipient of the formless’. He speaks of the jhāna as ‘perception of the formless’ by way of the perception.

original: jhānaṃ vadati. Rūpasaññāya anuppādanamevettha alābhitā. Bahiddhāva uppannanti bahiddhāvatthusmiṃyeva
analyzed: jhānam vadati rūpa saññāya anuppādanam eva ittha alābhi tā bahiddhā vā uppannanti bahiddhā vatthusmiṃyeva
translated: The non-arising of perception of form is the ‘non-obtainment’ here.🔽‘Arisen externally’: arisen only in external objects.

original: uppannaṃ. Abhidhamme pana “ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni
analyzed: uppannam abhidhamme pana ajjhattam arūpa saññī bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni
translated: But in the Abhidhamma it is said thus: ‘One percipient of the imperturbable internally sees forms externally as limited, beautiful and ugly, and unlimited, beautiful and ugly’ ,

original: suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni, appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti evaṃ catunnaṃ abhibhāyatanānaṃ🔽āgatattā abhidhammaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “kasmā pana yathā suttante – ‘ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī
analyzed: suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni appamāṇāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti evam catunnam abhibhāyatanānam  āgata ttā abhidhamma ṭṭhakathā ayam kasmā pana yathā suttante ajjhattam rūpa saññī
translated: and so on, in the four bases of success .

original: eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittānī’tiādi vuttaṃ, evaṃ avatvā idha catūsupi abhibhāyatanesu
analyzed: ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni itiādi vuttam evam avatvā idha catūsu pi abhibhāyatanesu
translated: So in the Abhidhamma Commentary it is said: ‘But why is it said in the sutta thus, “One internally percipient of form sees forms externally, limited, beautiful and ugly, and unlimited, beautiful and ugly,” and so on, and not thus in the four bases of success?

original: ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññitāva vuttā”ti codanaṃ katvā “ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyato”ti🔽kāraṇaṃ vatvā “tattha vā hi idha vā bahiddhārūpāneva abhibhavitabbāni, tasmā tāni
analyzed: ajjhattam arūpa saññi tā ava vuttā ati codanam katvā ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya toti  kāraṇam vatvā tattha vā hi idha vā abhibhavitabbāni tasmā tāni
translated: The reason is given: “because of the non-overwhelming of the internal material shapes.”🔽But the material shapes either here or there must be overwhelmed. Therefore they must be stated

original: niyamato vattabbānīti tatrāpi idhāpi vuttāni. ‘Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī’ti idaṃ pana
analyzed: niyamataḥ vattabbāni iti tatra api idha api vuttāni ajjhattam arūpa saññi iti idam pana
translated: as “external” too. And the words “not perceiving material shapes internally”

original: satthu desanāvilāsamattamevā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: satthu desanā vilāsa mattam evā ti vuttam
translated: are just the mere radiance of the Master’s teaching.

original: Ettha ca vaṇṇābhogarahitāni sahitāni ca sabbāni “parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti vuttāni,
analyzed: ettha ca vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni sahitāni ca sabbāni parittāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti vuttāni
translated: And here all the material shapes, whether devoid of or possessed of colour and extension, are called “limited, beautiful and ugly,”

original: tathā “appamāṇānī”ti daṭṭhabbāni. Atthi hi eso pariyāyo “parittāni abhibhuyya tāni
analyzed: tathā appamāṇāni iti daṭṭhabbāni atthi hi eso pariyāyo parittāni abhibhuyya tāni
translated: and so they should be regarded as “measureless” too. For there is this method of interpretation: “having overwhelmed the limited,

original: ce kadāci vaṇṇavasena ābhujitāni honti suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni abhibhuyyā”ti. Pariyāyakathā
analyzed: ce kadāci vaṇṇa vasena ābhujitāni honti suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni pariyāya kathā
translated: if at some time they are overwhelmed by him as beautiful and ugly by way of colour, then having overwhelmed the measureless,🔽the method of interpretation is a teaching in the texts.

original: hi suttantadesanāti. Abhidhamme pana nippariyāyadesanattā vaṇṇābhogarahitāni visuṃ
analyzed: hi suttanta desanā ti abhidhamme pana nippariyāya desana ttā vaṇṇa ābhoga rahitāni visum
translated: But in the Abhidhamma the teaching is not by way of method of interpretation. Therefore the material shapes devoid of colour and extension are stated separately.

original: vuttāni, tathā sahitāni. Atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavanapariyāyoti “ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī”tiādinā
analyzed: vuttāni tathā sahitāni atthi hi ubhayattha abhibhavana pariyāyaḥ ti ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti ādinā
translated: and so they are included in the same way. For there is the same method of “surpassing” in both cases.

original: paṭhamadutiyaabhibhāyatanesu paṭhamavimokkho, tatiyacatutthābhibhāyatanesu dutiyavimokkho,
analyzed: paṭhama dutiya abhibhāyatanesu paṭhama vimokkho tatiya catuttha abhibhāyatanesu dutiya vimokkho
translated: In the first and second bases for overcoming, the first liberation is included; in the third and fourth bases for overcoming, the second liberation is included;

original: vaṇṇābhibhāyatanesu tatiyavimokkho ca abhibhavanappavattito saṅgahito, abhidhamme🔽pana nippariyāyadesanattā vimokkhābhibhāyatanāni asaṅkarato dassetuṃ vimokkhe vajjetvā
analyzed: vaṇṇa abhibhāyatanesu tatiya vimokkhaḥ ca abhibhavana ppavattitaḥ saṅgahitaḥ abhidhamme  pana nippariyāya desana ttā vimokkha abhibhā āyatanāni asaṅkarataḥ dassetum vimokkhe vajjetvā
translated: and in the bases for overcoming colour, the third liberation is included. But in the Abhidhamma,🔽the liberations and the bases for overcoming are taught without distinction in order to show them in their entirety, and so the bases for overcoming are mentioned without omitting the liberations.

original: abhibhāyatanāni kathitāni, sabbāni ca vimokkhakiccāni jhānāni vimokkhadesanāyaṃ vuttāni.
analyzed: abhibhā āyatanāni kathitāni sabbāni ca vimokkha kiccāni jhānāni vimokkha desanāyam vuttāni
translated: And all the jhānas that are liberations are mentioned in the teaching of the liberations.

original: Tadetaṃ “ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī”ti āgatassa abhibhāyatanadvayassa abhidhamme abhibhāyatanesu
analyzed: tat etam ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti āgatassa abhibhāyatana dvayassa abhidhamme abhibhāyatanesu
translated: So it is evident that this is stated in order to distinguish the two bases for overcoming that are given in the way beginning, “Perceiving forms internally” as bases for overcoming in the Abhidhamma,

original: avacanato “rūpī rūpāni passatī”tiādīnañca sabbavimokkhakiccasādhāraṇavacanabhāvato🔽vavatthānaṃ katanti viññāyati.
analyzed: avacanataḥ rūpī rūpāni passati iti ādīnam ca sabba vimokkha kicca sādhāraṇa vacana bhāvato 🔽vavatthānam katam iti viññāyati
translated: because they are not mentioned there as bases for overcoming, and because the phrase “One who possesses form sees forms” and so on is common to all the liberations that have the function of liberation.

original: “Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyato”ti idaṃ abhidhamme katthacipi “ajjhattaṃ rūpāni
analyzed: idam abhidhamme katthacipi ajjhattam rūpāni
translated: “Because of the non-subjection of internal forms” : this is a statement of the reason why in the Abhidhamma it is said everywhere that one “sees forms internally”

original: passatī”ti avatvā sabbattha yaṃ vuttaṃ “bahiddhārūpāni passatī”ti, tassa kāraṇavacanaṃ.🔽Tena yaṃ aññahetukaṃ, taṃ tena hetunā vuttaṃ, yaṃ pana desanāvilāsahetukaṃ ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: passati iti avatvā sabbattha yat vuttam bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti tassa kāraṇa vacanam  tena yam añña hetukam tam tena hetunā vuttam yam pana desanā vilāsa hetukam ajjhattam
translated: without saying “one sees forms externally” as it is said in the Suttas.

original: arūpasaññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanaṃ, na tassa aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ maggitabbanti dasseti.🔽Ajjhattarūpānaṃ anabhibhavanīyatā ca tesaṃ bahiddhārūpānaṃ viya avibhūtattā, desanāvilāso
analyzed: arūpa saññitāya eva abhidhamme vacanam na tassa aññam kāraṇam maggitabbanti dasseti  ajjhatta rūpānam an abhibhavanīya tā ca tesam bahiddhā rūpānam viya avibhūta ttā desanā vilāsaḥ
translated: Thus it shows that what is due to another reason is stated by that reason, but that what is due to the variety of teaching is not to be sought for elsewhere in the Abhidhamma, where it is stated only by the phrase “one sees forms internally”

original: ca yathāvuttavavatthānavasena veditabbo, veneyyajjhāsayavasena vijjamānapariyāyakathanabhāvato.
analyzed: ca yathā vutta vavatthāna vasena veditabbaḥ veneyya jhāsaya vasena vijjamāna pariyāya kathana bhāvataḥ
translated: without the phrase “one sees forms externally.” And the non-subjection of internal forms is due to their not being evident in the way that external forms are. The variety of teaching should be understood as follows:

original: “Suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānī”ti eteneva siddhattā nīlādiabhibhāyatanāni na vattabbānīti ce?
analyzed: suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti etena iva siddha ttā nīla ādi abhibhāyatanāni na vattabbāni iti ce
translated: “Beautiful and ugly” : if it is asked why the blue kasiṇa, etc., are not mentioned,

original: Na, nīlādīsu katādhikārānaṃ nīlādibhāvasseva abhibhavanakāraṇattā. Na hi tesaṃ parisuddhāparisuddhavaṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: na nīla ādīsu kata adhikārānam nīla ādi bhāvassa iva abhibhavana kāraṇa ttā na hi tesam parisuddha aparisuddha vaṇṇānam
translated: because the state of being blue, etc., is the cause of the over- whelming of those who have had practice in the perception of blue, etc. For the pure and impure colours

original: parittatā tadappamāṇatā vā abhibhavanakāraṇaṃ, atha kho nīlādibhāvo evāti. Etesu
analyzed: paritta tā tad appamāṇa tā vā abhibhavana kāraṇam atha kho nīla ādi bhāvaḥ eva ati etesu
translated: because the mere blue, etc., is the cause of over- coming in the case of those who have already had practice in the blue, etc.; for the mere blue, etc., is the cause of overcoming, not the purity or impurity of the colour, nor its smallness or largeness.

original: ca parittādikasiṇarūpesu yaṃ caritassa imāni abhibhāyatanāni ijjhanti, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: ca paritta ādi kasiṇa rūpesu yam caritassa imāni abhibhāyatanāni ijjhanti tam dassetuṃ
translated: And in order to show which of these kasiṇas beginning with the small is successful as an over- coming base for one of a given temperament,

original: “imesu panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: imesu pana atiādi vuttam
translated: “As regards these” is said, and so on.

original: Sabbasaṅgāhikavasenāti sakalanīlavaṇṇanīlanidassananīlanibhāsānaṃ sādhāraṇavasena.🔽Vaṇṇavasenāti sabhāvavaṇṇavasena. Nidassanavasenāti passitabbatāvasena. Obhāsavasenāti
analyzed: sabba saṅgāhika vasena ati sakala nīla vaṇṇa nīla nidassana nīla nibhāsānam sādhāraṇa vasena  vaṇṇa vasena ati sabhāva vaṇṇa vasena nidassana vasena ati passitabba tā vasena obhāsa vasena ati
translated: By the words “as the all-inclusive” is meant as the common property of all blue colour, blue appearance, and blue lustre.🔽By the words “as colour” is meant as the individual essence of the colour. By the words “as appearance” is meant as the state of being visible. By the words “as lustre” is meant as the state of being manifest by means of the light that radiates from it.

original: sappabhāsatāya avabhāsanavasena. Umāpupphanti atasipupphaṃ. Nīlameva hoti vaṇṇasaṅkarābhāvato.
analyzed: sa pabhāsa tāya avabhāsana vasena umā pupphanti atasi puppham nīlam eva hoti vaṇṇa saṅkara abhāvato
translated: The umā flower is the atasī flower. It is only blue, because there is no mixing of colours.

original: Bārāṇasiyaṃ bhavanti bārāṇasiyaṃ samuṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: bārāṇasiyam bhavanti bārāṇasiyam samuṭṭhitam
translated: The Benares cloth is that made in Benares.

original: Te dhammeti te satipaṭṭhānādidhamme ceva aṭṭhavimokkhadhamme ca. Ciṇṇavasībhāvāyeva tattha abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya pariyosānuttaraṃ sataṃ gatā abhiññāvosānapāramippattā.
analyzed: te dhamme ti te sati paṭṭhāna ādi dhamme ca iva aṭṭha vimokkha dhamme ca ciṇṇavasībhāvāya iva tattha abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya pariyosāna uttaram satam gatāḥ abhiññā vosāna pārami ppattā
translated: “Those ideas”: those ideas consisting in the four foundations of mindfulness, and so on, and those consisting in the eight emancipations. They have reached the hundred in the form of the unexcelled culmination of the knowledge that is distinguished there by having reached mastery.

original: 250. Sakalaṭṭhenāti sakalabhāvena, asubhanimittādīsu viya ekadese aṭṭhatvā anavasesato
analyzed: sakala aṭṭhena ati sakala bhāvena asubha nimitta ādīsu eka dese anavasesato
translated: As the whole: in the sense of the whole, not standing in a part as in the case of the sign of foulness, etc.,🔽but in the sense of being graspable as the whole without exception.🔽As a field: just as a field is the place for the arising and the growth of crops,

original: gahetabbaṭṭhenāti attho. Yathā khettaṃ sassānaṃ uppattiṭṭhānaṃ vaḍḍhiṭṭhānañca, evameva
analyzed: gahetabba ṭṭhena āti atthaḥ yathā khettam sassānam uppatti ṭṭhānam vaḍḍhi ṭṭhānañca evam eva
translated: so too this is the place for the arising and the growth of the associated states.

original: taṃtaṃsampayuttadhammānanti āha “khettaṭṭhenā”ti. Paricchinditvāti idaṃ uddhaṃ adho
analyzed: tad tad sampayutta dhammānan ti āha khetta ṭṭhena ati paricchinditvā iti idam uddham adhas
translated: Having defined: this should be construed as “above, below, and across.”🔽For the kasiṇa must be extended everywhere after it has been defined.

original: tiriyanti yojetabbaṃ. Paricchinditvā eva hi sabbattha kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍhetabbaṃ. Tena🔽tena kāraṇenāti upariādīsu tena tena kasiṇena. Yathā kinti āha – “ālokamiva rūpadassanakāmo”ti,
analyzed: tiriyanti yojetabbam paricchinditvā eva hi sabbattha kasiṇam vaḍḍhetabbam tena  tena kāraṇena ati upari ādīsu tena tena kasiṇena yathā kim ti āha ālokam iva rūpa dassana kāmaḥ ti
translated: By means of that and that: by means of that and that kasiṇa above, etc.🔽How? “As one who wants to see visible objects sees the light”

original: yathā dibbacakkhunā uddhaṃ ce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo, uddhaṃ ālokaṃ pasāreti, adho ce,
analyzed: yathā dibba cakkhunā uddham ce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ uddham ālokam pasāreti adhas ce
translated: means that just as one who wants to see visible objects with the divine eye above sees the light above,

original: adho, samantato ce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo, samantato ālokaṃ pasāreti, evaṃ sabbakasiṇanti
analyzed: adhas samantataḥ ce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ samantataḥ ālokam pasāreti evam sabba kasiṇanti
translated: If he wants to see the sign below or all round, he extends the light all round. So the meaning is: “in all kasiṇas.”🔽In one: in each one of the earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: attho. Ekassāti pathavīkasiṇādīsu ekekassa. Aññabhāvānupagamanatthanti aññakasiṇabhāvānupagamanadīpanatthaṃ,
analyzed: atthaḥ ekassa ati pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu ekekassa añña bhāva anupagamana attham ti añña kasiṇa bhāva anupagamana dīpana ttham
translated: The meaning of the words is this: the words “because of not taking on the state of another” show that it does not take on the state of another kasiṇa;

original: aññassa vā kasiṇabhāvānupagamanadīpanatthaṃ. Na hi aññena pasāritakasiṇaṃ tato aññena
analyzed: aññassa vā kasiṇa bhāva an upagamana dīpana ttham na hi aññena pasārita kasiṇam tatas aññena
translated: or the words show that it does not take on the state of any other kasiṇa. For what has been extended as the earth kasiṇa by one person does not take on the state of what has been extended as the earth kasiṇa by other persons.

original: pasāritakasiṇabhāvaṃ upagacchati, evampi nesaṃ aññakasiṇasambhedābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: pasārita kasiṇa bhāvam upagacchati evam pi na isam añña kasiṇa sambheda abhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way.

original: Na aññaṃ pathavīādi. Na hi udakena ṭhitaṭṭhāne sasambhārapathavī atthi. Aññakasiṇasambhedoti
analyzed: na aññam pathavī ādi na hi udakena ṭhita ṭṭhāne sa sambhāra pathavī atthi añña kasiṇa sambhedo ti
translated: Not another earth, etc.: there is no earth kasiṇa with its accessories in the place occupied by the water kasiṇa, and so on.🔽Mixing with another kasiṇa: confusion with the water kasiṇa, etc.🔽Everywhere: in all the remaining kasiṇas.

original: āpokasiṇādinā saṅkaro. Sabbatthāti sabbesu sesakasiṇesu. Ekadese aṭṭhatvā anavasesapharaṇaṃ
analyzed: āpokasiṇa ādinā saṅkaro sabbattha ati sabbesu sesa kasiṇesu eka dese aṭṭhatvā anavasesa pharaṇam
translated: Not remaining in a single place but pervading the whole,

original: pamāṇassa aggahaṇato appamāṇaṃ. Teneva hi nesaṃ kasiṇasamaññā. Tathā hi “tañhī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: pamāṇassa aggahaṇato appamāṇam tena iva hi na isam kasiṇa samaññā tathā hi
translated: it is measureless because of the omission to mention a measure. For that is why they are called “kasiṇas.” For this is said: “That is called a kasiṇa only when it is measureless” .

original: Tattha cetasā pharantoti bhāvanācittena ārammaṇaṃ karonto. Bhāvanācittañhi kasiṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha cetasā pharantaḥ ti bhāvanā cittena ārammaṇam karontaḥ bhāvanā cittam hi kasiṇam
translated: Herein, pervading with his cognizance means making the kasiṇa his object with the development-of-what-is-unprofitable-consciousness. For the development-consciousness is

original: parittaṃ vā vipulaṃ vā sakalameva manasi karoti.
analyzed: parittam vā vipulam vā sakalam eva manasi karoti
translated: Herein, pervading with his cognizance means making the object with his development-of-cognizance cognizance. For the development-of-cognizance cognizance makes the kasiṇa the object either limitedly or measurelessly.🔽The limitedly is the measureless.

original: Kasiṇugghāṭimākāse pavattaṃ viññāṇaṃ pharaṇaappamāṇavasena “viññāṇakasiṇa”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse pavattam viññāṇam pharaṇa appamāṇa vasena viññāṇakasiṇanti vuttam
translated: The cognizance occurring in the space that is the delimitation of the kasiṇa is called the ‘ cognizance kasiṇa ’ in the sense of the measurelessness of the pervasion.🔽For that is called ‘ cognizance ’.

original: Tathā hi taṃ “viññāṇa”nti vuccati. Kasiṇavasenāti ugghāṭitakasiṇavasena kasiṇugghāṭimākāse🔽uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā. Yattakañhi ṭhānaṃ kasiṇaṃ pasāritaṃ, tattakaṃ ākāsabhāvanāvasena
analyzed: tathā hi tam viññāṇanti vuccati kasiṇa vasena ati ugghāṭita kasiṇa vasena kasiṇugghāṭim ākāse  veditabbā yattakam hi ṭhānam kasiṇam pasāritam tattakam ākāsa bhāvanā vasena
translated: In the kasiṇa’s space: in the space that is the delimitation of the kasiṇa.🔽The measurelessness should be understood as to up and down and as to breadth. For the space that is the delimitation of the kasiṇa is as much space as the kasiṇa was extended to.

original: ākāsaṃ hotīti. Evaṃ yattakaṃ ṭhānaṃ ākāsaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhitaṃ, tattakaṃ ākāsameva hutvā
analyzed: ākāsam hoti iti evam yattakam ṭhānam ākāsam hutvā upaṭṭhitam tattakam ākāsam eva hutvā
translated: So it is the space that is the delimitation of the kasiṇa that is the measurelessness of the pervasion.

original: viññāṇassa pavattanato āgamanavasena viññāṇakasiṇepi uddhaṃadhotiriyatā vuttāti “kasiṇugghāṭimākāsavasena🔽tattha pavattaviññāṇe uddhaṃadhotiriyatā veditabbā”ti āha.
analyzed: viññāṇassa pavattanataḥ āgamana vasena viññāṇa kasiṇe pi uddhaṃ adhas tiriya tā vuttā ati kasiṇugghāṭima ākāsa vasena 🔽tattha pavatta viññāṇe uddhaṃadhotiriya tā veditabbā ti āha
translated: And the measurelessness of the pervasion of the cognizance kasiṇa should be understood in the same way as to up and down and as to breadth.

original: 252. Vuttoyeva vammikasutte. Nissitañca chavatthunissitattā vipassanāñāṇassa. Paṭibaddhañca
analyzed: vuttaḥ yeva vammika sutte nissitañca cha vatthu nissita ttā vipassanā ñāṇassa paṭibaddhañca
translated: The “Ant-hill” Discourse has already been quoted. And it is “dependent” because it is dependent on the six bases, and “bound up” with them

original: tena vinā appavattanato kāyasaññitānaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇato ca. Suṭṭhu
analyzed: tena vinā a pavattanato kāya saññitānam rūpa dhammānam ārammaṇa karaṇato ca suṭṭhu
translated: because it does not occur without them and because it makes visible data, etc., its object. It “shines”

original: bhāti obhāsatīti vā subho. Kuruvindajātiādijātivisesopi maṇi ākarapārisuddhimūlako🔽evāti āha “suparisuddhaākarasamuṭṭhito”ti. Dosanīharaṇavasena parikammanipphattīti
analyzed: vā subhaḥ kuruvinda jāti ādi jāti visesaḥ api maṇi ākara pārisuddhi mūlakaḥ  eva iti āha su parisuddha ākara samuṭṭhitaḥ ti dosa nīharaṇa vasena parikamma nipphattī iti
translated: because it shines well. Or alternatively, it is “beautiful” because it shines. And the excellence of the species of the gem, such as its being a Kuru gem, is due to the excellence of the mine from which it comes.🔽So he said “well-refined in its mine.” The excellence of the working is due to the removal of the defects.

original: āha “suṭṭhu kataparikammo apanītapāsāṇasakkharo”ti. Dhovanavedhanādīhīti catūsu pāsāṇesu🔽dhovanena ceva kāḷakādiapaharaṇatthāya suttena āvunanatthāya ca vijjhanena. Tāpasaṇhakaraṇādīnaṃ🔽saṅgaho ādi-saddena. Vaṇṇasampattinti suttassa vaṇṇasampattiṃ.
analyzed: āha suṭṭhu kata parikammaḥ apanīta pāsāṇa sakkharo ti dhovana vedhana ādīhi iti catūsu pāsāṇesu  dhovanena ca iva kāḷaka ādi apaharaṇa tthāya suttena āvunana tthāya ca vijjhanena tāpasaṇha karaṇa ādīnam  saṅgahaḥ ādi saddena vaṇṇa sampattiṃ ti suttassa vaṇṇa sampattim
translated: So he said “well-worked, with its dross removed.” “By rubbing and piercing, etc.”: by rubbing on the four kinds of grindstone, and by piercing with the needle, and by cutting with the saw, and by burning with fire, and by dipping in water, and by rubbing with the hand, and by wrapping in the cloth, and by the test of the stone, and by the test of the balance.

original: Maṇi viya karajakāyo paccavekkhitabbato. Āvutasuttaṃ viya vipassanāñāṇaṃ anupavisitvā
analyzed: maṇi viya karaja kāyaḥ paccavekkhitabbataḥ āvuta suttam viya vipassanā ñāṇam an upavisitvā
