original: devaputtasadisakāyā”ti. Sabhāvoti sabhāvabhūto attho. Vīrakāraṇanti vīrabhāvakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: deva putta sadisa kāyā ti sabhāvaḥ oti sabhāva bhūtaḥ atthaḥ vīra kāraṇam ti vīra bhāva kāraṇam
translated: The hero, Sakka Ruler of Gods, is called “Vīraṅgarūpa” because he is the hero’s form, the hero’s state, the hero’s body, the hero’s appearance, the hero’s figure, the hero’s shape, the hero’s likeness, the hero’s image, the hero’s reflection, the hero’s counterpart, the hero’s equal, the hero’s peer, the hero’s match, the hero’s opposite, the hero’s rival, the hero’s antagonist, the hero’s opponent, the hero’s counter-part.🔽The meaning is that he is the same as the hero in nature. The cause of heroism is the cause of the hero’s being.

original: Vīriyamayasarīrā viyāti saviggahavīriyasadisā saviggahañce vīriyaṃ siyā, taṃsadisāti
analyzed: vīriya maya sarīrā viyāti sa viggaha vīriya sadisā sa viggaham ce vīriyam siyā tad sadisā ati
translated: They are like the hero’s body in being made of heroism. The meaning is that they are like the hero’s being made of heroism.

original: attho. Nanu rañño cakkavattissa paṭisenā nāma natthi, yamassa puttā pamaddeyyuṃ,
analyzed: atthaḥ nanu raññaḥ cakkavattissa paṭisenā nāma natthi yamassa puttā pamaddeyyum
translated: But has not the wheel-turning monarch no hostile army against which his sons might be intoxicated?

original: atha kasmā “parasenapamaddanā”ti vuttanti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “sace”tiādi. Tena parasenā
analyzed: atha kasmā vuttanti codanam sandhāya āha sacā itiādi tena para senā
translated: Why then is it said that they are intoxicated with the intoxication of a hostile army?

original: hotu vā mā vā, te pana evaṃ mahānubhāvāti dasseti. Dhammenāti katūpacitena attano🔽puññadhammena. Tena hi sañcoditā pathaviyaṃ sabbarājāno paccuggantvā “svāgataṃ te
analyzed: hotu vā mā vā te pana evam mahā anubhāvā ati dasseti dhammena ati katu upacitena attanaḥ  puñña dhammena tena hi sañcoditā pathaviyam sabba rājāno paccuggantvā svāgatam te
translated: The meaning is that whether there is a hostile army or not, they are so powerful.🔽By his own merit, which is his righteous conduct, well stored up.

original: mahārājā”tiādiṃ vatvā attano rajjaṃ rañño cakkavattissa niyyādenti. Tena vuttaṃ “so
analyzed: mahā rājā ati ādim vatvā attanaḥ rajjam raññaḥ cakkavattissa niyyādenti tena vuttam so
translated: For when they are urged by that, all the kings of the earth go out to meet him, saying, “Welcome, great king,” and so on, and they hand over their kingdoms to the wheel-turning monarch. That is why it is said:

original: imaṃ…pe… ajjhāvasatī”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana tassa yathāvuttadhammassa cirataraṃ vipaccituṃ
analyzed: imaṃ pe ajjhāvasati iti aṭṭhakathā ayam pana tassa yathāvutta dhammassa cirataram vipaccitum
translated: “He is living in such and such a place.” But in the commentary it is said that this action would take a long time to ripen.

original: paccayabhūtaṃ cakkavattivattasamudāgataṃ payogasampattisaṅkhātaṃ dhammaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: paccaya bhūtam cakkavatti vatta samudāgatam payoga sampatti saṅkhātam dhammam dassetuṃ
translated: and he dwells therein.” But in the commentary, in order to show the quality of the equipment of application, which is the condition for the aforesaid quality to ripen for a long time,

original: “pāṇo na hantabbotiādinā pañcasīladhammenā”ti vuttaṃ. Evañhi “adaṇḍena asatthenā”ti
analyzed: pāṇaḥ na hantabbaḥ iti ādinā pañca sīla dhammena ati vuttam evam hi a daṇḍena asatthena ati
translated: it is said: “by the five qualities of virtue beginning with ‘No living beings are to be killed.’ ” For in this way the statement “without rod or weapon”

original: idaṃ vacanaṃ suṭṭhutaraṃ samatthitaṃ hoti, yasmā rāgādayo pāpadhammā uppajjamānā
analyzed: idam vacanam suṭṭhutaram samatthitam hoti yasmai rāga ādayo pāpa dhammāḥ uppajjamānāḥ
translated: is established more clearly, since greed, etc., as bad qualities that arise

original: sattasantānaṃ chādetvā pariyonandhitvā tiṭṭhanti, kusalapavattiṃ nivārenti, tasmā
analyzed: satta santānam chādetvā pariyonandhitvā tiṭṭhanti kusala pavattim nivārenti tasmā
translated: cover over and envelop the continuity of the aggregates of the living being and prevent the occurrence of good qualities,

original: te “chadanā, chadā”ti ca vuttā.
analyzed: te chadanā chadāti ca vuttā
translated: therefore they are called “coverings” and “veiling.”🔽“Having turned away from them” means having turned away from them and having turned away from the round of rebirths.

original: Vivaṭṭetvā parivattetvā. Pūjārahatā vuttā “arahatīti araha”nti. Tassāti pūjārahatāya.
analyzed: vivaṭṭetvā parivattetvā pūjā rahatā vuttā arahati iti arahanti tassa ati pūjā rahatāya
translated: “Worthy of offerings” is said of the one who is worthy of offerings. “Worthy” means worthy of offerings. “Him” refers to the one worthy of offerings.

original: Yasmā sammāsambuddho, tasmā arahanti. Buddhattahetubhūtā vivaṭṭacchadatā vuttā savāsanasabbakilesappahānapubbakattā
analyzed: yasmai sammāsambuddhaḥ tasmai arahanti buddhatta hetu bhūtā vivaṭṭacchada tā vuttā sa vāsana sabba kilesa ppahāna pubbaka ttā
translated: Since he is a Perfectly Enlightened One, therefore he is worthy of offerings. The turning away from the coverings is said to be the cause of his being a Buddha, because of the prior relinquishment of all defilements together with their residues.

original: buddhabhāvasiddhiyā. Arahaṃ vaṭṭābhāvenāti phalena hetuanumānadassanaṃ. Sammāsambuddho🔽chadanābhāvenāti hetunā phalānumānadassanaṃ. Hetudvayaṃ vuttaṃ “vivaṭṭo vicchado
analyzed: buddha bhāva siddhiyā araham vaṭṭa abhāvena ati phalena hetu anumāna dassanam sammāsambuddhaḥ  chadana abhāvena ati hetunā phala anumāna dassanam hetu dvayam vuttam vivaṭṭaḥ vicchadaḥ
translated: and the establishment of the state of Buddhahood. “The Worthy One by the disappearance of the round” is the seeing of the inference of the cause by the fruit. “The Supremely Enlightened One”🔽is the seeing of the inference of the fruit by the cause. The two causes are stated: “The round has been turned back, the net has been cut through,🔽🔽

original: cā”ti. Dutiyavesārajjenāti “khīṇāsavassa te paṭijānato”tiādinā āgatena vesārajjena.🔽Purimasiddhīti purimassa padassa atthasiddhi. Paṭhamenāti “sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato”tiādinā🔽āgatena vesārajjena. Dutiyasiddhīti buddhattasiddhi. Tatiyacatutthehīti “ye kho pana
analyzed: ca ati dutiya vesārajjena ati khīṇāsavassa te paṭijānato tiādinā āgatena vesārajjena  purima siddhi iti purimassa padassa attha siddhi paṭhamena ati sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānataḥ tiādinā  āgatena vesārajjena dutiya siddhi iti tatiya catutthehi iti ye kho pana
translated: and the establishment of the state of Buddhahood. “He is accomplished in the destruction of the cankers” is the seeing of the inference of the cause by the fruit. “He is fully enlightened” is the seeing of the inference of the fruit by the cause. The two causes are stated in the words “the turning and the unfolding are complete.” “By the second kind of confidence” is by the confidence stated in the words “If you claim to be one in whom the cankers are destroyed” .

original: te antarāyikā dhammā”tiādinā, “yassa kho pana te atthāyā”tiādinā ca āgatehi tatiyacatutthehi
analyzed: te antarāyikāḥ dhammā ti ādinā yassa kho pana te atthāya ati ādinā ca āgatehi tatiya catutthehi
translated: “The establishment of the first” is the establishment of the meaning of the first clause. “By the first” is by the confidence stated in the words “If you claim to be fully enlightened” . “The establishment of the second” is the establishment of Buddhahood. “By the third and the fourth” is by the third and the fourth kinds of confidence stated respectively in the words “If there are any things that are obstructions” and “If there are any things that you have not understood” .

original: vesārajjehi. Tatiyasiddhīti vivaṭṭacchadanatā siddhi. Yāthāvato antarāyikaniyyānikadhammāpadesena
analyzed: vesārajjehi tatiya siddhi iti vivaṭṭa chadana tā siddhi yāthāvataḥ antarāyika niyyānika dhamma apadesena
translated: “The establishment of the third” is the establishment of the turning and the unfolding. By the declaration of the things that are obstructions and the things that are emancipations respectively as they are,

original: hi satthu vivaṭṭacchadabhāvo loke pākaṭo ahosi. Purimaṃ dhammacakkhunti purimapadaṃ
analyzed: hi satthu vivaṭṭa chada bhāvaḥ loke pākaṭaḥ ahosi purimam dhamma cakkhunti purima padam
translated: for the Blessed One’s state of having opened out the Dhamma was evident to the world. The first word

original: bhagavato dhammacakkhuṃ sādheti kilesārīnaṃ saṃsāracakkassa ca arānaṃ hatabhāvadīpanato.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ dhamma cakkhum sādheti kilesa arīnam saṃsāra cakkassa ca arānam hata bhāva dīpanato
translated: confirms the Blessed One’s eye of Dhamma, since it shows the destruction of the spokes, that is, of the defilements, and of the rim, that is, of the round of rebirths.

original: Dutiyaṃ padaṃ buddhacakkhuṃ sādheti sammāsambuddhasseva taṃ sambhavato. Tatiyaṃ padaṃ🔽samantacakkhuṃ sādheti savāsanasabbakilesappahānadīpanato. “Sammāsambuddho”ti hi
analyzed: dutiyam padam buddha cakkhum sādheti sammāsambuddhassa iva tam sambhavataḥ tatiyam padam  samanta cakkhum sādheti sa vāsana sabba kilesa ppahāna dīpanato sammāsambuddhaḥ ti hi
translated: The second word confirms his eye of omniscience, since that belongs only to a Fully Enlightened One. The third word🔽confirms his eye of omniscience, since it shows the abandoning of all defilements together with the underlying tendencies. For the statement that he is a “fully enlightened one”

original: vatvā “vivaṭṭacchado”ti vacanaṃ buddhabhāvāvahameva sabbakilesappahānaṃ vibhāvetīti.
analyzed: vatvā vivaṭṭa chadā iti vacanam buddha bhāva āvaham eva sabba kilesa ppahānam vibhāveti iti
translated: reveals the abandoning of all defilements, which is the state of being a Buddha, by showing that he has opened out the Dhamma.

original: Sūrabhāvanti lakkhaṇavibhāvanena visadañāṇataṃ.🔽385. Gavesīti ñāṇena pariyesanaṃ akāsi. Samānayīti ñāṇena saṅkalento samānaṃ ānayi
analyzed: sūra bhāvanti lakkhaṇa vibhāvanena  gavesi iti ñāṇena pariyesanam akāsi samānayi iti ñāṇena saṅkalentaḥ samānam ānayi
translated: “The radiance of his glory”: the clarity of his knowledge by the manifestation of the characteristics.

original: samāhari. Na sakkoti saṃkucite iriyāpathe yebhuyyena tesaṃ dubbibhāvanato. Kaṅkhatīti
analyzed: samāhari na sakkoti saṃkucite iriyāpathe yebhuyyena tesam dubbibhāvanataḥ kaṅkhati iti
translated: “He sought”: he sought by means of knowledge. “He brought together”: he brought together by means of knowledge, he caused to come, he caused to be collected. He could not do so with his posture contracted, for that is not usually inspiring. “He hesitated”🔽means

original: padassa ākaṅkhatīti ayamatthoti āha – “aho vata passeyyanti patthanaṃ uppādetī”ti.🔽Kicchatīti kilamati. “Kaṅkhatī”ti padassa pubbe āsīsanatthataṃ vatvā idāni tassa🔽saṃsayatthattameva vikappantaravasena dassento “kaṅkhāya vā dubbalā vimati vuttā”tiādi
analyzed: padassa ākaṅkhati iti ayam atthaḥ ti āha aho vata passeyyanti patthanam uppādeti iti  kicchati iti kilamati kaṅkhati iti padassa pubbe āsīsana tam vatvā idāni tassa  saṃsaya ttha ttam eva vikappa antara vasena dassento kaṅkhāya vā dubbalā vimati vuttā atiādi
translated: “He wishes for a sign” means he wishes for a sign of the kind he has seen before.🔽“He strives” means he makes an effort.🔽Having stated the meaning of the word “doubts” as “hesitation” earlier, he now shows its meaning as “uncertainty” by way of a distinction.🔽“Or doubt is said to be a weakness of uncertainty” means: by the three dhammas, by the three kinds of dhammas that are the objects of doubt.

original: vuttaṃ. Tīhi dhammehi tippakārehi saṃsayadhammehi. Kālussiyabhāvoti appasannatāya🔽hetubhūto āvilabhāvo. Yasmā bhagavato kosohitaṃ sabbabuddhāveṇikaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ suvisuddhakañcanamaṇḍalasannikāsaṃ🔽attano saṇṭhānasannivesasundaratāya ājāneyyagandhahatthino varaṅgacārubhāvaṃ vikasamānatapaniyāravindasamujjalakesarāvattavilāsaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tīhi dhammehi tippakārehi saṃsaya dhammehi kālussiya bhāvaḥ ti appasanna tāya  hetu bhūtaḥ āvila bhāvaḥ yasmai bhagavato kosohitam sabba buddha āveṇikam vattha guyham su visuddha kañcana maṇḍala sannikāsam  saṇṭhāna sannivesa sundara tāyai ājāneyya gandhahatthinaḥ varaṅga cāru bhāvam vikasamāna tapaniya aravinda samujjala kesara āvatta vilāsam
translated: The state of coarseness means the state of coarseness that is the cause of lack of confidence.🔽Because the Blessed One’s penis is concealed, being a unique characteristic of the Buddhas, and is similar to a pure golden disk,🔽beautiful by the loveliness of its shape and arrangement, having the beauty of the forehead of a noble gandhahastin, and having the splendor of a mass of hair like a blooming lotus,

original: sañjhāpabhānurañjitajalavanantarābhilakkhita-sampuṇṇacandamaṇḍalasobhañca attano
analyzed: sañjhāpa bhānu rañjita jala vana antara abhilakkhita sampuṇṇa canda maṇḍala sobham ca
translated: and is also beautiful like a full moon’s orb, which is marked by the water of the ocean shining with the light of the moon.

original: siriyā abhibhuyya virājati, yaṃ bāhirabbhantaramalehi anupakkiliṭṭhatāya cirakālaṃ
analyzed: siriyāḥ abhibhuyya virājati yam bāhis abbhantara malehi cira kālam
translated: He shines, outshining the beauty of the moon and sun, because he is not defiled by external and internal stains, and because,

original: suparicitabrahmacariyādhikāratāya susaṇṭhitasaṇṭhānasampattiyā ca kopīnampi santaṃ
analyzed: su paricita brahmacariya adhikāra tāya su saṇṭhita saṇṭhāna sampattiyā ca santam
translated: having long since perfected the life of purity, he has attained the perfection of a well-proportioned figure, so that even his private parts are concealed,🔽though they are not normally concealed. Therefore it is said, “The Blessed One’s body is…”

original: akopīnameva, tasmā vuttaṃ “bhagavato hī”tiādi. Pahūtabhāvanti puthulabhāvaṃ. Ettheva
analyzed: akopīnam eva tasmai vuttam bhagavataḥ hi itiādi pahūta bhāvanti puthula bhāvam etthā iva
translated: “Abundant” means extensive. For his doubt arose only in regard to that,

original: hi tassa saṃsayo, tanumudusukumāratādīsu panassa guṇesu tassa vicāraṇā eva nāhosi.
analyzed: hi tassa saṃsayo tanu mudu sukumāra tā ādīsu panassa guṇesu tassa vicāraṇā eva na ahosi
translated: but he did not even consider the qualities of slenderness, softness, and delicacy.

original: Hirikaraṇokāsanti hiriyitabbaṭṭhānaṃ. Chāyanti paṭibimbaṃ. Kīdisanti āha “iddhiyā”tiādi.
analyzed: hiri karaṇa ukāsanti hiriyitabba ṭṭhānam chāyanti paṭibimbam kīdisanti āha iddhiyā tiādi
translated: “An opportunity for shame” is a place for being ashamed. “Shadow” is a reflection. “What kind?” He says, “By his psychic power…”

original: Chāyārūpanti bhagavato paṭibimbarūpaṃ. Tañca kho buddhasantānato vinimuttaṃ rūpakamattaṃ
analyzed: chāyā rūpanti bhagavataḥ paṭibimba rūpam tat ca kho buddha santānataḥ vinimuttam rūpaka mattam
translated: “The shadow-form” is the reflection-form of the Blessed One. And that is a mere form, separate from the Buddha’s continuum,

original: bhagavato sarīravaṇṇasaṇṭhānāvayavaṃ iddhimayaṃ bimbakamattaṃ, taṃ pana dassento
analyzed: bhagavato sarīra vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna avayavam iddhi mayam bimbaka mattam tam pana dassento
translated: a mere image, made by psychic power, with the color, figure, and limbs of the Blessed One’s body. But when he shows that,

original: bhagavā yathā attano buddharūpaṃ na dissati, tathā katvā dasseti. Nīharitvāti pharitvā.
analyzed: bhagavā yathā attanaḥ buddha rūpam na dissati tathā katvā dassa iti nīharitvā ati pharitvā
translated: the Blessed One shows it in such a way that his own Buddha-form does not disappear. “Having taken out” means having spread out.

original: Kaṇṇasotānaṃ upacitatanutambalomatāya dhotarajatapanāḷikāsadisatā vuttā. Mukhapariyanteti kesante.
analyzed: upacita tanu tamba loma tāya vuttā mukha pariyantā iti kesa ante
translated: “At the edge of the mouth” means at the edge of the lips.

original: Kiriyākaraṇanti kiriyāya kāyikassa vācasikassa paṭipatti. Tatthāti tesu kiccesu.🔽Dhammakathikānaṃ vattaṃ dassetuṃ bījaniggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Na hi aññathā sabbassapi lokassa
analyzed: kiriyā karaṇam ti kiriyāya kāyikassa vācasikassa paṭipatti tattha ati tesu kiccesu  dhamma kathikānam vattam dassetum bīja niggahaṇam katam na hi aññathā sabbassa api lokassa
translated: “The performance of duties” means the performance of bodily and verbal duties. “There” means in those duties.🔽The simile of the seed is given in order to show the duties of a preacher of the Dhamma. For otherwise the face of the Buddhas, which is the most excellent ornament of the world,

original: alaṅkārabhūtaṃ paramukkaṃsagataṃ sikkhāsaṃyamānaṃ buddhānaṃ mukhacandamaṇḍalaṃ paṭicchādetabbaṃ hoti.
analyzed: alaṅkāra bhūtam param ukkaṃsa gatam sikkhāsaṃyamānam buddhānam mukha canda maṇḍalam paṭicchādetabbam hoti
translated: would be covered by the training and restraint that is the highest of all.🔽In a fragrant chamber, with a canopy spread above and garlands and incense suspended,

original: Pattharitavitānaolambitagandhadāmakusumadāmake gandhamaṇḍalamāḷe. Pubbabhāgena paricchinditvāti🔽“ettakaṃ velaṃ samāpattiyā vītināmessāmī”ti evaṃ pavattena pubbabhāgena kālaṃ paricchinditvā.🔽Paccayadāyakesu anurodhavasena parisaṃ ussādento vā paggaṇhanto, adāyakesu virodhavasena
analyzed: pattharita vitāna olambita gandhadāma kusuma dāmake gandha maṇḍala māḷe pubba bhāgena paricchinditvā ati  ettakam velam samāpattiyāḥ vītināmessāmi iti evam pavattena pubba bhāgena kālam paricchinditvā  paccaya dāyakesu anurodha vasena parisam ussādentaḥ vā paggaṇhantaḥ a dāyakesu virodha vasena
translated: having determined the time by the preliminary part of the meditation,🔽either by encouraging the assembly out of compliance with those who give the requisites or by opposing🔽those who do not give the requisites,🔽either by discouraging the assembly out of opposition to those who do not give the requisites or by encouraging

original: parisaṃ apasādento vā.
analyzed: parisam apasādentaḥ vā
translated: those who give the requisites, either by encouraging the assembly out of compliance with those who give the requisites or by opposing🔽those who do not give the requisites,

original: Yogakkhemaṃ antarāyābhāvaṃ. Sabhāvaguṇenevāti yathāvuttaguṇeneva. Bhoto gotamassa
analyzed: yogakkhemam antarāya abhāvam sabhāva guṇena iva ati yathā vutta guṇena iva bhoto gotamassa
translated: The state of security is the absence of obstruction. By means of the special qualities: by means of the qualities already mentioned.

original: guṇaṃ saviggahaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ atisambādhaṃ vitthārena sandhāretuṃ appahontato. Bhavaggaṃ
analyzed: guṇam sa viggaham cakkavāḷam ati sambādham vitthārena sandhāretum bha vaggam
translated: The world-sphere of the Cakkavāḷa is too crowded to contain the special qualities of Master Gotama in detail.

original: atinīcaṃ uparūpari sandhāretuṃ appahontato.
analyzed: ati nīcam upari upari sandhāretum
translated: The world-sphere of the Bhava is too low to contain them in succession.

original: 386. Ṭhānagamanādīsu bhūmiyaṃ suṭṭhu samaṃpatiṭṭhitā pādā etassāti suppatiṭṭhitapādo.
analyzed: ṭhāna gamana ādīsu bhūmiyam suṭṭhu samaṃpatiṭṭhitāḥ pādāḥ etassa ati suppatiṭṭhita pādaḥ
translated: He whose feet are well-planted on the ground is called one with well-planted feet.

original: Taṃ pana bhagavato suppatiṭṭhitapādataṃ byatirekamukhena vibhāvetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi
analyzed: tam pana bhagavato byatireka mukhena vibhāvetum yathā hi itiādi
translated: In order to show the excellence of the Blessed One’s well-planted feet by means of a simile, it is said:

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha aggatalanti aggapādatalaṃ. Paṇhīti paṇhitalaṃ. Passanti pādatalassa
analyzed: vuttam tattha agga talanti agga pāda talam paṇhī iti paṇhi talam passanti pāda talassa
translated: “For just as … ” and so on. There, the tip of the foot is the sole of the foot. The heel is the heel of the foot. They see the sole of the foot

original: dvīsu passesu ekekaṃ, ubhayameva vā pariyantaṃ passaṃ. Suvaṇṇapādukatalaṃ viya ujukaṃ
analyzed: dvīsu passesu ekekam ubhayam eva vā pariyantam passam suvaṇṇa pāduka talam viya ujukam
translated: on the two sides, or the whole of it, as if it were the sole of a golden plate,🔽being placed evenly. At one time: at one moment. The whole sole of the foot touches the ground

original: nikkhipiyamānaṃ. Ekappahārenevāti ekakkhaṇeyeva. Sakalaṃ pādatalaṃ bhūmiṃ phusati
analyzed: nikkhipiyamānam eka ppahārena iva ati eka khaṇeya iva sakalam pāda talam bhūmim phusati
translated: as it is being put down. At one stroke: in one moment. The whole of the sole of the foot touches the ground.

original: nikkhipane. Ekappahāreneva sakalaṃ pādatalaṃ bhūmito uṭṭhahatīti yojanā.
analyzed: nikkhipane eka pahārena iva sakalam pāda talam bhūmitaḥ uṭṭhahati iti yojanā
translated: The meaning is that the whole of the sole of the foot rises up from the ground at one time.

original: Tatrāti tāya suppatiṭṭhitapādatāya anupubbaninnāva acchariyabbhutaṃ idaṃ vuccamānaṃ
analyzed: tatra ati tāya su patiṭṭhita pāda tāya anupubba ninnāva idam vuccamānam
translated: Herein, this is said in order to show the wonderfulness of the gradual sinking down by means of the well-placed foot.

original: nissandaphalaṃ. Vuttamevatthaṃ satthu tidivagamanena supākaṭaṃ kātuṃ “tathā hī”tiādiṃ
analyzed: nissanda phalam satthu ti diva gamanena su pākaṭam kātum tathā hi itiādiṃ
translated: The meaning stated is made quite clear by the Teacher’s going to the three worlds. “For thus” is said

original: vatvā “na hī”tiādinā taṃ samattheti. Tena paṭhamalakkhaṇatopi dutiyalakkhaṇaṃ mahānubhāvanti
analyzed: vatvā na hi iti ādinā tam samatthā iti tena paṭhama lakkhaṇataḥ pi dutiya lakkhaṇam mahā anubhāvanti
translated: in order to establish that “it is not so.” Thus, by the first characteristic, he shows that the second characteristic is of great efficacy.

original: dasseti. Tathā hi vakkhati “antamaso cakkavattirañño parisaṃ upādāya sabbopi cakkalakkhaṇasseva
analyzed: dasseti tathā hi vakkhati antamasaḥ cakkavatti raññaḥ parisam upādāya sabbaḥ api cakka lakkhaṇassa iva
translated: For he says: “The whole retinue is the retinue of the wheel-mark itself, taking even the retinue of a universal monarch.”

original: parivāro”ti. Yugandharapabbatassa tāvatiṃsabhavanassa ca pakatipadanikkhepaṭṭhānupasaṅkamane
analyzed: parivāraḥ ti yugandhara pabbatassa tāvatiṃsa bhavanassa ca pakati pada nikkhepa ṭṭhāna upasaṅkamane
translated: In the case of the approach to the place of the natural setting down of the Yugandhara Mountain and the Thirty-three Gods’

original: neva buddhānaṃ, na devatānaṃ ānubhāvo, atha kho buddhānaṃ lakkhaṇānubhāvoti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: na iva buddhānam na devatānam ānubhāvaḥ atha kho buddhānam lakkhaṇa anubhāvaḥ ti imam attham
translated: there is no efficacy of the Buddhas or the gods, but rather the efficacy of the Buddhas’ characteristics. This is the meaning

original: nidassitaṃ. Sīlatejena…pe… dasannaṃ pāramīnaṃ ānubhāvenāti idampi lakkhaṇanibbattakammavisesakittanamevāti
analyzed: nidassitam dasannam pāramīnam ānubhāvena ati idam pi lakkhaṇa nibbatta kamma visesa kittanam eva ati
translated: and the rest is shown. “By the splendor of his virtue” and so on: this too should be regarded as a praise of the particular kamma that produced the characteristics.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabbāvantehīti sabbapadesavantehi.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sabbāvantehi iti sabba padesa vantehi
translated: “In all the world”: in all the regions of the world.

original: Nābhiparicchinnāti nābhiyaṃ paricchinnā paricchedavasena ṭhitā. Nābhimukhaparikkhepapaṭṭoti
analyzed: nābhi paricchinnā ati nābhiyam paricchinnā pariccheda vasena ṭhitā nābhi mukha parikkhepa paṭṭo ti
translated: “Defined by the navel”: defined by the navel, situated by way of delimitation. “A cord marked at the navel”

original: pakaticakkassa akkhabbhāhatapariharaṇatthaṃ nābhimukhe ṭhapetabbaparikkhepapaṭṭo.
analyzed: pakati cakkassa akkhabbha āhata pariharaṇa attham na abhimukhe ṭhapetabba parikkhepa paṭṭaḥ
translated: is a cord that should be placed in front of the navel for the purpose of avoiding the axle of the wheel of the chariot.

original: Nemimaṇikāti nemiyaṃ āvaḷibhāvena ṭhitamaṇikālekhā.
analyzed: nemimaṇikā ati āvaḷi bhāvena ṭhita maṇikā lekhā
translated: “Gem-studded spokes”: gem-studded lines situated in the spokes.

original: Sambahulavāroti bahuvidhalekhaṅgavibhāvanavāro. Sattīti āvudhasatti. Sirivacchoti
analyzed: sattī iti sirivaccho ti
translated: “Many sections”: a section showing many kinds of lines. “Sword” : a weapon. “Beautiful horse” :

original: sirimukhaṃ. Nandīti dakkhiṇāvaṭṭaṃ. Sovattikoti sovattiaṅko. Vaṭaṃsakoti āveḷaṃ.
analyzed: sirimukham nandī iti dakkhiṇā vaṭṭam sovattiko ti sovattiaṅkaḥ vaṭaṃsako ti āveḷam
translated: a horse with a beautiful face. “Joy” : a right-turning spiral. “Auspicious” : the auspicious mark. “Spiral” : a spiral.

original: Vaḍḍhamānakanti purisahāri purisaṅgaṃ. Morahatthakoti morapiñchakalāpo, morapiñcha
analyzed: vaḍḍhamānakam ti purisa hāri purisaṅgam morahatthako ti mora piñcha kalāpaḥ mora piñcha
translated: “Increasing” : a man-attracting ornament. “Peacock’s feather” : a peacock’s feather

original: parisibbito vā bījaniviseso. Vālabījanīti cāmarivālaṃ. Siddhatthādi puṇṇaghaṭapuṇṇapātiyo.
analyzed: parisibbitaḥ vā bīja nivisesaḥ vālabījanīti cāmarivālam siddhattha ādi puṇṇa ghaṭa puṇṇa pātiyaḥ
translated: Or the seed of a special kind of cotton. The cotton-seed is the cotton-tree’s seed. The rest is plain.

original: “Cakkavāḷo”ti vatvā tassa padhānāvayave dassetuṃ “himavā sineru…pe… sahassānī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cakkavāḷo ti vatvā tassa padhāna avayave dassetum himavā sinerupe sahassāni iti vuttam
translated: After the word “world-sphere” he said “the Himalayas, Sineru, … a thousand” in order to show the component parts of its pre-eminence.

original: Āyatapaṇhīti idaṃ aññesaṃ paṇhito dīghataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na pana atidīghatanti
analyzed: āyata paṇhī iti idam aññesam paṇhitaḥ dīgha tam sandhāya vuttam na pana ati dīgha tam ti
translated: “Long-legged” is said with reference to the length of the legs of others, not to their being too long.

original: āha “paripuṇṇapaṇhī”ti. Yathā pana paṇhilakkhaṇaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ nāma hoti, taṃ byatirekamukhena
analyzed: āha paripuṇṇa paṇhī iti yathā pana paṇhi lakkhaṇam paripuṇṇam nāma hoti tam byatireka mukhena
translated: Therefore he said “well-proportioned legs.” But in order to show the completeness of the characteristic of the legs,

original: dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Āraggenāti maṇḍalāya sikhāya. Vaṭṭetvāti yathā suvaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam āraggena ati maṇḍalāya sikhāya vaṭṭetvā iti yathā su vaṭṭam
translated: he said “like” and so on. “With a knee-cap” means with a knee-bone. “Well-rounded” means well-rounded off.

original: hoti, evaṃ vaṭṭetvā. Rattakambalageṇḍukasadisāti rattakambalamayageṇḍukasadisā.
analyzed: hoti evam vaṭṭetvā ratta kambala geṇḍuka sadisā ati ratta kambala maya geṇḍuka sadisā
translated: “Like a red blanket” means like a ball made of a red blanket.

original: Makkaṭassevāti vānarassa viya. Dīghabhāvena samataṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Niyyāsatelenāti chadikaniyyāsādiniyyāsasammissena telena.
analyzed: makkaṭassa iva āti vānarassa viya dīgha bhāvena samatam sandhāya itam vuttam niyyāsa telena ati chadika niyyāsa ādi niyyāsa sammissena telena
translated: “Like a monkey’s” means like a monkey’s. This is said with reference to the evenness of the length. “With oil applied” means with oil mixed with the oil applied to the roof and the oil applied to the floor.

original: Talunāti sukumārā.
analyzed: su kumārā
translated: “Tender” means delicate.

original: Cammenāti aṅgulantaraveṭhitacammena. Paṭibaddhaaṅgulantaroti ekato sambaddhaaṅgulantaro.🔽Ekappamāṇāti dīghato samānappamāṇā. Yavalakkhaṇanti abbhantarato aṅgulipabbeṭhitaṃ
analyzed: cammena ati aṅgula antara veṭhita cammena paṭibaddha aṅgula antaraḥ ti ekatas sambaddha aṅgula antaraḥ  eka ppamāṇā ati dīghataḥ samāna ppamāṇā yava lakkhaṇam ti abbhantarataḥ
translated: With a finger-protector means with a finger-stall. With a finger-protector tied on means with a finger-protector tied on one side.🔽Of the same size means of the same size in length. As far as the ankle means as far as the ankle-bone on the inside.

original: yavalakkhaṇaṃ. Paṭivijjhitvāti taṃtaṃpabbānaṃ samānadesatāya aṅgulīnaṃ pasāritakāle🔽aññamaññaṃ vijjhitāni viya phusitvā tiṭṭhanti.🔽Saṅkhā vuccanti gopphakā, uddhaṃ saṅkhā etesanti ussaṅkhā, pādā. Piṭṭhipādeti piṭṭhipādasamīpe.🔽Sukhena pādā parivattanti pādanāmanādīsu, teneva gacchantānaṃ tesaṃ heṭṭhā pādatalāni
analyzed: yava lakkhaṇam paṭivijjhitvā ti taṃ taṃ pabbānam samāna desa tāya aṅgulīnam pasārita kāle  aññam aññam vijjhitāni viya phusitvā tiṭṭhanti  saṅkhāḥ vuccanti gopphakāḥ uddham saṅkhāḥ etesanti ussaṅkhā pādā piṭṭhi pādā iti piṭṭhi pāda samīpe  sukhena pādā parivattanti pāda nāmana ādīsu tena iva gacchantānam tesam heṭṭhā pāda talāni
translated: Having pierced means that when the fingers are extended, the tips of the fingers touch each other as if they had pierced each other, because of the evenness of the bone-tips.🔽The ankles are called “ankles.” The feet are “with ankles” because of the ankles.🔽The feet turn easily in the ankle-bones, etc., and because of that, when they are walking, the soles of the feet are seen below.

original: dissanti. Tenāti gopphakānaṃ piṭṭhipādato uddhaṃ patiṭṭhitattā. Caturaṅgulamattañhi
analyzed: dissanti tena ati gopphakānam piṭṭhi pādataḥ uddham patiṭṭhita ttā catur aṅgula mattam hi
translated: Because of the ankles means because the ankles are placed above the feet.

original: tāni uddhaṃ ārohitvā patiṭṭhahanti, niguḷhāni ca honti, na aññesaṃ viya paññāyamānāni.
analyzed: tāni uddham ārohitvā patiṭṭhahanti niguḷhāni ca honti na aññesam viya paññāyamānāni
translated: For they are placed above the feet to the extent of four fingerbreadths, and they are hidden, not noticeable like those of other people.

original: Satipi desantarappavattiyaṃ niccaloti dassanatthaṃ nābhiggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sati pi desa antara ppavattiyam niccalaḥ ti dassana attham nābhiggahaṇam
translated: He does not bend forward in order to show that he is steady, even when he moves from place to place.

original: Yasmā eṇīmigassa samantato ekasadisamaṃsā anukkamena uddhaṃ thūlā jaṅghā honti, tasmā
analyzed: yasmai eṇīmigassa samantataḥ eka sadisa maṃsāḥ anukkamena uddham thūlāḥ jaṅghāḥ honti tasmai
translated: Since the deer’s thighs are the same all round, and gradually grow thicker above until they reach the hips,

original: vuttaṃ “eṇīmigasadisajaṅghā”ti. Paripuṇṇajaṅghoti samantato maṃsūpacayena paripuṇṇajaṅgho.
analyzed: vuttam eṇī miga sadisa jaṅghā ti paripuṇṇa jaṅghaḥ ti samantataḥ maṃsu upacayena paripuṇṇa jaṅghaḥ
translated: it is said that he has thighs like an antelope’s. He has well-rounded thighs because his thighs are well filled out all round with flesh.

original: Tenāha “na ekato”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha na ekatā iti ādi
translated: Hence he said, “not bent to one side.”🔽By this: by the words “without stooping” , etc., which show the state of his knees and hips.

original: Etenāti “anonamanto”tiādivacanena, jāṇuphāsubhāvadīpanenāti attho. Avasesajanāti🔽iminā lakkhaṇena rahitā janā. Khujjā vā honti heṭṭhimakāyato uparimakāyassa rassatāya.
analyzed: etena ati jāṇu phāsu bhāva dīpanena ati atthaḥ  iminā lakkhaṇena rahitā janā khujjāḥ vā honti heṭṭhima kāyataḥ uparima kāyassa
translated: Other people: people who are devoid of this mark.

original: Vāmanā vā uparimakāyato heṭṭhimakāyassa rassatāya. Etena ṭhapetvā sammāsambuddhaṃ
analyzed: vāmanāḥ vā uparima kāyataḥ heṭṭhima kāyassa rassa tāya etena ṭhapetvā sammāsambuddham
translated: They are either hunchbacked, with the upper part of the body bent forward because of the shortness of the lower part,🔽or dwarfish, with the lower part of the body bent forward because of the shortness of the upper part. By this he shows that, except for the Perfectly Enlightened One and a Wheel-turning Monarch,

original: cakkavattinañca itare sattā khujjā vāmanā cāti dasseti.
analyzed: cakkavattinam ca itare sattā khujjāḥ vāmanāḥ ca ati dasseti
translated: other beings are either hunchbacked or dwarfish.🔽It is let down: it is let down and hidden inside. But when it is in that state, it is covered up,

original: Ohitanti samohitaṃ antogadhaṃ. Tathābhūtaṃ pana taṃ tena channaṃ hotīti āha “paṭicchanna”nti.
analyzed: samohitam antogadham tathābhūtam pana tam tena channam hoti iti āha paṭicchannam iti
translated: thus he said “concealed.”

original: Suvaṇṇavaṇṇoti suvaṇṇavaṇṇavaṇṇoti ayamettha atthoti āha “jātihiṅgulakenā”tiādi.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo ti suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa vaṇṇo ti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti āha jāti hiṅgulakena atiādi
translated: “Golden-coloured” : the meaning here is “having a colour like gold” .

original: Svāyamattho āvuttiñāyena ca veditabbo. Sarīrapariyāyo idha vaṇṇasaddoti adhippāyena🔽paṭhamavikappaṃ vatvā tathārūpāya pana ruḷhiyā abhāvaṃ manasi katvā vaṇṇadhātupariyāyameva
analyzed: svāyam atthaḥ āvutti ñāyena ca veditabbo sarīra pariyāyaḥ idha vaṇṇa saddo ti adhippāyena  paṭhama vikappam vatvā tathārūpāya pana ruḷhiyāḥ abhāvam manasi katvā vaṇṇa dhātu pariyāyam eva
translated: This meaning can be understood by the method of word derivation.🔽The intention is that the word “colour” here is a synonym for “body”.🔽After stating the first interpretation, the second interpretation is stated by taking the word “colour” as a synonym for the colour element,

original: vaṇṇasaddaṃ gahetvā dutiyavikappo vutto.
analyzed: vaṇṇa saddam gahetvā dutiya vikappaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: having considered the absence of such a usage.

original: Rajoti sukhumarajo. Jallanti malīnabhāvāvaho reṇusañcayo. Tenāha “malaṃ vā”ti. Yadi vivaṭṭati, kathaṃ nhānādīti āha “hatthadhovanā”tiādi.
analyzed: rajaḥ iti sukhuma rajaḥ jallanti malīna bhāva āvahaḥ tena āha malam vāti yadi vivaṭṭati katham nhāna ādi iti āha hattha dhovana atiādi
translated: “Dust” : fine dust. “Dirt” : a collection of particles that causes a soiled condition. Therefore it is said, “or dirt”. If it is a whirl, how is it a bath, etc.? He says, “washing the hands,” etc.

original: Āvaṭṭapariyosāneti padakkhiṇāvaṭṭāya ante.
analyzed: āvaṭṭa pariyosāne iti padakkhiṇa avaṭṭāya ante
translated: “At the end of the whirl” : at the end of the clockwise whirl.

original: Brahmuno sarīraṃ purato vā pacchato vā anonamitvā ujukameva uggatanti āha “brahmā viya ujugatto”ti. Passavaṅkāti dakkhiṇapassena vā vāmapassena vā vaṅkā.
analyzed: brahmuno sarīram puratas vā pacchatas vā anonamitvā ujukam eva uggatanti āha brahmā viya uju gattaḥ ti passa vaṅkā ati dakkhiṇa passena vā vāma passena vā vaṅkā
translated: Brahmā’s body does not rise either in front or behind, but straight up. Therefore it is said, “straight like Brahmā.” “Bent to the right” : bent to the right side or to the left side.

original: Hatthapiṭṭhiādivasena satta ussadā etassāti sattussado.
analyzed: hattha piṭṭhi ādi vasena satta ussadāḥ etassa ati sattussadaḥ
translated: “Seven protuberances” : it has seven protuberances such as the back of the hand, etc.

original: Sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ sīhapubbaddhaṃ, paripuṇṇāvayavatāya sīhapubbaddhaṃ viya sakalo
analyzed: sīhassa pubbaddham sīha pubbaddham paripuṇṇa avayava tāya sīha pubbaddham viya sakalaḥ
translated: “Lion-like” : the body is like a lion’s. “With a body like a lion’s” : the whole body is like a lion’s body, which is complete in all its parts.

original: kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo. Sīhassevāti sīhassa viya. Saṇṭhantīti saṇṭhahanti.
analyzed: kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ sīhassa iva ati sīhassa viya saṇṭhanti iti saṇṭhahanti
translated: “Like a lion” : like a lion. “Set down” : placed down.

original: Nānācittenāti vividhacittena. Puññacittenāti pāramitāpuññacittarūpena. Cittitoti sañjātacittabhāvo.
analyzed: nānā cittena ati vividha cittena puñña cittena ati pāramitā puñña citta rūpena cittitas ti sañjāta citta bhāvaḥ
translated: “With various thoughts” : with various kinds of thoughts. “With thoughts of merit” : with thoughts of merit consisting of the perfections. “With thoughts arisen” : with thoughts that have come into being.

original: Dvinnaṃ koṭṭānamantaranti dvinnaṃ piṭṭhibāhānaṃ vemajjhaṃ, piṭṭhimajjhassa uparibhāgo.
analyzed: dvinnam koṭṭānam antaranti dvinnam vemajjham piṭṭhi majjhassa upari bhāgaḥ
translated: “Between the two shoulders” : in the middle of the two shoulders and back.

original: Citaṃ paripuṇṇanti aninnabhāvena citaṃ, dvīhi koṭṭehi samatalatāya paripuṇṇaṃ. Uggammāti uggantvā.
analyzed: citam paripuṇṇanti aninna bhāvena citam dvīhi koṭṭehi sama tala tāya paripuṇṇam uggamma ati uggantvā
translated: “The chest is full” : the chest is full because it is not sunken, and it is full because it is level with the two shoulders. “Rising up” : rising up.

original: Nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo viya parimaṇḍalo nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo ekassa parimaṇḍalasaddassa
analyzed: nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ viya parimaṇḍalaḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ ekassa parimaṇḍala saddassa
translated: “Round like the disk of the moon” : round like the disk of the moon. The word “disk” is omitted, as in the expression “the round moon.”

original: lopaṃ katvā. Na hi sabbo nigrodho maṇḍalo. Tenāha “samakkhandhasākho nigrodho”ti.
analyzed: lopam katvā na hi sabbaḥ nigrodhaḥ maṇḍalo tena āha sama khandha sākhaḥ nigrodhaḥ ti
translated: For the whole moon is not round. Therefore it is said: “The banyan tree is a tree with a level crown.”

original: Parimaṇḍalasaddasannidhānena vā parimaṇḍalova nigrodho gayhatīti parimaṇḍalasaddassa
analyzed: parimaṇḍala sadda sannidhānena vā parimaṇḍalaḥ uva nigrodhaḥ gayhati iti parimaṇḍala saddassa
translated: Or else, the word parimaṇḍala is taken as a bahubbīhi compound, the meaning of which is obtained even without the elision of the vowel, since the word parimaṇḍala is in the vicinity of the word sadda.

original: lopena vināpi ayamattho labbhatīti āha “nigrodho viya parimaṇḍalo”ti. Yāvatakvassāti
analyzed: lopena vinā api ayam attho labbhati iti āha nigrodhaḥ viya parimaṇḍalo ti yāvatakvassa ati
translated: The word parimaṇḍala is a bahubbīhi compound, the meaning of which is obtained even without the elision of the vowel, since the word parimaṇḍala is in the vicinity of the word sadda.

original: o-kārassa va-kārādesaṃ katvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: okārassa vakāra ādesam katvā vuttam
translated: The word yāvataka is a bahubbīhi compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the o of ojas to va.🔽The word samavaṭṭitakkhandho is a tatpurisa compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the order of the terms.

original: Samavaṭṭitakkhandhoti samaṃ suvaṭṭitakkhandho. Koñcā viya dīghagalā, bakā viya vaṅkagalā, varāhā viya puthulagalāti yojanā. Suvaṇṇāliṅgasadisoti suvaṇṇamayakhuddakamudiṅgasadiso.
analyzed: sama avaṭṭita khandho ti samam su vaṭṭita kkhandho koñcāḥ viya dīgha galāḥ bakāḥ viya vaṅka galāḥ varāhāḥ viya puthula galāḥ iti yojanā suvaṇṇa āliṅga sadisaḥ iti suvaṇṇa maya khuddaka mudiṅga sadisaḥ
translated: The word suvaṇṇāliṅgasadiso is a tatpurisa compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the order of the terms.

original: Rasaggasaggīti madhurādibhedaṃ rasaṃ gasanti anto pavesantīti rasaggasā, rasaggasānaṃ
analyzed: rasaggasaggī iti madhura ādi bhedam rasam gasanti antar pavesanti iti
translated: The word rasaggasaggī is a tatpurisa compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the order of the terms.

original: aggā rasaggasaggā, tā etassa santīti rasaggasaggī. Tenāti ojāya apharaṇena, hīnadhātukattā🔽te bahvābādhā honti.
analyzed: aggāḥ rasagga saggā tāḥ etassa santi iti rasagga saggī tena ati ojāya a pharaṇena hīna dhātuka ttā  te bahu ābādhāḥ honti
translated: The word rasaggasaggī is a tatpurisa compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the order of the terms.

original: “Hanū”ti sannissayadantādhārassa samaññā, taṃ bhagavato sīhahanusadisaṃ, tasmā bhagavā
analyzed: hanu uti sannissaya danta ādhārassa samaññā tam bhagavataḥ sīha hanu sadisam tasmai bhagavā
translated: The word hanū is a bahubbīhi compound, the meaning of which is obtained by changing the order of the terms.

original: sīhahanu. Tattha yasmā buddhānaṃ rūpakāyassa dhammakāyassa ca upamā nāma nihīnupamāva,
analyzed: sīha hanu tattha yasmā buddhānam rūpa kāyassa dhamma kāyassa ca upamā nāma nihīna upamā ava
translated: He has a lion-like jaw. Herein, since the physical body and the Dhamma body of Buddhas have no simile in what is inferior,

original: natthi samānupamā, kuto adhikūpamā, tasmā ayampi nihīnupamāti dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi
analyzed: natthi samānupamā kutas adhikūpamā tasmā ayam pi nihīnupamā ti dassetum tattha atiādi
translated: there is no simile in what is equal to them, still less in what is superior. So this is given in order to show that this is a simile in what is inferior.

original: vuttaṃ. Tibhāgavasena maṇḍalatāya dvādasiyaṃ pakkhassa candasadisāni.
analyzed: vuttam ti bhāga vasena maṇḍala tāya dvādasiyam pakkhassa canda sadisāni
translated: The teeth are like the moon in the twelve-day half-month in that they are circular all round.

original: Dantānaṃ uccanīcatā abbhantarabāhirapassavasenapi veditabbā, na aggavaseneva. Tenāha🔽“ayapaṭṭachinnasaṅkhapaṭalaṃ viyā”ti. Ayapaṭṭanti ca kakacaṃ adhippetaṃ. Visamāti visamasaṇṭhānā.
analyzed: dantānam ucca nīca tā abbhantara bāhira passa vasena api veditabbā na agga vasena iva tena āha  aya paṭṭa chinna saṅkha paṭalam viyāti ca kakacam adhippetam visamāti visama saṇṭhānā
translated: The height and shortness of the teeth should be understood as to position, both as to the inside and the outside, not as to the tip. Hence he said🔽“like a cut-off section of a cock’s nail.” And “cock’s nail” is intended as a kind of chisel. Uneven: of uneven shape.

original: Vicchinditvā vicchinditvā pavattasaratāya chinnassarāpi. Anekākāratāya bhinnassarāpi.
analyzed: vicchinditvā vicchinditvā pavatta saratāya chinna ssarā api aneka ākāra tāya bhinna ssarā api
translated: They are “jagged” because they are set out with a gap between each one. They are “broken” because they are of various shapes.

original: Kākassa viya amanuññasaratāya kākassarāpi. Apalibuddhattāti anupaddutavatthukattā.
analyzed: kākassa viya a manuñña sara tāya kākassarā api a palibuddha ttā ati an upadduta vatthuka ttā
translated: They are “crow-like” because of their unlovely shape like a crow’s. Not crowded: not pressing on each other.

original: Vatthunti ca akkharuppattiṭṭhānamāha. Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatoti ettha aṭṭhaṅgāni parato
analyzed: vatthum ti ca akkhara uppatti ṭṭhānam āha aṭṭhaṅga samannāgataḥ ti ettha aṭṭhaṅgāni paratas
translated: “Position” is the place where the letters are produced.

original: āgamissanti. Mañjughosoti madhurassaro.
analyzed: āgamissanti mañjughosaḥ uti madhurassaro
translated: will come. Sweet-voiced: having a melodious voice.

original: Karavīkasaddo yesaṃ sattānaṃ sotapathaṃ upagacchati, te attano sarasampattiyā pakatiṃ
analyzed: karavīka saddaḥ yesam sattānam sota patham upagacchati te attanaḥ sara sampattiyāḥ pakatim
translated: When the sound of the birds comes within the range of hearing of beings, they forget their own natural voices

original: jahāpetvā avase karonto attano vase vatteti, evaṃ madhuroti dassento “tatrida”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: jahāpetvā avase karontaḥ attanaḥ vase vatta iti evam madhurā iti dassentaḥ tatridanti ādim āha
translated: and, as if made subservient, come under the birds’ control. Showing that their voices are so sweet, he said, “There.”

original: Taṃ pītinti taṃ buddhagataṃ pītiṃ. Teneva nīhārena punappunaṃ pavattantaṃ avijahitvā
analyzed: tam pītin ti tam buddha gatam pītim tena iva nīhārena punappunam pavattantam a vijahitvā
translated: That rapture: that rapture in the Buddha. Without ever abandoning that rapture, which occurs again and again with that same inspiration,

original: vikkhambhitakilesā therānaṃ santike laddhadhammassavanasappāyā upanissayasampattiyā🔽paripakkañāṇatāya “sattahi…pe… patiṭṭhāsī”ti. Sattasatamattena orodhajanena saddhiṃ
analyzed: vikkhambhita kilesā therānam santike laddha dhamma ssavana sappāyā upanissaya sampattiyā  paripakka ñāṇa tāya satta hipe patiṭṭhāsi iti satta sata mattena orodha janena saddhim
translated: and with the fulfilment of the necessary conditions for listening to the Dhamma in the presence of the elders, with the abandoning of defilements,🔽and with the ripening of his knowledge, he stood on the plane of stream-entry.

original: padasāva therānaṃ santikaṃ upagatattā “sattahi jaṅghāsatehi saddhi”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: therānam santikam upagata ttā sattahi jaṅghā satehi saddhinti vuttam
translated: Since he went on foot in the presence of the elders with a following of seven hundred, it is said, “With seven hundred people on foot.”

original: Abhinīlanettoti adhikanīlanetto. Adhikanīlatā ca sātisayaṃ nīlabhāvena veditabbā,
analyzed: abhinīla netto ti adhika nīla netto adhika nīla tā ca sa atisayam nīla bhāvena veditabbā
translated: Deep-blue eyes: eyes that are more than just blue. The quality of being more than just blue should be understood as an excess of blueness,

original: na nette nīlavaṇṇasseva adhikabhāvatoti āha “na sakalanīlanettovā”tiādi. Pītalohitavaṇṇā
analyzed: na nette nīla vaṇṇassa iva adhika bhāvataḥ ti āha na pīta lohita vaṇṇā
translated: and because the black colour of the eyes is predominant, he says, “not the whole eye is black.”🔽The colour of the pupils is yellow and red,

original: setamaṇḍalagatarājivasena, nīlasetakāḷavaṇṇā pana taṃtaṃmaṇḍalavaseneva veditabbā.
analyzed: seta maṇḍala gata rāji vasena nīla seta kāḷa vaṇṇā pana tat tat maṇḍala vasena iva veditabbā
translated: and the colour of the whites is black, white, and red, and these should be understood as being in the respective parts.

original: Cakkhubhaṇḍanti akkhidalanti keci, akkhidalapattanti aññe. Akkhidalehi pana saddhiṃ akkhibimbanti veditabbaṃ. Evañhi viniggatagambhīrajotanāpi yuttā hoti.
analyzed: cakkhubhaṇḍanti akkhi dalanti keci akkhi dala pattanti aññe akkhi dalehi pana saddhim akkhi bimbanti veditabbam evam hi viniggata gambhīra jotanā api yuttā hoti
translated: “Eye-membrane” is the eye-film, some say; others say it is the eye-film and the eye-lid. But it should be understood as the eye-ball together with the eye-lids, for then the expression “deep and clear” is appropriate.

original: Uṇṇāsaddo loke avisesato lomapariyāyo, idha pana lomavisesavācakoti āha “uṇṇaloma”nti.
analyzed: uṇṇā saddaḥ loke avisesataḥ loma pariyāyaḥ idha pana loma visesa vācakaḥ iti āha uṇṇaloman ti
translated: The word “hair-tuft” is a term for the hair in the world in general, but here it is a term for a particular kind of hair, so he says “the hair-tuft hair.”

original: Nalāṭamajjhajātāti nalāṭamajjhagatā. Odātatāya upamā, na mudutāya. Rajatapubbuḷakāti rajatamayatārakā.🔽Dve atthavase paṭicca vuttanti yasmā buddhā cakkavattino ca paripuṇṇanalāṭatāya paripuṇṇasīsabimbatāya
analyzed: nalāṭa majjha jātā ati nalāṭa majjha gatā odāta tāya upamā na mudu tāya rajata pubbuḷakā ati rajata maya tārakā 🔽dve attha vase paṭicca vuttanti yasmai buddhā cakkavattino ca paripuṇṇa nalāṭa tāya paripuṇṇa sīsa bimba tāya
translated: “Arisen in the middle of the forehead”: situated in the middle of the forehead. The simile is in respect of whiteness, not softness. “Silver-coins”: silver stars.

original: ca “uṇhīsasīsā”ti vuccanti, tasmā te dve atthavase paṭicca “uṇhīsasīso”ti idaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca uṇhīsa sīsā ati vuccanti tasmā te dve attha vase paṭicca uṇhīsa sīsaḥ ti idam vuttam
translated: and so they are called “peaked-headed”. So this was said in order to point out these two reasons.

original: Idāni taṃ atthadvayaṃ bhagavati suppatiṭṭhitanti dassetuṃ “tathāgatassahī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni tam attha dvayam bhagavati suppatiṭṭhitanti dassetum tathāgatassa hi itiādi vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show that these two reasons are well-founded in the Blessed One, it was said, “The Tathāgata’s head is like a turban-knot,”

original: Saṇhatamatāya suvaṇṇavaṇṇatāya ca rañño baddhauṇhīsapaṭṭo viya virocati. Kappasīsāti
analyzed: saṇhatama tāya suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa tāya ca raññaḥ baddha oṇhīsa paṭṭaḥ viya virocati kappa sīsā ati
translated: and so on. It shines like a king’s turban-knot of fine cloth, because of its compactness and its golden colour. “A double-peaked head” :

original: dvidhābhūtasīsā. Phalasīsāti phalasadisasīsā. Aṭṭhisīsāti maṃsassa abhāvato tacopariyonaddhaaṭṭhimattasīsā.🔽Tumbasīsāti lābusadisasīsā. Pabbhārasīsāti piṭṭhibhāgena olambamānasīsā. Purimanayenāti🔽paripuṇṇanalāṭatāpakkhena. Uṇhīsaveṭhitasīso viyāti uṇhīsapaṭṭena veṭhitasīsapadeso
analyzed: dvidhā bhūta sīsā phala sīsā ati phala sadisa sīsā aṭṭhi sīsā ati maṃsassa abhāvato taca upari yonaddha aṭṭhi matta sīsā  tumba sīsā ati lābu sadisa sīsā pabbhāra sīsā ati piṭṭhi bhāgena olambamāna sīsā purima nayena ati  paripuṇṇa nalāṭa tā pakkhena uṇhīsa veṭhita sīsaḥ viyāti uṇhīsa paṭṭena veṭhita sīsa padesaḥ
translated: the head has two peaks. “A peaked head” : the head is like a peak. “A bony head” : the head is merely bone covered by skin, because of the absence of flesh.🔽“A pot-like head” : the head is like a pot. “A hanging-down head” : the head hangs down by the nape of the neck. “In the first way” :🔽by means of a forehead that is full and well-shaped. “Like a head wrapped in a turban” : like a place on the head wrapped in a turban.

original: viya. Uṇhīsaṃ viyāti chekena sippinā viracitauṇhīsamaṇḍalaṃ viya.
analyzed: viya uṇhīsam viyāti chekena sippinā viracita oṇhīsa maṇḍalam
translated: “Like a turban” : like a circle of turban cloth fashioned with a single fold.

original: Kammanti yena yena kammena yaṃ yaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ nibbattaṃ, taṃ taṃ kammaṃ. Kammasarikkhakanti
analyzed: kammanti yena yena kammena yam yam lakkhaṇam nibbattam tam tam kammam kamma sarikkhakam ti
translated: “The action” : the action by which each mark is produced. “The action’s likeness” :

original: tassa tassa lakkhaṇassa taṃkammānurūpatā. Lakkhaṇanti tassa mahāpurisalakkhaṇassa
analyzed: tassa tassa lakkhaṇassa tad kamma anurūpa tā lakkhaṇanti tassa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇassa
translated: The “sign” is the unperverted individual essence of that Great Man’s sign.

original: aviparītasabhāvo. Lakkhaṇānisaṃsanti taṃ lakkhaṇapaṭilābhena laddhabbaguṇo. Imāni
analyzed: aviparīta sabhāvaḥ tam lakkhaṇa paṭilābhena laddhabba guṇaḥ imāni
translated: The “advantage of the sign” is the special quality that can be obtained through obtaining the sign.

original: kammādīnīti imāni anantaraṃ vuttāni kammakammasarikkhakādīni dassetvā taṃ sarūpato
analyzed: kamma ādīni iti imāni anantaram vuttāni kamma kamma sarikkhaka ādīni dassetvā tam sarūpato
translated: The “action” and the rest should be explained by showing the action, etc.,

original: vibhāvetvā kathetabbāni saṃvaṇṇakena.🔽Ratanavicittasuvaṇṇatoraṇaṃ tasmiṃ kāle manussaloke natthīti vuttaṃ “devanagare”ti.
analyzed: vibhāvetvā kathetabbāni saṃvaṇṇakena  ratana vicitta suvaṇṇa toraṇam tasmim kāle manussa loke natthi iti vuttam devanagare iti
translated: and by expounding them in detail.🔽The golden archway studded with gems did not exist in the human world at that time, so it is said to have been in the city of the gods.

original: Sabbaso supupphitasālarukkho asādhāraṇasobho manussūpacāre na labbhatīti āha “selantaramhī”ti.
analyzed: sabbaso su pupphita sāla rukkhaḥ asādhāraṇa sobhaḥ manussu upacāre na labbhati iti āha
translated: The tree in full flower with its extraordinary beauty was not available for human use, so it is said to have been in the Himalayas.

original: Kiriyācāranti kāyikavācasikakiriyāpavattiṃ.
analyzed: kiriyā ācāranti kāyika vācasika kiriyā apavattim
translated: “The performance of action” is the performance of bodily and verbal action.

original: 387. Satatapāṭihāriyanti satataṃ carimabhave sabbakālaṃ lakkhaṇanibbattakakammānubhāvahetukaṃ
analyzed: satatapāṭihāriyanti satatam carima bhave sabbakālam lakkhaṇa nibbattaka kamma anubhāva hetukam
translated: “The constant miracle” is the constant miracle that is unique to Buddhas, which is due to the power of the kamma that produces the major marks throughout the last existence,

original: buddhāveṇikaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ. Buddhānaṃ atidūre pādaṃ nikkhipitukāmānampi nātidūre eva
analyzed: buddha āveṇikam pāṭihāriyam buddhānam atidūre pādam nikkhipitu kāmānam pi na atidūre eva
translated: and which is not too far away even when Buddhas wish to place their feet very far away.

original: nikkhipanaṃ hotīti “na atidūre ṭhapessāmīti uddharatī”ti vuttaṃ. Pakatisañcaraṇavasenetaṃ
analyzed: nikkhipanam hoti iti na atidūre ṭhapessāmi iti uddharati iti vuttam pakati sañcaraṇa vasena itaṃ
translated: “It is laid down” means “he lifts it up thinking ‘I shall not place it too far away.’”

original: vuttaṃ, tādisena pādena anekayojane ṭhapessāmīti uddharaṇampi hotiyeva. Atidūraṃ🔽hītiādi pamāṇātikkame dosadassanaṃ. Evaṃ satīti evaṃ dakkhiṇapādavāmapādānaṃ yathādhippetapatiṭṭhitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vuttam tādisena pādena aneka yojane ṭhapessāmi iti uddharaṇam pi ati dūram  hi itiādi pamāṇa atikkame dosa dassanam evam sati iti evam dakkhiṇa pāda vāma pādānam yathā adhippeta patiṭṭhita ṭṭhāne
translated: This is said according to the normal way of walking. But he can lift it up thinking “I shall place it many leagues away” with such a foot.🔽“Too far away” and so on point out the disadvantage in exceeding the right measure.🔽“If it is so” means if it is placed in the place where it should be placed with the right foot and the left foot.🔽“The break in the step” means the break in the sequence of the steps.

original: sati. Padavicchedoti padavāravicchedo. Yādisaṃ pasārento vāmapādassa uddharaṇaṃ patiṭṭhānañca,
analyzed: sati pada vicchedo ti pada vāra vicchedaḥ yādisam pasārentaḥ vāma pādassa uddharaṇam patiṭṭhānam ca
translated: The lifting up and the placing down of the left foot are the same as those of the right foot.

original: dakkhiṇapādassa tādisameva, iti nesaṃ uddharaṇapatiṭṭhānānaṃ samānato aññamaññabhāvena🔽anūnānadhikatāya vuttaṃ “dakkhiṇapādakiccaṃ vāmapādena niyamitaṃ, vāmapādakiccaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇa pādassa tādisam eva iti na īsam uddharaṇa patiṭṭhānānam samānatas aññamañña bhāvena  anūna anadhikatāya vuttam dakkhiṇa pāda kiccam vāma pādena niyamitam vāma pāda kiccam
translated: So, because of the similarity of the lifting up and the placing down of the two feet, there is no difference between them.

original: dakkhiṇapādena niyamita”nti.
analyzed: dakkhiṇa pādena
translated: The function of the right foot is determined by the left foot, and the function of the left foot is determined by the right foot.

original: Divāti upakaṭṭhāya velāya. Vihārabhattatthāyāti vihāre yathāvuddhaṃ gahetabbabhattatthāya.
analyzed: divā ti upakaṭṭhāya velāya vihāra bhatta tthāya ati vihāre yathāvuddham gahetabba bhatta tthāya
translated: “Day” means the time when it is light. “For the sake of the meal in the monastery” means for the sake of the meal to be received in the monastery according to seniority.

original: Pacchato āgacchantoti pakatigamanena pacchato āgacchanto. Okāsaṃ na labhatīti padanikkhepaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pacchatas āgacchanto ti pakati gamanena pacchatas āgacchanto okāsam na labhati iti pada nikkhepa ṭṭhānam
translated: Coming behind him: coming behind by the normal way of going. He does not get a chance to put his foot down: he does not get a chance to put his foot down on the place where the other has put his.

original: na labhati. Ūrupariyāyo idha satthi-saddoti āha “na ūruṃ unnāmetī”ti. Daṇḍaṅkusaṃ🔽vuccati dīghadaṇḍo aṅkuso, tena rukkhasākhaṃ chindato purisassa yathā pacchābhāgena
analyzed: na labhati ūru pariyāyaḥ idha satthi saddo ti āha na ūrum unnāmeti iti daṇḍaṅkusam  vuccati dīgha daṇḍaḥ aṅkuso tena rukkha sākham chindataḥ purisassa yathā pacchābhāgena
translated: The word satthi here is used in the sense of thigh, says the Commentary. He does not raise his thigh:

original: pādānaṃ osakkanaṃ hoti, evaṃ bhagavato pādā na osakkantīti āha “rukkhasākhāchedana…pe…🔽osakkāpetī”ti. Obaddhānābaddhaṭṭhānehi pādaṃ koṭṭento viyāti ābaddhaṭṭhānena anābaddhaṭṭhānena🔽ca pādakhaṇḍaṃ koṭṭetvā thaddhaṃ karonto viya. Na ito cito ca cāletīti aparāparaṃ🔽na cāleti. Ussaṅkhapādatāya sukheneva pādānaṃ parivattanato nābhito paṭṭhāya uparimakāyo
analyzed: pādānam osakkanam hoti evam bhagavato pādāḥ na osakkanti iti āha rukkha sākhā chedana pe  osakkā apeti iti obaddha an ābaddha ṭṭhānehi pādam koṭṭentaḥ viyāti ābaddha ṭṭhānena an ābaddha ṭṭhānena  ca pāda khaṇḍam koṭṭetvā thaddham karontaḥ viya na itas citas ca cāleti iti apara aparam  na cāleti ussaṅkha pāda tāya sukhena iva pādānam parivattanataḥ nābhitaḥ paṭṭhāya uparima kāyaḥ
translated: A long-handled goad is called a daṇḍaṅkusaka. Just as when a man cuts a tree branch with such a goad, his feet sink down at the back, so too the Blessed One’s feet did not sink down. He does not sink his feet down:🔽He does not stamp his feet as if he were treading on something soft by pressing down on the parts of the foot that are not pressed down and pressing down on the parts that are pressed down. He does not move his body to and fro:🔽he does not move it to and fro from side to side. His upper body does not sway:

original: na iñjatīti heṭṭhimakāyova iñjati. Tenāha “uparima…pe… niccalo hotī”ti. Na jānāti
analyzed: na iñjati iti heṭṭhima kāyaḥ uva iñjati tena āha upari mape niccalaḥ hoti iti na jānāti
translated: his upper body does not sway because his feet turn easily owing to the possession of well-developed feet. Only his lower body sways. Therefore the Commentary says: “His upper body … remains motionless.” He does not know:

original: aniñjanato. Kāyabalenāti gamanapayogasaṅkhātena kāyagatena visesabalena. Javagamanahetubhūtena
analyzed: kāya balena ati gamana payoga saṅkhātena kāya gatena visesa balena java gamana hetu bhūtena
translated: “With the strength of his body” means with the special strength of his body, which is the means of locomotion.🔽Or it means with the strength of his body, which is the cause of his swiftness in walking.

original: vā kāyabalena. Tenāha “bāhā khipanto”tiādi. Javena gacchanto hi bāhā khipati, sarīrato
analyzed: vā kāya balena tena āha bāhā javena gacchantaḥ hi bāhā khipati sarīrataḥ
translated: Hence it is said: “Swinging his arms” and so on. For one who walks swiftly swings his arms and the sweat breaks out on his body.

original: sedā muccanti. Nāgāpalokitavasenāti nāgassa apalokanamiva sakalakāyeneva parivattetvā apalokanavasena.🔽Anāvaraṇañāṇassāti anāvaraṇañāṇabalena dassanassa. Anāvaraṇavāro pana kāye patiṭṭhitarūpadassanampi
analyzed: sedāḥ muccanti nāga apalokita vasena ati nāgassa apalokanam iva sakala kāyena iva parivattetvā apalokana vasena  anāvaraṇa ñāṇassa ati anāvaraṇa ñāṇa balena dassanassa anāvaraṇa vāraḥ pana kāye patiṭṭhita rūpa dassanam pi
translated: “With the look of a Nāga” means with the look of a Nāga, that is, by turning his whole body around as a Nāga does.🔽“With unobstructed knowledge” means with the power of unobstructed knowledge of seeing.🔽But the section on unobstructed knowledge is stated in order to show that the seeing of visible forms that are in contact with the body is also unobstructed.

original: anāvaraṇamevāti dassanatthaṃ vutto. Indakhīlato paṭṭhāyāti nagaradvāre indakhīlato
analyzed: anāvaraṇam eva ti dassana attham vuttaḥ inda khīlato paṭṭhāya ati nagara dvāre inda khīlato
translated: “From the Inda-hall” means from the Inda-hall at the city gate.

original: paṭṭhāya. Pakatiiriyāpathenevāti onamanādiṃ akatvā ujukagamanādinā eva. Yadi evaṃ🔽koṭṭhakadvāragehappavese kathanti āha “daliddamanussāna”ntiādi. Parivattentenāti
analyzed: paṭṭhāya pakati iriyāpathena iva ati onamana ādim a katvā ujuka gamana ādinā eva yadi evam  koṭṭhaka dvāra geha ppavese katham ti āha dalidda manussāna nti ādi parivattentena ati
translated: “With his normal gait” means without bending down and so on, but with a straight walk and so on.🔽If that is so, how is it that he entered the houses and the doorways of the alleys?

original: nipajjanatthaṃ kāyaṃ parivattentena.
analyzed: nipajjana attham kāyam parivattentena
translated: “Turning around” means turning his body around for the purpose of lying down.

original: Hatthehi gahetvāti ubhohi hatthehi ubhosu kaṭippadesesu pariggahetvā. Patati nisīdanaṭṭhāne🔽nipajjanavasena patati. Orimaṃ aṅgaṃ nissāya nisinnoti pallaṅkamābhujitvā ukkuṭikanisajjāya
analyzed: hatthehi gahetvā ti ubhohi hatthehi ubhosu kaṭi ppadesesu pariggahetvā patati nisīdanaṭṭhāne  nipajjana vasena patati orimam aṅgam nissāya nisinno ti pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ukkuṭika nisajjāya
translated: He sits holding it with his hands: he sits holding it with both hands at the two sides of the buttocks. It falls: it falls on the sitting place, in the sense of lying down.

original: uparimakāyaṃ heṭṭhimakāye patiṭṭhapentoyeva bhārīkaraṇavasena orimaṅgaṃ nissāya nisinno.🔽Ghaṃsantoti ānisadadesena āsanaṭṭhānaṃ ghaṃsanto. Pārimaṅganti satthibhāgasammaddaṃ🔽ānisadapadesaṃ. Tathevāti ghaṃsanto eva. Olambakaṃ dhārento viyāti olambakasuttaṃ
analyzed: uparima kāyam heṭṭhima kāye patiṭṭhapento yeva bhārīkaraṇa vasena orim aṅgam nissāya nisinnaḥ  ghaṃsanto ti ānisada desena āsana ṭhānam ghaṃsanto pārimaṅganti satthi bhāga sammaddam  ānisada padesam tathā iva ati ghaṃsantaḥ eva olambakam dhārentaḥ viya ati olambaka suttam
translated: He sits leaning on that part: he sits leaning on the front part, in the sense of making it heavy, by placing the upper body on the lower body in the sitting posture of the cross-legged position.🔽He strokes: he strokes the sitting place in the sense of sitting down. The back part: the part of the buttocks. Just so: just as he strokes.🔽He sits supporting it as if it were a swing: he sits supporting it as if he were hanging down a swing. By that he says that the sitting place should be straight.

original: otārento viya. Tena ujukameva nisīdanamāha. Sarīrassa garukabhāvahetūnaṃ dūrato samupāyitabhāvena🔽sallahukabhāvato tūlapicuṃ ṭhapento viya.
analyzed: viya tena ujukam eva nisīdanam āha sarīrassa garuka bhāva hetūnam dūratas samupāyita bhāvena  tūla picum ṭhapentaḥ viya
translated: As if he were placing a ball of cotton: as if he were placing a ball of cotton because of the lightness of the body due to the removal from a distance of the causes of heaviness of the body.

original: Appesakkhānaṃ mahānubhāvagehappavese siyā chambhitattaṃ, cittakkhobho, darathavasena
analyzed: appesakkhānam mahā anubhāva geha ppavese siyā chambhita ttam citta kkhobhaḥ daratha vasena
translated: There might be fear, agitation of mind, and depression in the case of those of little importance on entering a house of great importance.

original: nānappakārakappanaṃ, bhayavasena taṇhāvasena paritassanaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato natthīti
analyzed: nānā pakāra kappanam bhaya vasena taṇhā vasena paritassanam tat sabbam bhagavataḥ natthi iti
translated: He has no fear of any kind, no anxiety through craving,

original: dassetuṃ pāḷiyaṃ “na chambhatī”tiādi vuttanti āha “na chambhatī”tiādi.🔽Udakaṃ dīyati etenāti udakadānaṃ, bhiṅkārādi udakabhājanaṃ. Baddhaṃ katvāti hatthagatamattikaṃ🔽viya attano vase avattantaṃ katvā. Parivattetvāti kujjitvā. Vichaḍḍayamāno udakassa
analyzed: dassetum pāḷiyam na chambhati itiādi vuttanti āha na chambhati itiādi  udakam dīyati etena ati udaka dānam bhiṅkāra ādi udaka bhājanam baddham katvā ati hattha gata mattikam  viya attanaḥ vase avattantam katvā parivattetvā ati kujjitvā vichaḍḍayamānaḥ udakassa
translated: in order to show this, the words “he is not agitated” are given in the text.

original: vikkhipanavasena chaḍḍayamāno.🔽Tathā na gaṇhāti, byañjanamattāya eva gaṇhanto. Bhattaṃ vā amanāpanti ānetvā yojanā.🔽Byañjanena ālopaatināmanaṃ, ālopena byañjanaatināmananti imesu pana dvīsu paṭhamameva🔽asāruppatāya aniṭṭhaṃ vajjetabbanti pāḷiyaṃ paṭikkhittanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sabbatthevāti
analyzed: vikkhipana vasena chaḍḍayamānaḥ 🔽tathā na gaṇhāti byañjana mattāya eva gaṇhantaḥ bhattam vā amanāpanti ānetvā yojanā 🔽ālopena ālopa atināmanam ālopena imesu pana dvīsu paṭhamam eva 🔽a sāruppa tāya aniṭṭham vajjetabbanti pāḷiyam paṭikkhittanti daṭṭhabbam sabbattha eva ati

original: sabbasmiṃ āharitabbavatthusmiṃ supaṇītabhāvena raso pākaṭo hoti ñāṇena pariññātattā.
analyzed: sabbasmim āharitabba vatthusmim su paṇīta bhāvena raso pākaṭaḥ hoti ñāṇena pariññāta ttā
translated: The taste of all the things that have been brought is evident in a well-proportioned way because of the thorough knowledge by means of knowledge.

original: Rasagedho pana natthi setughātattā.
analyzed: rasa gedhaḥ pana natthi setu ghāta ttā
translated: But there is no excess of taste because of the breaking of the dam.

original: Assāti “neva davāyā”tiādipadassa. Vuttametanti “visuddhimagge vinicchayo āgato”ti
analyzed: assa āti na iva davāya ati ādi padassa vuttam etat ti visuddhi magge vinicchayaḥ āgataḥ ti
translated: “The word ‘horse’ ” : of the word “neva davāya” , etc.

original: sabbāsavasutte saṃvaṇṇayantena vuttametaṃ, tasmā na ettha taṃ vattabbanti adhippāyo,
analyzed: sabbāsava sutte saṃvaṇṇayantena vuttam etam tasmā na ettha tat vattabbanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “It is said” : this is said by one who commends the Sabbāsavasutta. The intention is that it should not be said here.

original: tasmā yo tasmiṃ tasmiṃ vinicchaye visesavādo icchitabbo. So paramatthamañjūsāya visuddhimaggavaṇṇanāya
analyzed: tasmā yaḥ tasmin tasmin vinicchaye visesa vādaḥ icchitabbo saḥ paramattha mañjūsāya visuddhi magga vaṇṇanāya
translated: Therefore, whatever special statement is desired in this or that Vinaya should be understood in the way stated in the commentary on the Visuddhimagga, the Paramatthamañjūsā.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Pattassa gahaṇaṭṭhānanti hatthena pattassa gahaṇapadesaṃ.🔽Vinivattitvāti patte sabbaṃ āmisagataṃ saddhiṃ bhattena vinivattitvā gacchati. Pamāṇātikkantanti
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ pattassa gahaṇa ṭṭhānan ti hatthena pattassa gahaṇa padesam  vinivattitvā ti patte sabbam āmisa gatam saddhim bhattena vinivattitvā gacchati pamāṇa atikkantam ti
translated: The place of holding the bowl with the hand is the place of holding the bowl with the hand.

original: kelāyanavasena atikkantapamāṇaṃ ārakkhaṃ ṭhapeti. Cīvarabhogantaranti cīvarapaṭalantaraṃ.
analyzed: kelāyana vasena atikkanta pamāṇam ārakkham ṭhapeti cīvara bhoga ntaranti cīvara paṭala ntaram
translated: Having turned back: having turned back all the food in the bowl together with the rice, it goes. Exceeding the measure: having exceeded the measure by way of greed, he sets up a guard. In the interval of the robe: in the interval of the robe-pouch.

original: Udarena akkamitvāti udareneva sannirumbhitvā.🔽Appattakālaṃ abhimukhaṃ nāmeti upanāmetīti atināmeti, pattakālaṃ atikkāmento nāmeti🔽apanetīti atināmeti. Ubhayampi ekajjhaṃ gahetvā pāḷiyaṃ “na ca anumodanassa kālamatināmetī”ti🔽vuttanti dassento “yo hī”tiādimāha.🔽Vegagamanena paṭisaṃmuñcitvā dhāvitvā gacchati. Accukkaṭṭhanti ativiya uddhaṃ katvā
analyzed: udarena udarena iva san nirumbhitvā  appatta kālam abhimukham nāmeti upanāmeti iti atināmeti patta kālam atikkāmentaḥ nāma iti  apaneti iti atināmeti ubhayam pi ekajjham gahetvā pāḷiyam na ca anumodanassa kālam atināmeti iti  vuttanti dassentaḥ yaḥ hi itiādim āha  vega gamanena paṭisaṃmuñcitvā dhāvitvā gacchati accukkaṭṭhanti ativiya uddham katvā
translated: Having pressed with his belly: having pressed with his belly alone.

original: kaḍḍhitapārutaṃ. Tenāha “yo hi yāva hanukaṭṭhito…pe… hotī”ti. Accokkaṭṭhanti ativiya🔽heṭṭhā katvā kaḍḍhitapārutaṃ. Tenāha “yāva gopphakā otāretvā”ti. Ubhato ukkhipitvāti🔽dakkhiṇato vāmatoti ubhosu passesu uttarāsaṅgaṃ ukkhipitvā. Thananti dakkhiṇathanaṃ.🔽Vissaṭṭhoti vimutto. Tenāha “vissaṭṭhattāyeva cesa viññeyyo”ti. Yasmā amuttavādino
analyzed: kaḍḍhita pārutam tena āha yaḥ hi hanu kaṭṭhita upe hoti iti accokkaṭṭhanti 🔽heṭṭhā katvā kaḍḍhita pārutam tena āha yāva gopphakāḥ otāretvā iti ubhatas ukkhipitvā iti 🔽dakkhiṇatas vāmatas ti ubhosu passesu uttarāsaṅgam ukkhipitvā thananti dakkhiṇa thanam 🔽vissaṭṭhaḥ ti vimuttaḥ tena āha vissaṭṭha ttāya iva ca isa viññeyyaḥ ti yasmai amutta vādino
translated: He does not bring forward the time for rejoicing: he does not bring forward the time for giving. He brings forward the time for giving: he brings forward the time for giving. He brings forward the time for giving: he brings forward the time for giving. He brings forward the time for giving: he brings forward the time for giving. He brings forward the time for giving: he brings forward the time for

original: vacanaṃ avissaṭṭhatāya na siniyhati, na evaṃ muttavādinoti āha “siniddho”ti. Viññeyyoti
analyzed: vacanam a vissaṭṭha tāya na siniyhati na evam mutta vādinaḥ iti āha siniddhaḥ ti viññeyyaḥ ti
translated: It does not break up because it is not confused in expression. He says “smooth” because it is not like the speech of one who is excreting.

original: suparibyattatāya akkharato ca byañjanato ca viññātuṃ sakkuṇeyyo. Tenāha “pākaṭo”ti.
analyzed: su paribyatta tāya akkharataḥ ca byañjanataḥ ca viññātum sakkuṇeyyaḥ tena āha pākaṭaḥ iti
translated: It is to be known because it is well-polished and can be understood by the letters and syllables. Therefore he says “clear.”

original: Viññāpaniyoti vijānitabbo. Byañjanavaseneva cettha viññeyyatā veditabbā ghosassa
analyzed: viññāpaniyo ti vijānitabbaḥ byañjana vasena iva ca ittha viññeyya tā veditabbā ghosassa
translated: It is to be recognized because it can be recognized. But here the state of being to be known should be understood as being by way of the syllables,🔽because the sound is intended.

original: adhippetattā. Madhuroti piyo pemanīyo apalibuddho. Savanamarahati, savanassa sotassa
analyzed: adhippeta ttā madhuraḥ uti piyaḥ pemanīyaḥ apalibuddhaḥ savanam arahati savanassa sotassa
translated: It is sweet because it is dear, lovable, and not repulsive. It is worthy of hearing because it is beneficial for the ear of the hearer.

original: hitoti vā savanīyo. Sampiṇḍitoti sahito. Bhagavato hi saddo uppattiṭṭhānakatāsañcitattā
analyzed: hitaḥ iti vā savanīyaḥ sampiṇḍito ti sahitaḥ bhagavataḥ hi saddo uppatti ṭṭhānaka tā sañcita ttā
translated: It is to be heard. It is combined because it is associated. For the Blessed One’s voice comes within the range of hearing as a combination,

original: sahitākāreneva āpāthamāgacchati, na ayosalākāya pahaṭakaṃsathālaṃ viya vippakiṇṇo.🔽Tenāha “avisārī”ti. Gambhīroti yathā gambhīravatthuparicchindanena ñāṇassa gambhīrasamaññā,
analyzed: sahita ākārena iva āpātham āgacchati na ayaḥ salākāya pahaṭa kaṃsa thālam viya vippakiṇṇaḥ  tena āha avisārī iti gambhīraḥ ti yathā gambhīra vatthu paricchindanena ñāṇassa gambhīra samaññā
translated: not scattered like the sound of a gong struck with a wooden clapper, because it is accumulated in the place of its origination.🔽Therefore he says “unbroken.” It is deep because it is profound.🔽Just as the knowledge that discerns a profound object is called “profound,”

original: evaṃ gambhīraṭṭhānasambhavato saddassa gambhīrasamaññāti āha “gambhīroti gambhīrasamuṭṭhito”ti.
analyzed: evam gambhīra ṭṭhāna sambhavataḥ saddassa gambhīra samaññā iti āha gambhīraḥ ti gambhīra samuṭṭhitaḥ ti
translated: so the sound is called “profound” because it is possible to have a profound basis. Therefore he says “profound” means “arisen from a profound basis.”

original: Ninnādavāti savisesaṃ ninnādavā. Svāyaṃ viseso gambhīrabhāvasiddhoti āha “gambhīrattāyeva
analyzed: ninnādavā ati sa visesam ninnādavā āha gambhīra ttāya iva
translated: The sound is especially deep, thus it is said to be “deep-sounding.”🔽This distinction is established by its profundity.

original: cesa ninnādī”ti. Evamettha cattāri aṅgāni caturaṅganipphādīni veditabbāni. Akāraṇā
analyzed: evam ettha cattāri aṅgāni catur aṅga nipphādīni veditabbāni akāraṇā
translated: The four factors are the four factors of the proclamation.

original: mā nassīti buddhānubhāvena viya sarassa parisapariyantatā vuttā, dhammatāvaseneva
analyzed: mā buddha anubhāvena viya sarassa parisa pariyanta tā vuttā dhamma tā vasena iva
translated: “So that it may not be lost” is said by the Buddha’s power as if the lake were surrounded by an assembly. But it should be understood by the principle of nature,

original: pana sā veditabbā tassa mūlakāraṇassa tathā avaṭṭhitattā.
analyzed: pana sā veditabbā tassa mūla kāraṇassa tathā avaṭṭhita ttā
translated: because that root cause is established in that way.🔽“Having turned back” means having turned around.

original: Paccosakkitvāti paṭinivattitvā. Samussitakañcanapabbataṃ viya upari indanīlaratanavitatasikhaṃ
analyzed: paccosakkitvā ti paṭinivattitvā samussita kañcana pabbatam viya upari inda nīla ratana vitata sikham
translated: Like a mountain of heaped-up gold, with a canopy of sapphire jewels above,

original: vijjullatābhūsitaṃ. Mahāpathavīādayo satthuguṇapaṭibhāgatāya nidassanaṃ, kevalaṃ
analyzed: vijjullatā bhūsitam mahā pathavī ādayaḥ satthu guṇa paṭibhāga tāya nidassanam kevalam
translated: adorned with lightning flashes. The great earth, etc., are shown by way of the Buddha’s qualities,

original: mahantatāmattaṃ upādāya nidassitā.
analyzed: mahanta tā mattam upādāya nidassitā
translated: shown by way of greatness alone.

original: 390. Appaṭisaṃviditoti anārocito. Āgamanavasena cettha paṭisaṃveditanti āha “aviññātaāgamano”ti. Uggatabhāvanti kulabhogavijjādīhi uḷārabhāvaṃ. Anuddayasampannāti kāruṇikā.
analyzed: appaṭisaṃviditaḥ ti anārocitaḥ āgamana vasena ca ittha paṭisaṃveditan ti āha aviññāta āgamanā ti uggata bhāvam ti kula bhoga vijjā ādīhi uḷāra bhāvam anuddaya sampannā iti kāruṇikā
translated: “Unannounced” means unreported. Here, “announced” is by way of coming. Thus it is said: “unannounced coming.” “Nobility” means excellence by way of family, wealth, knowledge, etc. “Compassionate” means merciful.

original: 391. Sahasāva okāsakaraṇena uccakulīnatā dīpitā hotīti āha “vegena uṭṭhāya dvidhā bhijjitvā”tiādi.
analyzed: ucca kulīna tā dīpitā hoti iti āha vegena uṭṭhāya dvidhā bhijjitvā atiādi
translated: The meaning of “noble birth” is indicated by the phrase “rising up quickly and splitting in two” .

original: Nārisamānanāmanti itthiatthajotakanāmaṃ. Tenāha “itthiliṅga”nti. Avhātabbāti kathetabbā.
analyzed: nāri samāna nāmanti itthi attha jotaka nāmam tena āha itthi liṅgam ti a vhātabbā ati kathetabbā
translated: “The name of a woman” is the name that shows a woman’s sex.🔽By means of a single method he answers the eight questions.

original: 394. Ekanīhāreneva aṭṭha pañhe byākaronto. “Pubbenivāsaṃ…pe… pavuccatī”ti iminā pubbenivāsassa🔽viditakāraṇaṃ vuttanti āha “tassa pubbenivāso pākaṭo”ti. Dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ kathitaṃ
analyzed: eka nīhārena iva aṭṭha pañhe byākaronto pubbenivāsaṃpe pavuccati iti iminā pubbenivāsassa  vidita kāraṇam vuttanti āha tassa pubbenivāsaḥ pākaṭaḥ ti dibba cakkhu ñāṇam kathitam
translated: The reason for the knowledge of recollection of past lives is stated in the passage beginning with the words “The knowledge of recollection of past lives is said to be” .🔽Therefore it is said: “His recollection of past lives is evident” .🔽The knowledge of the divine eye is stated in the passage beginning with the words “The knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings is said to be” .🔽Because it is the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings that is called the knowledge of the divine eye.🔽The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is stated in the passage beginning with the words “The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is said to be” .🔽The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is called the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers because it is the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers.

original: tassa paribhaṇḍañāṇabhāvato yathākammūpagañāṇassa. “Jātikkhayaṃ patto, abhiññā vosito”ti🔽ca vuttattā munīti asekkhamuni idhādhippetoti āha “arahattañāṇamoneyyena samannāgato”ti.
analyzed: tassa paribhaṇḍa ñāṇa bhāvataḥ yathā kammūpaga ñāṇassa jāti kkhayam pattaḥ abhiññā vosito ti  ca vutta ttā muni iti asekkha muni idha adhippeto ti āha arahatta ñāṇa moneyyena samannāgataḥ ti
translated: The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is called the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers because it is the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers.

original: Kilesarāgehi kilesavivaṇṇatāhi. Jātikkhayappattattā “atho jātikkhayaṃ patto”ti vuttattā.
analyzed: kilesa rāgehi kilesa vivaṇṇa tāhi jāti khaya ppatta ttā atho jāti khayam patto ti vutta ttā
translated: The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is called the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers because it is the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers.

original: Abhijānitvāti abhivisiṭṭhatāya aggamaggapaññāya ñatvā. Idāni paṭisambhidāyaṃ āgatanayena
analyzed: abhijānitvā iti abhivisiṭṭha tāya agga magga paññāya ñatvā idāni āgata nayena
translated: Having known by direct knowledge: having known by the knowledge of the path of distinction. Now, by the method given in the Paṭisambhidā:🔽

original: pariññāpahānabhāvanāsacchikiriyāsamāpattīnaṃ pāragamanena pāragūti ayamettha atthoti
analyzed: pariññā apahāna bhāvanā sacchikiriyā samāpattīnam pāra gamanena pāragū ti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti
translated: Having known by the knowledge of the path of Arahantship, which is the most distinguished of all kinds of knowledge. Now, in order to show that the meaning here is this, that he is gone to the other shore by going to the other shore of full-understanding, giving up, realization, and penetration, which are stated in the method of the Paṭisambhidā,

original: dassetuṃ “pāragūti vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Abhiññeyyadhammānaṃ jānanavasena abhiññāpāragū.
analyzed: dassetum pāragū ti vā tiādi vuttam abhiññeyya dhammānam jānana vasena abhiññā pāragū
translated: he said, “Or he is gone to the other shore” , etc. He is gone to the other shore of direct knowledge by knowing the states that should be directly known.

original: Tādisoti yādiso “pāragū sabbadhammāna”nti padadvayena vutto, tādiso. Chahi ākārehīti
analyzed: tādisaḥ ti yādisaḥ pāragū sabba dhammānam ti pada dvayena vutto tādisaḥ chahi ākārehi iti
translated: Such as he is described by the two phrases, “gone to the other shore of all things” .

original: pajānanādīhi yathāvuttehi chahi ākārehi.
analyzed: pajānana ādīhi yathā vuttehi chahi ākārehi
translated: By the six ways, by the six ways beginning with “knowing” , as stated.

original: Kāmañcettha dve eva pucchāgāthā dve ca vissajjanāgāthā, pucchāpaṭipāṭiyā pana asaṅkarato🔽ca vissajjanaṃ pavattati, taṃ niddhāretuṃ kiṃ panātiādi vuttaṃ. Vedehi gatattāti
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha dve eva pucchāgāthā dve ca vissajjanāgāthā pucchā paṭipāṭiyā pana asaṅkarato  ca vissajjanam pavattati tam niddhāretum kim pana atiādi vuttam vedehi gata ttā ti
translated: Although there are two questions and two answers here, the answer is given in the order of the questions,🔽without confusion. In order to show this, he said, “But what is the reason? ” , etc. He has gone to the other shore by the paths of direct knowledge.

original: vedehi maggañāṇehi pāraṅgatattā. Pubbenivāsantiādīhi vijjānaṃ atthitāya bodhitattā.
analyzed: vedehi magga ñāṇehi pāraṅga tattā pubbenivāsa nti ādīhi vijjānam atthitāya bodhita ttā
translated: He is enlightened by the existence of the kinds of direct knowledge beginning with knowledge of recollecting past lives.

original: Pāpadhammānanti chattiṃsapāpadhammānaṃ sotthānaṃ maggaṃ pāpanena nissesato sodhitattā.🔽395. Dhammo nāma arahattamaggo kusaladhammesu ukkaṃsapāramippattiyā ukkaṭṭhaniddesena.
